question_text: A 60-year-old man comes to the physician because his wife has noticed that his left eye looks smaller than his right. He has had worsening left shoulder and arm pain for 3 months. He has smoked two packs of cigarettes daily for 35 years. Examination shows left-sided ptosis. The pupils are unequal but reactive to light; when measured in dim light, the left pupil is 3 mm and the right pupil is 5 mm. Which of the following is the most likely cause of this patient's ophthalmologic symptoms?
content_preview: A 60-year-old man comes to the physician because his wife has noticed that his left eye looks smaller than his right. He has had worsening left shoulder and arm pain for 3 months. He has smoked two packs of cigarettes daily for 35 years. Examination shows left-sided ptosis. The pupils are unequal but reactive to light; when measured in dim light, the left pupil is 3 mm and the right pupil is 5 mm. Which of the following is the most likely cause of this patient's ophthalmologic symptoms?
hint: Horner syndrome (HS) is a neurological disorder characterized by a symptom triad of miosis, partial ptosis, and facial anhidrosis, of which this patient has the former two symptoms. In a heavy smoker, symptoms of Horner syndrome combined with ipsilateral shoulder and arm pain are concerning for a Pancoast tumor.
learning_objective: Recognize compression of the stellate ganglion causing Horner syndrome.

answers.explanation_why: Cavernous sinus thrombosis can result in Horner syndrome due to compression of postganglionic sympathetic neurons. However, cavernous sinus thrombosis has additional symptoms that are not present in this case, such as headache, photophobia, proptosis, and other cranial nerve palsies (commonly CN VI). In addition, cavernous sinus thrombosis is most commonly caused by an ascending infection from the face or sinuses, signs of which are not present here. This patient's arm and shoulder pain would likewise not be explained by cavernous sinus thrombosis.

images.title: Pituitary gland and cavernous sinuses
images.description: The pituitary gland lies within the pituitary fossa and is surrounded by the left and right cavernous sinuses and the intercavernous sinuses connecting them. The internal carotid artery and the abducens nerve pass through the middle of each cavernous sinus, while the oculomotor, trochlear, ophthalmic, and maxillary nerves are located towards the lateral wall of the sinuses.

answers.content: Aneurysm of the posterior cerebral artery
answers.explanation_why: Aneurysm of the posterior cerebral artery could compress CN III, which carries parasympathetic fibers to the pupillary sphincter and ciliary muscle, and motor fibers to the levator palpebrae superioris and all extraocular muscles except for the superior oblique muscle and the lateral rectus muscle. Such an aneurysm would result in ptosis, which this patient has, as well as diplopia, a fixed and dilated pupil, and a down-and-out gaze, which are not present here. Rather than mydriasis, this patient has miosis. Furthermore, if such an aneurysm were symptomatic, it would manifest with headache rather than the shoulder and arm pain seen here.

Infarction of the hypothalamus is a rare cause of Horner syndrome secondary to injury of centrally located sympathetic neurons. This patient's smoking history is a risk factor for stroke, including infarction of the hypothalamus. However, an infarction of the hypothalamus would likely manifest with additional stroke symptoms, typically contralateral hemiparesis and hypesthesia, as well as impeded homeostatic functions of the hypothalamus (e.g., thermoregulation, electrolyte balance, sleep-wake cycle). Furthermore, infarction of the hypothalamus would not explain this patient's shoulder and arm pain.

Carotid artery dissection can cause Horner syndrome by compressing the postganglionic sympathetic fibers near the internal carotid artery and damaging them directly or decreasing blood flow to their vasa nervorum. This patient's smoking history is a risk factor for carotid artery dissection. However, carotid artery dissection most often has an acute onset of symptoms following some types of trauma (e.g., blunt trauma), which is not the case here. Furthermore, in addition to Horner syndrome, carotid artery dissection would manifest with headache and/or neck pain, while this patient has shoulder and arm pain.

Compression of the stellate ganglion by a Pancoast tumor can lead to Horner syndrome via injury of preganglionic sympathetic fibers. Superior sulcus tumors can infiltrate neighboring structures and cause additional symptoms, which is known as Pancoast syndrome. This patient's shoulder and arm pain are likely symptoms of Pancoast syndrome, which also includes atrophy of the arm and hand muscles, and possibly superior vena cava syndrome and hoarseness due to compression of the recurrent laryngeal nerve. The most common cause of Pancoast syndrome is NSCLC, for which this patient is at risk because of his history of smoking.

images.title: Horner syndrome
images.description: Horner syndrome is characterized by ipsilateral miosis, partial ptosis, and anhidrosis. These features may be due to a central lesion affecting the hypothalamus or first neuron (e.g., brainstem stroke, cervical spine injury, anatomical malformations, demyelinating disease), a preganglionic/second neuron lesion (e.g., Pancoast tumor, trauma, lymphadenopathy, carotid artery lesion), or a postganglionic/third neuron lesion (e.g., internal carotid dissection, tumor, herpes zoster infection).

answers.explanation_why: Infiltration of the cervical plexus, typically by neck soft tissue tumors or lymph node metastases, manifests with pain in the neck and submandibular area, as well as sensory loss in the C2, C3, and C4 dermatomes, symptoms which this patient does not have. It would not be expected to cause Horner syndrome or shoulder and arm pain.

question_text: A 56-year-old man comes to the physician because of worsening double vision and drooping of the right eyelid for 2 days. He has also had frequent headaches over the past month. Physical examination shows right eye deviation laterally and inferiorly at rest. The right pupil is dilated and does not react to light or with accommodation. The patient's diplopia improves slightly on looking to the right. Which of the following is the most likely cause of this patient’s findings?
content_preview: A 56-year-old man comes to the physician because of worsening double vision and drooping of the right eyelid for 2 days. He has also had frequent headaches over the past month. Physical examination shows right eye deviation laterally and inferiorly at rest. The right pupil is dilated and does not react to light or with accommodation. The patient's diplopia improves slightly on looking to the right. Which of the following is the most likely cause of this patient’s findings?
hint: Double vision, eyelid droop, lateral and inferior eye deviation at rest, and a dilated pupil that does not react to light point to oculomotor nerve (CN III) palsy, with both somatic and parasympathetic involvement.
learning_objective: Recognize oculomotor nerve palsy, and recall its potential causes.

answers.explanation_why: Thrombosis of the cavernous sinus has a highly variable clinical manifestation because of the number of cranial nerves passing through the region (CN III, IV, V1, V2, VI). Patients with cavernous sinus thrombosis can present with headaches and unilateral CN III palsy. However, this patient does not have the typical signs of fever, unilateral periorbital edema, photophobia, and chemosis seen in cavernous sinus thrombosis. Moreover, isolated involvement of CN III without damage to any of the other cranial nerves that pass through the cavernous sinus would be uncommon.

Ischemia of the intraneural arterioles of CN III is commonly caused by nonenzymatic glycosylation of vasculature, in which prolonged periods of hyperglycemia (due to diabetes mellitus) lead to irreversible damage to small vessels. The inner part of CN III provides motor output to the extraocular muscles and is most sensitive to ischemia because of its reliance on diffusion for oxygen and nutrients. However, ischemic damage to CN III typically manifests with a pupil-sparing palsy.

answers.content: Aneurysm of the posterior communicating artery
answers.explanation_why:
An aneurysm of the posterior communicating artery can cause compression of the nearby oculomotor nerve (CN III). Compressive lesions are characterized by pupillary involvement due to injury to the outer parasympathetic layer of CN III (which controls pupil dilation, light reactivity, and accommodation). Additional injury to the deeper somatic fibers of the nerve (which control extraocular muscles) is responsible for this patient's ptosis and “down and out” gaze.

Acute CN III palsy due to a cerebral aneurysm is very concerning for imminent rupture. A patient presenting with dilated pupils and a history of recent headaches should undergo an urgent MRI with MR angiography.

images.title: Oculomotor nerve palsy
images.description: Oculomotor nerve palsy (here, of the left eye) causes ipsilateral impairment of both motor and autonomic (parasympathetic) nerve functions. Paralysis of the inferior rectus, medial rectus, superior rectus, and inferior oblique muscles results in downward deviation (hypotropia) and outward deviation (exotropia) of the affected eye (down-and-out gaze) due to the unopposed actions of the lateral rectus and superior oblique muscles. Weakness of the levator palpebrae superioris muscle results in ptosis and impairment of parasympathetic function in mydriasis (as well as loss of accommodation and pupillary light reflex, which are not shown). Patients present with horizontal or horizontal and vertical double vision (diplopia) that worsens when turning the gaze away from the affected side. The ptosis, however, may prevent patients from experiencing diplopia.

answers.content: Demyelination of the medial longitudinal fasciculus
answers.explanation_why: Demyelination of the medial longitudinal fasciculus (MLF) causes internuclear ophthalmoplegia (INO). When present bilaterally, INO is often a sign of multiple sclerosis. Lesions in the MLF cause horizontal diplopia and impaired adduction on lateral gaze in one eye, with nystagmus in the contralateral abducting eye. However, this patient does not have nystagmus and the diplopia in INO is only present when the patient's gaze moves towards the contralateral side of the lesion, in contrast to this patient's resting diplopia. Moreover, INO would not explain this patient's eyelid droop, lateral and inferior eye deviation at rest, or the dilated pupil.

Enlarging pituitary adenomas typically present with bitemporal hemianopsia due to compression of the optic chiasm. Sufficiently large adenomas can cause headaches and CN III palsy due to compression resulting from lateral extension of the tumor. However, a tumor at the optic chiasm is unlikely to cause an isolated CN III palsy.

Infarctions of the posterior cerebral artery cause damage to the third cranial nerve nucleus in the midbrain. Patients present with ipsilateral CN III palsy and diplopia, which are seen in this case. However, such an infarct would usually also damage other parts of the midbrain, causing further neurologic features based on the structures involved (e.g., contralateral hemiataxia, cerebellar tremor). Furthermore, because the innervation of the levator palpebrae superioris muscles is supplied by a single subnucleus in the midbrain, ptosis would be expected to be bilateral, not unilateral as seen here.

question_text:
Patient Information
Age: 62 years
Gender: F, self-identified
Race/Ethnicity: unspecified
Site of Care: office 
History
Reason for Visit/Chief Concern: “My vision is blurry.” 
History of Present Illness:

worsening double vision for 3 days

double vision is present throughout the day and decreases when closing either eye or looking to the left
frequent headaches over the past month
no ocular pain
no history of fever or joint pains

Past Medical History:

hypertension
type 2 diabetes mellitus

Medications:

lisinopril
metformin

Vaccinations:
up-to-date
Allergies:
no known drug allergies
Family history:
father: deceased at age 69 years from ischemic stroke
Psychosocial history:

lives alone
drinks one beer daily
does not smoke or use nonprescribed medications or other substances

Physical Examination

Temp
Pulse
Resp
BP
O_2 Sat
Ht
Wt
BMI

36.6°C
(97.9°F)

72/min
12/min
130/80 mm Hg
-

182 cm
(6 ft)
85 kg
(190 lb)
25.7 kg/m^2

Appearance: no acute distress; alert and fully oriented
Skin: no rashes
HEENT: visual acuity is 20/40 in the left eye and 20/20 in the right eye; drooping of the left eyelid and exotropia and hypotropia of the left eye in the primary gaze; left pupil is dilated and does not react to light; indirect light reflex and accommodation reflex are absent in left eye; right pupil is normal and no defects are present on confrontational visual field testing of the right eye; no nystagmus; normal conjunctivae and oropharynx
Pulmonary: clear to auscultation
Cardiac: regular rhythm; no murmurs
Neurologic: grade 5/5 muscle strength; no tremors; sensation to light touch and temperature intact; no facial asymmetry; no deviation of the tongue or uvula; gag reflex intact 

Which of the following is the most likely cause of this patient’s findings?

hint: Double vision, eyelid droop, lateral and inferior eye deviation at rest, and a dilated pupil that does not react to light point to oculomotor nerve (CN III) palsy, with both somatic and parasympathetic involvement.
learning_objective: Recognize posterior communicating artery aneurysm as a cause of CN III palsy.

answers.explanation_why: An aneurysm of the posterior communicating artery can cause compression of the nearby oculomotor nerve (CN III). Compressive lesions are characterized by pupillary involvement due to injury to the outer parasympathetic layer of CN III (which controls pupil dilation, light reactivity, and accommodation). Additional injury to the deeper somatic fibers of the nerve (which control extraocular muscles) is responsible for this patient's ptosis and “down and out” gaze. Acute CN III palsy due to a cerebral aneurysm is very concerning for imminent rupture. A patient presenting with dilated pupils and a history of recent headaches should undergo an urgent MRI with MR angiography.

images.title: Oculomotor nerve palsy
images.description: Oculomotor nerve palsy (here, of the left eye) causes ipsilateral impairment of both motor and autonomic (parasympathetic) nerve functions. Paralysis of the inferior rectus, medial rectus, superior rectus, and inferior oblique muscles results in downward deviation (hypotropia) and outward deviation (exotropia) of the affected eye (down-and-out gaze) due to the unopposed actions of the lateral rectus and superior oblique muscles. Weakness of the levator palpebrae superioris muscle results in ptosis and impairment of parasympathetic function in mydriasis (as well as loss of accommodation and pupillary light reflex, which are not shown). Patients present with horizontal or horizontal and vertical double vision (diplopia) that worsens when turning the gaze away from the affected side. The ptosis, however, may prevent patients from experiencing diplopia.

answers.explanation_why: Sufficiently large pituitary macroadenomas can cause headaches and cranial nerve palsies due to compression resulting from parasellar growth and extension of the tumor into the cavernous sinus. However, visual field defects on confrontational visual field testing (e.g., temporal hemianopsia) would be expected and an isolated CN III palsy is an unlikely presentation of a pituitary macroadenoma.

images.title: Pituitary mass 2/2
images.description: MRI head (T1-weighted; without contrast; sagittal plane) of a male patient with headache, retroorbital pressure, fatigue, and elevated serum prolactinA large mass, which is isointense to gray matter, is seen in the area of the sella turcica (indicated by arrows).Considering the patient's history, a prolactin-secreting macroadenoma (prolactinoma) of the pituitary gland is the most likely diagnosis.

answers.explanation_why: Thrombosis of the cavernous sinus has a highly variable clinical manifestation because of the number of cranial nerves passing through the region (CN III, IV, V1, V2, VI). Patients with cavernous sinus thrombosis can present with headaches and unilateral CN III palsy. However, this patient does not have the typical signs of fever, unilateral periorbital edema, photophobia, and chemosis seen in cavernous sinus thrombosis. Moreover, isolated involvement of CN III without damage to any of the other cranial nerves that pass through the cavernous sinus would be uncommon.

Ischemia of the intraneural arterioles of CN III is commonly caused by nonenzymatic glycosylation of vasculature, in which prolonged periods of hyperglycemia (due to diabetes mellitus) lead to irreversible damage to small vessels. The inner part of CN III provides motor output to the extraocular muscles and is most sensitive to ischemia because of its reliance on diffusion for oxygen and nutrients. However, ischemic damage to CN III typically manifests with a pupil-sparing palsy.

Demyelination of the medial longitudinal fasciculus (MLF) causes internuclear ophthalmoplegia (INO). When present bilaterally, INO is often a sign of multiple sclerosis. Lesions in the MLF cause horizontal diplopia and impaired adduction on lateral gaze in one eye, with nystagmus in the contralateral abducting eye. However, this patient does not have nystagmus and the diplopia in INO is only present when the patient's gaze moves towards the contralateral side of the lesion, in contrast to this patient's resting diplopia. Moreover, INO would not explain this patient's eyelid droop, lateral and inferior eye deviation at rest, or the dilated pupil.

Infarctions of the posterior cerebral artery cause damage to the third cranial nerve nucleus in the midbrain. Patients can present with ipsilateral CN III palsy but such an infarct would usually also damage other parts of the midbrain, causing further neurologic features based on the structures involved (e.g., contralateral hemiataxia, cerebellar tremor). Furthermore, because the innervation of the levator palpebrae superioris muscles is supplied by a single subnucleus in the midbrain, ptosis would be expected to be bilateral, not unilateral as seen here.

question_text: An otherwise healthy 8-year-old girl is brought to the physician by her parents because of concern for growth retardation. Although she has always been short for her age, her classmates have begun teasing her for her height. She is at the 5^th percentile for height and 25^th percentile for weight. Physical examination shows a low-set posterior hairline, increased skin folds along the side of the neck, and a high-arched palate. The nipples are widely spaced and the fourth metacarpal bones are shortened bilaterally. This patient is at increased risk of developing which of the following complications?
content_preview: An otherwise healthy 8-year-old girl is brought to the physician by her parents because of concern for growth retardation. Although she has always been short for her age, her classmates have begun teasing her for her height. She is at the 5th percentile for height and 25th percentile for weight. Physical examination shows a low-set posterior hairline, increased skin folds along the side of the neck, and a high-arched palate. The nipples are widely spaced and the fourth metacarpal bones are shortened bilaterally. This patient is at increased risk of developing which of the following complications?
hint: Short stature, webbed neck, wide-spaced nipples, and short fourth metacarpals are suggestive of Turner syndrome.
learning_objective: Recognize Turner syndrome, and recall its cardiovascular complications.

answers.explanation_why: Turner syndrome, unlike many chromosomal conditions (e.g., Down syndrome, fragile X syndrome), is not associated with intellectual disability.

Polycystic kidneys are seen in patients with autosomal recessive or autosomal dominant polycystic kidney disease. However, Turner syndrome is associated with an increased risk of horseshoe kidney (∼ 15% of patients), not polycystic kidneys.

Patients with Turner syndrome are at increased risk of cardiovascular anomalies, most commonly bicuspid aortic valve and coarctation of the aorta. Early in life, a bicuspid valve is often asymptomatic or only becomes symptomatic with exertion. At this time, the condition typically manifests with a systolic click heard best at the left lower sternal border or apex. Bicuspid aortic valve predisposes to early-onset valvular calcifications, which can lead to premature aortic stenosis and/or insufficiency as early as the fourth decade of life. In contrast, senile calcific aortic stenosis peaks in patients > 80 years.

Patients with bicuspid aortic valve are also at increased risk of infectious endocarditis.
Turner syndrome typically presents with delayed rather than precocious puberty. Precocious puberty in girls is seen, e.g., in those with pinealoma, astrocytoma, or certain ovarian tumors.

Studies indicate that patients with Turner syndrome have a decreased risk of developing breast cancer, but an increased risk for certain brain tumors and bladder cancer. The overall excess risk for individual cancers remains very low, and therefore, no specific screening measures are indicated in patients with Turner syndrome. Down syndrome, not Turner syndrome, increases the risk of acute lymphatic leukemia and acute myeloid leukemia.

Lens dislocation is typical for Marfan syndrome (superior dislocation) and homocystinuria (inferior dislocation), which present with tall rather than short stature. Turner syndrome, in turn, increases the risk of amblyopia and strabismus, not lens dislocation.

question_text: A 34-year-old man with AIDS comes to the physician because of a 2-day history of decreasing vision and seeing black spots in his right eye. He has no pain and the left eye is asymptomatic. He was treated for fungal esophagitis 6 months ago with fluconazole. He was diagnosed with Kaposi sarcoma 2 years ago. Current medications include efavirenz, tenofovir, emtricitabine, azithromycin, trimethoprim/sulfamethoxazole, multivitamins, and a nutritional supplement. He is 170 cm (5 ft 7 in) tall and weighs 45 kg (99 lb); BMI is 16 kg/m^2. His temperature is 37°C (98.6°F), pulse is 89/min, and blood pressure is 110/70 mm Hg. Examination shows cervical lymphadenopathy. There are multiple violaceous plaques seen over his trunk and extremities. Funduscopic examination shows granular yellow-white opacities around the retinal vessels and multiple areas of dot-blot hemorrhages. His CD4+ T-lymphocyte count is 36/mm^3. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
content_preview: A 34-year-old man with AIDS comes to the physician because of a 2-day history of decreasing vision and seeing black spots in his right eye. He has no pain and the left eye is asymptomatic. He was treated for fungal esophagitis 6 months ago with fluconazole. He was diagnosed with Kaposi sarcoma 2 years ago. Current medications include efavirenz, tenofovir, emtricitabine, azithromycin, trimethoprim/sulfamethoxazole, multivitamins, and a nutritional supplement. He is 170 cm (5 ft 7 in) tall and weighs 45 kg (99 lb); BMI is 16 kg/m2. His temperature is 37°C (98.6°F), pulse is 89/min, and blood pressure is 110/70 mm Hg. Examination shows cervical lymphadenopathy. There are multiple violaceous plaques seen over his trunk and extremities. Funduscopic examination shows granular yellow-white opacities around the retinal vessels and multiple areas of dot-blot hemorrhages. His CD4+ T-lymphocyte count is 36/mm3. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
hint: This patient with HIV has an opportunistic infection typically only seen in severely immunocompromised individuals.
learning_objective: Recognize cytomegalovirus retinitis in HIV/AIDS.

answers.explanation_why:
Cytomegalovirus retinitis is an AIDS-defining condition that most commonly affects patients with a CD4 count < 50/mm^3. Funduscopic findings in CMV retinitis are described as having a “pizza pie” appearance because of a distinct mixture of red and white lesions. The red spots are retinal hemorrhages. The white spots are granular perivascular white opacities around retinal vessels that resemble cotton-wool spots. In the early stages of the disease, vision may still be unaffected even though funduscopic findings are already present. If left untreated, CMV retinitis progresses rapidly and patients develop painless vision loss or scotomas depending on the location of the retinal lesions and whether there is retinal detachment.

See “Ophthalmologic complications of HIV” table.

images.title: CMV retinitis
images.description: Fundus photography of the left eyeThere are diffuse perivascular retinal hemorrhages (examples indicated by blue hatched overlay), whitish retinal necroses (examples indicated by yellow overlay), and periphlebitis with vascular occlusion (examples indicated by blue overlay). In addition, hard exudates (examples indicated by arrowheads) can be seen. The combination of these features causes the characteristic pizza-pie appearance (zoom-box and illustration).These findings are consistent with retinitis caused by cytomegalovirus, which is most commonly seen in immunocompromised patients.

answers.explanation_why: Diagnosis of herpes simplex keratitis is based on a clinical history of infection with herpes simplex virus and slit lamp findings showing dendritic lesions of the cornea. Symptoms include pain, blurry vision, and watering of the eye, none of which is present in this patient. Moreover, the retina is unaffected and funduscopic findings are normal in herpes simplex keratitis.

images.title: Herpes simplex keratitis
images.description: Slit lamp photography with fluorescein application under cobalt blue light filterFluorescein staining of the cornea under blue light shows green fluorescence of geographic epithelial defects. These defects are characteristic of herpes simplex keratitis, though less common than dendritic epithelial defects, which represent the hallmark of herpes simplex keratitis.

answers.explanation_why: Toxoplasmosis is an opportunistic infection that typically occurs when CD4 counts are < 100/mm^3. On examination, this patient's yellow-white opacities may be mistaken for toxoplasma retinitis. However, this patient's opacities are perivascular (located around the retinal vessels), while toxoplasma lesions are nonvascular (their distribution is not related to the vessels). Additionally, patients with toxoplasma retinitis most commonly present with eye pain.

images.title: Ocular toxoplasmosis
images.description:
Fundus photography of a right eyeThe image appears cloudy, which is consistent with vitreous opacity. There is a yellow-white, fluffy retinal lesion (blue overlay) at the temporal superior vascular arch. The pigmented scar (arrowhead) in the nasal area is most likely the remnant of a previous manifestation of toxoplasmosis. In addition, the optic disc (circle) appears blurred.

M: macula

answers.explanation_why: HIV retinopathy is a microvascular disorder of the retina that occurs in about 60% of patients with AIDS. It classically manifests with cotton-wool spots, retinal hemorrhages, and microaneurysms. This patient's perivascular yellow-white opacities could be confused with cotton-wool spots. The key differences are that cotton-wool spots are smaller in size, and tend to resolve on their own without progression. Vision is typically unaffected in HIV retinopathy, which helps to distinguish it from other causes of eye disease in HIV-positive patients. The “black spots” seen by this patient also suggest a different diagnosis.

images.title: HIV retinopathy
images.description: Fundus photography of the right eye of a HIV-positive patientOpaque white patches are present along the retinal blood vessels in the upper third of the image (a prominent example is indicated by the arrow).These small perivascular opacities are called “cotton-wool spots” and are consistent with noninfectious retinopathy in HIV patients.

answers.explanation_why: Varicella zoster virus retinitis is a rare disease of the retina that begins by affecting the periphery, causing severe pain, retinal necrosis, and vision loss. If this patient had VZV retinitis, he would have eye pain and fundoscopy would not show yellow-white opacities.

question_text: A 7-year-old boy is brought to the emergency department because of a 2-day history of photophobia and pruritus on the periocular area of the right eye. He also had crusts over the eyelashes of the right eye that morning. The boy has a history of asthma and atopic dermatitis. His medications include inhaled steroids and salbutamol. Vital signs are within normal limits. Physical examination shows conjunctival injection and redness of the affected eye with watery discharge. There are multiple vesicles with an erythematous base located on the upper and lower eyelids. Visual acuity test shows no abnormalities. Which of the following is the most likely cause?
content_preview: A 7-year-old boy is brought to the emergency department because of a 2-day history of photophobia and pruritus on the periocular area of the right eye. He also had crusts over the eyelashes of the right eye that morning. The boy has a history of asthma and atopic dermatitis. His medications include inhaled steroids and salbutamol. Vital signs are within normal limits. Physical examination shows conjunctival injection and redness of the affected eye with watery discharge. There are multiple vesicles with an erythematous base located on the upper and lower eyelids. Visual acuity test shows no abnormalities. Which of the following is the most likely cause?
hint: What infection associated with multiple vesicles are patients with atopic dermatitis prone to?
learning_objective: Recognize herpes simplex virus conjunctivitis in patients with atopic dermatitis.

answers.explanation_why: Molluscum contagiosum virus is a cause of chronic follicular conjunctivitis, a condition that usually manifests with chronic unilateral ocular irritation and mucoid discharge. The virus causes typical umbilicated nodules which can be found on the lid margin and possibly on other areas of the skin. The patient, in this case, presents with acute conjunctivitis and a rash characteristic of a different disease.

Chlamydia trachomatis is the leading cause of neonatal conjunctivitis (or ophthalmia neonatorum). Infection is usually caused by exposure to contaminated maternal discharge, typically during birth, and patients present with mucopurulent discharge. Infection of older patients leads to granular conjunctivitis (trachoma) and can cause blindness. Common findings include follicles and papillae on the conjunctiva as well as scarring and corneal damage later in the course of the disease. These features are inconsistent with this patient's watery discharge and a periorbital rash.

Adenoviruses are the most common cause of viral (nonpurulent) conjunctivitis. The disease is highly contagious and commonly occurs in small outbreaks. Typical symptoms include itching, serous discharge, severe foreign body sensation, and conjunctival hyperemia, as mentioned in this case. However, adenovirus conjunctivitis typically affects both eyes, either simultaneously or in sequence. Most importantly, although it often presents with signs of systemic infection, such as pharyngitis, fever, and lymphadenopathy, it is not associated with a vesicular rash.

Enterovirus 70 is a picornavirus that causes acute hemorrhagic conjunctivitis. Patients present with a sudden onset of pain, periorbital swelling, subconjunctival hemorrhages, and conjunctival injection. In most cases, the infection involves both eyes. Though the patient, in this case, presents with conjunctival injection, a periocular rash is characteristic of a different disease.

Acute infection with varicella-zoster virus sometimes causes conjunctivitis. Patients are usually children and present with additional symptoms such as fever and a generalized vesiculopustular rash. The conjunctiva can also be affected in reactivation of the latent virus in the trigeminal ganglion (herpes zoster ophthalmicus). These patients are often older or immunosuppressed and present with a headache, fever, and a vesicular rash along the trigeminal dermatome. None of these features are present in this patient.

Bacterial conjunctivitis is the most common form of infectious conjunctivitis in children. Common pathogens include Staphylococcus aureus, Streptococcus pneumoniae, Haemophilus influenzae, and Moraxella catarrhalis. Infection usually manifests as purulent conjunctivitis with thick yellow, white, or green discharge, which is inconsistent with this patient's nonpurulent conjunctivitis and watery discharge.

Herpes simplex virus (HSV) can cause nonpurulent conjunctivitis, which manifests with photophobia, pruritus on the periocular area, crusts over the eyelashes, conjunctival injection, redness, and watery discharge from the eye. HSV-1 conjunctivitis is more common in children and adults, while HSV-2 often affects neonates. HSV conjunctivitis is usually unilateral and often manifests with a vesicular rash and corneal involvement (e.g., dendritic keratitis). Additionally, patients with a history of atopic dermatitis are particularly susceptible to HSV conjunctivitis.

HSV conjunctivitis is usually self-limited and resolves within 2 weeks, although neonatal forms can be fatal. The gold standard for diagnosis of HSV conjunctivitis is cell culture. However, typical cases in neonates or immunosuppressed patients should be treated without laboratory confirmation, as testing may delay treatment. In adults, treatment is only indicated in corneal involvement. Therapy usually consists of topical, oral, and/or IV acyclovir, depending on the severity of the disease, the age of the patient, and underlying conditions (e.g., immunosuppression).

images.title: Viral conjunctivitis
images.description: Left eyeThe conjunctival blood vessels are dilated (injection). There is no purulent discharge.This finding is consistent with viral conjunctivitis.

answers.explanation_why: Allergic conjunctivitis manifests with itchiness, chemosis (swelling of the conjunctiva), and serous secretion. Despite its association with atopic conditions such as asthma and atopic dermatitis, symptoms of allergic conjunctivitis are usually milder than those of infectious conjunctivitis and do not include a vesicular rash.

question_text: A 12-year-old girl is brought to the emergency department because of severe pain and swelling of her right eye for 3 days. Over the past 2 weeks, she has had nasal congestion and a constant, mild headache. She did not visit a doctor and instead took over-the-counter naproxen and phenylephrine. Her nasal congestion has since improved, but the headache persists. She underwent a dental procedure for caries about 10 days ago. She does not recollect any recent insect bites or trauma. Her immunizations are up-to-date. She appears ill and reports occasional chills. Her temperature is 38.3°C (101°F), pulse is 89/min, and blood pressure is 110/70 mm Hg. Examination shows proptosis of the right eye. Vision is impaired in the affected eye. Her right upper and lower eyelids are erythematous, swollen, and tender to touch. Ocular movements cause severe pain. Her headache is worsened by leaning forward and improves when the patient is lying on her back. Which of the following is the most likely cause of this patient's current symptoms?
content_preview: A 12-year-old girl is brought to the emergency department because of severe pain and swelling of her right eye for 3 days. Over the past 2 weeks, she has had nasal congestion and a constant, mild headache. She did not visit a doctor and instead took over-the-counter naproxen and phenylephrine. Her nasal congestion has since improved, but the headache persists. She underwent a dental procedure for caries about 10 days ago. She does not recollect any recent insect bites or trauma. Her immunizations are up-to-date. She appears ill and reports occasional chills. Her temperature is 38.3°C (101°F), pulse is 89/min, and blood pressure is 110/70 mm Hg. Examination shows proptosis of the right eye. Vision is impaired in the affected eye. Her right upper and lower eyelids are erythematous, swollen, and tender to touch. Ocular movements cause severe pain. Her headache is worsened by leaning forward and improves when the patient is lying on her back. Which of the following is the most likely cause of this patient's current symptoms?
hint: This girl has impaired vision (likely due to diplopia), proptosis, eyelid erythema and tenderness, and severe pain on ocular movement, which is indicative of orbital cellulitis.
learning_objective: Recognize bacterial orbital cellulitis secondary to ethmoidal sinusitis.

answers.explanation_why: Cavernous sinus thrombosis leads to proptosis and swelling of the conjunctiva. However, cavernous sinus thrombosis also manifests with symptoms related to the damage caused to structures that pass through the sinus, such as the cranial nerves responsible for eye movement (oculomotor, CN III; trochlear, CN IV; abducens, CN VI) and the ophthalmic and maxillary branches of the trigeminal nerve (CN V). This leads to ophthalmoplegia and loss of sensation in the upper two-thirds of the face. Since this patient does not have any cranial nerve symptoms, cavernous sinus thrombosis is unlikely.

Patients who have recently undergone a dental procedure are at risk of developing a dental abscess, which can spread to the orbit and cause orbital cellulitis. However, dental abscesses typically manifest with pain and swelling in the area of the abscess and systemic symptoms, such as fever, nausea, vomiting, and difficulty swallowing and/or speaking. This patient does not have any symptoms that indicate a tooth infection or dental abscess; therefore, her symptoms are likely due to a different underlying disorder.

Rarely, dacryocystitis can spread to adjacent areas, causing orbital cellulitis. However, this patient does not have a history of dacryocystitis and typical clinical features (e.g., localized tenderness in medial canthal region, epiphora, purulent discharge from the punctum) are absent; therefore, her symptoms are likely due to a different underlying disorder.

images.title: Dacryocystitis
images.description: Right eye of a 54-year-old male patientA solid and immobile mass can be seen in the right fossa lacrimalis. There is no discharge of pus or other secretions.These findings are typical of dacryocystitis, which can result from chronic inflammation of the lacrimal sac and/or chronic stenosis of the tear duct.

answers.explanation_why: This patient may have initially had viral sinusitis. However, the persistence of this patient's symptoms for two weeks makes it more likely that she now has bacterial sinusitis. In addition, orbital cellulitis is typically due to bacterial rather than viral pathogens. Lastly, the sphenoid sinuses are located in the sphenoid bones near the optic nerve and pituitary gland. Therefore, spread to the orbit from a sphenoid sinus would be less likely than spread from a sinus that is closer to the orbits.

Orbital mucormycosis may occur due to fungal spread in patients with ethmoid or maxillary fungal sinusitis. Patients with fungal sinusitis typically have either poorly controlled diabetes mellitus, HIV, or a history of long-term steroid therapy, and are usually immunocompromised. These patients would present with palatal or nasal mucosal ulceration in addition to the other signs and symptoms of sinusitis. Since this patient is young, healthy, and is not immunocompromised, a fungal source of infection is unlikely.

Orbital cellulitis is most commonly caused by bacterial spread from ethmoidal or maxillary sinusitis, as these sinuses are most proximal to the orbits. This patient's history of recent sinusitis makes bacterial spread from the ethmoidal sinus the most likely cause of her symptoms. Sinusitis can cause orbital or preseptal (anterior to the orbital septum) cellulitis. Orbital cellulitis can be distinguished from preseptal cellulitis by the presence of pain with ocular movements and vision changes.

images.title: Orbital cellulitis
images.description: The left upper and lower eyelids are red and severely swollen, resulting in the patient not being able to open the eye. Orbital cellulitis is an emergency requiring immediate treatment.

question_text: A 5-year-old girl is brought to the physician by her mother because of a 2-week history of watery discharge from her right eye. She and her parents have immigrated from Sudan one month ago. Her immunization status is unknown. She is at the 25^th percentile for weight and the 50^th percentile for height. Her temperature is 37.2°C (99.0°F), pulse is 90/min, and respirations are 18/min. Examination of the right eye shows matting of the eyelashes. Everting the right eyelid shows hyperemia, follicles, and papillae on the upper tarsal conjunctiva. Slit-lamp examination of the right eye shows follicles in the limbic region and the bulbar conjunctiva. There is corneal haziness with neovascularization at the 12 o'clock position. Examination of the left eye is unremarkable. Direct ophthalmoscopy of both eyes shows no abnormalities. Right preauricular lymphadenopathy is present. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
content_preview: A 5-year-old girl is brought to the physician by her mother because of a 2-week history of watery discharge from her right eye. She and her parents have immigrated from Sudan one month ago. Her immunization status is unknown. She is at the 25th percentile for weight and the 50th percentile for height. Her temperature is 37.2°C (99.0°F), pulse is 90/min, and respirations are 18/min. Examination of the right eye shows matting of the eyelashes. Everting the right eyelid shows hyperemia, follicles, and papillae on the upper tarsal conjunctiva. Slit-lamp examination of the right eye shows follicles in the limbic region and the bulbar conjunctiva. There is corneal haziness with neovascularization at the 12 o'clock position. Examination of the left eye is unremarkable. Direct ophthalmoscopy of both eyes shows no abnormalities. Right preauricular lymphadenopathy is present. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
hint: Histopathological examination of conjunctival scrapings from this patient's right eye would likely show intracytoplasmic inclusion bodies and large multinucleated cells.
learning_objective: Recognize trachoma conjunctivitis.

answers.explanation_why: Vernal conjunctivitis is IgE-mediated allergic conjunctivitis that is bilateral, seasonal, and self-limiting. It is prevalent among male individuals between the age of 4 and 20 years and manifests with severe itching with reflex lacrimation. However, this patient is a girl with unilateral watery discharge. Additionally, examination of a patient with vernal conjunctivitis would show giant cobblestone papillae on the upper tarsal conjunctivae.

Adenoviral conjunctivitis is the most common cause of viral conjunctivitis in children and adults. It has an acute onset and usually affects one eye but can spread to the other eye within a few days. It also manifests with marked foreign body sensation, photophobia, lacrimation, and follicular conjunctivitis. Adenoviral conjunctivitis does not manifest with papillae or corneal haziness with neovascularization, however, meaning it is an unlikely diagnosis.

Giant papillary conjunctivitis is a form of allergic conjunctivitis that commonly manifests with a foreign body sensation, itching, and mild mucoid discharge in patients who wear contact lenses or ocular prostheses. Examination shows giant papillae (> 1 mm), which is the hallmark of this disease. This 5-year-old girl does not wear contact lenses and does not have giant papillae on physical examination. Moreover, the follicles and the corneal haziness with neovascularization make giant papillary conjunctivitis unlikely.

Patients with angular conjunctivitis present with itching, redness, conjunctival hyperemia, and foamy discharge at the angles of the eye rather than the watery discharge seen in this patient. Examination showing papillae, follicles, and corneal neovascularization would not be expected.

The most characteristic clinical feature of acute hemorrhagic conjunctivitis is subconjunctival hemorrhage, which is not present in this patient. The fact that it manifests as bilateral conjunctivitis with conjunctival hyperemia and chemosis makes it an even less likely diagnosis in this patient.

Neisserial conjunctivitis predominantly affects neonates and sexually active adults. It is acute in nature and manifests as severe, bilateral conjunctivitis with profuse mucopurulent discharge. It is also associated with arthritis and urethritis but not neovascularization of the cornea. Although it can also manifest with preauricular lymphadenopathy, this 5-year-old girl's unilateral conjunctivitis is not consistent with neisserial conjunctivitis

Acute herpetic conjunctivitis is typically caused by HSV type 1 and commonly affects small children and adults. Patients present with acute onset unilateral conjunctivitis with serous discharge. Examination typically shows follicular conjunctivitis and sometimes vesicular lesions around the eye and face, neither of which are seen in this patient. If it involves the cornea, it causes dendritic or punctate ulcers rather than corneal haziness with neovascularization.

This patient's presentation is consistent with trachoma, which is caused by Chlamydia trachomatis serotypes A–C. While it is rare in North America, it constitutes a major public health concern in rural areas of developing countries, particularly in Africa, Asia, and the Middle East. Trachoma initially manifests as follicular conjunctivitis and then progresses to a mixed papillary and follicular conjunctivitis, as seen in this case. The patient's corneal haziness with neovascularization is called pannus and is a classic presentation of active trachoma.

See “Overview of conjunctivitis subtypes in children and adults” table.

images.title: Trachoma
images.description:
Clinical features of trachoma in a childA: Conjunctival follicles, consisting of whitish hyperplastic lymphatic tissue, on the ectropionized
upper eyelidB: Conjunctival scarring of the ectropionized upper eyelidC: The upper eyelid is folded inwards (entropion) and the eyelashes are growing inwards towards the cornea (trichiasis)D: Corneal opacification due to scarring (manifests as loss of vision)These findings are consistent with the active and cicatricial phase of C. trachomatis infection.

question_text:
A 56-year-old woman comes to the physician because of a 6-month history of dark spots in her vision. She has been unable to drive at night for the past 4 months. The patient has rheumatoid arthritis, type 2 diabetes mellitus, and depression. Her mother has glaucoma. She has never smoked. She drinks one or two glasses of homemade moonshine every day after dinner. Current medications include metformin, citalopram, and chloroquine. She is 168 cm (5 ft 6 in) tall and weighs 79 kg (174 lb); BMI is 28 kg/m^2. Her temperature is 36.8°C (98.2°F), pulse is 68/min, and blood pressure is 138/83 mm Hg. Examination shows swan neck deformities of both hands. The patient's vision is 20/20 in both eyes. She has difficulty adapting to changes in lighting in both eyes. Slit-lamp examination shows a normal anterior segment. The posterior segment shows bilateral bull's eye macular lesions. Laboratory studies show:

Hemoglobin
11.7 g/dL

Mean corpuscular volume
98 μm^3

Serum

 Alkaline phosphatase
65 U/L

 Aspartate aminotransferase (AST, GOT)
20 U/L

 Alanine aminotransferase (ALT, GPT)
17 U/L

 γ-Glutamyltransferase (GGT)

90 U/L (N = 5–50 U/L)

Which of the following is the most likely cause of this patient's symptoms?
content_preview: A 56-year-old woman comes to the physician because of a 6-month history of dark spots in her vision. She has been unable to drive at night for the past 4 months. The patient has rheumatoid arthritis, type 2 diabetes mellitus, and depression. Her mother has glaucoma. She has never smoked. She drinks one or two glasses of homemade moonshine every day after dinner. Current medications include metformin, citalopram, and chloroquine. She is 168 cm (5 ft 6 in) tall and weighs 79 kg (174 lb); BMI is 28 kg/m2. Her temperature is 36.8°C (98.2°F), pulse is 68/min, and blood pressure is 138/83 mm Hg. Examination shows swan neck deformities of both hands. The patient's vision is 20/20 in both eyes. She has difficulty adapting to changes in lighting in both eyes. Slit-lamp examination shows a normal anterior segment. The posterior segment shows bilateral bull's eye macular lesions. Laboratory studies show: Hemoglobin 11.7 g/dL Mean corpuscular volume 98 μm3 Serum Alkaline phosphatase 65 U/L Aspartate aminotransferase (AST, GOT) 20 U/L Alanine aminotransferase (ALT, GPT) 17 U/L γ-Glutamyltransferase (GGT) 90 U/L (N = 5–50 U/L) Which of the following is the most likely cause of this patient's symptoms?
hint: The combination of night blindness, floaters (dark spots in the field of vision), and bull's eye maculopathy suggests a specific type of retinopathy. These symptoms are indirectly associated with one of the patient's diseases.
learning_objective: Recognize chloroquine retinopathy.

answers.explanation_why:
At higher doses, chloroquine is known to cause visual disturbances and may lead to irreversible retinopathy, the key fundoscopic finding being bull's eye maculopathy. Visual acuity can remain normal until severe stages of the disease. For early detection of chloroquine retinopathy, all patients given high doses of chloroquine should undergo regular ophthalmic examinations. In this patient, treatment with chloroquine should be discontinued to prevent further eye damage.

Other common side effects of chloroquine include sensorineural deafness, anorexia, photosensitivity, alopecia, tinnitus, leukopenia, and worsening of conditions like epilepsy, psoriasis, and porphyrias.

Retinitis pigmentosa (RP) may be associated with neurosensory or developmental disorders. While RP can manifest with night-blindness and floaters, peripheral vision is typically impaired, onset is usually earlier, and there is commonly a positive family history. Additionally, fundoscopy in RP shows a pattern of dark spots and star-shaped blotches (bone spicule formation), a waxy optic nerve appearance, and retinal arteriolar attenuation. RP is therefore an unlikely diagnosis.

images.title: Retinitis pigmentosa
images.description: Fundus photography of a left eyeThe retina shows pigmentary deposits (blue overlay) resembling bone spicules in the mid periphery of the fundus along with retinal atrophy (yellow overlay), enhancing the visibility of the choroid vessels (examples indicated by arrowheads). The macula (M) shows a circular depigmentation (green overlay). The retinal blood vessels are attenuated.This is the typical fundoscopic appearance of retinitis pigmentosa.Circle: optic disc

answers.explanation_why: Methanol toxicity refers to the clinical features seen after ingestion of methanol, which may include optic neuropathy associated with vision problems and blindness. Symptoms begin 12–24 hours after ingestion and can include perceived flashes of light, blurring of vision, abdominal pain, nausea, headache, and altered mental status. Methanol rarely causes the macular damage seen in this patient. Although this woman drinks home-distilled liquor regularly, she has been symptomatic for over 6 months and has no other systemic signs. Methanol toxicity is therefore an unlikely diagnosis.

This patient is at increased risk for diabetic retinopathy, as she has type 2 diabetes mellitus. Although diabetic retinopathy can also manifest with floaters, blurred vision, and visual field defects, fundoscopy would typically show microaneurysms, hemorrhages, cotton wool spots, macular edema, or retinal vessel proliferation, but not bull's eye macular changes.

images.title: Proliferative diabetic retinopathy
images.description:
Fundus photography of the right eyeThere is massive neovascularization (examples indicated by arrows) of the optic disk (NVD), cotton wool spots (overlay), hard exudates (circle), intraretinal hemorrhages (examples indicated by white arrowheads), and a microaneurysm (example indicated by black arrowhead).The diagnosis of proliferative disease requires the presence of neovascularization.

Outline: optic disc

answers.explanation_why: While this patient does have some risk factors for angle-closure glaucoma (female sex, older age, positive family history, use of citalopram causing mydriasis), glaucoma typically causes a hollowed-out (cupping) of the optic nerve, not bull's eye maculopathy. Individuals with angle-closure glaucoma would also manifest with a sudden onset of symptoms that includes a unilaterally reddened and painful eye, headache, vomiting, and a nonreactive pupil. Moreover, floaters (black spots in the field of vision) are not a typical finding in individuals with angle-closure glaucoma.

Age-related macular degeneration (AMD), which is the leading cause of blindness in the US, commonly affects individuals > 55 years. Although it often manifests with difficulty adapting to changes in lighting, AMD would typically cause central vision impairment. Moreover, fundoscopy of patients would reveal small, discrete, yellowish-white spots (drusen) in the macula in the case of dry AMD (80% of cases) or proliferation of abnormal new blood vessels in the case of wet AMD (much less common).

Vitamin A deficiency is a leading cause of blindness in developing countries, but it is rarely seen in developed countries. Vitamin A deficiency may cause night blindness, but it would typically manifest with keratomalacia and Bitot spots. Although this woman's alcohol intake is a risk factor for vitamin A deficiency, her conjunctiva and cornea appear normal, which makes vitamin A deficiency an unlikely diagnosis.

question_text: A 2-week-old female newborn is brought to the physician for the evaluation of red eyes with discharge for 2 days. She was born at 39 weeks' gestation to a 22-year-old woman in a birthing center. Pregnancy and delivery were uncomplicated. The mother received irregular prenatal care during the second half of the pregnancy. The newborn weighed 3700 g (8 lb 2.5 oz) at birth, and no congenital anomalies were noted. She currently weighs 4000 g (8 lb 13 oz). Examination of the newborn shows pink skin. The lungs are clear to auscultation. There is mucopurulent discharge in both eyes and mild eyelid swelling. Polymerase chain reaction assay of conjunctival scraping confirms the diagnosis. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?
content_preview: A 2-week-old female newborn is brought to the physician for the evaluation of red eyes with discharge for 2 days. She was born at 39 weeks' gestation to a 22-year-old woman in a birthing center. Pregnancy and delivery were uncomplicated. The mother received irregular prenatal care during the second half of the pregnancy. The newborn weighed 3700 g (8 lb 2.5 oz) at birth, and no congenital anomalies were noted. She currently weighs 4000 g (8 lb 13 oz). Examination of the newborn shows pink skin. The lungs are clear to auscultation. There is mucopurulent discharge in both eyes and mild eyelid swelling. Polymerase chain reaction assay of conjunctival scraping confirms the diagnosis. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?
hint: Chlamydial conjunctivitis (CC) typically occurs in newborns 5–14 days after delivery and manifests with watery or mucopurulent discharge.
learning_objective: Choose the most appropriate management for neonatal chlamydial conjunctivitis.

answers.explanation_why: Topical erythromycin is insufficient for the treatment of CC because of the high rates of concomitant upper respiratory tract colonization by Chlamydia trachomatis, which topical erythromycin cannot treat. Topical therapy with an erythromycin ointment administered shortly after delivery is recommended for prophylaxis of gonococcal conjunctivitis, which usually manifests at age 2–5 days with copious mucopurulent drainage.

Reassurance and follow-up are indicated after flushing eyes with saline in cases of non-herpes viral conjunctivitis or chemical conjunctivitis, which generally resolves on its own. Chemical conjunctivitis occurs after topical silver nitrate administration and typically manifests within a day of birth and resolves after 4–5 days. Nonherpetic viral conjunctivitis is commonly unilateral with mucopurulent discharge.

Acyclovir is used to treat herpes infections. Herpetic neonatal conjunctivitis manifests with unilateral or bilateral lid edema, moderate conjunctival injection, and nonpurulent, serosanguinous discharge within 1–2 weeks after birth. Other signs include vesicles on the skin surrounding the eye and corneal epithelial involvement with dendritic or geographic ulcers. In this neonate, who has clinical features of CC, intravenous acyclovir would not be helpful.

Ceftriaxone is effective against neisserial conjunctivitis, not against chlamydial infections. Neisserial conjunctivitis typically manifests 2–7 days after birth with profuse bilateral purulent drainage and prominent eyelid swelling. This patient's mucopurulent discharge and mild swelling that developed almost 2 weeks after birth are more consistent with CC.

Oral erythromycin is the treatment of choice for neonates with CC as it provides systemic Chlamydia trachomatis coverage, given the high rates of concomitant upper respiratory tract colonization in patients with CC. These benefits are generally considered to outweigh the increased risk of developing infantile hypertrophic pyloric stenosis (IHPS) associated with the medication, which is more common in newborns < 2 weeks old. Infants should still be closely monitored for any signs of IHPS, such as nonbilious vomiting and irritability when feeding. See “Overview of neonatal conjunctivitis” table.

The CDC recommends chlamydia screening for all pregnant women < 25 years of age (and those over 25 years of age if at increased risk) and retesting during the third trimester because neither oral nor topical antibiotic therapy is effective for the prevention of CC.

A silver nitrate solution was formerly instilled into the eyes of neonates as a prophylaxis against gonococcal conjunctivitis (Crede prophylaxis). However, silver nitrate was later found to be toxic to the conjunctiva and thus cause chemical conjunctivitis. Today, silver nitrate is no longer used prophylactically or therapeutically in the US and topical antibiotics are used instead.

question_text: Two days after delivery, a newborn is brought to the physician because of a red, irritated eye with yellow discharge. She was born via vaginal delivery at 39 weeks' gestation to a 28-year-old woman, gravida 1, para 1. The mother had an unmedicated delivery at home; the patient did not receive any routine postpartum medications. The mother had not seen her gynecologist since her first prenatal visit. The newborn's temperature is 37.2°C (99.0°F), pulse is 140/min, respirations are 42/min, and blood pressure is 73/53 mm Hg. Ophthalmic examination shows eyelid edema, conjunctival injection, and copious yellow mucopurulent discharge from the right eye. There is no corneal ulceration or evidence of keratitis. The remainder of the examination shows no abnormalities. Which of the following is most likely to have prevented this patient's condition?
content_preview: Two days after delivery, a newborn is brought to the physician because of a red, irritated eye with yellow discharge. She was born via vaginal delivery at 39 weeks' gestation to a 28-year-old woman, gravida 1, para 1. The mother had an unmedicated delivery at home; the patient did not receive any routine postpartum medications. The mother had not seen her gynecologist since her first prenatal visit. The newborn's temperature is 37.2°C (99.0°F), pulse is 140/min, respirations are 42/min, and blood pressure is 73/53 mm Hg. Ophthalmic examination shows eyelid edema, conjunctival injection, and copious yellow mucopurulent discharge from the right eye. There is no corneal ulceration or evidence of keratitis. The remainder of the examination shows no abnormalities. Which of the following is most likely to have prevented this patient's condition?
hint: This patient presents with conjunctival injection and copious yellow mucopurulent discharge 2 days after birth, all of which are consistent with neonatal gonococcal conjunctivitis (NGC). NGC is typically caused by ophthalmic colonization of the newborn's conjunctiva during delivery from mothers with Neisseria gonorrhea infection.
learning_objective: Recognize neonatal gonococcal conjunctivitis, and choose the appropriate prophylactic medication to prevent it.

answers.content: Oral erythromycin administered to the infant
answers.explanation_why: Oral erythromycin is the first-line treatment for chlamydial neonatal conjunctivitis, which typically occurs 5–14 days after delivery and manifests with mild eyelid swelling and watery or mucopurulent ocular discharge. This patient's presentation is consistent with NGC, for which oral erythromycin is not indicated as either prophylaxis or treatment.

answers.content: IV ceftriaxone administered to the infant
answers.explanation_why: Intravenous or intramuscular ceftriaxone is the treatment of choice in infants with NGC. However, ceftriaxone is not used for NGC prophylaxis.

answers.content: Topical erythromycin administered to the infant
answers.explanation_why: Topical erythromycin ointment should be applied within 1 hour of birth to prevent NGC. In most states in the US, prophylaxis against NGC is required by law. If left untreated, NGC may result in corneal scarring and blindness. After confirming NGC (using culture and Gram stain or PCR), systemic treatment with either an IV or IM third-generation cephalosporin (e.g., ceftriaxone) is indicated. In addition, the eyes should be flushed with saline until the discharge clears.

images.title: Infant with gonococcal ophthalmic disease
images.description: The eyelids are swollen, with purulent exudate forming crusts around them. Below the crusts there may be a large reservoir of pus. Special care should be taken and safety goggles should be worn when examining the eyes.

answers.content: Oral doxycycline administered to the mother
answers.explanation_why: Oral doxycycline may be administered to treat mothers of newborns who have newborn conjunctivitis due to an infection with Chlamydia trachomatis. However, administration of oral doxycycline (as a prophylactic measure) in pregnant women is contraindicated because it may lead to bone damage and deposits in teeth (yellowing of the primary teeth) in the offspring.

answers.content: Oral amoxicillin administered to the mother
answers.explanation_why: Oral amoxicillin can be used to treat infection with Chlamydia trachomatis in pregnant women and, therefore, help prevent chlamydial neonatal conjunctivitis (CNC). However, CNC typically occurs 5–14 days after delivery and manifests with mild eyelid swelling and watery or mucopurulent ocular discharge. This patient's presentation is more consistent with NGC. Amoxicillin is not the first-line treatment for infection with Neisseria gonorrhea and, therefore, would have not prevented this newborn's NGC.

question_text: A 26-year-old woman comes to the physician because of a 3-day history of redness, foreign body sensation, and discharge in both eyes. She reports that her eyes feel “stuck together” and form yellow crusts every morning. She has a 3-year history of nasal allergies. Family history is remarkable for allergic rhinitis in her sister. She is sexually active with two male partners and uses condoms inconsistently. Vital signs are within normal limits. Ophthalmic examination shows edema of both eyelids, bilateral conjunctival injection, and a thin purulent discharge. Examination of the cornea, anterior chamber, and fundus is unremarkable. The remainder of the examination, including a visual acuity test, shows no abnormalities. Which of the following is the most appropriate pharmacotherapy?
content_preview: A 26-year-old woman comes to the physician because of a 3-day history of redness, foreign body sensation, and discharge in both eyes. She reports that her eyes feel “stuck together” and form yellow crusts every morning. She has a 3-year history of nasal allergies. Family history is remarkable for allergic rhinitis in her sister. She is sexually active with two male partners and uses condoms inconsistently. Vital signs are within normal limits. Ophthalmic examination shows edema of both eyelids, bilateral conjunctival injection, and a thin purulent discharge. Examination of the cornea, anterior chamber, and fundus is unremarkable. The remainder of the examination, including a visual acuity test, shows no abnormalities. Which of the following is the most appropriate pharmacotherapy?
hint: This patient's eyelid edema, conjunctival injection, and yellow purulent discharge are suggestive of acute bacterial conjunctivitis.
learning_objective: Choose the most appropriate pharmacotherapy for acute bacterial conjunctivitis.

answers.explanation_why: Topical ketorolac, an NSAID, is used to reduce the pain, inflammation, and swelling seen in allergic conjunctivitis, which manifests with bilateral redness, foreign body sensation, and discharge of eyes, as seen in this patient. This patient's personal and family history of allergies is also a risk factor for the development of allergic conjunctivitis. However, the discharge in this patient is purulent instead of watery/mucoid; and itching and follicles on the tarsal conjunctiva, both characteristic features of allergic conjunctivitis, are not seen in this patient.

images.title: Allergic conjunctivitis
images.description: Right eye of an older adultConjunctival injection, massive chemosis, and tearing are visible. The eyelids appear edematous.This is the classical appearance of allergic conjunctivitis.

answers.explanation_why:
Topical glucocorticoids (e.g., prednisolone acetate drops) may be used for the treatment of refractory allergic conjunctivitis (e.g., vernal keratoconjunctivitis), which manifests with bilateral redness, foreign body sensation, and discharge of eyes, as seen in this patient. This patient's personal and family history of allergies is also a risk factor for allergic conjunctivitis. However, the discharge in this patient is purulent instead of watery/mucoid, and itching and follicles on the tarsal conjunctiva, both characteristic features of allergic conjunctivitis, are not seen in this patient.

Topical glucocorticoids should not be used for conjunctivitis unless an infectious etiology is ruled out, as they can lead to worsening of the infection and sight-threatening complications such as keratitis and corneal perforation.

images.title: Vernal keratoconjunctivitis 1/2
images.description: Ectropionized upper right eyelid of a young boyCobblestone-like lesions, called “giant papillae” (green outline), are visible on the tarsal conjunctive of the upper eyelid.This finding is consistent with vernal keratoconjunctivitis, a severe form of allergic inflammation in the eye. It may lead to further complications, including corneal ulcer.

answers.explanation_why: The most common organism causing bacterial conjunctivitis in adults is Staphylococcus aureus, followed by Streptococcus pneumoniae and Haemophilus influenzae. While most cases of bacterial conjunctivitis are self-limited, the use of topical antibiotics speeds up recovery and may reduce the risk of transmission. There is no superior antibiotic regimen; selection should be based on cost, availability, and local resistance data. Empiric treatment should be with a topical broad-spectrum antibiotic, such as erythromycin or a combination of trimethoprim/polymyxin B.

images.title: Bacterial conjunctivitis
images.description: Left eyeThere is massive conjunctival injection (hyperemia) and purulent discharge, especially visible in the medial corner of the eye and the margin of the lower lid.This is the characteristic appearance of bacterial conjunctivitis.

answers.explanation_why: Topical fluoroquinolones like ciprofloxacin are usually not preferred for empiric treatment of bacterial conjunctivitis because of the concerns surrounding increasing bacterial drug resistance. The only exception is contact lens wearers since the most common causative organism of bacterial conjunctivitis in this group of patients is Pseudomonas aeruginosa, against which fluoroquinolones are effective. Pseudomonas conjunctivitis is often more fulminant and can rapidly lead to sight-threatening keratitis and corneal perforation. As this patient does not wear contact lenses and her presentation is not as severe, another treatment option is more appropriate.

Artificial tears (e.g., carboxymethyl cellulose) can be used for lubrication in patients with dry eye disease (keratoconjunctivitis sicca) as well as in contact lens wearers. Dry eye disease manifests with a foreign body sensation in the eye, along with itching and redness, but it is not accompanied by purulent discharge. While artificial tears may be used in bacterial conjunctivitis for symptomatic relief, a different treatment is required to target this patient's infection.

Oral azithromycin is the treatment of choice for patients with inclusion conjunctivitis, which is caused by infection with Chlamydia trachomatis (types D–K) and frequently occurs in combination with chlamydial genitourinary infections. Although this patient is at risk of developing a chlamydial infection because of the inconsistent use of condoms with more than one sexual partner and presents with bilateral conjunctival injection and purulent discharge, both of which are characteristic of inclusion conjunctivitis, the absence of conjunctival follicles, and a cobblestone appearance of the palpebral conjunctiva makes this diagnosis unlikely.

images.title: Inclusion conjunctivitis
images.description: The tarsal conjunctiva appears edematous with developing follicles (examples indicated by green overlay).These findings are consistent with inclusion conjunctivitis due to Chlamydia trachomatis infection.

question_text: A 35-year-old man comes to the physician because of itchy, watery eyes for the past week. He has also been sneezing multiple times a day during this period. He had a similar episode 1 year ago in spring. He has iron deficiency anemia and ankylosing spondylitis. Current medications include ferrous sulfate, artificial tear drops, and indomethacin. He works as an elementary school teacher. His vital signs are within normal limits. Physical examination shows bilateral conjunctival injection with watery discharge. The pupils are 3 mm, equal, and reactive to light. Visual acuity test and slit-lamp examination show no abnormalities. Which of the following is the most appropriate treatment?
content_preview: A 35-year-old man comes to the physician because of itchy, watery eyes for the past week. He has also been sneezing multiple times a day during this period. He had a similar episode 1 year ago in spring. He has iron deficiency anemia and ankylosing spondylitis. Current medications include ferrous sulfate, artificial tear drops, and indomethacin. He works as an elementary school teacher. His vital signs are within normal limits. Physical examination shows bilateral conjunctival injection with watery discharge. The pupils are 3 mm, equal, and reactive to light. Visual acuity test and slit-lamp examination show no abnormalities. Which of the following is the most appropriate treatment?
hint: This patient's recurrent symptoms of sneezing and bilateral itchy, watery conjunctivitis that worsen around springtime are suggestive of seasonal allergic conjunctivitis (SAC).
learning_objective: Recognize seasonal allergic conjunctivitis, and choose the most appropriate treatment.

answers.explanation_why: Erythromycin ointment may be administered in the case of bacterial conjunctivitis, which is typically unilateral and often leads to purulent discharge. Although this patient presents with conjunctivitis, his conjunctivitis is bilateral and is associated with itching and watery discharge. Moreover, it occurs during specific times of the year, which makes a bacterial infection unlikely.

Ganciclovir eye drops may be used to treat patients with herpes simplex conjunctivitis, which typically present with unilateral conjunctival injections, chemosis, and tearing. Concurrent vesicular blepharitis with eyelid edema is common. This patient has bilateral conjunctivitis and no evidence of eyelid involvement, making herpes simplex conjunctivitis an unlikely diagnosis.

Second-generation antihistamines such as ketotifen can be used in the treatment of SAC. Patients should also try to avoid irritating agents (e.g., allergens, contact lenses) if possible. The use of cold compresses, artificial tears, and local NSAIDs (e.g., ketorolac) can provide additional symptomatic relief for these patients.

images.title: Allergic conjunctivitis
images.description: Right eye of an older adultConjunctival injection, massive chemosis, and tearing are visible. The eyelids appear edematous.This is the classical appearance of allergic conjunctivitis.

answers.explanation_why: Warm compresses may be used to treat hordeolum, which typically manifests with a painful, erythematous, pus-filled tender nodule that can perforate, releasing purulent discharge. However, this patient presents with signs and symptoms that are consistent with SAC, for which cold rather than warm compresses are usually recommended.

Low-dose glucocorticoids such as fluorometholone are used as second-line treatment for SAC. Because glucocorticoids are associated with numerous ophthalmologic side effects (e.g., intraocular pressure elevation, cataract formation), they are only indicated if patients do not respond to first-line treatment.

Glucocorticoids are also used for the treatment of uveitis, which is a common finding in patients with systemic inflammatory conditions, including ankylosing spondylitis. However, this patient's normal slit-lamp examination findings make uveitis highly unlikely.

Latanoprost eye drops are used to treat elevated intraocular pressure in chronic glaucoma, which typically affects older individuals and manifests with few, often nonspecific symptoms such as headache, burning, reddening of the eye, and possibly halos. Although this patient presents with reddening of the eyes, he is only 35 years of age and his recurrent symptoms of sneezing and bilateral itchy and watery conjunctivitis are more consistent with SAC.
