question_text: A 76-year-old man comes to the emergency department because of an episode of seeing jagged edges followed by loss of central vision in his right eye. The episode occurred 6 hours ago and lasted approximately 5 minutes. The patient has no pain. He has a 3-month history of intermittent blurriness out of his right eye and reports a 10-minute episode of slurred speech and left-sided facial droop that occurred 2 months ago. He has hypercholesterolemia, stable angina pectoris, hypertension, and a 5-year history of type 2 diabetes mellitus. Medications include glyburide, atorvastatin, labetalol, isosorbide, lisinopril, and aspirin. He feels well. He is oriented to person, place, and time. His temperature is 37°C (98.6°F), pulse is 76/min, respirations are 12/min, and blood pressure is 154/78 mm Hg. The extremities are well perfused with strong peripheral pulses. Ophthalmologic examination shows visual acuity of 20/30 in the left eye and 20/40 in the right eye. Visual fields are normal. Fundoscopic examination shows two grayish-white spots along the supratemporal and inferotemporal arcade. Neurologic examination shows no focal findings. Cardiopulmonary examination shows systolic rumbling at the right carotid artery. The remainder of the examination shows no abnormalities. An ECG shows normal sinus rhythm with no evidence of ischemia. In addition to obtaining a CT scan of the head, which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?
content_preview: A 76-year-old man comes to the emergency department because of an episode of seeing jagged edges followed by loss of central vision in his right eye. The episode occurred 6 hours ago and lasted approximately 5 minutes. The patient has no pain. He has a 3-month history of intermittent blurriness out of his right eye and reports a 10-minute episode of slurred speech and left-sided facial droop that occurred 2 months ago. He has hypercholesterolemia, stable angina pectoris, hypertension, and a 5-year history of type 2 diabetes mellitus. Medications include glyburide, atorvastatin, labetalol, isosorbide, lisinopril, and aspirin. He feels well. He is oriented to person, place, and time. His temperature is 37°C (98.6°F), pulse is 76/min, respirations are 12/min, and blood pressure is 154/78 mm Hg. The extremities are well perfused with strong peripheral pulses. Ophthalmologic examination shows visual acuity of 20/30 in the left eye and 20/40 in the right eye. Visual fields are normal. Fundoscopic examination shows two grayish-white spots along the supratemporal and inferotemporal arcade. Neurologic examination shows no focal findings. Cardiopulmonary examination shows systolic rumbling at the right carotid artery. The remainder of the examination shows no abnormalities. An ECG shows normal sinus rhythm with no evidence of ischemia. In addition to obtaining a CT scan of the head, which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?
hint: Sudden, painless, transient monocular loss of vision with cloudy discoloration along the retinal arterial supply on fundoscopy is highly suggestive of retinal artery occlusion. The most common cause in older adults is atherosclerotic emboli, which is consistent with this patient's age, extensive atherosclerotic risk factors (hypercholesterolemia, stable angina pectoris, hypertension, type 2 diabetes mellitus), history of possible transient ischemic attack, and finding of an ipsilateral carotid bruit on examination.
learning_objective: Recognize retinal artery occlusion secondary to atherosclerotic emboli, and choose the most appropriate diagnostic test.

answers.explanation_why: Echocardiography is used to evaluate for cardiac causes of retinal vessel occlusion and TIA, such as emboli due to atrial fibrillation. Cardiogenic emboli are the most common cause of retinal artery occlusion in younger patients (< 40 years of age) and should be suspected based on a patient history that includes, e.g., atrial fibrillation (AF), endocarditis, or valvular disease. However, while this patient does have a history and exam findings that both suggest retinal vessel occlusion and a TIA, he has no AF and there are signs of carotid artery stenosis. Echocardiography would be an appropriate step in management only after atherosclerotic causes of this patient's symptoms have been ruled out.

Fluorescein angiography allows for visualization of flow through the retinal vessels and may be used to diagnose a variety of retinal disorders, such as macular degeneration, diabetic retinopathy, and retinal vascular occlusions. While fluorescein angiography might show slow or absent filling of retinal arteries in retinal artery occlusion, it is usually indicated when the diagnosis is not otherwise clear, e.g., when ischemic retinal whitening is not clearly present on fundoscopy. In this case, such findings are apparent, as is the diagnosis of retinal artery occlusion. Fluorescein angiography would not contribute significantly to this patient's care.

Reassurance and follow-up might be appropriate in a patient with transient vision loss secondary to a benign etiology. For example, migraine is the most common cause of transient binocular vision loss in young adults. This patient's vision loss was transient and he has a history of intermittent blurriness that could be consistent with migrainous aura, but the lack of other migraine symptoms, along with the monocular presentation, make the diagnosis of migrainous aura unlikely.

Temporal artery biopsy could conclusively evaluate for the presence of giant cell arteritis (GCA), which can result in permanent vision loss if untreated. Suspicion of GCA should be especially high in patients above the age of 50 with fundoscopy findings of pallid optic disc swelling without apparent emboli. While our patient's monocular vision loss and history of intermittent monocular blurriness could be consistent with GCA, he lacks additional symptoms such as temporal headache or jaw claudication, and his fundus examination reveals clearly demarcated areas of vascular involvement, which is not consistent with GCA. A temporal artery biopsy is therefore not indicated.

images.title: Polymyalgia rheumatica and giant cell arteritis fact sheet

answers.explanation_why:
Carotid duplex ultrasonography is the best next step in the management of a patient with transient retinal artery occlusion secondary to atherosclerotic emboli. This procedure allows for the assessment of the carotid arteries for atherosclerotic plaques and vessel stenosis, and thus the patient's candidacy for treatment options (e.g., antiplatelet therapy, carotid endarterectomy).

Retinal vessel occlusion is primarily a clinical diagnosis, so confirmatory testing is generally not indicated, except in unusual cases. This patient presented with classic history and exam findings, making testing unnecessary in his case. Instead, the diagnostic focus is on the cause of occlusion, which might be cardiovascular or inflammatory disease.

question_text: A 67-year-old man comes to the emergency department because of decreased vision and black spots in front of his left eye for the past 24 hours. He states that it feels as if 'a curtain is hanging over his eye.' He sees flashes of light intermittently. He has no pain or diplopia. He underwent cataract surgery on the left eye 2 weeks ago. He has hypertension and type 2 diabetes mellitus. His sister has open-angle glaucoma. Current medications include metformin, linagliptin, ramipril, and hydrochlorothiazide. Vital signs are within normal limits. Examination shows a visual acuity in the right eye of 20/25 and the ability to count fingers at 3 feet in the left eye. The pupils are equal and reactive. The corneal reflex is present. The anterior chamber shows no abnormalities. The confrontation test is normal on the right side and shows nasal and inferior defects on the left side. Cardiopulmonary examination shows no abnormalities. The patient is awaiting dilation for fundus examination. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
content_preview: A 67-year-old man comes to the emergency department because of decreased vision and black spots in front of his left eye for the past 24 hours. He states that it feels as if 'a curtain is hanging over his eye.' He sees flashes of light intermittently. He has no pain or diplopia. He underwent cataract surgery on the left eye 2 weeks ago. He has hypertension and type 2 diabetes mellitus. His sister has open-angle glaucoma. Current medications include metformin, linagliptin, ramipril, and hydrochlorothiazide. Vital signs are within normal limits. Examination shows a visual acuity in the right eye of 20/25 and the ability to count fingers at 3 feet in the left eye. The pupils are equal and reactive. The corneal reflex is present. The anterior chamber shows no abnormalities. The confrontation test is normal on the right side and shows nasal and inferior defects on the left side. Cardiopulmonary examination shows no abnormalities. The patient is awaiting dilation for fundus examination. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
hint: The sudden painless decreased vision in one eye with flashes of light and floaters after a cataract surgery indicates a pathology in the posterior segment of the eyeball.
learning_objective: Recognize retinal detachment.

answers.explanation_why: Degenerative retinoschisis may be confused with retinal detachment because the separation of layers within the retina appears similar to separation of the retina from the retinal pigment epithelium on dilated exam. However, in contrast to retinal detachment, degenerative retinoschisis is typically asymptomatic, has a very good prognosis, and rarely requires intervention, which is not consistent with this patient's acute and dramatic visual impairment, making this diagnosis less likely.

Retinal detachment is vision-threatening and considered an ophthalmological emergency. Retinal detachment is associated with a number of risk factors, including previous intraocular surgery (e.g., cataract surgery). Patients may experience a prodrome of flashes of light (photopsia) and moving dark spots or “floaters” prior to detachment, which correlate to retinal traction and vitreous hemorrhage respectively. Patients classically describe a “rising wall” or “dark curtain” across their field of vision as the retina partially separates from the underlying retinal pigment epithelium. Although the patient is awaiting fundus examination, which would conclusively diagnose retinal detachment, his symptoms and the absence of an anterior chamber pathology are consistent with the classic presentation of retinal detachment.

Most cases of retinal detachment require prompt surgical treatment (e.g., vitrectomy followed by internal tamponade and laser photocoagulation/cryoretinopexy).

images.title: Rhegmatogenous retinal detachment
images.description: Fundus photography of the eyeThe detached part of the retina is visible as a yellow-gray, bullous elevation (blue overlay) in the upper part of the image. The detachment is due to a retinal tear (dashed outline).

answers.explanation_why: Acute angle-closure glaucoma typically presents acutely as a severely painful, reddened, and inflamed eye, with an opacified cornea that may be perceptibly harder on palpation than the unaffected eye. Patients may complain of headaches, nausea/vomiting, blurred vision, and halos around light sources, none of which are present in this patient. While visual acuity may be affected, the patient's painless loss of vision and normal anterior chamber findings are not consistent with acute angle-closure glaucoma, making it an unlikely diagnosis.

Endophthalmitis may occur as a result of inoculation from ocular trauma, intraocular surgery, or hematogenous spread of bloodstream infections, especially in diabetic or otherwise immunocompromised patients. Endophthalmitis typically manifests with dull or aching eye pain, eye redness, and generally decreased vision. While this patient does have risk factors for endophthalmitis such as recent intraocular surgery and a history of diabetes, his painless, well-demarcated vision loss and normal anterior chamber findings are not consistent with endophthalmitis, making it an unlikely diagnosis.

Wet age-related macular degeneration (AMD) typically has an insidious onset of weeks to months, or over the span of days in severe cases. AMD generally manifests as gradually worsening central or pericentral visual impairment, which leads to difficulty with fine focusing tasks like reading. Patients may describe or reveal metamorphopsia on examination. This patient's description of acute-onset vision loss progressing rapidly from top-to-bottom and obscuring peripheral visual fields is not consistent with wet AMD.

Hemorrhagic choroidal detachment is a rare event and can occur during or shortly after intraocular surgery. Its manifestation varies widely, occurring with or without pain and with varying degrees and distributions of vision loss. While this patient's painless vision loss with nasal and inferior defects on confrontation exam could be consistent with hemorrhagic choroidal detachment following his cataract surgery, it is unlikely that this event would occur two weeks after an uneventful surgery, during which time the patient was asymptomatic. The dark “floaters” noted by the patient, moreover, are consistent with retinal traction and therefore more suggestive of subsequent retinal detachment as the cause of this patient's visual symptoms. Retinal detachment as a whole is also much more common and would be the more likely diagnosis.

question_text: A 43-year-old woman is brought into the emergency room by emergency medical services 30 minutes after a kitchen fire during which she sustained burns to the face. On arrival, she is distressed but awake and alert; she is able to speak normally. Her temperature is 37.9°C (100.3°F), pulse is 99/min, respirations are 22/min, and blood pressure is 140/80 mm Hg. Breath sounds are normal. There is erythema with ruptured and unruptured blistering visible over the forehead, cheeks, and around the eyes, all of which are minimally tender. There is no erythema, edema, or blistering apparent around or in the patient's mouth. The remainder of the examination shows no abnormalities. Following cleaning and debridement of the burned areas, which of the following is the best management for this patient's burns?
content_preview: A 43-year-old woman is brought into the emergency room by emergency medical services 30 minutes after a kitchen fire during which she sustained burns to the face. On arrival, she is distressed but awake and alert; she is able to speak normally. Her temperature is 37.9°C (100.3°F), pulse is 99/min, respirations are 22/min, and blood pressure is 140/80 mm Hg. Breath sounds are normal. There is erythema with ruptured and unruptured blistering visible over the forehead, cheeks, and around the eyes, all of which are minimally tender. There is no erythema, edema, or blistering apparent around or in the patient's mouth. The remainder of the examination shows no abnormalities. Following cleaning and debridement of the burned areas, which of the following is the best management for this patient's burns?
hint: This patient has facial burns that must be managed carefully to avoid damage to the eyes.
learning_objective: Recognize second-degree periorbital burns, and choose the appropriate topical management.

answers.content: Topical silver sulfadiazine cream with nonadherent dressing
answers.explanation_why: Topical silver sulfadiazine cream with nonadherent dressing is generally appropriate for the management of second-degree burns. However, this patient's burns are periorbital, and silver sulfadiazine is toxic to the eyes.

answers.content: Topical bacitracin ointment with nonadherent dressing
answers.explanation_why: Topical bacitracin ointment with nonadherent dressing is appropriate for the management of second-degree burns affecting the periorbital area. Some topical antimicrobial agents that are typically used for the management of burns (e.g., silver sulfadiazine) are toxic to the eyes and should be avoided in patients with periorbital burns.

answers.content: Topical povidone-iodine ointment with nonadherent dressing
answers.explanation_why: Topical povidone-iodine ointment with nonadherent dressing is generally appropriate for the management of second-degree burns. However, this patient's burns are periorbital and povidone-iodine ointment is toxic to the eyes.

answers.content: IV cephalosporin antibiotic with nonadherent dressing
answers.explanation_why: A nonadherent dressing is indicated in this patient's case. However, systemic antibiotics are only administered in burn treatment when signs of burn wound infection or sepsis are present.
Because this patient has a second-degree burn, nonadherent dressings alone are not sufficient. An antimicrobial agent is also indicated.

question_text: A 31-year-old woman is brought to the emergency department because of a severe right-sided temporal headache with conjunctival swelling and anterior bulging of the left eye for 1 hour. The patient has had right-sided purulent nasal discharge and nasal congestion for the past 2 days. There is no personal or family history of serious illness. The patient does not smoke or drink alcohol. She takes no medications. She appears to be in acute distress. Her temperature is 40°C (104°F), pulse is 105/min, and blood pressure is 125/80 mm Hg. Examination shows bilateral ptosis. The pupils are equal and reactive to light; lateral gaze of the left eye is limited. Ophthalmic examination shows periorbital edema and chemosis of the left eye. The remainder of the examination shows no abnormalities. The patient most likely requires treatment with which of the following?
content_preview: A 31-year-old woman is brought to the emergency department because of a severe right-sided temporal headache with conjunctival swelling and anterior bulging of the left eye for 1 hour. The patient has had right-sided purulent nasal discharge and nasal congestion for the past 2 days. There is no personal or family history of serious illness. The patient does not smoke or drink alcohol. She takes no medications. She appears to be in acute distress. Her temperature is 40°C (104°F), pulse is 105/min, and blood pressure is 125/80 mm Hg. Examination shows bilateral ptosis. The pupils are equal and reactive to light; lateral gaze of the left eye is limited. Ophthalmic examination shows periorbital edema and chemosis of the left eye. The remainder of the examination shows no abnormalities. The patient most likely requires treatment with which of the following?
hint: This patient presents with periorbital edema, chemosis, high fever, and dysfunction of CN III (bilateral ptosis) and CN VI (impaired lateral gaze) 2 days after the onset of sinusitis. These features suggest septic cavernous sinus thrombosis.
learning_objective: Recognize septic cavernous sinus thrombosis, and choose the appropriate empiric antibiotic therapy.

answers.explanation_why: Timolol, a topical beta-blocker, is recommended for the treatment of acute angle-closure glaucoma. Although this condition would also manifest with a unilateral headache and chemosis, the headache is usually frontal rather than temporal. Acute angle-closure glaucoma primarily affects older individuals and would also cause symptoms such as eye pain and blurred vision. Additionally, acute angle-closure glaucoma does not manifest with periorbital edema, lateral gaze restriction, bilateral ptosis, or fever.

Anticoagulants support the recanalization of the dural sinuses and prevent the formation of new thrombi, which decreases the risk of septic emboli. Although some studies have shown a reduction in mortality with the use of heparin, its use remains controversial because it increases the risk of hemorrhagic complications. Because it is difficult to achieve a stable drug level, oral warfarin is generally not recommended in the acute phase of this disease.

Oral clindamycin and amoxicillin are an empiric treatment option for preseptal cellulitis (periorbital cellulitis). In preseptal cellulitis, the infection is typically restricted anteriorly by the orbital septum and characterized by unilateral ocular pain with edema and erythema of the eyelid. As most cases of preseptal cellulitis stem from a contiguous skin infection, the orbit is not involved. This patient's ophthalmoplegia, bilateral ptosis, and high fever are not characteristic of preseptal cellulitis and are more concerning for a disseminated infection involving the orbit and paranasal sinuses, for which the combination of oral clindamycin and amoxicillin would not be appropriate.

images.title: Preseptal cellulitis
images.description: The left eyelid appears swollen and erythematous.These clinical features are suggestive of preseptal cellulitis, an inflammation of tissue anterior to the orbital septum.

answers.explanation_why: Intranasal sumatriptan is indicated for the treatment of cluster headaches and migraines. Either condition can manifest with a severe unilateral headache. However, typical features of a cluster headache include short recurring pain attacks (lasting only minutes) and ipsilateral autonomic symptoms (e.g., lacrimation, nonpurulent nasal discharge, facial sweating), which this patient lacks. As for migraines, patients commonly have nausea, vomiting, photophobia, or phonophobia, which are also not present here. Neither condition is associated with periorbital edema, chemosis, or fever.

Surgical debridement, along with amphotericin B, is the treatment of choice for mucormycosis, which can manifest with headache, nasal discharge, fever, erythema of the skin overlying the orbit, and cranial nerve palsies, which are seen here. However, this condition is seen almost exclusively in patients who are immunocompromised or diabetic, particularly those with diabetic ketoacidosis, which this patient does not have. Most commonly, such patients develop a rhino-orbital-cerebral infection, which is characterized by the formation of a black eschar on the palate or nasal mucosa due to extensive local tissue necrosis. In septic cavernous sinus thrombosis, endonasal surgery (e.g., sphenoidectomy, ethmoidectomy, mastoidectomy) is only indicated if first-line treatment options are unsuccessful.

Antibiotic therapy is the mainstay of treatment for septic cavernous sinus thrombosis. Empiric therapy with vancomycin (for coverage of MRSA) should be combined with a third- or fourth-generation cephalosporin (ceftriaxone or cefepime) and, if the infection originated from the sinus or the teeth, metronidazole (for anaerobic coverage). Affected patients should be treated with high-dose, prolonged antibiotic therapy to reach bacteria sequestered within thrombi. Antifungal therapy (amphotericin B) is indicated in confirmed cases of fungal origin.

IV dihydroergotamine is an alternative treatment option for the acute management of cluster headaches and migraines in patients who do not respond to the preferred treatment options. Either condition can manifest with a severe unilateral headache. However, typical features of a cluster headache include short recurring pain attacks (lasting only minutes) and ipsilateral autonomic symptoms (e.g., lacrimation, nonpurulent nasal discharge, facial sweating), which this patient lacks. As for migraines, patients commonly have nausea, vomiting, photophobia, or phonophobia, which are also not present here. Neither condition is associated with periorbital edema, chemosis, or fever.

question_text:
A 75-year-old woman comes to the physician because of generalized weakness for 6 months. During this period, she has also had a 4-kg (8.8-lb) weight loss and frequent headaches. She also reports severe jaw pain while chewing. She has hypertension and osteoporosis. She underwent a total left-sided knee arthroplasty 2 years ago because of osteoarthritis. The patient does not smoke or drink alcohol. Her current medications include enalapril, metoprolol, and a multivitamin. She appears pale. Her temperature is 37.5°C (99.5°F), pulse is 82/min, and blood pressure is 135/80 mm Hg. Physical examination shows no abnormalities. Laboratory studies show:

Hemoglobin

10 g/dL 

Mean corpuscular volume

87 μm^3 

Leukocyte count
8,500/mm^3

Platelet count
450,000/mm^3

Erythrocyte sedimentation rate

90 mm/h 

Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?
content_preview: A 75-year-old woman comes to the physician because of generalized weakness for 6 months. During this period, she has also had a 4-kg (8.8-lb) weight loss and frequent headaches. She also reports severe jaw pain while chewing. She has hypertension and osteoporosis. She underwent a total left-sided knee arthroplasty 2 years ago because of osteoarthritis. The patient does not smoke or drink alcohol. Her current medications include enalapril, metoprolol, and a multivitamin. She appears pale. Her temperature is 37.5°C (99.5°F), pulse is 82/min, and blood pressure is 135/80 mm Hg. Physical examination shows no abnormalities. Laboratory studies show: Hemoglobin 10 g/dL Mean corpuscular volume 87 μm3 Leukocyte count 8,500/mm3 Platelet count 450,000/mm3 Erythrocyte sedimentation rate 90 mm/h Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?
hint: This 75-year-old patient presents with headache, jaw claudication, normochromic anemia, and a significantly elevated ESR, all of which suggest giant cell arteritis (GCA).
learning_objective: Recognize giant cell arteritis, and choose the most appropriate initial management.

answers.content: Duplex ultrasound of the temporal arteries
answers.explanation_why: Duplex ultrasound of the temporal arteries is the first-line imaging modality for diagnosing GCA. However, if clinical suspicion for GCA is high, treatment should not be delayed for diagnostic workup.

Glucocorticoid-sparing therapy, such as tocilizumab and methotrexate, should be considered as adjunctive treatment in all patients with newly diagnosed or relapsed GCA and those with adverse effects due to glucocorticoids. However, glucocorticoid-sparing agents are not the first-line treatment for GCA.

Low-dose aspirin may be used as adjunctive therapy in GCA to reduce the risk of ischemic events in patients with critical stenosis of the vertebral or carotid arteries. However, low-dose aspirin is not the first-line treatment for GCA.

Glucocorticoids are the first-line treatment for patients with GCA. High-dose oral glucocorticoids, such as prednisone, are indicated in patients without signs of acute ischemic organ damage (e.g., impaired vision and/or neurological deficits). If clinical suspicion for GCA is high, treatment should be initiated before the diagnostic workup (e.g., temporal artery biopsy) to minimize the risk of complications such as vision loss and stroke.

The patient's generalized weakness could also be associated with concurrent polymyalgia rheumatica, which is present in about half of all patients with giant cell arteritis. Both conditions are treated with corticosteroids.

Temporal artery biopsy is the gold standard for diagnosing GCA. However, if clinical suspicion for GCA is high, initial treatment should not be delayed for diagnostic workup. Delaying treatment increases the risk of severe ischemic complications, such as temporary (e.g., amaurosis fugax) or permanent vision loss and cerebral ischemia (e.g., stroke or transient ischemic attack).

question_text: A 29-year-old woman comes to the physician for the evaluation of progressive loss of vision in her left eye and gradual blurring of vision in her right eye over the past 2 months. She also has occasional headaches and noticed a decrease in her sense of smell lately. She has never had these symptoms before. The patient's only medication is fexofenadine for seasonal allergies. She is 158 cm (5 ft 2 in) tall and weighs 61 kg (135 lb); BMI is 24 kg/m^2. Vital signs are within normal limits. Visual acuity is 20/40 in the right eye and there is minimal light perception in the left eye. In the swinging flashlight test, both of her eyes dilate as the light moves from the right to left eye. Fundoscopy shows papilledema in the right optic disc and a pale left optic disc. The remainder of the examination shows no abnormalities. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
content_preview: A 29-year-old woman comes to the physician for the evaluation of progressive loss of vision in her left eye and gradual blurring of vision in her right eye over the past 2 months. She also has occasional headaches and noticed a decrease in her sense of smell lately. She has never had these symptoms before. The patient's only medication is fexofenadine for seasonal allergies. She is 158 cm (5 ft 2 in) tall and weighs 61 kg (135 lb); BMI is 24 kg/m2. Vital signs are within normal limits. Visual acuity is 20/40 in the right eye and there is minimal light perception in the left eye. In the swinging flashlight test, both of her eyes dilate as the light moves from the right to left eye. Fundoscopy shows papilledema in the right optic disc and a pale left optic disc. The remainder of the examination shows no abnormalities. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
hint: Ipsilateral atrophy of the optic nerve (as indicated by the pale optic disc and the afferent defect seen in the swinging flashlight test), contralateral papilledema, and anosmia suggest Foster-Kennedy syndrome.
learning_objective: Recognize olfactory groove meningioma.

answers.explanation_why: Leber hereditary optic neuropathy is the most common inherited optic neuropathy in young adults. Optic neuropathy causes acute visual changes, but it would not cause papilledema or anosmia. Visual field testing demonstrates a central scotoma and telangiectasias around the papilla as well as microangiopathy, none of which are seen in this patient. The lack of family history of optic neuropathy also makes hereditary neuropathy unlikely.

Pseudotumor cerebri (i.e., idiopathic intracranial hypertension) should always be considered in women of childbearing age who present with subacute-to-chronic headaches and visual changes. However, pseudotumor cerebri typically affects overweight women, causes bilateral rather than unilateral papilledema, and is rarely associated with anosmia.

Anterior ischemic optic neuropathy (AION) is the most common cause of optic neuropathy in adults > 50 years old and manifests with acute visual loss. Fundoscopic examination would show pale optic disc swelling, sometimes associated with splinter hemorrhages. Unlike in this patient, AION progresses over the course of a few days (not months) and does not cause anosmia.

Frontal lobe tumors, mainly parasellar or subfrontal meningiomas, are the most common cause of Foster-Kennedy syndrome. Anosmia is typically associated with meningiomas arising from the olfactory groove (i.e., from the cribriform plate and frontosphenoidal suture), which account for 22% of all skull base meningiomas. The most appropriate next step in diagnosis is a brain MRI, which is likely to show a round, sharply demarcated space-occupying lesion (resembling a snowball) with significant contrast enhancement. Management is based on the location and grade of the tumor, as well as patient-specific factors (e.g., age, comorbidities, accompanying symptoms). Treatment that reduces elevated intracranial pressure may improve visual function.

images.title: Dural based lesion
images.description: MRI head (T1-weighted; with contrast; sagittal plane) of a 58-year-old patient with parosmia.There is a large, well-defined mass with homogeneous contrast enhancement in the olfactory groove (green overlay.This is an example of an olfactory groove meningioma.

answers.explanation_why: Multiple sclerosis (MS) is a common cause of optic neuritis, especially in women of childbearing age. Optic neuritis can manifest with acute vision change and a relative afferent pupillary defect. While optic neuritis may cause papillitis, which occasionally manifests with papilledema, it does not result in optic atrophy. Also, MS typically manifests with relapsing, remitting neurologic symptoms in anatomically unrelated locations (i.e., symptoms disseminated in time and space), whereas this patient's symptoms are chronic and progressive. Less commonly, MS can cause chronic, progressive symptoms, but it does not cause elevated intracranial pressure, thus it would not explain this patient's headaches.

question_text: A 7-month-old boy is brought to the emergency department by his mother because of a 3-day history of nonbloody vomiting and poor feeding. He transitioned to pureed vegetables 10 days ago. Over the past 2 weeks, he has become increasingly irritable and within the past day has taken more daytime naps and appears much less responsive and interactive. His mother denies any history of fever or trauma at home. He has not received any vaccinations as his parents believe he is already healthy and does not need them. He spends most of the day with a babysitter while both parents are at work. He appears lethargic. His temperature is 37.8°C (100.1°F), pulse is 140/min, respirations are 18/min, and blood pressure is 90/55 mm Hg. The abdomen is soft and nontender. Auscultation of the heart and lungs shows no abnormalities. The anterior fontanelle is tense and bulging. Fundoscopic examination shows bilateral retinal hemorrhage. A complete blood count shows a leukocyte count of 10,000/mm^3. An x-ray of the chest shows healing fractures of the 2^nd and 3^rd right ribs. Further evaluation of this patient is most likely to show which of the following findings?
content_preview: A 7-month-old boy is brought to the emergency department by his mother because of a 3-day history of nonbloody vomiting and poor feeding. He transitioned to pureed vegetables 10 days ago. Over the past 2 weeks, he has become increasingly irritable and within the past day has taken more daytime naps and appears much less responsive and interactive. His mother denies any history of fever or trauma at home. He has not received any vaccinations as his parents believe he is already healthy and does not need them. He spends most of the day with a babysitter while both parents are at work. He appears lethargic. His temperature is 37.8°C (100.1°F), pulse is 140/min, respirations are 18/min, and blood pressure is 90/55 mm Hg. The abdomen is soft and nontender. Auscultation of the heart and lungs shows no abnormalities. The anterior fontanelle is tense and bulging. Fundoscopic examination shows bilateral retinal hemorrhage. A complete blood count shows a leukocyte count of 10,000/mm3. An x-ray of the chest shows healing fractures of the 2nd and 3rd right ribs. Further evaluation of this patient is most likely to show which of the following findings?
hint: Retinal hemorrhage and associated rib fractures in a 7-month-old infant should raise concern for child abuse.
learning_objective: Recognize signs of child abuse, and recall the diagnostic finding associated with shaken baby syndrome.

answers.explanation_why: Tumors of the posterior fossa (e.g., juvenile pilocytic astrocytoma) are the most common pediatric primary brain tumors. A mass in the posterior fossa could gradually lead to altered mental status and could also increase intracranial pressure in a 7-month-old child to the extent that the anterior fontanelle would be tense and bulging. However, increased intracranial pressure would more likely be associated with papilledema on fundoscopic examination than retinal hemorrhages. In addition, this child's healing rib fractures should raise suspicion of a traumatic etiology.

The skeletal manifestations of vitamin D deficiency, rickets, can also be associated with pathological fractures of the ribs and other locations. However, this child has no other signs of bony deformities or fractures, and pathological fracture at an isolated location is less common in vitamin D deficiency. In addition, vitamin D deficiency is not associated with this patient's other findings of retinal hemorrhage, bulging anterior fontanelle, and altered mental status.

images.title: Rickets secondary to vitamin D deficiency fact sheet

answers.explanation_why: Bacterial meningitis could lead to altered mental status, which might manifest in the irritability and lethargy seen in this child. Before the anterior fontanelle closes (at 18–24 months of age), increased intracranial pressure (e.g., due to meningitis) can cause it to bulge. Children who are septic from meningitis may also rarely present with retinal hemorrhages. However, bacterial meningitis typically presents more acutely, in a matter of hours or days. Additionally, this child is afebrile and has a normal white blood cell count, both of which are unexpected findings in children with meningitis, particularly in meningitis due to bacterial pathogens.

An epidural hematoma could also lead to irritability, lethargy, signs of increased intracranial pressure, including a bulging anterior fontanelle, and retinal hemorrhage in rare cases. However, retinal hemorrhages are less frequently associated with epidural hemorrhage than other etiologies. Additionally, an epidural hematoma would likely present more acutely and with other physical examination findings, such as a visible hematoma or swelling in the area of head trauma, which this patient does not have. While this diagnosis cannot be excluded completely, a different option is more likely.

Diffuse axonal injury (DAI) is commonly seen in children with shaken baby syndrome (SBS). In such cases, DAI is most likely caused by rotational acceleration-deceleration forces inflicted by violent shaking of the infant and by secondary hypoxia (e.g., due to transient apnea). Long-term deficits resulting from SBS include sight, hearing, and speech impairment. SBS has an extremely high mortality rate, with approx. 25% of affected children dying as a result of sustained injuries. Cranial CT scan in patients with SBS often shows additional brain injuries such as chronic subdural hematoma (which would explain this patient's subacute presentation over 2 weeks), subarachnoid bleeding, and/or diffuse punctate parenchymal hemorrhages.

Osteogenesis Imperfecta (OI) is caused by defective synthesis of type I collagen. Patients with this disorder are prone to pathologic fractures and may present with rib fractures. Skull fractures and associated intracranial bleeding are more common in children with OI and could cause altered mental status in the absence of a history of significant trauma. However, patients with OI often have blue sclera, hearing loss, and joint laxity, which are not present in this patient. Additionally, while OI is often hard to differentiate from child abuse, the low prevalence of OI makes child abuse more likely in the general population.

Many rodenticides contain long-acting anticoagulants, such as super warfarin. Ingestion of these rodenticides can lead to coagulopathy and pathological bleeding, usually beginning about 24 hours after ingestion. This coagulopathy could cause both retinal hemorrhages and intracranial bleeding leading to altered mental status, as seen in this patient. However, coagulopathy would likely also manifest in other locations, causing gastrointestinal bleeding, ecchymoses, epistaxis, and hematuria. This patient does not have any other signs of pathological bleeding, nor would this etiology explain this patient's associated rib fractures.

question_text: A 57-year-old woman comes to the emergency department because of a 4-hour history of severe pain around her right eye, blurred vision in the same eye, and a headache. She is nauseous but has not vomited. She can see colored bright circles when she looks at a light source. She is currently being treated for a urinary tract infection with trimethoprim-sulfamethoxazole. She appears uncomfortable. Vital signs are within normal limits. Examination shows visual acuity of 20/20 in the left eye and counting fingers at 5 feet in the right eye. The right eye shows conjunctival injection and edema of the cornea. The right pupil is dilated and fixed. Intravenous analgesia and antiemetics are administered. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?
content_preview: A 57-year-old woman comes to the emergency department because of a 4-hour history of severe pain around her right eye, blurred vision in the same eye, and a headache. She is nauseous but has not vomited. She can see colored bright circles when she looks at a light source. She is currently being treated for a urinary tract infection with trimethoprim-sulfamethoxazole. She appears uncomfortable. Vital signs are within normal limits. Examination shows visual acuity of 20/20 in the left eye and counting fingers at 5 feet in the right eye. The right eye shows conjunctival injection and edema of the cornea. The right pupil is dilated and fixed. Intravenous analgesia and antiemetics are administered. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?
hint: The presence of an acute painful red eye with blurred vision and halos (colored bright circles when looking at a light source), edematous cornea, conjunctival injection, a dilated, fixed pupil, and (usually frontal) headaches are suspicious for acute angle-closure glaucoma.
learning_objective: Recognize acute angle-closure glaucoma, and choose the most appropriate diagnostic procedure.

answers.explanation_why: Ultrasound biomicroscopy can be used to visualize the anterior chamber angle. However, this technique is time-consuming and costly, and requires operator proficiency, making it less preferable than another option for the diagnosis of angle-closure glaucoma.

Topical atropine is often administered for anterior uveitis to help prevent scarring and relieve pain. While anterior uveitis usually presents with eye pain, redness, and photophobia, it would not present with corneal edema or a fixed dilated pupil (unless the patient has had multiple previous bouts of uveitis causing iris scarring). These features suggest angle-closure glaucoma, in which mydriasis (i.e., relaxation of the iris) worsens the blockage of the trabecular meshwork and further reduces the drainage of aqueous humor from the eye. Therefore, the administration of atropine or other mydriatic drugs, as well as covering the eye (darkness induces mydriasis), can worsen the condition and must be avoided.

Gonioscopy allows for direct visualization of the anterior chamber angle of the eye and is the gold standard for diagnosis of angle-closure glaucoma. Once the diagnosis is confirmed, prompt treatment with agents to lower intraocular pressure (e.g., beta blockers, α2 agonists, and/or carbonic anhydrase inhibitors) is necessary to prevent permanent vision loss, with definitive surgical treatment (e.g., peripheral iridotomy) indicated after the acute attack is controlled.

Increased age, female sex, and the intake of certain drugs (e.g., trimethoprim-sulfamethoxazole) are all risk factors for acute angle-closure glaucoma.

Retinal photocoagulation is commonly used for diabetic retinopathy or central retinal vein occlusion, as ischemic areas of the retina are coagulated to prevent the secretion of vascular endothelial growth factor and subsequent neovascularization of healthy retinal tissue. Although central retinal vein occlusion could present with reduced visual acuity, it is usually painless and would not show signs of corneal edema, conjunctival injection, or fixation of the pupil.

Topical ciprofloxacin is an antibiotic that can be used to treat bacterial conjunctivitis. Although conjunctivitis can cause unilateral conjunctival injection and visual loss, this patient demonstrates no purulent discharge that would be typical of bacterial conjunctivitis. Additionally, fixation of the pupil, severe pain causing nausea, and corneal edema are not common features of conjunctivitis.

Fundoscopy may be useful for patients with diabetic retinopathy who may present with reduced visual acuity, but these patients would not present with corneal edema, pain, or conjunctival injection. This patient's angle-closure glaucoma is an ophthalmologic emergency and warrants prompt diagnosis and treatment. Additionally, visualization of the retina through an edematous cornea would be poor, and pupillary dilatation could worsen obstruction of the anterior chamber angle.

Topical steroids are used in the treatment of anterior uveitis. While anterior uveitis usually presents with eye pain, redness, headache, and photophobia, it would not present with corneal edema or a fixed dilated pupil (unless the patient has had multiple previous bouts of uveitis, causing iris scarring). These features are suggestive of angle-closure glaucoma, for which topical steroids would be ineffective.

question_text: A 9-year-old girl is brought to the emergency department by her mother because of a headache and double vision 1 hour after being hit on the head while playing with a friend. Her friend's elbow struck her head, just above her left ear. She did not lose consciousness, but her mother reports that she was confused for 20 minutes after the incident and did not recall being hit. She is alert and oriented to person, place, and time. Her temperature is 37.2°C (99°F), pulse is 86/min, respirations are 15/min, and blood pressure is 118/78 mm Hg. Examination shows the head tilted toward the right shoulder. A photograph of the eyes at primary gaze is shown. The finding in the patient's left eye worsens when she is asked to look to the right side or tilt her head toward her left shoulder. There is mild tenderness to palpation over the left temporal bone. Visual acuity is 20/20 in both eyes when tested independently. The pupils are equal and reactive to light. Muscle strength and sensation are intact bilaterally. Deep tendon reflexes are 2+ bilaterally. Plantar reflex shows a flexor response. Which of the following is the most likely cause of this patient's ocular symptoms?
content_preview: A 9-year-old girl is brought to the emergency department by her mother because of a headache and double vision 1 hour after being hit on the head while playing with a friend. Her friend's elbow struck her head, just above her left ear. She did not lose consciousness, but her mother reports that she was confused for 20 minutes after the incident and did not recall being hit. She is alert and oriented to person, place, and time. Her temperature is 37.2°C (99°F), pulse is 86/min, respirations are 15/min, and blood pressure is 118/78 mm Hg. Examination shows the head tilted toward the right shoulder. A photograph of the eyes at primary gaze is shown. The finding in the patient's left eye worsens when she is asked to look to the right side or tilt her head toward her left shoulder. There is mild tenderness to palpation over the left temporal bone. Visual acuity is 20/20 in both eyes when tested independently. The pupils are equal and reactive to light. Muscle strength and sensation are intact bilaterally. Deep tendon reflexes are 2+ bilaterally. Plantar reflex shows a flexor response. Which of the following is the most likely cause of this patient's ocular symptoms?
hint: This patient has unilateral hypertropia in the primary gaze (i.e., while looking straight ahead), which can be due to ipsilateral weakness of eye depressors or contralateral weakness of eye elevators. Worsening of this patient's hypertropia in the right lateral gaze (on left eye adduction) and when the patient tilts her head to the left shoulder (on left eye intorsion) suggests ophthalmoplegia of the left superior oblique muscle (SOM).
learning_objective: Recognize trochlear nerve damage.

answers.explanation_why: The trochlear nerve innervates only the superior oblique muscle (SOM), which is a depressor and intortor of the eyeball. Trochlear nerve damage, therefore, causes hypertropia and vertical diplopia, as seen here. Hypertropia due to left SOM palsy worsens during right lateral gaze because the SOM is the only muscle that can depress an adducted eye. Hypertropia due to SOM palsy also worsens when the head is tilted toward the ipsilateral shoulder because the superior rectus muscle (an elevator) takes over the role of the paralyzed SOM as the primary intortor, resulting in elevation of the eye. To decrease vertical diplopia, patients with SOM ophthalmoplegia tilt their head away from the affected side (compensatory head tilt), like this patient who tilts her head to the right. The trochlear nerve is the cranial nerve that is most commonly damaged in cases of trauma, because its long course and thin diameter make it vulnerable to shearing injury.

images.title: Trochlear nerve palsy
images.description: Trochlear nerve palsy (here of the left eye) causes paralysis of the ipsilateral superior oblique muscle. This leads to hypertropia (upwards deviation) and excyclotorsion (outward rotation) of the affected eye (middle image). Patients typically present with vertical or oblique diplopia. Hypertropia and diplopia may increase with ipsilateral head-tilt (right image) and decrease with contralateral head-tilt (left image; patients may adopt this posture as a compensatory posture).

answers.explanation_why: Retrobulbar hemorrhage from trauma is an ophthalmologic emergency that can result in strabismus and diplopia. However, patients would have proptosis, severe eye pain, periorbital ecchymosis, subconjunctival hemorrhage, and/or visual impairment due to occlusion of the central retinal artery and/or optic neuropathy.
Abducens nerve damage causes lateral rectus palsy, which leads to an impaired abduction of the ipsilateral eye and horizontal, not vertical strabismus.

images.title: Abducens nerve palsy
images.description: Abducens nerve palsy (here of the left eye) impairs the function of the lateral rectus muscle. This causes esotropia (medial deviation) of the affected eye and limits its abduction. Patients present with horizontal diplopia that worsens when turning the gaze to the affected side or looking at distant objects.

answers.explanation_why: Damage to the oculomotor nerve (CN III) leads to strabismus due to unopposed contraction of the lateral rectus and the superior oblique muscle. This typically results in eye abduction and depression with the pupil looking “down and out” in primary gaze, as opposed to this patient's hypertropia. Complete oculomotor palsy would additionally result in ptosis (due to denervation of the levator palpebrae superioris) and mydriasis (due to loss of parasympathetic innervation to the pupillary sphincter).

images.title: Oculomotor nerve palsy
images.description: Oculomotor nerve palsy (here, of the left eye) causes ipsilateral impairment of both motor and autonomic (parasympathetic) nerve functions. Paralysis of the inferior rectus, medial rectus, superior rectus, and inferior oblique muscles results in downward deviation (hypotropia) and outward deviation (exotropia) of the affected eye (down-and-out gaze) due to the unopposed actions of the lateral rectus and superior oblique muscles. Weakness of the levator palpebrae superioris muscle results in ptosis and impairment of parasympathetic function in mydriasis (as well as loss of accommodation and pupillary light reflex, which are not shown). Patients present with horizontal or horizontal and vertical double vision (diplopia) that worsens when turning the gaze away from the affected side. The ptosis, however, may prevent patients from experiencing diplopia.

answers.explanation_why: Damage to the medial longitudinal fasciculus (MLF) leads to internuclear ophthalmoplegia (INO), which may manifest with diplopia and strabismus. However, these symptoms only manifest with gaze to the side contralateral to the lesion as a result of ipsilateral adduction weakness that occurs only during horizontal conjugate eye movements. Patients also have horizontal nystagmus in the contralateral eye with abduction, and a characteristic absence of ipsilateral adductor weakness during disconjugate movements (e.g., convergence). Moreover, trauma is an extremely rare cause of INO which more often occurs in multiple sclerosis or following a brainstem stroke.

Damage to the dorsal midbrain can cause Parinaud syndrome, which manifests with impaired upgaze in both eyes and dilated nonreactive pupils. This patient has hypertropia in one eye and reactive pupils in both eyes. Moreover, Parinaud syndrome is most commonly seen in patients with hydrocephalus or posterior midbrain compression (e.g., pineal tumors); trauma is an extremely rare cause of Parinaud syndrome.

images.title: Hypertropia
images.description: While the right eye fixates straight, the left eye deviates upwards (hypertropia). This may be due to congenital superior oblique palsy or trochlear nerve palsy.

question_text: A 5-year-old boy is brought to the physician because of early morning headaches for the past 6 months. During this period, he has had severe nausea and occasional episodes of vomiting. For the past month, he has had difficulty walking and intermittent double vision. He was born at term and has been healthy apart from an episode of sinusitis 8 months ago that resolved spontaneously. He is at the 60^th percentile for height and 50^th percentile for weight. His temperature is 37.1°C (98.8°F), pulse is 80/min, and blood pressure is 105/64 mm Hg. Examination shows normal muscle strength and 2+ deep tendon reflexes bilaterally. He has a broad-based gait and impaired tandem gait. Fundoscopy shows bilateral swelling of the optic disc. There is esotropia of the left eye. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
content_preview: A 5-year-old boy is brought to the physician because of early morning headaches for the past 6 months. During this period, he has had severe nausea and occasional episodes of vomiting. For the past month, he has had difficulty walking and intermittent double vision. He was born at term and has been healthy apart from an episode of sinusitis 8 months ago that resolved spontaneously. He is at the 60th percentile for height and 50th percentile for weight. His temperature is 37.1°C (98.8°F), pulse is 80/min, and blood pressure is 105/64 mm Hg. Examination shows normal muscle strength and 2+ deep tendon reflexes bilaterally. He has a broad-based gait and impaired tandem gait. Fundoscopy shows bilateral swelling of the optic disc. There is esotropia of the left eye. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
hint: This tumor is derived from primitive neuroectodermal tissue.
learning_objective: Recognize medulloblastoma in a child.

answers.explanation_why: Optic gliomas may cause esotropia, visual impairment, and can potentially lead to increased intracranial pressure. However, these tumors are uncommon and would not cause ataxia.

images.title: Intraconal orbital mass
images.description: MRI head (T2-weighted; axial plane)There is a large hyperintense mass (green overlay) in the left intraconal space displacing the ocular globe out of the orbital cavity (exophthalmos). The intraconal space is located posterior to the globe and contained within the cone formed by the recti muscles. The mass is well-defined and displaces rather than invades surrounding structures. The left optic nerve is not visualized on this image, and the mass either arises from it or displaces it. The normal-appearing right optic nerve (red overlay) is well visualized.The differential diagnosis for intraconal masses depends on whether or not the lesion is continuous with the optic nerve. Differential diagnoses for masses involving the optic nerve include, but are not limited to, meningioma, glioma, and lymphoma. Differential diagnoses for masses not involving the nerve include, but are not limited to, hemangioma, schwannoma, and rhabdomyosarcoma.

answers.explanation_why: Schwannomas are most commonly located in the cerebellopontine angle (acoustic/vestibular schwannomas) and typically manifest with tinnitus, hearing loss, dizziness, and/or disequilibrium from cranial nerve VIII (CN VIII) compression. Although ataxia and hydrocephalus may result from compression of posterior fossa structures in late stages of the disease, this patient has no auditory symptoms (the onset of which would be insidious) and is uncharacteristically young (the median age is 50 years).

images.title: Acoustic neuroma (vestibular schwannoma)
images.description: Acoustic neuromas are benign tumors that arise from Schwann cells and primarily originate within the vestibular portion of cranial nerve VIII. The tumor originates within the internal acoustic canal with variable extension into the cerebellopontine angle. Early symptoms occur due to pressure on the cochlear nerve (unilateral sensorineural hearing loss, tinnitus) and vestibular nerve (dizziness, unsteady gait, disequilibrium). If the tumor further expands into the cerebellopontine angle, further symptoms arise due to compression of CN V (paresthesia, hypoesthesia, unilateral facial pain), CN VII (unilateral facial weakness), and the cerebellum (ataxia).

answers.explanation_why: Pituitary adenomas may cause bitemporal hemianopsia from compression of the optic chiasm, hypopituitarism, or other syndromes from excess secretion of pituitary hormones. These tumors do not typically cause ataxia and are much more common in adults.

images.title: Pituitary mass 2/2
images.description: MRI head (T1-weighted; without contrast; sagittal plane) of a male patient with headache, retroorbital pressure, fatigue, and elevated serum prolactinA large mass, which is isointense to gray matter, is seen in the area of the sella turcica (indicated by arrows).Considering the patient's history, a prolactin-secreting macroadenoma (prolactinoma) of the pituitary gland is the most likely diagnosis.

answers.explanation_why: Craniopharyngiomas may present with headaches and vomiting (due to obstructive hydrocephalus and traction on surrounding structures), as well as visual symptoms (typically bitemporal hemianopsia from compression of the optic chiasm). However, the lack of additional symptoms, such as hyperprolactinemia/delayed growth or central diabetes insipidus from compression of the anterior or posterior pituitary gland, makes this diagnosis less likely. In addition, ataxia would be an uncommon finding in craniopharyngioma.

images.title: Craniopharyngioma
images.description: MRI head (T1 weighted; with contrast; sagittal plane) of a patient with acute visual loss in the right eyeThere is an intrasellar and suprasellar mass (green overlay) with both cystic and solid portions. The solid portions show strong contrast enhancement.

answers.explanation_why: Although hemangioblastoma may manifest with ataxia and increased intracranial pressure, these tumors are rare and most commonly occur in adults.

images.title: Cerebellar hemangioblastoma
images.description: MRI head (with contrast; axial view)A brightly enhancing, sharply delimited nodular mass (white arrow) with nonenhancing, cystic areas is visible within the right cerebellar hemisphere.These findings are consistent with cerebellar hemangioblastoma.

answers.explanation_why: While meningiomas are the most common primary central nervous system tumors in adults (with a peak incidence in the sixth decade of life), they are rarely found in children. Due to their slow growth, meningiomas are usually asymptomatic, but they may manifest with seizures or focal neurologic deficits resulting from compression or increased intracranial pressure due to obstructive hydrocephalus. They are not usually associated with ataxia.

images.title: Dural based mass
images.description: MRI head (T1-weighted; with contrast; sagittal plane)There is a well-circumscribed homogeneous mass (green overlay) along the cerebral convexity. It demonstrates intense, homogeneous enhancement, equivalent to that of adjacent dura mater. Displacement without invasion of the surrounding white matter supports an extra-axial location.This is a case of meningioma, a dural-based tumor. The dura is represented in this image by the thin, discontinuously enhancing line covering the inner surface of the skull (indicated by arrowhead).

answers.explanation_why:
Medulloblastoma is the most common malignant brain tumor in children, with a peak incidence between 3–5 years of age. The mass is characteristically located in the cerebellum. Patients typically present with symptoms of hydrocephalus/increased ICP and involvement of the cerebellar vermis such as vomiting, morning headaches, ataxia, and cranial nerve dysfunction. Spinal drop metastases are found in about 40% of cases.

Ependymomas are often located in the posterior fossa and may also manifest with signs of hydrocephalus, as well as ataxia and cranial nerve dysfunction. However, these tumors are less common than medulloblastomas, accounting for ∼ 10% of pediatric brain tumors.

images.title: Medulloblastoma
images.description:
Cranial MRI (T1-weighted, with contrast)There is a mass in the posterior cranial fossa. It features solid parts (green overlay) and cystic parts (red overlay).Location and appearance are typical of a medulloblastoma.

(D: diencephalon; P: pons; C: cerebellum; yellow outline: cerebellar tentorium)

question_text: A 33-year-old woman comes to the physician because of vision impairment in her right eye for the past 2 weeks. During this period, she was unable to distinguish colors with her right eye. She also reports pain with eye movement. She has no double vision. She occasionally has headaches that are relieved with ibuprofen. One year ago, she had a similar episode that affected her left eye and resolved spontaneously. She has no history of serious illness. She works at a library and enjoys reading, even in poor lighting conditions. Her vital signs are within normal limits. Examination shows that the right and left pupils do not constrict when a light is shone into the right eye. When light is shone into the left eye, both pupils constrict. Without correction, visual acuity is 20/50 in the left eye, and 20/100 in the right eye. With spectacles, the visual acuity is 20/20 in the left eye and 20/100 in the right eye. Slit-lamp examination shows no abnormalities. Muscle strength is normal. Deep tendon reflexes are 2+ bilaterally. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
content_preview: A 33-year-old woman comes to the physician because of vision impairment in her right eye for the past 2 weeks. During this period, she was unable to distinguish colors with her right eye. She also reports pain with eye movement. She has no double vision. She occasionally has headaches that are relieved with ibuprofen. One year ago, she had a similar episode that affected her left eye and resolved spontaneously. She has no history of serious illness. She works at a library and enjoys reading, even in poor lighting conditions. Her vital signs are within normal limits. Examination shows that the right and left pupils do not constrict when a light is shone into the right eye. When light is shone into the left eye, both pupils constrict. Without correction, visual acuity is 20/50 in the left eye, and 20/100 in the right eye. With spectacles, the visual acuity is 20/20 in the left eye and 20/100 in the right eye. Slit-lamp examination shows no abnormalities. Muscle strength is normal. Deep tendon reflexes are 2+ bilaterally. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
hint: This 33-year-old female patient presents with acute, unilateral color blindness, a decrease in visual acuity, and pain with eye movements, all of which are consistent with a specific diagnosis.
learning_objective: Recognize optic neuritis.

answers.explanation_why: Open-angle glaucoma would typically present in patients > 40 years old with painless, slowly progressive scotomas and/or a decrease in visual acuity. A different diagnosis should be considered in this 33-year-old woman with two episodes of painful loss of vision that had complete remission a year in between.

Retinal detachment typically results in sudden, painless, visual field defects or complete loss of vision in the affected eye and is usually preceded by prodromal symptoms such as floaters and/or photopsia. The presence of only defective color vision and moderately decreased visual acuity, as well as the presence of pain, make the diagnosis of retinal detachment extremely unlikely.

Retinitis pigmentosa leads to a progressive loss of vision in both eyes and the initial clinical manifestations are night-blindness and decreased peripheral vision. This patient has developed acute visual impairment in one eye and has no difficulty reading in a poorly lit environment.

Angle-closure glaucoma manifests acutely with eye pain and a decrease in visual acuity. However, other clinical features such as photophobia, nausea, vomiting, corneal cloudiness, congestion of the ciliary and conjunctival vessels, and a fixed, semi-dilated pupil are not seen in this patient. Moreover, slit lamp examination in angle-closure glaucoma shows a shallow anterior chamber.

Common causes of macular degeneration include age-related macular degeneration (AMD) and myopic macular degeneration. AMD usually occurs in people > 60 years old and presents with a slowly progressive, painless, bilateral decrease in visual acuity. Myopic macular degeneration may occur in younger patients and would also present with an insidious, painless loss of vision but is seen in patients with pathological myopia. Patients with pathological myopia would have a deep anterior chamber on slit lamp examination, and an uncorrected visual acuity that is far worse than 20/200 in both eyes.

This patient's presentation is consistent with optic neuritis, which is often the first manifestation of multiple sclerosis (MS). MS is more common in women than men and it typically manifests at 20–40 years of age, with a relapsing-remitting clinical pattern. Most patients with optic neuritis have a relative afferent pupillary defect and a normal fundus on ophthalmoscopy.

All patients who present with new-onset optic neuritis should undergo a brain MRI to assess for demyelinating plaques, which support a diagnosis of MS.

question_text: A 22-year-old woman comes to the emergency department because of frontal throbbing headaches for 3 weeks. Yesterday, the patient had blurry vision in both eyes and a brief episode of double vision. She has been taking ibuprofen with only mild improvement of her symptoms. She has not had any trauma, weakness, or changes in sensation. Medical history is remarkable for polycystic ovarian syndrome, type 2 diabetes mellitus, and facial acne. Her current medications include metformin and vitamin A. She is 158 cm (5 ft 2 in) tall and weighs 89 kg (196 lb); BMI is 36 kg/m^2. Vital signs are within normal limits. Examination shows decreased peripheral vision. Fundoscopic examination of both eyes is shown. An MRI of the brain with contrast shows an empty sella but no other abnormalities. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?
content_preview: A 22-year-old woman comes to the emergency department because of frontal throbbing headaches for 3 weeks. Yesterday, the patient had blurry vision in both eyes and a brief episode of double vision. She has been taking ibuprofen with only mild improvement of her symptoms. She has not had any trauma, weakness, or changes in sensation. Medical history is remarkable for polycystic ovarian syndrome, type 2 diabetes mellitus, and facial acne. Her current medications include metformin and vitamin A. She is 158 cm (5 ft 2 in) tall and weighs 89 kg (196 lb); BMI is 36 kg/m2. Vital signs are within normal limits. Examination shows decreased peripheral vision. Fundoscopic examination of both eyes is shown. An MRI of the brain with contrast shows an empty sella but no other abnormalities. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?
hint: Recurrent headaches and visual changes in a young woman with obesity and a history of vitamin A use raise concern for idiopathic intracranial hypertension (IIH). Papilledema (a sign of intracranial hypertension) and an empty sella on MRI support the diagnosis.
learning_objective: Recognize idiopathic intracranial hypertension, and choose the most appropriate diagnostic test.

answers.explanation_why: Craniotomy is required for acute, severe intracranial hypertension secondary to intracranial hemorrhage (e.g., epidural hematoma). While this patient does have intracranial hypertension, epidural hematoma is usually traumatic and manifests with altered mental status and focal neurologic deficits. Additionally, the condition usually progresses more rapidly (i.e., within hours).
Acetazolamide is a first-line pharmacotherapy for patients with confirmed IIH. While this patient very likely has IIH, her diagnosis must be confirmed before pharmacotherapy would be indicated.

Cerebrospinal fluid shunting (e.g., ventriculoperitoneal shunt) is a treatment option for IIH that has not responded to maximal medical therapy. However, this patient must have her diagnosis confirmed before initiating any form of treatment.

Once neuroimaging has been performed to exclude other sources of intracranial hypertension, lumbar puncture (with opening pressure) is indicated for the diagnosis of IIH (according to the modified Dandy criteria). Because in IIH the intracranial pressure is uniformly elevated in the ventricular system and the subarachnoid space, there is no risk of cerebral herniation and, therefore, a lumbar puncture may safely be performed. An opening pressure > 20–25 cm H_2O confirms intracranial hypertension, and normal CSF studies rule out other common causes of intracranial hypertension (e.g., meningitis, intracranial hemorrhage). Once the diagnosis is confirmed, discontinuation of potential causes (e.g., vitamin A supplements), a low-sodium weight loss program, and carbonic anhydrase inhibitors (e.g., acetazolamide) would be recommended.

images.title: Optic disc edema
images.description: Fundus photography of the left eyeLeft image: Blurred disc margins (green overlay) with venous dilatation and tortuosity (blue overlay) and small hemorrhages (examples indicated by arrowheads) are visible.Blurred disc margins suggest optic disc edema. In intracranial hypertension, as seen in this image, optic disc edema is called papilledema.Right image: Resolution of optic disc edema after treatment. Sharp disc margins and normal retinal vessels are visible. There are no hemorrhages.

answers.explanation_why: Sumatriptan is a treatment for migraine headaches, which are a common cause of headache and may cause visual symptoms. The visual symptoms associated with migraine typically precede headache (i.e., aura). Additionally, migraine would not explain this patient's papilledema or empty sella.

Thrombolytics (e.g., alteplase) are indicated for certain patients with ischemic stroke, which can present with visual loss as well intracranial hypertension and a consequent headache due to cerebral edema. However, symptoms usually have a more acute onset in ischemic stroke and are typically associated with unilateral neurologic deficits (e.g., weakness, numbness, or cranial nerve palsies). Additionally, MRI in a stroke patient would show signs of cerebral ischemia (e.g., a zone of infarction/hypoattenuation) rather than this patient's empty sella.

images.title: Bilateral papilledema
images.description: Fundus photography of right (R) and left (L) optic disc of the same patientThe optic discs show severely blurred margins (dashed circle indicates supposed margin). The retinal veins are dilated and tortuous (examples marked by white lines). There are multiple peripapillary hemorrhages, which appear as flame-shaped hemorrhages (examples marked by blue overlay). Cotton wool spots are also present and appear as bright spots (examples marked by arrowheads).These features are characteristic of papilledema. If present bilaterally, possible causes include cranial hypertension or hypertensive emergency.

question_text: A 31-year-old woman comes to the physician because of headaches and nausea for 2 weeks. The headaches are worse on awakening and she describes them as 7 out of 10 in intensity. During this period, she has noticed brief episodes of visual loss in both eyes lasting several seconds, especially when she suddenly stands up or bends over. She is 165 cm (5 ft 5 in) tall and weighs 98 kg (216 lb); BMI is 36 kg/m^2. Vital signs are within normal limits. Examination shows a visual acuity of 20/20 in both eyes with mild peripheral vision loss. Fundoscopic examination shows bilateral optic disc swelling. An MRI of the brain shows no abnormalities. A lumbar puncture is performed; opening pressure is 310 mm H_2O. Cerebrospinal fluid analysis shows a leukocyte count of 4/mm^3 (75% lymphocytes), a protein concentration of 35 mg/dL, and a glucose concentration of 45 mg/dL. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?
content_preview: A 31-year-old woman comes to the physician because of headaches and nausea for 2 weeks. The headaches are worse on awakening and she describes them as 7 out of 10 in intensity. During this period, she has noticed brief episodes of visual loss in both eyes lasting several seconds, especially when she suddenly stands up or bends over. She is 165 cm (5 ft 5 in) tall and weighs 98 kg (216 lb); BMI is 36 kg/m2. Vital signs are within normal limits. Examination shows a visual acuity of 20/20 in both eyes with mild peripheral vision loss. Fundoscopic examination shows bilateral optic disc swelling. An MRI of the brain shows no abnormalities. A lumbar puncture is performed; opening pressure is 310 mm H2O. Cerebrospinal fluid analysis shows a leukocyte count of 4/mm3 (75% lymphocytes), a protein concentration of 35 mg/dL, and a glucose concentration of 45 mg/dL. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?
hint: The presence of headaches, nausea, and transient vision loss in an obese woman with unremarkable MRI findings and a raised opening pressure on lumbar puncture indicates idiopathic intracranial hypertension (IIH).
learning_objective: Recognize idiopathic intracranial hypertension, and choose the initial pharmacotherapy.

answers.explanation_why: Carbonic anhydrase inhibitors (CAIs) such as acetazolamide are the first-line pharmacotherapy for patients with IIH. Patients with newly-diagnosed IIH should discontinue any offending agents (e.g., vitamin A analogs, tetracyclines), adopt a low-sodium weight loss diet (if overweight), and begin acetazolamide. Although the mechanism is not clear, CAIs are believed to reduce the rate of CSF production, thereby decreasing intracranial hypertension.

images.title: Optic disc edema
images.description: Fundus photography of the left eyeLeft image: Blurred disc margins (green overlay) with venous dilatation and tortuosity (blue overlay) and small hemorrhages (examples indicated by arrowheads) are visible.Blurred disc margins suggest optic disc edema. In intracranial hypertension, as seen in this image, optic disc edema is called papilledema.Right image: Resolution of optic disc edema after treatment. Sharp disc margins and normal retinal vessels are visible. There are no hemorrhages.

answers.explanation_why: Corticosteroids (e.g., prednisone) are indicated as a supplement to first-line therapy in patients with IIH or in patients who present with moderate or progressive visual field loss. This patient has only mild visual field loss, so she should be started on first-line therapy before considering corticosteroids.

Optic nerve sheath fenestration is a first-line surgical treatment option for patients with IIH who have not responded to maximal medical management or in patients presenting with rapid, severe vision loss. This patient has only mild visual symptoms, so conservative management should be attempted before surgery can be considered.

Serial lumbar puncture is typically used in IIH patients to decrease intracranial pressure before surgery or in pregnant patients who decline pharmacotherapy. Lumbar puncture only temporarily treats IIH because CSF regenerates in ∼ 6 hours. Consequently, it is rarely indicated other than as a temporary measure in patients with IIH who are awaiting a more definitive therapy.

CSF diversion procedures (e.g., ventriculoperitoneal shunting) are surgical treatment options for patients in whom all medical treatment options have been exhausted or in patients presenting with rapid, severe vision loss. This patient has only mild visual symptoms, so conservative management should be attempted before surgery can be considered.

In patients with IIH in whom first-line therapy is ineffective, poorly tolerated, or contraindicated, furosemide can be added as an adjunct therapeutic agent. This patient has no contraindications against the recommended first-line therapy, thus it should be initiated before considering furosemide.
