question_text: A 59-year-old woman comes to the emergency department 25 minutes after the onset of severe left periorbital pain and blurred vision in the same eye. The pain began soon after she entered a theater to watch a movie. She has a headache and vomited twice on the way to the hospital. Two weeks ago, she had acute sinusitis that resolved spontaneously. She has atrial fibrillation and hypertension. Current medications include warfarin and metoprolol. Her temperature is 37.1°C (98.8°F), pulse is 101/min, and blood pressure is 140/80 mm Hg. Visual acuity is counting fingers at 3 feet in the left eye and 20/20 in the right eye. The left eye shows conjunctival injection and edematous cornea. The left pupil is mid-dilated and irregular; it is not reactive to light. Extraocular movements are normal. Fundoscopic examination is inconclusive because of severe corneal edema. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
content_preview: A 59-year-old woman comes to the emergency department 25 minutes after the onset of severe left periorbital pain and blurred vision in the same eye. The pain began soon after she entered a theater to watch a movie. She has a headache and vomited twice on the way to the hospital. Two weeks ago, she had acute sinusitis that resolved spontaneously. She has atrial fibrillation and hypertension. Current medications include warfarin and metoprolol. Her temperature is 37.1°C (98.8°F), pulse is 101/min, and blood pressure is 140/80 mm Hg. Visual acuity is counting fingers at 3 feet in the left eye and 20/20 in the right eye. The left eye shows conjunctival injection and edematous cornea. The left pupil is mid-dilated and irregular; it is not reactive to light. Extraocular movements are normal. Fundoscopic examination is inconclusive because of severe corneal edema. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
hint: The left eye would be rock-hard on palpation!
learning_objective: Recognize acute angle-closure glaucoma.

answers.explanation_why: Although central retinal artery occlusion (CRAO) also causes acute loss of vision in one eye, this vision loss is typically painless, not painful. Additionally, CRAO would not explain this patient's conjunctival injection, corneal edema, or pupil abnormalities, making this diagnosis an unlikely cause of her symptoms.

images.title: Central retinal artery occlusion
images.description: Left: lateral view of the right eye in longitudinal (sagittal) section. Depiction of an embolism in the central retinal artery causing retinal ischemia.Right: fundus photography of the right eye. Diffuse retinal ischemia causes edema in the inner retinal layers, manifesting as a gray-white discoloration of the retina (most markedly around the fovea; dotted circle). The fovea centralis, where the inner retinal layers are moved to the side, is not affected by edema. The underlying, well-vascularized choroid shines through, appearing as a cherry-red spot.

answers.explanation_why: Open-angle glaucoma is slowly progressive and initially often asymptomatic. Later, nonspecific symptoms such as mild headaches and impaired adaptation to darkness can occur. Typically it affects both eyes, not one, and leads to bilateral peripheral vision loss over time.

images.title: Glaucomatous excavation of the optic disc
images.description: Fundus photography of a right eyeAn enlarged cup (yellow overlay) of the optic disc with thinning of the neuroretinal rim (green overlay) can be seen, especially evident in the temporal superior area of the optic disc (focal notching, indicated by arrow). Cupping leads to kinking of the blood vessels at the base of the cup (examples indicated by arrowheads).This is a pathognomonic finding in glaucoma, predominantly caused by elevated intraocular pressure.

answers.explanation_why: Although retrobulbar neuritis also causes acute blurring of vision and eye pain, especially with movement of the affected eye, it would not lead to conjunctival injection, corneal edema, or pupillary abnormalities.

images.title: Papillitis in optic neuritis
images.description:
Fundus photography of the left eye of a patient with acute vision loss and painful eye movementsDiscrete optic disc edema is visible: Discrete blurring of the nasal superior, superior, and temporal superior disc margin can be seen (green overlay). Otherwise, the fundus is normal.

This finding, in addition to the patient's symptoms, suggests papillitis in optic neuritis.M: macula; circle: optic disc

answers.explanation_why: Acute iridocyclitis can cause eye pain, redness, and blurry vision, all of which are seen in this patient. However, the onset is usually less acute and most patients have an additional history of a systemic illness (e.g., IBD, SLE, sarcoidosis) or recent infection (particularly sexually transmitted diseases), which this patient lacks. Also, acute iridocyclitis typically causes photophobia and miosis with associated dilation of ciliary vessels, not a mid-dilated nonreactive pupil.

Although orbital cellulitis can also cause periorbital pain, blurry vision, and conjunctival injection following rhinosinusitis, the characteristic finding is painful ophthalmoplegia. Orbital cellulitis also causes inflammation; however, it typically affects the extraocular muscles and the surrounding fat within the orbit, not the cornea. Additionally, most cases of orbital cellulitis occur in young children, not older adults.

images.title: Orbital cellulitis
images.description: The left upper and lower eyelids are red and severely swollen, resulting in the patient not being able to open the eye. Orbital cellulitis is an emergency requiring immediate treatment.

answers.explanation_why: Acute angle-closure glaucoma is an ophthalmologic emergency that is precipitated by sudden obstruction of the trabecular meshwork outflow tract. Mydriasis narrows the space between the iris and the lens and can cause this obstruction. When this patient entered the dark theater her pupils dilated, which likely caused the acute obstruction. This patient shows the most common signs and symptoms of angle-closure glaucoma including ocular pain, blurry vision, headache, vomiting, and a nonreactive pupil in the affected eye. First-line treatment for acute angle-closure glaucoma is pressure-lowering eye drops (e.g., timolol or pilocarpine), often in combination with systemic treatment (e.g., acetazolamide), followed by laser peripheral iridotomy.

images.title: Angle-closure glaucoma
images.description: Slit-lamp photograph of anterior eye segmentProminent blood vessels are visible on the sclera and conjunctiva (mixed injection). The pupil is medium wide and its shape is slightly irregular. Iris details appear blurred due to corneal endothelial decompensation, leading to corneal edema.

question_text: A 64-year-old woman comes to the physician because of a 6-month history of blurred vision when reading. She has tried using multiple over-the-counter glasses with different strengths, but they have not helped. She has hypertension and type 2 diabetes mellitus. Current medications include insulin and enalapril. Her temperature is 37.1°C (98.8°F), pulse is 80/min, and blood pressure is 126/84 mm Hg. The pupils are round and react sluggishly to light. Visual acuity in the left eye is 6/60 and in the right eye counting fingers at 6 feet. Fundoscopy shows pallor of the optic disc bilaterally. The cup-to-disc ratio is 0.7 in the left eye and 0.9 in the right eye (N = 0.3). Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
content_preview: A 64-year-old woman comes to the physician because of a 6-month history of blurred vision when reading. She has tried using multiple over-the-counter glasses with different strengths, but they have not helped. She has hypertension and type 2 diabetes mellitus. Current medications include insulin and enalapril. Her temperature is 37.1°C (98.8°F), pulse is 80/min, and blood pressure is 126/84 mm Hg. The pupils are round and react sluggishly to light. Visual acuity in the left eye is 6/60 and in the right eye counting fingers at 6 feet. Fundoscopy shows pallor of the optic disc bilaterally. The cup-to-disc ratio is 0.7 in the left eye and 0.9 in the right eye (N = 0.3). Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
hint: Topical latanoprost is one of the drugs used to treat this condition.
learning_objective: Recognize open-angle glaucoma.

answers.explanation_why: Hypertensive retinopathy would typically present with generalized or focal narrowing of retinal arteries and retinal hemorrhage. Optic disc pallor may be present in grade IV hypertensive retinopathy as a result of papilledema, but optic disc cupping is not typically seen.

images.title: Grade IV hypertensive retinopathy
images.description: Fundus photography of the right eyeThere are cotton wool spots (blue overlay), narrow arterioles, and a retinal hemorrhage in close proximity to the papilla (hatched overlay). The papilla shows an unsharply demarcated margin nasally (blurry margin of the disc marked by dashed blue line, sharply demarcated margin marked by blue line), which is consistent with the diagnosis of papilledema.These findings are consistent with grade IV hypertensive retinopathy.M: Macula

answers.explanation_why: Age-related macular degeneration, which is the leading cause of blindness in the US, may present initially with a decrease in visual acuity and difficulty reading. However, fundoscopy would typically reveal small, discrete, yellow-white spots (drusen) in the macula. The optic disc would be normal.

Diabetic retinopathy may present with a decrease in visual acuity. However, fundoscopy would reveal microaneurysm, dot and blot retinal hemorrhage, cotton wool spots, hard exudates, and/or macular edema. Optic disc pallor and cupping are not typically seen in diabetic retinopathy. Instead, neovascularization of the optic disc may occur in proliferative diabetic retinopathy.

images.title: Nonproliferative diabetic retinopathy
images.description:
Fundus photography of a right eyeHard exudates appear as sharply demarcated, yellow lesions (examples marked by blue overlay). When arranged in a circle, exudates are called circinate rings (hatched overlay). Microaneurysms and retinal bleedings appear as small red dots and larger red blotches (examples marked by arrowheads). Neovascularizations are absent.These findings are consistent with nonproliferative diabetic retinopathy.Blue circle: Optic disc
M: Macula

answers.explanation_why: Open-angle glaucoma is characterized by slowly progressive optic nerve atrophy due to chronically increased intraocular pressure. This condition is usually asymptomatic for as long as central vision is preserved. Over time, optic nerve atrophy results in large, cupped optic discs (a cup-to-disc ratio > 0.6), optic disc pallor, and decreased visual acuity. Having to frequently change reading glasses is commonly reported in patients with open-angle glaucoma because increased pressure on the ciliary muscle results in impaired accommodation and sluggish pupillary reflexes.

images.title: Glaucomatous excavation of the optic disc
images.description: Fundus photography of a right eyeAn enlarged cup (yellow overlay) of the optic disc with thinning of the neuroretinal rim (green overlay) can be seen, especially evident in the temporal superior area of the optic disc (focal notching, indicated by arrow). Cupping leads to kinking of the blood vessels at the base of the cup (examples indicated by arrowheads).This is a pathognomonic finding in glaucoma, predominantly caused by elevated intraocular pressure.

answers.explanation_why: Patients with papillitis (a clinical subtype of optic neuritis) may develop decreased visual acuity and optic disc changes. However, the optic disc would appear hyperemic with blurred retinal margins and decreased optic disc cupping (as a result of optic disc swelling). The majority of patients with optic neuritis have retrobulbar neuritis with a normal fundoscopic examination.

images.title: Papillitis in optic neuritis
images.description:
Fundus photography of the left eye of a patient with acute vision loss and painful eye movementsDiscrete optic disc edema is visible: Discrete blurring of the nasal superior, superior, and temporal superior disc margin can be seen (green overlay). Otherwise, the fundus is normal.

This finding, in addition to the patient's symptoms, suggests papillitis in optic neuritis.M: macula; circle: optic disc

question_text: A 64-year-old woman comes to the physician because of a 5-month history of progressively worsening blurry vision. She has also had intermittent headaches for the past 2 months. She has type 2 diabetes mellitus, osteoarthritis, second-degree heart block, and presbyopia. Her current medications include metformin, lisinopril, and ibuprofen. Examination shows bilateral equal and reactive pupils. The best-corrected visual acuity in each eye is 20/40. There is narrowing of her visual fields bilaterally. Funduscopic examination shows bilateral narrowing of the outer rim of the optic nerve head and cupping of the optic disc. Intraocular pressure by applanation tonometry is 27 mm Hg in the right eye and 26 mm Hg in the left eye (N = 10–21). Gonioscopy shows no abnormalities. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?
content_preview: A 64-year-old woman comes to the physician because of a 5-month history of progressively worsening blurry vision. She has also had intermittent headaches for the past 2 months. She has type 2 diabetes mellitus, osteoarthritis, second-degree heart block, and presbyopia. Her current medications include metformin, lisinopril, and ibuprofen. Examination shows bilateral equal and reactive pupils. The best-corrected visual acuity in each eye is 20/40. There is narrowing of her visual fields bilaterally. Funduscopic examination shows bilateral narrowing of the outer rim of the optic nerve head and cupping of the optic disc. Intraocular pressure by applanation tonometry is 27 mm Hg in the right eye and 26 mm Hg in the left eye (N = 10–21). Gonioscopy shows no abnormalities. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?
hint: Blurry vision and headaches in an individual with cupping of the optic nerve on funduscopy and raised intraocular pressure suggests glaucoma. A normal gonioscopic examination excludes angle closure; therefore, this patient has primary open-angle glaucoma (POAG).
learning_objective: Recognize primary open-angle glaucoma, and choose the most appropriate initial therapy.

answers.explanation_why: Surgical trabeculectomy is indicated for patients with POAG who are refractory to medical treatment or laser therapy. Although effective at lowering intraocular pressure, surgical trabeculectomy is associated with complications, such as the early development of cataracts. This patient should attempt conservative therapy before considering surgery.

Topical pilocarpine is an alternative medical therapy for open-angle glaucoma. It is no longer a first-line treatment due to significant side effects, such as worsening of vision from increased myopia and miosis and shallowing of the anterior chamber. First-line treatment options should be attempted first before considering pilocarpine.

Topical prostaglandins such as latanoprost are the first-line treatment for POAG. They lower intraocular pressure by improving the drainage of aqueous humor. Side effects include increased pigmentation of the iris, elongated eyelashes, and burning/stinging during instillation. If topical prostaglandins are too expensive for patients, topical beta blockers (e.g., timolol) may offer a cheaper initial option, though they would be contraindicated in this patient with second-degree heart block.

images.title: Glaucomatous excavation of the optic disc
images.description: Fundus photography of a right eyeAn enlarged cup (yellow overlay) of the optic disc with thinning of the neuroretinal rim (green overlay) can be seen, especially evident in the temporal superior area of the optic disc (focal notching, indicated by arrow). Cupping leads to kinking of the blood vessels at the base of the cup (examples indicated by arrowheads).This is a pathognomonic finding in glaucoma, predominantly caused by elevated intraocular pressure.

answers.explanation_why: Although topical beta blockers like timolol can treat POAG by reducing the production of aqueous humor, they are no longer considered as first-line treatment and are contraindicated in this patient with a second-degree heart block. Additional contraindications to timolol include severe chronic obstructive pulmonary disease, asthma, acute heart failure, and sinus bradycardia.
Laser iridotomy is used in the management of acute angle-closure glaucoma. It has no use in POAG as the elevation of intraocular pressure in POAG is not due to drainage angle obstruction.

question_text: A 50-year-old man comes to the emergency department because of a severely painful right eye. The pain started an hour ago and is accompanied by frontal headache and nausea. The patient has vomited twice since the onset of the pain. He has type 2 diabetes mellitus. He immigrated to the US from China 10 years ago. He works as an engineer at a local company and has been under a great deal of stress lately. His only medication is metformin. Vital signs are within normal limits. The right eye is red and is hard on palpation. The right pupil is mid-dilated and nonreactive to light. The left pupil is round and reactive to light and accommodation. Which of the following agents is contraindicated in this patient?
content_preview: A 50-year-old man comes to the emergency department because of a severely painful right eye. The pain started an hour ago and is accompanied by frontal headache and nausea. The patient has vomited twice since the onset of the pain. He has type 2 diabetes mellitus. He immigrated to the US from China 10 years ago. He works as an engineer at a local company and has been under a great deal of stress lately. His only medication is metformin. Vital signs are within normal limits. The right eye is red and is hard on palpation. The right pupil is mid-dilated and nonreactive to light. The left pupil is round and reactive to light and accommodation. Which of the following agents is contraindicated in this patient?
hint: This patient presents with a unilateral red, hard, severely painful eye with a mid-dilated, nonreactive pupil as well as frontal headaches, vomiting, and nausea. These features are consistent with acute closed-angle glaucoma. The condition is particularly common in Asian individuals and can be precipitated by stress.
learning_objective: Recognize acute closed-angle glaucoma, and recall contraindicated agents.

answers.explanation_why:
Pilocarpine is used to treat both closed- and open-angle glaucoma. It causes miosis, which opens the iridocorneal angle, resulting in a reduction in intraocular pressure. For this reason, it is often given as a component of first-line therapy for acute angle-closure glaucoma.

This agent should only be administered once intraocular pressure (IOP) is < 40 mm Hg, and it is contraindicated in cases of lens-induced glaucoma (e.g., in lens luxation), which is not seen in this patient.

Timolol is commonly used in the treatment of glaucoma. Inhibition of β-receptors decreases aqueous humor production and leads to contraction of the ciliary muscle, which increases trabecular meshwork pore size and subsequently increases aqueous outflow. This agent is indicated in cases of acute angle-closure glaucoma.

Epinephrine is an α- and β-adrenergic receptor agonist (β > α) that causes pupillary dilator muscle contraction (via α1-receptors), leading to mydriasis, and ciliary muscle relaxation (via β2-receptors), which in turn results in a reduction in trabecular meshwork pore size. Together, these effects impede the natural outflow of aqueous humor and lead to increased intraocular pressure. In a patient with signs and symptoms of acute angle-closure glaucoma, increasing the intraocular pressure can quickly lead to permanent loss of vision; for this reason, epinephrine is contraindicated in this patient.

images.title: Anterior chamber angle
images.description: The anterior chamber angle is formed by the iris, cornea, and sclera. It contains the trabecular meshwork, which drains the aqueous humor. The spaces in the trabecular tissue are called spaces of Fontana, which connect the anterior chamber and Schlemm's canal, which is located in the sclera. The aqueous humor drains via Schlemm's canal into the episcleral veins.

answers.explanation_why: Apraclonidine is commonly used to acutely reduce intraocular pressure by decreasing aqueous humor production. It is a component of the treatment regimen for patients with acute angle-closure glaucoma and would be indicated in this patient.
Acetazolamide reduces aqueous humor production via carbonic anhydrase inhibition and is often given in conjunction with other medications for the treatment of acute angle-closure glaucoma.

question_text: A 68-year-old man comes to the physician because of double vision and unilateral right eye pain that began this morning. His vision improves when he covers either eye. He has hypertension, mild cognitive impairment, and type 2 diabetes mellitus. The patient has smoked two packs of cigarettes daily for 40 years. His current medications include lisinopril, donepezil, metformin, and insulin with meals. His temperature is 37.0°C (98.6°F), pulse is 85/min, respirations are 12/min, and blood pressure is 132/75 mm Hg. His right eye is abducted and depressed with slight intorsion. He can only minimally adduct the right eye. Visual acuity is 20/20 in both eyes. Extraocular movements of the left eye are normal. An MRI of the head shows no abnormalities. His fingerstick blood glucose concentration is 325 mg/dL. Further evaluation is most likely to show which of the following?
content_preview: A 68-year-old man comes to the physician because of double vision and unilateral right eye pain that began this morning. His vision improves when he covers either eye. He has hypertension, mild cognitive impairment, and type 2 diabetes mellitus. The patient has smoked two packs of cigarettes daily for 40 years. His current medications include lisinopril, donepezil, metformin, and insulin with meals. His temperature is 37.0°C (98.6°F), pulse is 85/min, respirations are 12/min, and blood pressure is 132/75 mm Hg. His right eye is abducted and depressed with slight intorsion. He can only minimally adduct the right eye. Visual acuity is 20/20 in both eyes. Extraocular movements of the left eye are normal. An MRI of the head shows no abnormalities. His fingerstick blood glucose concentration is 325 mg/dL. Further evaluation is most likely to show which of the following?
hint: The most likely cause of isolated oculomotor nerve palsy in a patient with uncontrolled diabetes mellitus is diabetic mononeuropathy, which occurs as a result of microangiopathic ischemia.
learning_objective: Recognize diabetic mononeuropathy as a cause of cranial nerve palsy, and recall that ptosis is a feature of oculomotor nerve palsy.

answers.explanation_why:
Ptosis occurs in patients with CN III palsy because the levator palpebrae superioris muscle is innervated by the oculomotor nerve. Whereas patients with CN III palsy due to compression usually show dilated pupils, those with diabetic mononeuropathy normally do not have pupillary involvement because the microangiopathy typically involves the vasa nervorum within the oculomotor nerve, while the pial blood vessels (which supply the superficial parasympathetic fibers) are usually spared.

CN III palsy due to diabetic or hypertensive microangiopathy usually improves with blood pressure and glycemic control. Patients should be monitored closely (every 2 days) during the first week. If the diplopia, ptosis, and/or external ophthalmoplegia worsen during this period or persist after 3 months, an MRI should be performed.

images.title: Oculomotor nerve palsy
images.description: Oculomotor nerve palsy (here, of the left eye) causes ipsilateral impairment of both motor and autonomic (parasympathetic) nerve functions. Paralysis of the inferior rectus, medial rectus, superior rectus, and inferior oblique muscles results in downward deviation (hypotropia) and outward deviation (exotropia) of the affected eye (down-and-out gaze) due to the unopposed actions of the lateral rectus and superior oblique muscles. Weakness of the levator palpebrae superioris muscle results in ptosis and impairment of parasympathetic function in mydriasis (as well as loss of accommodation and pupillary light reflex, which are not shown). Patients present with horizontal or horizontal and vertical double vision (diplopia) that worsens when turning the gaze away from the affected side. The ptosis, however, may prevent patients from experiencing diplopia.

answers.explanation_why: A dilated and fixed pupil in a patient with an oculomotor nerve palsy is typically seen with compression (e.g., from an aneurysm, tentorial herniation) or complete transection of the oculomotor nerve (e.g., base of the skull fractures) because the parasympathetic fibers that control pupillary constriction are located superficially on the oculomotor nerve. However, there is no clinical or radiological evidence of elevated intracranial pressure and/or hemiparesis to suggest tentorial herniation, or a history of trauma to suggest a skull base fracture; aneurysms only account for approx. 5% of cases of isolated CN III palsy.

Miosis and anhidrosis are seen in patients with preganglionic and central Horner's syndrome. Although patients with severe long-standing diabetes mellitus may present with Horner's syndrome as a result of diabetic autonomic neuropathy, Horner's syndrome is not typically associated with CN III palsy.

images.title: Horner syndrome triad
images.description: Orbital region of a female patientThe left eyelid is drooping (ptosis), the left pupil is smaller (miosis) than the right, and the left bulbus appears sunken into the orbit (enophthalmos).Ptosis, miosis and anhydrosis (not shown) represent the classical triad of Horner syndrome.

answers.explanation_why: Bitemporal hemianopsia occurs with lesions that compress the optic chiasm such as a pituitary adenoma, craniopharyngioma, meningioma, or a hypothalamic glioma. A tumor at the optic chiasm is unlikely to cause an isolated CN III palsy. Also, the MRI is normal in this patient and does not reveal a sellar tumor.

A positive swinging flashlight test indicates a relative afferent pupillary defect. An afferent pupillary defect is caused by retinal and/or optic nerve lesions (e.g., central retinal vessel occlusion, extensive retinal detachment, optic neuritis), and not by lesions of the oculomotor nerve, which transmits the efferent impulses of the pupillary reflex. A patient with an afferent pupillary defect would also have decreased visual acuity in the affected eye, whereas this patient has 20/20 vision in both eyes.

question_text: Three days after delivery, a 1100-g (2-lb 7-oz) newborn has a tonic seizure that lasts for 25 seconds. She has become increasingly lethargic over the past 18 hours. She was born at 31 weeks' gestation. Antenatal period was complicated by chorioamnionitis. Apgar scores were 3 and 6 at 1 and 5 minutes, respectively. She appears ill. Her pulse is 123/min, respirations are 50/min and irregular, and blood pressure is 60/30 mm Hg. Examination shows a tense anterior fontanelle. The pupils are equal and react sluggishly to light. Examination shows slow, conjugate back and forth movements of the eyes. Muscle tone is decreased in all extremities. The lungs are clear to auscultation. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
content_preview: Three days after delivery, a 1100-g (2-lb 7-oz) newborn has a tonic seizure that lasts for 25 seconds. She has become increasingly lethargic over the past 18 hours. She was born at 31 weeks' gestation. Antenatal period was complicated by chorioamnionitis. Apgar scores were 3 and 6 at 1 and 5 minutes, respectively. She appears ill. Her pulse is 123/min, respirations are 50/min and irregular, and blood pressure is 60/30 mm Hg. Examination shows a tense anterior fontanelle. The pupils are equal and react sluggishly to light. Examination shows slow, conjugate back and forth movements of the eyes. Muscle tone is decreased in all extremities. The lungs are clear to auscultation. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
hint: The condition described here is a serious complication of preterm birth.
learning_objective: Recognize intraventricular hemorrhage in preterm infants.

answers.explanation_why: If left untreated, classic galactosemia may manifest with lethargy, hypotonia, and seizures, as seen here. However, the absence of cataracts (typically manifests within the first days of life), jaundice, and hepatomegaly make this diagnosis less likely.

Spinal muscular atrophy is a possible cause of muscular hypotonia in infants. The most severe type (Werdnig-Hoffmann disease) may manifest immediately after birth or up to 6 months of age. Proximal muscles, mostly of the lower extremities, are usually involved symmetrically. However, seizures, a tense anterior fontanelle, impaired pupillary response, and roving eye movements would not be consistent with this diagnosis.

While most patients are asymptomatic at birth, half of the patients with phenylketonuria (PKU) have seizures with cerebral foci, a lag of psychomotor development, and a musty body odor by 4–6 months of age. Additional features include light, pale hair and blue eyes (due to decreased melanin production). Since most patients are asymptomatic until severe and often irreversible complications have occurred, direct measurement of phenylalanine levels is an important part of newborn screening for metabolic disorders. The screening test is performed on the second day after birth using blood obtained from a heel prick.

Hydrocephalus due to congenital causes, such as the Arnold-Chiari malformation, Dandy-Walker malformation, and intrauterine infections, may manifest in neonates with lethargy, tense fontanelles, seizures, and changes in vital signs due to brain stem compression (e.g., irregular breathing). However, elevated intracranial pressure usually manifests with rapidly increasing circumference of the head in neonates, which is not seen in this infant. Furthermore, instead of the roving eye movements, a downward deviation of the eyes (sunset eye sign) would be expected in patients with hydrocephalus.

images.title: Manifestations of increased intracranial pressure in infants

answers.explanation_why:
Intraventricular hemorrhage (IVH) is a common complication in preterm infants and usually occurs within the first five days after birth. This complication is typically seen in neonates of < 1500 g birth weight and born before 32 weeks' gestation due to the fragility of the germinal matrix. Additional risk factors include peripartal chorioamnionitis and hypoxia (as suggested by this patient's low Apgar scores). Most infants with IVH are asymptomatic, but saltatory (over several days) or, more rarely, catastrophic (over minutes to hours) courses are also possible. Symptoms include lethargy, hypotonia, irregular respirations, bulging anterior fontanelle, and neurologic symptoms (e.g., seizures, cranial nerve abnormalities as suggested by poor pupillary light reflexes and roving eye movements), all of which this patient has.

Cranial ultrasonography is the preferred method to diagnose IVH in newborns. Since most patients are asymptomatic, screening ultrasounds are routinely performed in infants with a birth weight < 1500 g and delivery before 30 weeks' gestation.

images.title: Neonatal intraventricular hemorrhage (IVH)
images.description:
Ultrasound head (top row: coronal plane; bottom row: parasagittal plane) of a newbornThe first column shows bleeding confined to the subependymal germinal matrix (red overlay), which is consistent with grade 1 IVH.
The second column shows blood occupying less than 50% of the left lateral ventricle (red overlay), with no enlargement of the lateral ventricles (yellow overlay) or the cavum septi pellucidi (green overlay). In addition, the choroid plexus is clearly demarcated (blue overlay). Together, these findings are consistent with grade 2 IVH.
The third column shows blood occupying more than 50% of the lateral ventricles (red overlay) with enlargement of the cavum septi pellucidi (green overlay) and both lateral ventricles (yellow overlay). This appearance is consistent with grade 3 IVH.These features suggest impaired progressive posthemorrhagic ventricular dilatation (PHVD) due to associated impairment of CSF circulation, which is a potential complication of high-grade IVH.

question_text: An 8-month-old boy is brought to the physician by his parents for gradually increasing loss of neck control and inability to roll over for the past 2 months. During this time, he has had multiple episodes of unresponsiveness with a blank stare and fluttering of the eyelids. His parents state that he sometimes does not turn when called but gets startled by loud noises. He does not maintain eye contact. He was able to roll over from front to back at 5 months of age and has not yet begun to sit or crawl. His parents are of Ashkenazi Jewish descent. Neurological examination shows generalized hypotonia. Deep tendon reflexes are 3+ bilaterally. Plantar reflex shows extensor response bilaterally. Fundoscopy shows bright red macular spots bilaterally. The remainder of the examination shows no abnormalities. Which of the following is the most likely cause of this patient's symptoms?
content_preview: An 8-month-old boy is brought to the physician by his parents for gradually increasing loss of neck control and inability to roll over for the past 2 months. During this time, he has had multiple episodes of unresponsiveness with a blank stare and fluttering of the eyelids. His parents state that he sometimes does not turn when called but gets startled by loud noises. He does not maintain eye contact. He was able to roll over from front to back at 5 months of age and has not yet begun to sit or crawl. His parents are of Ashkenazi Jewish descent. Neurological examination shows generalized hypotonia. Deep tendon reflexes are 3+ bilaterally. Plantar reflex shows extensor response bilaterally. Fundoscopy shows bright red macular spots bilaterally. The remainder of the examination shows no abnormalities. Which of the following is the most likely cause of this patient's symptoms?
hint: This infant presents with developmental delay, regression of achieved milestones (inability to roll over despite reaching this milestone three months prior), absence seizures (episodes of unresponsiveness with a blank stare), decreased eye contact, hypotonia, exaggerated startle response as a result of hyperacusis, hearing loss (unresponsive when called), hyperreflexia, and bilateral bright red (“cherry-red”) spots on fundoscopy, all of which are characteristic features of Tay-Sachs disease.
learning_objective: Recognize Tay-Sachs disease, and recall the enzyme deficiency it involves.

answers.explanation_why: Sphingomyelinase deficiency is the cause of Niemann-Pick disease, a sphingolipidosis that leads to neurodegeneration at a young age. It is more prevalent in individuals with Ashkenazi Jewish heritage. Although patients with this disease also present with cherry-red spots on the macula, developmental delay, and regression; the absence of hepatosplenomegaly makes this diagnosis unlikely.

Arylsulfatase A deficiency causes metachromatic leukodystrophy, a sphingolipidosis that can also lead to developmental delay and regression, and hypotonia starting at 6 months of age. However, metachromatic leukodystrophy is not associated with bright red spots on the macula, but rather optic nerve atrophy, ataxia, and peripheral neuropathy.

Gaucher disease is the most common of the sphingolipidoses and results from a deficiency of β-glucocerebrosidase. It is more prevalent in individuals with Ashkenazi Jewish heritage. Some forms of Gaucher disease can cause seizures, and developmental delay can be seen in more severe cases. However, hepatosplenomegaly, bone abnormalities (pain and osteopenia), and pancytopenia are much more common findings. Also, bright red spots on the macula are inconsistent with Gaucher disease.

Alpha-galactosidase A deficiency causes Fabry disease, which characteristically leads to severe distal limb pain (due to peripheral neuropathy) and angiokeratomas beginning around the age of 10–17 years. Renal failure and cardiovascular disease occur in most patients between the ages of 30– 40 years. The diagnosis of Fabry disease would not explain this patient's developmental delay that started at 6 months of age, nor would it cause bright red spots on the macula, hypotonia, and absence seizures.

A deficiency in lysosomal galactocerebrosidase results in Krabbe disease, a sphingolipidosis which can cause developmental delay or regression, similar to the motor symptoms seen in this case. However, patients with Krabbe disease tend to have hypertonia, not hypotonia, and do not have bright red spots on the macula. Instead, visual impairment secondary to optic nerve atrophy and peripheral neuropathy occur.

Beta-hexosaminidase A deficiency is the cause of Tay-Sachs disease, a rare neurological disease that causes intracellular accumulation of GM_2 gangliosides in neural cells, leading to progressive neurological degeneration beginning around the age of 6 months and cherry-red spots on fundoscopy. Individuals of Ashkenazi Jewish descent are more prone to develop the disease and carrier testing is therefore commonly performed in pregnant patients of this group or patients who wish to conceive. There is no cure and treatment is largely supportive. Usually, patients die of respiratory infections before 5 years of age. See “Overview of lysosomal storage diseases” table.

The extensor response to the plantar reflex seen in this infant is physiologic and should only be interpreted as a sign of neurologic damage if it persists beyond 24 months of age or is only seen unilaterally.

images.title: Cherry-red spot of the macula
images.description: Fundus photography of the left eye of a child with Tay-Sachs diseaseThe fovea centralis is visible as a deep red spot (cherry-red spot; blue overlay). Surrounding the fovea, the retina appears paler than normal because of accumulation of gangliosides within the retinal cells.Differential diagnosis of a cherry-red spot in children include Niemann-Pick disease, in which this appearance is caused by the accumulation of sphingomyelin within the retinal cells. In adults the diagnosis is most likely central retinal artery occlusion.

question_text: An 11-year-old boy is brought to the physician for a follow-up examination. He has been having difficulties with his schoolwork over the past 4 years. He has a seizure disorder treated with valproic acid. He was able to walk independently at the age of 3 years and was able to use a fork and spoon at the age of 4 years. He is at the 40^th percentile for height and 60^th percentile for weight. Vitals signs are within normal limits. Examination shows multiple freckles in the axillary and groin skin folds as well as scoliosis. There are 14 hyperpigmented macules over the back and chest. There are multiple soft, painless nodules over the extremities and the trunk. Ophthalmic examination shows hyperpigmented iris nodules bilaterally. This patient is at greatest risk for developing which of the following?
content_preview: An 11-year-old boy is brought to the physician for a follow-up examination. He has been having difficulties with his schoolwork over the past 4 years. He has a seizure disorder treated with valproic acid. He was able to walk independently at the age of 3 years and was able to use a fork and spoon at the age of 4 years. He is at the 40th percentile for height and 60th percentile for weight. Vitals signs are within normal limits. Examination shows multiple freckles in the axillary and groin skin folds as well as scoliosis. There are 14 hyperpigmented macules over the back and chest. There are multiple soft, painless nodules over the extremities and the trunk. Ophthalmic examination shows hyperpigmented iris nodules bilaterally. This patient is at greatest risk for developing which of the following?
hint: This child presents with a seizure disorder, intellectual disability, developmental delay (walking well and using a fork and spoon should occur at around 14–15 months), axillary and inguinal freckling, café au lait spots (hyperpigmented macules), neurofibromas (soft, painless nodules), Lisch nodules (hyperpigmented iris nodules), and scoliosis, all of which indicate neurofibromatosis type 1 (NF1).
learning_objective: Recognize neurofibromatosis type 1, and recall its associated tumor risks.

answers.explanation_why:
Individuals with NF1 are at increased risk for developing benign and/or malignant nervous system tumors, especially optic gliomas. Because optic gliomas are often asymptomatic, all children with NF1 should undergo an annual ophthalmologic examination and have a brain and orbit MRI if they develop symptoms associated with this tumor (e.g., decreased visual acuity, proptosis, strabismus, precocious puberty). Individuals with NF1 are also at increased risk of developing pheochromocytoma and nephroblastoma.

See “Overview of neurocutaneous syndromes” table.

images.title: Clinical features of neurofibromatosis type 1 and type 2
images.description: Neurofibromatoses are autosomal dominant-inherited neurocutaneous syndromes that are caused by mutations in tumor suppressor genes. Neurofibromatosis type 1 has a typical onset in adolescence and manifests with multiple neurofibromas, benign peripheral nerve sheath tumors that originate from neural crest cells. Neurofibromatosis type 2 has a later onset in early adulthood and manifests with multiple cerebral and spinal tumors.

answers.explanation_why: Individuals with neurofibromatosis type 2 (NF2) are at increased risk of developing (especially bilateral) vestibular schwannoma. NF2 typically manifests with complications of schwannomas (e.g., hearing loss, balance problems) and may cause other tumors of the central nervous system (e.g., meningioma). Hyperpigmented iris nodules and cognitive impairment, as seen in this patient, are not associated with NF2.

Individuals with ataxia telangiectasia are at increased risk of developing non-Hodgkin lymphoma. Ataxia telangiectasia should be suspected in patients with progressive cerebellar ataxia (due to cerebellar atrophy), athetosis, telangiectasias on the face and conjunctivae, and immunodeficiency (e.g. recurrent upper respiratory infections). This patient's skin findings and developmental delay are not typically seen in ataxia telangiectasia.

Individuals with Sturge-Weber syndrome are at increased risk of developing glaucoma due to increased intraorbital pressure. Patients with Sturge-Weber syndrome typically have vascular malformations of the choroid and central nervous system (which can also cause seizures), e.g., leptomeningeal angioma, and intellectual disabilities. However, cutaneous findings include facial port-wine stains, not skin fold freckling and café au lait spots.

Individuals with von Hippel-Lindau disease are at increased risk of developing (especially bilateral) renal cell carcinoma. Patients generally present with renal and pancreatic cysts and numerous benign and malignant tumors (e.g., hemangioblastomas of the retina, cerebellum, brain stem, and spine, or pheochromocytoma). The condition would not explain this patient's skin and cognitive findings.

Individuals with tuberous sclerosis are at increased risk for subependymal giant cell astrocytoma. Tuberous sclerosis can also manifest with intellectual disability and seizures. However, cutaneous symptoms include hypopigmented ash-leaf spots rather than skinfold freckling and hyperpigmented café au lait spots. Additionally, patients usually have various benign tumors in specific areas (e.g., rhabdomyoma, ungual fibromas, renal angiomyolipoma) instead of this patient's disseminated tumors over the extremities and trunk.

question_text: A 2-year-old boy is brought to the emergency department because of a 5-minute episode of repetitive, involuntary, twitching movements of his left arm that occurred 1 hour ago. His symptoms began while playing with some toys. His parents say that he began to stand with support at 18 months and has recently started to walk with support. He speaks in bisyllables. He is at the 70^th percentile for length and 80^th percentile for weight. His vital signs are within normal limits. Examination shows a purple-pink patch over the right cheek that extends to the right eyelid. The right eyeball is firm. Neurologic examination shows left arm hypotonia and absent biceps reflex on the left side. Fundoscopy shows cupping of the right optic disc. Which of the following is the most likely cause of this patient's symptoms?
content_preview: A 2-year-old boy is brought to the emergency department because of a 5-minute episode of repetitive, involuntary, twitching movements of his left arm that occurred 1 hour ago. His symptoms began while playing with some toys. His parents say that he began to stand with support at 18 months and has recently started to walk with support. He speaks in bisyllables. He is at the 70th percentile for length and 80th percentile for weight. His vital signs are within normal limits. Examination shows a purple-pink patch over the right cheek that extends to the right eyelid. The right eyeball is firm. Neurologic examination shows left arm hypotonia and absent biceps reflex on the left side. Fundoscopy shows cupping of the right optic disc. Which of the following is the most likely cause of this patient's symptoms?
hint: This boy presents with a focal seizure, developmental delay, naevus flammeus (purple-pink patch over the cheek and eyelid) and signs of early-onset glaucoma (buphthalmos, cupping of the optic disc).
learning_objective: Recognize Sturge-Weber syndrome.

answers.explanation_why: While Beckwith-Wiedemann syndrome (BWS) can manifest in infants with a facial naevus flammeus, other features of this condition, such as macroglossia or overgrowth (> 97th percentile for height and weight) are not present in this patient. BWS also does not usually cause neurologic deficits or significant developmental delay.

While ataxia telangiectasia also causes facial skin changes, it usually manifests after 3 years of age with telangiectasias on the bulbar conjunctiva, the nasal bridge, the malar areas, external ears, and hard palate. This patient also does not have any other common manifestations of ataxia telangiectasia such as ataxia, oculomotor apraxia, and recurrent infections (due to immunodeficiency). Additionally, glaucoma, buphthalmos, and developmental delay are not typically seen in the condition.

images.title: Telangiectasia
images.description: Small dilated blood vessels with a threadlike appearance are visible.This is the typical appearance of telangiectasia.

answers.explanation_why: A diagnosis of hereditary hemorrhagic telangiectasia (HHT) requires at least two of the following criteria: epistaxis, telangiectasias, visceral lesions, or a first-degree relative with HHT. Telangiectasias associated with HHT can have macular appearance similar to the lesion seen in this patient, but telangiectasias are more commonly found on the lips, tongue, buccal mucosa, and fingertips. Seizures and developmental delay are not seen in the syndrome.

This patient has several characteristics of Sturge-Weber syndrome. Most patients with the disorder are born with a naevus flammeus (port-wine stain), which usually lies over the region of the trigeminal nerve. The left-sided focal seizures, hypotonia, and absent reflexes are likely due to a right-sided leptomeningeal angioma, which classically occurs on the same side as the naevus flammeus. Vascular malformations within the eye lead to increased intraocular pressure and early-onset glaucoma. Patients with Sturge-Weber syndrome require anticonvulsants for seizure prophylaxis and regular ophthalmological screening. The naevus flammeus may be treated with laser therapy.

See “Overview of neurocutaneous syndromes” table.

Von Hippel-Lindau disease (VHL) is characterized by the formation of tumors, including hemangioblastomas and fluid-filled cysts in different parts of the body. The formation of hemangioblastomas in the brain may lead to neurological deficits and focal seizures, but the onset of symptoms occurs later in life, typically in young adulthood. The condition is not associated with the skin lesions seen in this patient.

Klippel-Trenaunay syndrome (KTS) may cause a naevus flammeus, but it usually occurs in the lower extremities. KTS is also associated with varicosities and hypertrophy of the limb with the naevus flammeus.

Neurofibromatosis type 1 (NF1) can rarely manifest with infantile seizures. However, café au lait spots or macules associated with NF1 are usually brown rather than purple or red. The diagnosis of NF1 requires any two of the following: six or more café au lait spots, at least two neurofibromas, axillary or inguinal freckling, optic gliomas, Lisch nodules on the iris, a distinctive bony lesion (e.g., sphenoid dysplasia, cortical thinning of long bones), or a family history of NF1 in a first-degree relative.

images.title: Clinical features of neurofibromatosis type 1 and type 2
images.description: Neurofibromatoses are autosomal dominant-inherited neurocutaneous syndromes that are caused by mutations in tumor suppressor genes. Neurofibromatosis type 1 has a typical onset in adolescence and manifests with multiple neurofibromas, benign peripheral nerve sheath tumors that originate from neural crest cells. Neurofibromatosis type 2 has a later onset in early adulthood and manifests with multiple cerebral and spinal tumors.

answers.explanation_why: Tuberous sclerosis can present with infantile seizures, developmental delay, and ash-leaf spots on physical examination. However, unlike the purple-red facial patch in this patient, the ash-leaf macule of tuberous sclerosis is hypopigmented, does not blanch with pressure, and more commonly occurs on the trunk or extremities.

question_text: A 25-year-old woman comes to the physician because of intermittent painful double vision for the past 3 days. Her symptoms occur only when looking sideways. She has myopia and has been wearing corrective lenses for 10 years. Ten days ago, she lost her balance and fell off her bike, for which she went to a hospital. A CT scan of the head at that time showed no abnormalities and she was released without further treatment. Her only medication is an oral contraceptive. Vital signs are within normal limits. The pupils are equal and reactive to light. Her best corrected visual acuity is 20/40 in each eye. She has an adduction deficit in the right eye and horizontal nystagmus in the left eye when looking left; she has an adduction deficit in the left eye and horizontal nystagmus in the right eye when looking right. Convergence testing shows no abnormalities. Fundoscopy shows bilateral disc hyperemia. Which of the following is the most likely cause of this patient's findings?
content_preview: A 25-year-old woman comes to the physician because of intermittent painful double vision for the past 3 days. Her symptoms occur only when looking sideways. She has myopia and has been wearing corrective lenses for 10 years. Ten days ago, she lost her balance and fell off her bike, for which she went to a hospital. A CT scan of the head at that time showed no abnormalities and she was released without further treatment. Her only medication is an oral contraceptive. Vital signs are within normal limits. The pupils are equal and reactive to light. Her best corrected visual acuity is 20/40 in each eye. She has an adduction deficit in the right eye and horizontal nystagmus in the left eye when looking left; she has an adduction deficit in the left eye and horizontal nystagmus in the right eye when looking right. Convergence testing shows no abnormalities. Fundoscopy shows bilateral disc hyperemia. Which of the following is the most likely cause of this patient's findings?
hint: Impaired adduction of the ipsilateral eye and abduction nystagmus of the contralateral eye (i.e., dissociated nystagmus) on lateral horizontal gaze should raise concern for internuclear ophthalmoplegia (INO), in which convergence is usually preserved. This patient's findings are consistent with bilateral INO. In addition, painful eye movements and hyperemia of the optic discs suggest optic neuritis.
learning_objective: Recognize internuclear ophthalmoplegia, and recall its association with demyelination in multiple sclerosis.

answers.explanation_why: Caudal displacement of the cerebellar vermis occurs in patients with Chiari II malformation, a condition that usually causes hydrocephalus secondary to stenosis of the aqueduct of Sylvius and may cause cerebellar signs (e.g., ataxia). While this patient has signs of balance problems, Chiari II malformation is almost always seen in conjunction with a lumbosacral or thoracic meningomyelocele, so it is often detected at birth. Based on her history alone, this adult patient is very unlikely to have this diagnosis. Moreover, Chiari II malformation does not cause INO.

answers.content: Demyelination of the medial longitudinal fasciculus
answers.explanation_why: Bilateral INO, optic neuritis, and ataxia (loss of balance) in a young woman should raise concern for multiple sclerosis (MS). In MS, demyelination of the medial longitudinal fasciculus (MLF) can lead to INO. In younger patients, MS is the most common cause of INO. In older patients (especially those with arteriosclerotic risk factors), INO is more commonly caused by ischemic infarction and manifests with unilateral findings and additional stroke findings. All patients with INO should undergo MRI of the brain.

Antibodies against acetylcholine receptors cause myasthenia gravis (MG). MG may manifest initially with painless diplopia and ptosis due to ocular muscle fatigue, which is characteristically worse at the end of the day or with exercise. While this patient has diplopia, MG would not cause this patient's horizontal gaze abnormality or eye pain.

images.title: Comparison between myasthenia gravis and Lambert-Eaton syndromes
images.description: AChR: acetylcholine receptor; Anti-AChR-Ab: acetylcholine receptor antibody; VGCC-Ab: voltage-gated calcium channel antibody

answers.explanation_why: A compressive tumor in the pons (e.g., pontine glioma) may cause bilateral INO if it compresses the structure responsible for conjugate horizontal gaze. Furthermore, this patient's episode of balance difficulties is consistent with a brainstem tumor. However, it would be rare for these tumors to cause INO in isolation, as they usually also cause additional cranial nerve abnormalities (e.g., dysarthria, dysphagia, facial sensory loss) and other neurological changes (ataxia and upper motor neuron lesions). Finally, brainstem gliomas are much more common in individuals under the age of 20 years.

answers.content: Oxidative damage due to thiamine deficiency
answers.explanation_why: Oxidative damage due to thiamine deficiency is the underlying mechanism of Wernicke encephalopathy, a condition that causes ophthalmoplegia and balance difficulties. However, this condition usually presents with more severe cognitive symptoms such as delirium and occurs primarily in patients with alcohol use disorder and/or those with nutritional deficiencies, neither of which is seen in this patient. Though the ophthalmoplegia seen in Wernicke encephalopathy may be similar to INO, it usually causes lateral gaze nystagmus without adduction difficulties.

answers.content: Subdural hematoma extending into the orbit
answers.explanation_why: Subdural hematomas can cause elevated intracranial pressure and headache following traumatic injury. Most cases of subdural hematoma cause headaches, confusion, nausea, or vomiting several days to weeks after trauma, none of which are seen in this patient. Although INO caused by subdural hematomas have been described in case reports, it is an exceedingly rare phenomenon, especially in a patient without any other signs of subdural hematoma (e.g., altered mental status, headache).

Brainstem infarction is the most common cause of INO in older patients. It is most likely in patients with vascular risk factors (e.g., obesity, smoking, factor V Leiden) and usually causes unilateral, not bilateral, INO with other stroke findings (e.g., unilateral hemiparesis, cranial nerve abnormalities). This patient has a very low risk of stroke, and another cause of INO is more likely.

question_text: A 6-year-old girl is brought to the physician because of a 4-day history of irritation and redness in both eyes. Her symptoms initially started in the left eye and progressed to involve both eyes within 24 hours. She presents with profuse tearing and reports that her eyes are sticky and difficult to open in the morning. She was diagnosed with asthma 2 years ago and has been admitted to the hospital for acute exacerbations three times since then. Current medications include inhaled beclomethasone, inhaled albuterol, and montelukast. Her temperature is 38.2°C (100.8°F). Physical examination reveals a tender left preauricular lymph node. There is chemosis and diffuse erythema of the bulbar conjunctiva bilaterally with watery discharge. Slit-lamp examination shows a follicular reaction in both palpebral conjunctivae and diffuse, fine epithelial keratitis of both corneas. Corneal sensation is normal. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?
content_preview: A 6-year-old girl is brought to the physician because of a 4-day history of irritation and redness in both eyes. Her symptoms initially started in the left eye and progressed to involve both eyes within 24 hours. She presents with profuse tearing and reports that her eyes are sticky and difficult to open in the morning. She was diagnosed with asthma 2 years ago and has been admitted to the hospital for acute exacerbations three times since then. Current medications include inhaled beclomethasone, inhaled albuterol, and montelukast. Her temperature is 38.2°C (100.8°F). Physical examination reveals a tender left preauricular lymph node. There is chemosis and diffuse erythema of the bulbar conjunctiva bilaterally with watery discharge. Slit-lamp examination shows a follicular reaction in both palpebral conjunctivae and diffuse, fine epithelial keratitis of both corneas. Corneal sensation is normal. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?
hint: Redness and profuse watery discharge which start in one eye and rapidly spread to the other, preauricular lymphadenopathy, low-grade fever, and signs of corneal inflammation are consistent with epidemic keratoconjunctivitis.
learning_objective: Choose the most appropriate management for epidemic keratoconjunctivitis.

answers.explanation_why:
Supportive therapy with artificial tears and cold compresses is the most appropriate treatment for uncomplicated epidemic keratoconjunctivitis, a self-limiting adenovirus infection that typically resolves completely within one week. Due to the highly contagious nature of this adenovirus infection, prevention is critical, especially in healthcare settings.

See “Overview of conjunctivitis subtypes in children and adults” table.

Oral cetirizine is used to treat symptoms of allergic rhinitis. The ocular manifestations of allergic rhinitis may also include conjunctival erythema with watery discharge, but almost always include immediate bilateral involvement and prominent itchiness, none of which is seen in this patient. Moreover, lymphadenopathy is not a feature of allergic rhinitis.

Topical prednisolone acetate is used to minimize ocular inflammation in cases of severe allergic conjunctivitis, autoimmune conditions such as uveitis or severe bacterial keratitis, and after ophthalmic surgery. Steroids are not indicated for viral infections such as epidemic keratoconjunctivitis.

Oral acyclovir is the first-line treatment for herpes simplex keratitis, which usually manifests with unilateral conjunctivitis accompanied by a foreign body sensation. The classic finding on ocular examination is linearly branching corneal ulcers (dendritic ulcers). This patient has bilateral conjunctivitis with watery discharge, making herpes simplex infection unlikely.

Natamycin is an appropriate treatment for fungal eye infections, which are very rare. The major risk factor for development of these infections is a traumatic eye injury with fungal contamination. Symptoms besides erythema include intense pain, photophobia, and purulent drainage. Since this patient does not have severe pain or photophobia and has no history of eye injury, fungal infection is highly unlikely.

Topical moxifloxacin is reserved for use in moderate to severe bacterial conjunctivitis, which manifests with erythematous conjunctiva, purulent discharge, upper lid papillae on slit-lamp examination, and possibly fever and lymphadenopathy. This patient has copious watery discharge and follicles on slit-lamp examination, meaning bacterial conjunctivitis is unlikely.

Topical erythromycin is an appropriate treatment for mild bacterial conjunctivitis, which manifests with erythematous conjunctiva, purulent discharge, and upper lid papillae on slit-lamp examination. This patient has copious watery ocular discharge, lymphadenopathy, and follicles on slit-lamp examination, all of which make mild bacterial conjunctivitis unlikely.

question_text: A 4-year-old boy is brought to his pediatrician by his mother for recurrent nosebleeds. The mother reports that the boy has had five nosebleeds within the past 2 weeks, each lasting between 15 and 20 minutes. The patient was born at term and has been hospitalized twice for pneumonia treatment. There is no family history of serious illness. The patient is at the 8th percentile for height and the 30th percentile for weight. Vital signs are within normal limits. Examination shows a small, thin child with two flat, dark brown areas of hyperpigmentation across the upper back and a similar discoloration on the left buttock. There is bilateral esotropia. Laboratory studies show a hemoglobin concentration of 9.3 g/dL, mean corpuscular volume of 107 μm^3, leukocyte count of 3800/mm^3, and platelet count of 46,000/mm^3. Which of the following is the most likely underlying cause of this patient's condition?
content_preview: A 4-year-old boy is brought to his pediatrician by his mother for recurrent nosebleeds. The mother reports that the boy has had five nosebleeds within the past 2 weeks, each lasting between 15 and 20 minutes. The patient was born at term and has been hospitalized twice for pneumonia treatment. There is no family history of serious illness. The patient is at the 8th percentile for height and the 30th percentile for weight. Vital signs are within normal limits. Examination shows a small, thin child with two flat, dark brown areas of hyperpigmentation across the upper back and a similar discoloration on the left buttock. There is bilateral esotropia. Laboratory studies show a hemoglobin concentration of 9.3 g/dL, mean corpuscular volume of 107 μm3, leukocyte count of 3800/mm3, and platelet count of 46,000/mm3. Which of the following is the most likely underlying cause of this patient's condition?
hint: This patient with pancytopenia, short stature, cafe-au-lait spots, and strabismus most likely has Fanconi anemia.
learning_objective: Recognize Fanconi anemia, and recall its genetic basis.

answers.explanation_why:
Fanconi anemia is an autosomal recessive disorder caused by a heterogeneous group of mutations, all of which lead to deficits in DNA repair mechanisms and, thus, a high frequency of chromosomal aberrations. Fanconi anemia has a wide variety of clinical manifestations. One of the most common and notable features is a predisposition for developing acute myeloid leukemia or myelodysplastic syndromes in early adulthood. Pancytopenia is also common and manifests with mucocutaneous bleeding, recurrent infections, and anemia (normocytic or macrocytic). Other skin, skeletal, and organ anomalies include short stature, hypopigmentation and hyperpigmentation of the skin, cafe-au-lait spots, microcephaly and developmental delay, ocular abnormalities (e.g., esotropia and hypertelorism), and thumb and forearm malformations.

Fanconi anemia should not be confused with Fanconi syndrome, a proximal renal tubular defect resulting in type 2 renal tubular acidosis (Type II RTA) and defective reabsorption of, e.g., potassium, glucose, phosphate, and amino acids.

Wiskott-Aldrich syndrome (WAS), an X-linked disorder caused by a mutation in the WAS protein, is characterized by eczema, bleeding diathesis, and recurrent infections. Although WAS may cause thrombocytopenia and leukopenia, it is not associated with short stature, cafe-au-lait spots, or strabismus.

Parvovirus B19 infection in children can cause anemia due to aplastic crisis and may also lead to mild leukopenia and thrombocytopenia. However, parvovirus B19 infection is not associated with short stature, cafe-au-lait spots, or strabismus.

Paroxysmal nocturnal hemoglobinuria (PNH) is caused by a defect in a cell membrane protein leading to hemolysis and venous thromboembolism. Hemolysis leads to jaundice, anemia, and, in some cases, end-organ damage. Although pancytopenia is consistent with the present case, the absence of jaundice or other signs of hemolysis makes PNH unlikely. PNH is also not associated with short stature, cafe-au-lait spots, or strabismus.
Vitamin B_12 deficiency causes macrocytic anemia and neurological defects such as paresthesias and sensory ataxia. It is not associated with short stature, cafe-au-lait spots, or strabismus.

About 60% of cases of pediatric immune thrombocytopenic purpura (ITP) occur within a few weeks of a viral infection. Postviral ITP is generally a self-limiting condition that does present with thrombocytopenia, as in this case, but does not involve a decreased leukocyte count or anemia. Rather than the hyperpigmentation and cafe-au-lait spots seen here, the skin changes associated with ITP are petechiae that may coalesce into larger purpura and ecchymoses.

Acute lymphoblastic leukemia (ALL) is the most common childhood malignancy. Although this patient has some features of ALL (infections, anemia, and thrombocytopenia), the absence of other symptoms of ALL, e.g., bone pain, fever, and lymphadenopathy, makes this diagnosis less likely. In addition, ALL is not classically associated with short stature, cafe-au-lait spots, or strabismus.

question_text: A 4-month-old boy is brought to the physician for a well-child examination. He was born at 36 weeks' gestation. The mother has had no prenatal care. His 6-year-old sister has a history of osteosarcoma. He is exclusively breastfed. He is at the 60^th percentile for height and weight. Vital signs are within normal limits. Examination shows inward deviation of the right eye. Penlight examination shows a white reflex in the right eye and a red reflex in the left eye. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?
content_preview: A 4-month-old boy is brought to the physician for a well-child examination. He was born at 36 weeks' gestation. The mother has had no prenatal care. His 6-year-old sister has a history of osteosarcoma. He is exclusively breastfed. He is at the 60th percentile for height and weight. Vital signs are within normal limits. Examination shows inward deviation of the right eye. Penlight examination shows a white reflex in the right eye and a red reflex in the left eye. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?
hint: All children who present with leukocoria should be considered to have retinoblastoma until proven otherwise.
learning_objective: Recognize leukocoria as a sign of retinoblastoma, and choose the most appropriate initial diagnostic test.

answers.explanation_why: Galactosemia is a rare metabolic disorder that often manifests with cataracts. While this patient presents with possible findings of cataract (e.g., leukocoria and strabismus), he has no other features of galactosemia (e.g., hepatomegaly, jaundice). Moreover, galactosemia would normally be detected by newborn screening or become apparent in the first few days after birth and initiation of breast milk rather than manifest at 4 months of age.

Visual training therapy is indicated in many patients with strabismus. Treatment of strabismus should be initiated as early as possible to prevent amblyopia and loss of binocular vision. However, although this patient has strabismus, visual training therapy is not indicated because the presence of leukocoria is highly concerning for retinoblastoma, which requires further investigation.

Imaging of the eye is an important step in the evaluation of the size and extent of retinoblastoma prior to surgery. Although this patient's presentation is highly concerning for retinoblastoma, other interventions are preferred over CT scan, which increases the risk of radiation-induced tumors in patients with RB1 gene mutation. CT scan is occasionally considered if retinoblastoma is clinically suspected but difficult to confirm.

Occlusion therapy (i.e., an eye patch) is often indicated in patients with strabismus to prevent amblyopia and loss of binocular vision. However, although this patient has strabismus, occlusion therapy is not indicated at this point because the presence of leukocoria is highly concerning for retinoblastoma, which requires further investigation.

All children who present with leukocoria should undergo a prompt funduscopic examination to rule out retinoblastoma. Retinoblastoma is the most common and, if left untreated, most lethal primary intraocular malignancy in children. The condition typically manifests with leukocoria, strabismus, and a white mass in the retina on fundoscopy. Less commonly, there is visual impairment and/or redness of the eye due to inflammation. Ocular ultrasound and MRI are indicated to evaluate the size and extent of the tumor. Treatment is primarily surgical, with specific surgical techniques (e.g., cryotherapy vs. enucleation) dictated by imaging results. Chemotherapy is used as an adjuvant if there is metastatic disease.

Retinoblastoma is caused by sporadic or inherited mutations in the retinoblastoma gene (Rb) and may be associated with other malignancies (e.g., osteosarcoma, pinealoma). This patient's sister has a history of osteosarcoma, which suggests an inherited mutation. Molecular genetic testing is recommended in all patients with retinoblastoma to identify germline mutations, as family members may also be at risk.

images.title: Leukocoria
images.description: Photograph of a patient with retinoblastomaThe left eye shows the normal retinal reflection, whereas the right pupil appears white (leukocoria or white pupil). This phenomenon occurs if light (e.g., during an ophthalmologic examination or flash photography) is not reflected by the retina but by intraocular lesions such as tumors.Leukocoria is a typical early symptom of retinoblastoma.

answers.explanation_why: Observation with follow-up is indicated for isolated strabismus in children < 3 months old, as it often resolves spontaneously. However, this patient's leukocoria with concurrent strabismus raises suspicion for retinoblastoma, the most common and, if left untreated, fatal primary intraocular malignancy in children. All children who present with leukocoria should undergo further examination.

Serum rubella titers should be acquired in cases of suspected rubella. This patient's mother has not had routine prenatal care, which puts her at risk of contracting congenital infections, including rubella. Rubella infection during pregnancy may cause congenital rubella syndrome, typically manifesting with sensorineural hearing loss, cataracts, and/or cardiac defects (e.g., patent ductus arteriosus) at birth or later. Although cataracts may cause leukocoria and strabismus, other features of congenital rubella syndrome are absent in this patient (e.g., cardiopulmonary abnormalities). Another investigation is warranted in this patient to rule out retinoblastoma.

question_text: A 3-year-old boy is brought to the physician by his parents for a well-child examination. The boy was born at term via vaginal delivery and has been healthy except for severe myopia. He is at the 97th percentile for height and 25th percentile for weight. Oral examination shows a high-arched palate. He has unusually long, slender fingers and toes, and his finger joints are hyperflexible. The patient is asked to place his thumbs in the palms of the same hand and then clench to form a fist. The thumbs are noted to protrude beyond the ulnar border of the hand. Slit-lamp examination shows lens subluxation in the superotemporal direction bilaterally. Which of the following is the most likely underlying cause of this patient's condition?
content_preview: A 3-year-old boy is brought to the physician by his parents for a well-child examination. The boy was born at term via vaginal delivery and has been healthy except for severe myopia. He is at the 97th percentile for height and 25th percentile for weight. Oral examination shows a high-arched palate. He has unusually long, slender fingers and toes, and his finger joints are hyperflexible. The patient is asked to place his thumbs in the palms of the same hand and then clench to form a fist. The thumbs are noted to protrude beyond the ulnar border of the hand. Slit-lamp examination shows lens subluxation in the superotemporal direction bilaterally. Which of the following is the most likely underlying cause of this patient's condition?
hint: Other features associated with this patient's condition include aortic conditions, pectus deformity, and skin hyperextensibility.
learning_objective: Recognize Marfan syndrome, and recall its genetic basis.

answers.explanation_why:
This patient presents with severe myopia, tall stature, high-arched palate, arachnodactyly, positive thumb sign, and superotemporal lens subluxation, which together strongly suggest Marfan syndrome (MFS). A mutation in the fibrillin-1 gene causes MFS. Fibrillin-1 is needed to form microfibrils that provide strength to connective tissue and store growth factors. A mutation in the fibrillin-1 gene thus leads to defective connective tissue (causing hypermobility and lens dislocation) and excessive growth factor release (causing tall stature).

While there is no cure for MFS, preliminary data suggest that ARBs (e.g., losartan) may have a protective or even reversing effect in some of the clinical manifestations of MFS. Other treatment options focus on preventing specific symptoms (e.g., aortic dilatation treated with beta blockers, and scoliosis treated with bracing, physical therapy, and analgesia).

Defects in homocysteine metabolism (e.g., cystathionine synthase deficiency) cause homocystinuria, which presents with tall stature, arachnodactyly, and/or lens subluxation. However, subluxation of the ocular lens in homocystinuria is typically inferior and nasal and not superior and temporal as seen in this patient. Other typical features of homocystinuria include intellectual disability and increased risk of thromboembolic episodes, for which there are no indications in this patient.
Defective collagen cross-linking causes Ehler-Danlos syndrome type VI (EDS VI), which can cause joint hypermobility. However, EDS does not result in lens subluxation.

Nondisjunction of the sex chromosomes can cause Klinefelter syndrome, which presents with tall, slim stature because of delayed growth plate closure due to testosterone deficiency. However, it is not associated with myopia, lens subluxation, or joint hypermobility.

A mutation in the fragile X mental retardation 1 gene (FMR1 gene) causes fragile X syndrome, which can present with tall stature and hypermobile joints. However, other typical craniofacial features include a long and narrow face, large ears, and relative macrocephaly, which this patient lacks. Moreover, it does not cause lens subluxation.

A point mutation in the RET gene can cause multiple endocrine neoplasia type 2A and 2B (MEN 2A and MEN 2B). Individuals with MEN 2B classically present with tall stature and joint hypermobility, as seen in this patient, but other typical findings, such as multiple neuromas, pheochromocytoma, and medullary thyroid carcinoma are absent. Moreover, multiple endocrine neoplasia does not cause lens subluxation. MEN 2A can manifest with medullary thyroid carcinoma, pheochromocytoma, and primary hyperparathyroidism.
