question_text:
A 12-year-old boy comes to the physician for the evaluation of intermittent blood-tinged urine for several months. Four months ago, he had an episode of fever and sore throat that resolved without treatment after 5 days. During the past 2 years, he has also had recurrent episodes of swelling of his face and feet. Five years ago, he was diagnosed with mild bilateral sensorineural hearing loss. His brother died of a progressive kidney disease at the age of 23. The patient appears pale. His temperature is 37°C (98.6°F), pulse is 70/min, and blood pressure is 145/85 mm Hg. Slit lamp examination shows a conical protrusion of both lenses. Laboratory studies show:

Hemoglobin
11 g/dL

Serum

 Urea nitrogen
40 mg/dL

 Creatinine
2.4 mg/dL

Urine

 Blood

2+

 Protein

1+

 RBC
5–7/hpf

 RBC casts
rare

Which of the following is the most likely underlying cause of this patient's symptoms?
content_preview: A 12-year-old boy comes to the physician for the evaluation of intermittent blood-tinged urine for several months. Four months ago, he had an episode of fever and sore throat that resolved without treatment after 5 days. During the past 2 years, he has also had recurrent episodes of swelling of his face and feet. Five years ago, he was diagnosed with mild bilateral sensorineural hearing loss. His brother died of a progressive kidney disease at the age of 23. The patient appears pale. His temperature is 37°C (98.6°F), pulse is 70/min, and blood pressure is 145/85 mm Hg. Slit lamp examination shows a conical protrusion of both lenses. Laboratory studies show: Hemoglobin 11 g/dL Serum Urea nitrogen 40 mg/dL Creatinine 2.4 mg/dL Urine Blood 2+ Protein 1+ RBC 5–7/hpf RBC casts rare Which of the following is the most likely underlying cause of this patient's symptoms?
hint: This patient's recurrent edema of the face and feet, hypertension, elevated urea nitrogen and creatinine, and urinalysis that shows microscopic hematuria and proteinuria are suggestive of nephritic syndrome. The combination of intermittent gross hematuria, nephritic syndrome, sensorineural hearing loss, and anterior lenticonus in a patient with a family history of renal disease is indicative of Alport syndrome.
learning_objective: Recognize Alport syndrome, and recall its genetic basis.

answers.explanation_why: Deposition of IgA in the glomeruli is seen in IgA nephropathy and in Henoch-Schönlein purpura (HSP), both of which may manifest with nephritic syndrome. However, a purpuric rash would typically precede the onset of renal disease in patients with HSP, and other symptoms such as abdominal pain and/or joint pain would be expected. Moreover, both HSP and IgA nephropathy do not explain the sensorineural deafness and lenticonus seen here.

Type II hypersensitivity reactions caused by antibodies against intrinsic type IV collagen antigens in the basement membrane are responsible for Goodpasture disease, which manifests with acute nephritic syndrome. However, Goodpasture disease rarely manifests during early childhood and usually progresses rapidly (unlike in this patient, who presents with a 2-year history of intermittent edema). Also, especially in younger individuals, pulmonary symptoms (e.g., hemoptysis, dyspnea) often precede the onset of nephritic syndrome.

A WT1 gene mutation is one of the causes of nephroblastoma (i.e., Wilms tumor), which can result in hematuria, hypertension, and anemia. However, nephroblastoma typically manifests in early childhood (usually before the age of 5 years) and patients almost always have a palpable abdominal or flank mass on physical examination.

Antibodies against phospholipase A2 receptors on podocytes are responsible for membranous nephropathy. Membranous nephropathy typically manifests between the ages of 30 and 50 years with nephrotic syndrome, unlike this 12-year-old boy child with nephritic syndrome.

Alport syndrome is caused by a genetic defect of type IV collagen, which is most commonly inherited in an X-linked dominant pattern. Type IV collagen is found in the glomerular basement membrane, the cochlea, and the lens of the eye. Thus, a defect of type IV collagen may result in hematuria and nephritic syndrome, sensorineural hearing loss, and anterior lenticonus leading to vision problems (patients with Alport syndrome “can't pee, can't see, can't hear a bee”).

The diagnosis of Alport syndrome is confirmed via skin biopsy (showing the absence of type IV collagen alpha-5 chains in the basement membrane) or, if skin biopsy is inconclusive, kidney biopsy. Patients with proteinuria, such as this boy, should receive ACE inhibitors or angiotensin II receptor blockers to slow the progression to end-stage renal disease.

Pharyngitis caused by group A beta-hemolytic streptococci (GAS) is common in children 5–15 years of age and can cause poststreptococcal glomerulonephritis (PSGN) 1–3 weeks after the infection. This patient had an episode of febrile pharyngitis 4 months ago that could be due to GAS. However, while PSGN would present with nephritic syndrome, it does not explain the 2-year history of intermittent edema or the presence of sensorineural deafness and lenticonus in this patient.

Hematuria, hypertension, anemia, and raised creatinine in a 12-year-old child with an onset of symptoms during infancy as well a family history of early death due to end-stage renal disease might suggest a diagnosis of autosomal recessive polycystic kidney disease (ARPKD), which is a cause for multiple bilateral kidney cysts. However, ARPKD does not account for sensorineural deafness and lenticonus. Instead, patients with ARPKD who survive to adolescence usually have evidence of cirrhosis and portal hypertension (e.g., ascites, splenomegaly).

In about 15% of cases, Alport syndrome may be the result of an autosomal-recessive mutation. However, the majority of affected patients have an X-linked mutation.

question_text: A 2-year-old boy is brought to the physician because of progressive difficulty breathing and a productive cough for the past 2 days. During the past 6 months, he has had recurrent episodes of pneumonia treated with antibiotics. He has not gained weight in this time period. His temperature is 38.5°C (101.3°F), pulse is 130/min, respirations are 18/min, and blood pressure is 100/60 mm Hg. Auscultation of the lungs shows decreased breath sounds over the right lung fields. Ocular examination shows periorbital subcutaneous bleeding and bulging of both eyes. The remainder of the examination is unremarkable. His leukocyte count is 16,000/mm^3. An x-ray of the chest shows a right-sided opacity and a collapsed right lung. An MRI of the chest shows a heterogeneous mass in the posterior mediastinum that compresses the heart and the great vessels to the left side. Further evaluation is most likely to show which of the following?
content_preview: A 2-year-old boy is brought to the physician because of progressive difficulty breathing and a productive cough for the past 2 days. During the past 6 months, he has had recurrent episodes of pneumonia treated with antibiotics. He has not gained weight in this time period. His temperature is 38.5°C (101.3°F), pulse is 130/min, respirations are 18/min, and blood pressure is 100/60 mm Hg. Auscultation of the lungs shows decreased breath sounds over the right lung fields. Ocular examination shows periorbital subcutaneous bleeding and bulging of both eyes. The remainder of the examination is unremarkable. His leukocyte count is 16,000/mm3. An x-ray of the chest shows a right-sided opacity and a collapsed right lung. An MRI of the chest shows a heterogeneous mass in the posterior mediastinum that compresses the heart and the great vessels to the left side. Further evaluation is most likely to show which of the following?
hint: This patient's presentation raises concern for the most common extracranial solid tumor in children.
learning_objective: Recognize neuroblastoma, and recall its genetic association.

answers.content: Unregulated parafollicular cell proliferation in the thyroid gland
answers.explanation_why: Unregulated parafollicular cell proliferation in the thyroid gland indicates medullary thyroid carcinoma, which typically occurs in patients with MEN 2A or MEN 2B syndromes. MEN 2 syndromes are also associated with pheochromocytoma, which may arise in the posterior mediastinum. However, pheochromocytoma causes hypersecretion of norepinephrine, epinephrine, and/or dopamine, which leads to episodes of sweating, tachycardia, hypertension, and headaches, typically starting between the age of 20–40 years. This constellation of symptoms is not present in this 2-year-old boy, making pheochromocytoma and an associated MEN 2 syndrome very unlikely.

Overexpression of N-myc oncogene may lead to the formation of neuroblastoma, a tumor of the sympathetic nervous system usually found in the adrenal glands or sympathetic ganglia. General symptoms of neuroblastoma include failure to thrive, weight loss, nausea, and fever, while more specific symptoms depend on the location of the tumor. In approx. 20% of cases, the tumor arises from the thoracic ganglia, and mass effects in the posterior mediastinum can lead to dyspnea, cough, and airway obstruction that predisposes to respiratory infections. At the time of diagnosis, the majority of patients with neuroblastoma already have features of metastasis to the eye orbit (e.g., proptosis, “raccoon eyes”), bones (e.g., pain), and/or the skin (subcutaneous nodules).

Overexpression of N-myc oncogene is associated with a poor prognosis.

images.title: Periorbital ecchymoses
images.description: 3-year-old girl with orbital neuroblastomaThe periorbital region of the right eye appears swollen and shows a purplish-bluish hematoma. Proptosis of the eye and subconjunctival hemorrhage (hyposphagma) can also be seen.These findings are typical of a periorbital ecchymoses (raccoon eye) and are here associated with the spread of neuroblastoma.

answers.content: Increased lymphoblast count in the bone marrow
answers.explanation_why: An increased lymphoblast count in the bone marrow should raise concern for acute lymphocytic leukemia (ALL), which typically manifests in children 2–5 years of age with fatigue, fever, night sweats, pallor, headaches, visual field changes, and/or bone pain. ALL may metastasize to the mediastinum and cause lymphadenopathy but would not cause a posterior mediastinal mass. This patient's presentation is not consistent with ALL.

answers.content: Unregulated B-cell proliferation in the mediastinum
answers.explanation_why: Unregulated B-cell proliferation can lead to mediastinal lymphomas (e.g., non-Hodgkin lymphoma), which may manifest with fever and failure to thrive, as well as dyspnea and cough due to airway compression. However, lymphomas are usually located in the anterior rather than the posterior mediastinum, and most patients present with nontender lymphadenopathy. Furthermore, lymphomas are rare in children < 5 years of age. This patient's posterior mediastinal mass and periorbital ecchymoses indicate a different diagnosis.

AChR antibodies are responsible for myasthenia gravis (MG). Although MG is often associated with a concurrent thymoma, this patient does not show any signs of progressive generalized muscular weakness (e.g., ptosis or diplopia due to ocular muscle weakness). A thymoma would also be located in the anterior rather than the posterior mediastinum. Moreover, neither MG nor thymoma is associated with recurrent pulmonary infections, periorbital ecchymoses, or proptosis.

Sputum microscopy shows acid-fast bacteria in active tuberculosis (TB). Active TB usually manifests with a persistent dry cough and B symptoms (fevers, weight loss, sweating at night) for > 3 weeks. This patient has had a productive cough for only 2 days and his chest x-ray shows a right-sided opacity, which makes TB very unlikely. A posterior mediastinal mass would also not be expected in TB.

images.title: Pulmonary tuberculosis
images.description:
Active pulmonary tuberculosis (TB) typically manifests with systemic (e.g., low-grade fever, night sweats, weight loss, decreased appetite, and malaise) and pulmonary symptoms (e.g., dyspnea, pleuritic chest pain due to pleural effusion, productive cough, and possibly hemoptysis in advanced stages).
Symptomatic TB can occur as a result of primary infection (primary active TB) or reactivation of latent infection (reactivation TB). While symptoms are similar in both conditions, radiographic presentation differs.
Radiographic imaging in primary TB commonly shows a Ghon complex (Ghon focus with its associated lymph node), unilateral hilar lymphadenopathy, and homogenous consolidation with ill-defined borders in the middle and lower lobes. Chest x-ray in reactivation TB typically shows multiple cavities in the upper lobes, calcifications, patchy consolidations, and features fibroproliferative disease (e.g, scarring) due to inflammatory tissue destruction.

answers.explanation_why: Elevated alpha-fetoprotein levels can indicate an extragonadal germ cell tumor. This tumor most commonly occurs in the mediastinum and can cause chest pain, dyspnea, and a cough. However, mediastinal extragonadal germ cell tumors typically occur in the anterior mediastinum, not the posterior mediastinum. Furthermore, a germ cell tumor would not explain this boy's ocular symptoms.

question_text: A 3-year-old girl with cystic fibrosis is brought to the physician for a follow-up examination. Her mother has noticed that the child has had multiple falls over the past 4 months while walking, especially in the evening. Her current medications include pancreatic enzyme supplements, an albuterol inhaler, and acetylcysteine. She is at the 10^th percentile for height and the 5^th percentile for weight. Examination shows dry skin and cone-shaped elevated papules on the trunk and extremities. There is an irregularly shaped foamy gray patch on the left conjunctiva. The remainder of the examination shows no abnormalities. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?
content_preview: A 3-year-old girl with cystic fibrosis is brought to the physician for a follow-up examination. Her mother has noticed that the child has had multiple falls over the past 4 months while walking, especially in the evening. Her current medications include pancreatic enzyme supplements, an albuterol inhaler, and acetylcysteine. She is at the 10th percentile for height and the 5th percentile for weight. Examination shows dry skin and cone-shaped elevated papules on the trunk and extremities. There is an irregularly shaped foamy gray patch on the left conjunctiva. The remainder of the examination shows no abnormalities. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?
hint: This treatment would also be prescribed as a part of the treatment of severe measles.
learning_objective: Choose the appropriate management for vitamin A deficiency.

answers.explanation_why:
Niacin deficiency (vitamin B_3 deficiency) leads to a condition called pellagra. Dermatitis in these patients usually manifests as a symmetric rash with hyperpigmented skin lesions in the sun-exposed areas of skin, rather than the elevated papules seen on this child's trunk.

Foods rich in niacin include meat, liver, cereals, seeds, and legumes.

images.title: Vitamin B₃ deficiency
images.description: Pellagra can be deadly if left untreated (due to the formerly high mortality rate, “death” is sometimes still listed as the fourth “D” of pellagra). Populations with a diet low in niacin-rich foods (e.g., corn-based diets without proper preparation) are at higher risk.

answers.explanation_why:
The classic triad of zinc deficiency is acral or periorificial dermatitis (dry, erythematous dry patches in an acral distribution or surrounding body orifices), alopecia, and diarrhea. This patient's skin lesions are morphologically inconsistent with the dermatitis seen in zinc deficiency. Also, her lesions are located on the trunk and extremities, rather than the palms, soles, and nail beds, or periorally. In addition, she does not have any of the known risk factors for zinc deficiency.

Foods rich in zinc include shellfish, fish, red meat, whole grains, and nuts.

This patient with cystic fibrosis (CF) has classic signs of vitamin A deficiency, i.e., night blindness, xerophthalmia (manifested as Bitot spots), and skin manifestations (xeroderma and follicular hyperkeratosis). Although patients with fat malabsorption disorders such as CF, celiac disease, inflammatory bowel disease, pancreatic insufficiency, and cholestasis are particularly vulnerable to developing vitamin A deficiency, this can be prevented with fat-soluble vitamin supplementation.

Food sources of vitamin A include liver, fish, carrots, and eggs.

Riboflavin (Vitamin B_2) deficiency leads to cheilitis, glossitis, stomatitis, normocytic normochromic anemia, seborrheic dermatitis, and a sore throat. Although riboflavin deficiency can also cause eye involvement (corneal vascularization), it does not lead to impaired vision or gray conjunctival lesions. This child does not have symptoms or risk factors for riboflavin deficiency.

Foods rich in riboflavin include meat, fish, eggs, milk, green vegetables, and yeast.

Lutein is a macula-protective supplement that may benefit patients with macular degeneration. Although juvenile macular degeneration could cause poor night vision in a child, this condition is extremely rare. Also, a lutein deficiency is inconsistent with the rest of this child's symptoms.

question_text:
A previously healthy 13-year-old boy is brought to the emergency department by his parents for the evaluation of several episodes of vomiting since this morning. He reports nausea and severe headache. Over the past four days, he has had fever, a runny nose, and a sore throat. His mother gave him an analgesic drug that she uses for rheumatoid arthritis. He has not had any trauma. Last month, the patient traveled to Mexico with his family. He is at the 85th percentile for height and 25th percentile for weight. He appears weak. His temperature is 38°C (100°F), pulse is 90/min, respirations are 18/min, and blood pressure is 100/60 mm Hg. Mental status examination shows psychomotor agitation alternating with lethargy. Examination shows bilateral optic disc swelling. Serum studies show:

Urea nitrogen
30 mg/dL

Glucose
67 mg/dL

Aspartate aminotransferase (AST, GOT)
132 U/L

Alanine aminotransferase (ALT, GPT)
126 U/L

Arterial blood gas analysis on room air shows a pH of 7.30. Which of the following is the most likely cause of this patient's symptoms?
content_preview: A previously healthy 13-year-old boy is brought to the emergency department by his parents for the evaluation of several episodes of vomiting since this morning. He reports nausea and severe headache. Over the past four days, he has had fever, a runny nose, and a sore throat. His mother gave him an analgesic drug that she uses for rheumatoid arthritis. He has not had any trauma. Last month, the patient traveled to Mexico with his family. He is at the 85th percentile for height and 25th percentile for weight. He appears weak. His temperature is 38°C (100°F), pulse is 90/min, respirations are 18/min, and blood pressure is 100/60 mm Hg. Mental status examination shows psychomotor agitation alternating with lethargy. Examination shows bilateral optic disc swelling. Serum studies show: Urea nitrogen 30 mg/dL Glucose 67 mg/dL Aspartate aminotransferase (AST, GOT) 132 U/L Alanine aminotransferase (ALT, GPT) 126 U/L Arterial blood gas analysis on room air shows a pH of 7.30. Which of the following is the most likely cause of this patient's symptoms?
hint: Aspirin is a common analgesic agent used to treat arthralgia in adults.
learning_objective: Recognize Reye syndrome, and recall its etiology.

answers.explanation_why: Hepatitis A infection may also lead to fever, vomiting, and transaminitis, and is an important differential given this patient's recent travels to Mexico, where hepatitis A is endemic. However, patients with acute viral hepatitis such as hepatitis A usually have extremely high concentrations of serum transaminases (≥ 10 times the normal levels) and an AST:ALT ratio of < 1. Moreover, features of hepatic failure (e.g., hepatic encephalopathy, hypoglycemia, acidosis) would not be expected because hepatic failure is extremely rare with hepatitis A infection.

Reye syndrome is caused by hepatic mitochondrial injury that can develop in children 3–5 days after aspirin treatment of a febrile viral illness. Reye syndrome presents with features of hepatic encephalopathy such as profuse vomiting, lethargy, altered mental status, headache, and papilledema (due to increased intracranial pressure). Patients can eventually develop seizures and coma. Other typical findings include hepatomegaly, elevated transaminases (≥ 3 times the normal levels), and features of hepatic failure (e.g., hyperammonemia, hypoglycemia, lactic acidosis).

Acetaminophen should be used as an antipyretic or analgesic instead of aspirin in children to avoid Reye syndrome!

answers.content: Ruptured aneurysm in the circle of Willis
answers.explanation_why: In pediatric patients, a ruptured berry aneurysm in the circle of Willis and subsequent subarachnoid hemorrhage may also present with a severe headache, impaired consciousness, bilateral optic disc swelling, and fever. Patients with Marfan syndrome are predisposed to such aneurysms. However, except for being tall for his age, this patient has no other signs of Marfan syndrome (e.g., chest wall abnormalities, joint hypermobility). Additionally, neither a ruptured aneurysm nor Marfan syndrome cause transaminitis or acidosis.

Infection with Neisseria meningitidis is the most common cause of meningitis in this patient's age group and may also occur after pharyngitis. Patients present with fever, headache, vomiting, and altered mental status. However, this patient does not have typical signs of meningitis such as neck stiffness (nuchal rigidity) or a positive Kernig sign or Brudzinski sign. Additionally, it would not explain this patient's transaminitis or acidosis.

Antifreeze ingestion causes ethylene glycol poisoning, which may also present with an altered mental status, acidosis, vomiting, and signs of liver damage. However, patients typically also present with a sweet-smelling breath, signs of tetany due to hypocalcemia, and features of calcium oxalate deposition in the kidneys (e.g., flank pain, hematuria), none of which are seen in this patient.

answers.content: Autoimmune destruction of pancreatic beta cells
answers.explanation_why: Autoimmune destruction of pancreatic beta cells occurs in type 1 diabetes mellitus, which may also present with acidosis (diabetic ketoacidosis), altered mental status, and vomiting. However, diabetic ketoacidosis is characterized by very high blood glucose levels and would not explain this patient's transaminitis.

question_text: A 65-year-old woman comes to the emergency department because of a 10-hour history of blurry vision and a 2-day history of fatigue and nausea. She has also had urinary urgency and discomfort while urinating for the past 4 days. She has type 2 diabetes mellitus and hypertension. She drinks 2–3 glasses of wine weekly. Current medications include captopril, metoprolol, and metformin. Her temperature is 37.5°C (99.5°F), pulse is 107/min, respirations are 14/min, and blood pressure is 95/70 mm Hg. Visual acuity is decreased in both eyes. The pupils are equal and reactive to light. The corneal reflexes are brisk. The mucous membranes of the mouth are dry. The abdomen is soft, nontender, and nondistended. Cardiopulmonary examination shows no abnormalities. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
content_preview: A 65-year-old woman comes to the emergency department because of a 10-hour history of blurry vision and a 2-day history of fatigue and nausea. She has also had urinary urgency and discomfort while urinating for the past 4 days. She has type 2 diabetes mellitus and hypertension. She drinks 2–3 glasses of wine weekly. Current medications include captopril, metoprolol, and metformin. Her temperature is 37.5°C (99.5°F), pulse is 107/min, respirations are 14/min, and blood pressure is 95/70 mm Hg. Visual acuity is decreased in both eyes. The pupils are equal and reactive to light. The corneal reflexes are brisk. The mucous membranes of the mouth are dry. The abdomen is soft, nontender, and nondistended. Cardiopulmonary examination shows no abnormalities. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
hint: This patient's urine dipstick would be positive for nitrite, leukocyte esterase, and glucose.
learning_objective: Recognize hyperosmolar hyperglycemic state (HHS).

answers.explanation_why: Posterior cerebral artery (PCA) stroke should be suspected in patients with visual changes, particularly if they have longstanding hypertension and diabetes mellitus, which are important risk factors for cerebrovascular accidents. However, occlusion of a PCA manifests with contralateral homonymous hemianopia that is often accompanied by headache and other possible neurological symptoms (e.g., vertigo, hemisensory loss, memory deficits). This patient presents with signs of dehydration and reduced visual acuity, and has no neurological deficits, making this diagnosis unlikely.

images.title: Posterior cerebral artery infarct
images.description:
A posterior cerebral artery infarct (left-sided here) typically leads to the following:
– Contralateral sensory loss (due to lateral thalamic involvement)
– Contralateral homonymous hemianopsia with macular sparing (because the macula receives collateral vascular supply from the middle cerebral artery)

answers.explanation_why: Anterior ischemic optic neuropathy (AION) typically presents with unilateral vision impairment. Visual field defects and an abnormal afferent pupillary light reflex would be expected. Its etiology is unknown, although hypertension and diabetes mellitus have been identified as risk factors. This patient's blurred vision and dehydration in association with a UTI suggest a different diagnosis.

Hypoglycemia can cause neuroglycopenic symptoms (e.g., blurred vision, weakness) and autonomic features (e.g., tachycardia, nausea). However, hypoglycemia usually manifests within minutes or hours rather than days. Moreover, in patients with type 2 diabetes mellitus, hypoglycemia usually occurs when the patient is on insulin therapy and has a relative overdose of insulin (e.g., in times of decreased food intake) or is taking certain medications such as insulin secretagogues (e.g., sulfonylureas, meglitinides) or nonselective beta-blockers. Biguanides (e.g., metformin) and selective beta-blockers (e.g., metoprolol) are not typically associated with hypoglycemia.

Posterior uveitis is a painless intraocular inflammation that manifests with floaters in the visual field and blurred vision. It can occur as a post-infectious autoimmune complication, in which case it generally occurs in association with reactive arthritis occurring 1–4 weeks after a UTI or enteritis. This patient's UTI began 4 days ago, which makes this diagnosis unlikely. Infectious uveitis is also unlikely since this condition would generally cause unilateral manifestations and would not explain the patient's other symptoms (e.g., fatigue, dehydration).

In a patient with type 2 diabetes mellitus (T2DM) who presents with a UTI, blurred vision and signs of dehydration should raise suspicion of a hyperosmolar hyperglycemic state (HHS). Patients with T2DM have a reduced insulin secretion capacity, which can lead to severe hyperglycemia in times of stress (infections, surgery, trauma) due to increased insulin demand. Hyperglycemia in turn leads to progressive volume depletion via osmotic diuresis. Patients present with polyuria, polydipsia, signs of volume depletion (dry mucous membranes, decreased skin turgor), hypotension, and even circulatory collapse. Hyperglycemia with subsequent osmotic diuresis also affects visual acuity, most probably due to swelling of the lens.

Serum glucose > 600 mg/dL would support the diagnosis of HHS. Treatment consists of aggressive IV electrolyte and fluid replacement as well as insulin for hyperglycemia, which should be given under vigilant monitoring of serum glucose and potassium.

Alcoholic ketoacidosis develops as a complication of recent binge drinking in malnourished patients with chronic alcohol abuse. The episode of binge drinking is usually followed by nausea, abdominal pain, and vomiting. The ensuing hypoglycemia and increased lipolysis promote the production of ketone bodies. Clinical and laboratory signs of alcohol-associated hepatitis and signs of alcohol withdrawal syndrome would be expected. Although patients with diabetes are particularly at risk of developing ketoacidosis if they consume alcohol without sufficient caloric intake from foods, it is more likely in type 1 DM. Moreover, this patient has no history of chronic alcohol abuse or liver disease, making this diagnosis unlikely.

Although diabetic retinopathy causes visual impairment, its onset is generally very gradual and patients are typically asymptomatic until the very late stages of the disease. Visual impairment may occasionally occur abruptly as a result of retinal detachment or vitreous hemorrhage, in which case patients report seeing floaters, flashes, or a curtain descending in their field of vision. This patient's blurred vision and dehydration in association with a UTI suggest a different diagnosis.

Diabetic ketoacidosis (DKA) would cause dehydration, blurred vision, and weakness but the onset and progression of DKA are generally much more rapid (< 24 hours) and other classic features of DKA such as abdominal pain and hyperventilation are absent, making this diagnosis unlikely. Furthermore, DKA typically occurs in patients with type 1 diabetes mellitus, which results in absolute insulin insufficiency. In the case of type 2 diabetes mellitus, DKA usually occurs in the advanced stages when the patient is completely insulin-dependent and beta-cell function has declined so much that endogenous insulin production is negligible.

question_text: A 25-year-old woman comes to the physician for the evaluation of blindness in her right eye that suddenly started 1 hour ago. She has no feeling of pain, pressure, or sensation of a foreign body in the right eye. She has a history of major depressive disorder treated with fluoxetine. The patient attends college and states that she has had a lot of stress lately due to relationship problems with her partner. She does not smoke or drink alcohol. She does not use illicit drugs. Her vital signs are within normal limits. Ophthalmologic examination shows a normal-appearing eye with no redness. Slit-lamp examination and fundoscopy show no abnormalities. A visual field test shows nonspecific visual field defects. An MRI of the brain shows no abnormalities. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
content_preview: A 25-year-old woman comes to the physician for the evaluation of blindness in her right eye that suddenly started 1 hour ago. She has no feeling of pain, pressure, or sensation of a foreign body in the right eye. She has a history of major depressive disorder treated with fluoxetine. The patient attends college and states that she has had a lot of stress lately due to relationship problems with her partner. She does not smoke or drink alcohol. She does not use illicit drugs. Her vital signs are within normal limits. Ophthalmologic examination shows a normal-appearing eye with no redness. Slit-lamp examination and fundoscopy show no abnormalities. A visual field test shows nonspecific visual field defects. An MRI of the brain shows no abnormalities. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
hint: This patient presents with unilateral blindness but has a normal ophthalmologic examination and MRI.
learning_objective: Recognize functional neurological symptom disorder.

answers.explanation_why: Malingering involves the falsification of manifestations of illness to attain a secondary gain such as financial compensation or time off from work. Though this patient has a normal ophthalmologic examination and MRI, there is no indication that she is intentionally falsifying her symptom of blindness or seeking secondary gain. In addition, patients who malinger typically avoid extensive diagnostic procedures.

Factitious disorder is a condition in which patients intentionally falsify manifestations of illness to assume the role of a sick patient (primary gain). Though this patient has a normal ophthalmologic examination and MRI, there is no indication that she is intentionally falsifying her symptom of blindness or seeking primary gain. Patients usually also have a history of multiple health care visits, are evasive in providing history, and often refuse access to prior medical records.

Central retinal artery occlusion can cause sudden, painless, monocular vision loss. However, this patient does not have characteristic findings of this condition on fundoscopy such as a pale, edematous retina, and a cherry-red spot near the fovea. In addition, she does not have risk factors for central retinal artery occlusion such as age > 60 years, atrial fibrillation, carotid artery atherosclerosis, or a history of stroke.

images.title: Central retinal artery occlusion
images.description: Left: lateral view of the right eye in longitudinal (sagittal) section. Depiction of an embolism in the central retinal artery causing retinal ischemia.Right: fundus photography of the right eye. Diffuse retinal ischemia causes edema in the inner retinal layers, manifesting as a gray-white discoloration of the retina (most markedly around the fovea; dotted circle). The fovea centralis, where the inner retinal layers are moved to the side, is not affected by edema. The underlying, well-vascularized choroid shines through, appearing as a cherry-red spot.

answers.explanation_why: Retinal detachment can cause sudden, painless, monocular vision loss. However, this patient does not have other typical manifestations of this condition such as prodromal symptoms (e.g., floaters, flashes of light), an afferent pupillary defect, or a fundoscopic examination that shows a retinal tear and a detached, gray, and freely floating retina that moves with eye movements.

Acute stress disorder is a condition that develops after a traumatic event and manifests with symptoms such as anxiety, intrusive thoughts, and negative mood that last between 3 days and 1 month. This condition does not cause somatic manifestations (e.g., blindness).

Somatic symptom disorder is a condition in which a patient has persistent somatic symptoms (e.g., headache, fatigue) that result in excessive thoughts and/or behaviors that disrupt daily life. This patient has monocular blindness. However, a diagnosis of somatic symptom disorder requires symptoms to persist for ≥ 6 months.

Optic neuritis can cause sudden, monocular vision loss. However, this patient does not have other typical manifestations of this condition such as periocular pain, an afferent pupillary defect, or a fundoscopic examination that shows hyperemia and swelling of the optic disc. In addition, optic neuritis typically causes optic nerve inflammation that is visible on MRI.

This patient has functional neurological symptom disorder (FND), a condition that manifests with neurologic symptoms that are inconsistent with neurologic disease. She presents with unilateral blindness but has an ophthalmologic examination and MRI that do not indicate an underlying neurologic etiology. FND is more common among young women who have a comorbid psychiatric condition and typically develops after an acute stressor (e.g., trauma, interpersonal conflict). The diagnosis of this condition requires thorough evaluation and ruling out of other possible diagnoses, such as retinal detachment in this patient with sudden, painless, monocular vision loss.

Patients with FND were classically considered to have la belle indifference, which refers to a lack of concern about their symptoms. However, la belle indifference is not specific to this condition; patients typically have distress and/or impairment.

question_text: A 43-year-old man comes to the physician for evaluation of a headache that he has had for the past 6 months. The patient reports that nothing helps to relieve the headache and that it is more severe in the morning. During the past 2 months, he has been unable to maintain an erection and he has had decreased sexual desire. There is no personal or family history of serious illness. His temperature is 37.0°C (98.6°F), pulse is 80/min, and blood pressure is 150/90 mm Hg. Examination shows an enlarged nose, forehead, and jaw and widened hands, fingers, and feet. His hands are sweaty. His serum glucose concentration is 260 mg/dL. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in diagnosis?
content_preview: A 43-year-old man comes to the physician for evaluation of a headache that he has had for the past 6 months. The patient reports that nothing helps to relieve the headache and that it is more severe in the morning. During the past 2 months, he has been unable to maintain an erection and he has had decreased sexual desire. There is no personal or family history of serious illness. His temperature is 37.0°C (98.6°F), pulse is 80/min, and blood pressure is 150/90 mm Hg. Examination shows an enlarged nose, forehead, and jaw and widened hands, fingers, and feet. His hands are sweaty. His serum glucose concentration is 260 mg/dL. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in diagnosis?
hint: This patient's headache, erectile dysfunction, decreased libido, hypertension, coarsened facial features, and diabetes mellitus (serum glucose concentration > 200 mg/dL) suggest acromegaly.
learning_objective: Recognize the clinical features of acromegaly, and choose the most appropriate initial diagnostic test.

answers.explanation_why: Random serum growth hormone (GH) measurement could detect an increase in GH concentrations in a patient with acromegaly. However, this test is not generally recommended because daily fluctuations in serum GH concentration limit its sensitivity.

This patient presents with symptoms of acromegaly, a condition most commonly caused by a pituitary adenoma that secretes growth hormone (GH). Excess secretion of GH stimulates IGF-1 synthesis, which in turn mediates the effects of GH. As IGF-1 is the most reliable indicator of acromegaly and normal concentrations rule out the diagnosis, measurement of serum IGF-1 concentration is the most appropriate initial step in diagnosis.

This patient presents with symptoms of acromegaly, which is caused by a pituitary adenoma in the majority of cases. Although an MRI is used to confirm the presence of a pituitary mass in patients with acromegaly, it is not the first step in diagnosis.

An oral glucose tolerance test is used to screen for hyperglycemia and diabetes. In patients with acromegaly, it is part of a test used to determine whether a patient is experiencing ectopic production of growth hormone. While this test is important in the overall workup of acromegaly, it is not the first diagnostic step.

Basal prolactin concentrations are evaluated in individuals with suspected hyperprolactinemia, which is often caused by prolactin-secreting pituitary adenomas. In men, symptoms include gynecomastia, hypogonadotropic hypogonadism (erectile dysfunction, loss of libido), and headache due to compression effects of the tumor. However, hyperprolactinemia does not cause skeletal changes or hyperglycemia.

A 24-hour urine cortisol measurement is performed to screen for increased cortisol concentrations in individuals with suspected Cushing syndrome. Both Cushing syndrome and acromegaly are most commonly caused by pituitary adenomas and manifest with hyperglycemia. However, the absence of further typical features of Cushing syndrome (e.g., proximal muscle weakness, central obesity) makes this diagnosis unlikely.

question_text: A 19-year-old woman comes to the physician because of a 3-month history of blurred vision upon awakening. When she wakes up in the morning, both eyelids are irritated, sore, and covered with a dry crust. Her symptoms improve after she takes a hot shower. She is otherwise healthy and takes no medications. She does not wear contact lenses. Recently, she became sexually active with a new male partner. Her temperature is 37.4°C (99.3°F). Both eyes show erythema and irritation at the superior lid margin, and there are flakes at the base of the lashes. There is no discharge. Visual acuity is 20/20 bilaterally. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?
content_preview: A 19-year-old woman comes to the physician because of a 3-month history of blurred vision upon awakening. When she wakes up in the morning, both eyelids are irritated, sore, and covered with a dry crust. Her symptoms improve after she takes a hot shower. She is otherwise healthy and takes no medications. She does not wear contact lenses. Recently, she became sexually active with a new male partner. Her temperature is 37.4°C (99.3°F). Both eyes show erythema and irritation at the superior lid margin, and there are flakes at the base of the lashes. There is no discharge. Visual acuity is 20/20 bilaterally. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?
hint: Chronic inflammation and scaling at the eyelid margins associated with eye irritation and visual abnormalities is consistent with a diagnosis of blepharitis.
learning_objective: Recognize blepharitis, and choose the most appropriate initial management.

answers.explanation_why: Triamcinolone, a topical glucocorticoid, is an agent of last resort for treating severe, treatment-refractory blepharitis. Topical steroids should be used carefully in this situation given the side effect profile, and patients should be evaluated by an ophthalmologist prior to initiation. This patient has a mild presentation and so a different management approach is more appropriate.

Culture and gram stain can be useful in diagnosing gonococcal conjunctivitis. While this patient has some risk factors (new sexual partner), gonococcal conjunctivitis is characterized by acute conjunctival hyperemia, purulent discharge, and periorbital swelling. Her symptoms are not consistent with gonococcal infection and a culture would not be helpful.

Oral doxycycline can be used in the treatment of severe or treatment-refractory blepharitis. It is not used as first-line treatment, especially for a mild presentation such as this one, because of the risk of adverse events, such as photosensitivity, gastrointestinal distress, and interference with oral contraceptives.

Topical erythromycin can be helpful in the treatment of severe or treatment-refractory blepharitis, or in the perioperative period for patients undergoing eye surgery. It is a broad-spectrum antibiotic that reduces the bacterial load around the eyelids, lashes, and conjunctiva. However, it is not an appropriate first-line therapy for mild blepharitis.

Mupirocin, a topical antibiotic, can be used to treat superficial community-acquired methicillin-resistant S. aureus (MRSA) infections. While Staphylococcus is commonly implicated in blepharitis, this patient has a mild presentation and so a different management approach is more appropriate.

Warm compresses, lid massage, and gentle lid cleansing are the cornerstones of therapy for mild blepharitis. As blepharitis is often a chronic condition with discrete episodes, ongoing lid hygiene is important in minimizing the frequency and intensity of flares.

question_text: A 70-year-old man comes to the emergency department because of acute loss of vision in the right eye over the last 24 hours. He has noticed progressive bilateral loss of central vision over the last year. During this time, he has had difficulty reading the newspaper and watching television. He has smoked 1 pack of cigarettes daily for 50 years. Ophthalmologic examination shows visual acuity of 20/60 in the left eye and 20/200 in the right eye. The pupils are equal and reactive to light. Tonometry shows an intraocular pressure of 18 mm Hg in the right eye and 20 mm Hg in the left eye. Anterior segment examination is unremarkable. Fundoscopic examination shows subretinal fluid and small hemorrhages with grayish-green discoloration in the macular area in the right eye, and multiple drusen in the left eye with retinal pigment epithelial changes. Which of the following is the most appropriate initial treatment for this patient's condition?
content_preview: A 70-year-old man comes to the emergency department because of acute loss of vision in the right eye over the last 24 hours. He has noticed progressive bilateral loss of central vision over the last year. During this time, he has had difficulty reading the newspaper and watching television. He has smoked 1 pack of cigarettes daily for 50 years. Ophthalmologic examination shows visual acuity of 20/60 in the left eye and 20/200 in the right eye. The pupils are equal and reactive to light. Tonometry shows an intraocular pressure of 18 mm Hg in the right eye and 20 mm Hg in the left eye. Anterior segment examination is unremarkable. Fundoscopic examination shows subretinal fluid and small hemorrhages with grayish-green discoloration in the macular area in the right eye, and multiple drusen in the left eye with retinal pigment epithelial changes. Which of the following is the most appropriate initial treatment for this patient's condition?
hint: This patient's acute, painless, unilateral loss of vision, together with his history of gradual loss of central vision and fundoscopic findings of subretinal hemorrhages and grayish-green retinal discoloration, are characteristic of wet age-related macular degeneration (AMD). Advanced age and smoking are risk factors for this condition.
learning_objective: Recognize wet age-related macular degeneration, and choose the most appropriate initial treatment.

answers.explanation_why: Etanercept is a tumor necrosis factor (TNF) inhibitor used in the treatment of systemic inflammatory illnesses like rheumatoid arthritis. It has no role in the treatment of wet AMD yet. However, there are ongoing investigations that test the use intravitreal TNF-alpha inhibitors for the treatment of vascular and neovascular retinal diseases (e.g., wet AMD).

Thermal laser photocoagulation (retinal photocoagulation) can be used to coagulate the abnormal choroidal neovascular membrane in wet AMD. However, laser photocoagulation can also damage the overlying retina and may result in a permanent blind spot. Newer options with better efficacy and safety profiles are available and should be attempted first.

Vascular endothelial growth factor (VEGF) inhibitors (e.g., ranibizumab, bevacizumab) delivered via intravitreal injection are the first-line treatment for wet AMD. These substances inhibit the growth of new, friable blood vessels in the choriocapillaris, which are prone to bleeding and leaking. Second-line treatment options for wet AMD include photodynamic therapy and laser photocoagulation. Smoking cessation, hypertension control, and antioxidant vitamin supplementation are recommended for both dry and wet AMD.

images.title: Exudative age-related macular degeneration
images.description: Fundus photography of the left eyeSubretinal and intraretinal hemorrhage (blue overlay) is visible in the region between the optic disc (blue circle) and macula (the macula is not visible, its approximate position is marked with an “M”). The light-yellow spots in the region of the macula indicate exudates and drusen (hatched overlay).Subretinal and intraretinal hemorrhages can result from pathological neovascularization of the choroid (CNV). The presence of CNV is required for the diagnosis of exudative/wet/neovascular macular degeneration.

answers.explanation_why: Macular translocation surgery involves detaching the macula from the posterior pole and attaching it to an area of intact retinal pigment epithelium. It can be used as a treatment of last resort for advanced wet AMD in patients with subfoveal neovascularization, edema, and hemorrhages if less invasive therapies have been unsuccessful.
Photodynamic therapy (PDT) is a second-line treatment for wet AMD that can be used for patients who fail first-line therapy.

question_text: A 22-year-old woman is brought to the emergency department because of a 1-day history of double vision and rapidly worsening pain and swelling of her right eye. For the past week, she has had nasal congestion, recurrent headaches, and a watery nasal discharge that became purulent 4 days ago. She started antibiotics for these symptoms but did not complete the course. She has asthma treated with theophylline and inhaled β-adrenergic agonists and corticosteroids. She appears to be in severe distress. Her temperature is 38.5°C (101.3°F), pulse is 100/min, and blood pressure is 130/80 mm Hg. Ophthalmic examination of the right eye shows proptosis and diffuse edema, erythema, and tenderness of the eyelids. Right eye movements are restricted and painful in all directions. The pupils are equal and reactive to light. There is tenderness to palpation over the right cheek and purulent nasal discharge in the right nasal cavity. The left eye shows no abnormalities. Laboratory studies show a leukocyte count of 12,000/mm^3. Which of the following provides the strongest indication for administering intravenous antibiotics to this patient?
content_preview: A 22-year-old woman is brought to the emergency department because of a 1-day history of double vision and rapidly worsening pain and swelling of her right eye. For the past week, she has had nasal congestion, recurrent headaches, and a watery nasal discharge that became purulent 4 days ago. She started antibiotics for these symptoms but did not complete the course. She has asthma treated with theophylline and inhaled β-adrenergic agonists and corticosteroids. She appears to be in severe distress. Her temperature is 38.5°C (101.3°F), pulse is 100/min, and blood pressure is 130/80 mm Hg. Ophthalmic examination of the right eye shows proptosis and diffuse edema, erythema, and tenderness of the eyelids. Right eye movements are restricted and painful in all directions. The pupils are equal and reactive to light. There is tenderness to palpation over the right cheek and purulent nasal discharge in the right nasal cavity. The left eye shows no abnormalities. Laboratory studies show a leukocyte count of 12,000/mm3. Which of the following provides the strongest indication for administering intravenous antibiotics to this patient?
hint: This patient presents with features consistent with right-sided orbital cellulitis. Her recent episode of acute bacterial rhinosinusitis (as evidenced by nasal congestion, headaches, cheek tenderness, and purulent nasal discharge) is the most likely primary source of infection.
learning_objective: Recognize signs specific to orbital cellulitis, and choose the strongest indication for administering intravenous antibiotics.

answers.explanation_why: Worsening ocular pain can be caused by a number of ophthalmic conditions, such as corneal abrasions, angle-close glaucoma, endophthalmitis, preseptal cellulitis, and orbital cellulitis. Therefore, ocular pain is a non-specific symptom that, as a sole clinical feature, is not an indication for the initiation of IV antibiotics.

answers.content: Edema, erythema, and tenderness of the eyelid
answers.explanation_why: Unilateral diffuse edema, erythema, and tenderness of the eyelid can occur in any condition that causes ocular infection or inflammation, e.g. blepharitis, bacterial conjunctivitis, endophthalmitis, preseptal cellulitis, and orbital cellulitis. Therefore, diffuse inflammation of the eyelid as a sole clinical feature is non-specific and not an indication to initiate IV antibiotics.

Leukocytosis is a nonspecific symptom of many conditions, including viral infections or inflammatory conditions, some of which do not require antibiotic treatment at all. In this case, the patient's leukocytosis could be a sign of sinusitis or preseptal cellulitis. Bacterial sinusitis and mild preseptal cellulitis can be managed with oral antibiotics. Because both orbital cellulitis and preseptal cellulitis manifest with fever, leukocytosis, and acute ocular pain and inflammation, usually in conjunction with acute rhinosinusitis, it is important to identify specific findings of orbital cellulitis, which always requires IV antibiotics.

Rapidly progressive pain with eye movements is a sign of inflammation of the orbital content. While fever, leukocytosis, and eyelid changes (e.g., edema, erythema, tenderness) can occur with both preseptal cellulitis and orbital cellulitis, painful ocular movements, ophthalmoplegia, reduced vision, and proptosis are specific for orbital cellulitis, a sight-threatening infection of the orbital contents. While preseptal cellulitis can be treated with oral antibiotics, the spread of infection to the orbital tissues requires prompt treatment with empiric IV antibiotics (vancomycin plus one of the following: ceftriaxone, cefotaxime, ampicillin/sulbactam, piperacillin/tazobactam).

See “Orbital cellulitis vs. preseptal cellulitis” table.

answers.content: Purulent nasal discharge and right cheek tenderness
answers.explanation_why: Purulent discharge in the right nasal cavity, right cheek tenderness, and a recent history of headaches and nasal congestion are characteristic of right maxillary sinusitis. Bacterial sinusitis is the most likely etiological factor of this patient's orbital cellulitis. However, oral (not parenteral) antibiotics alone would be appropriate to treat bacterial sinusitis.

Fever is a nonspecific symptom of many conditions, including viral infections or inflammatory conditions, some of which do not require antibiotic treatment at all. In this case, the patient's fever could be a sign of sinusitis or preseptal cellulitis. Bacterial sinusitis and mild preseptal cellulitis can be managed with oral antibiotics. Because both orbital cellulitis and preseptal cellulitis manifest with fever and acute ocular pain and inflammation, usually in conjunction with acute rhinosinusitis, it is important to identify specific findings of orbital cellulitis, which always requires IV antibiotics.

question_text: A 36-year-old woman with HIV infection comes to the physician because of a 3-day history of pain and watery discharge in her left eye. She also has blurry vision and noticed that she is more sensitive to light. Her right eye is asymptomatic. She had an episode of shingles 7 years ago. She was diagnosed with HIV 5 years ago. She admits that she takes her medication inconsistently. She wears contact lenses. Current medications include abacavir, lamivudine, efavirenz, and a nutritional supplement. Her temperature is 37°C (98.6°F), pulse is 89/min, and blood pressure is 110/70 mm Hg. Examination shows conjunctival injection of the left eye. Visual acuity is 20/20 in the right eye and 20/80 in the left eye. Extraocular movements are normal. Her CD4+ T-lymphocyte count is 90/mm^3. A photograph of the left eye after fluorescein administration is shown. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
content_preview: A 36-year-old woman with HIV infection comes to the physician because of a 3-day history of pain and watery discharge in her left eye. She also has blurry vision and noticed that she is more sensitive to light. Her right eye is asymptomatic. She had an episode of shingles 7 years ago. She was diagnosed with HIV 5 years ago. She admits that she takes her medication inconsistently. She wears contact lenses. Current medications include abacavir, lamivudine, efavirenz, and a nutritional supplement. Her temperature is 37°C (98.6°F), pulse is 89/min, and blood pressure is 110/70 mm Hg. Examination shows conjunctival injection of the left eye. Visual acuity is 20/20 in the right eye and 20/80 in the left eye. Extraocular movements are normal. Her CD4+ T-lymphocyte count is 90/mm3. A photograph of the left eye after fluorescein administration is shown. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
hint: This patient has AIDS (T-lymphocytes < 200/mm^3) and acquired an opportunistic eye infection. The photograph shows a corneal lesion that resembles the branches of a tree.
learning_objective: Recognize herpes simplex keratitis.

answers.explanation_why: Neurotrophic keratopathy (NK) is caused by nerve damage due to trauma, surgery, LASIK, or herpes infection. Given that this patient has a herpes infection, she is at risk of developing NK. However, NK manifests with decreased visual acuity, chronic dry eye, and the absence of eye pain. On slit lamp examination, spots on the corneal epithelium (early stage) or a circular/oval non-healing corneal ulcer (late stage) are visible. This patient presents with an acute 3-day history of eye pain, watery discharge, and a dendritic ulcer on examination, making NK an unlikely diagnosis.

Pseudomonas keratitis is more common in contact lens wearers and immunosuppressed patients and typically manifests with ocular pain, photophobia, epiphora, and decreased visual acuity. Although this patient presents similarly, slit lamp examination would show a central, white corneal ulcer, often accompanied by a hypopyon, rather than a dendritic ulcer.

images.title: Infective keratitis
images.description: Prominent blood vessels are visible on the sclera and conjunctiva (mixed injection; examples indicated by arrowheads). A dense corneal infiltration (white opacification; green overlay) is visible at the center of the cornea. The peripheral cornea shows slight opacification indicating corneal decompensation (blurred details of the iris). An accumulation of white-yellow exudate (hypopyon; blue overlay) consisting of inflammatory cells and/or bacteria/fungi within the anterior chamber can be seen completely covering the inferior aspect of the iris.These findings are consistent with infective keratitis, associated here with contact lens use.

answers.explanation_why: Herpes zoster keratitis can occur in immunocompromised individuals and manifests with a dendritic ulcer on slit lamp examination, like in this patient. However, herpes zoster keratitis typically manifests with a prodrome (fever, malaise) and vesicular eruptions on the ipsilateral forehead, eyelids, and nose. As this patient has no prodromal symptoms or skin findings, another diagnosis is more likely.

images.title: Herpes zoster keratitis
images.description: Slit-lamp photography, blue-light filter with fluorescein staining of a left eyeSuperficial patchy erosions, marked by the fluorescein staining, are visible in a geographic pattern on the surface of the cornea (examples indicated by red overlay).In combination with the cutaneous red lesions in the supraorbital region, the findings are typical for keratitis caused by herpes zoster ophthalmicus.

answers.explanation_why: Fusarium keratitis is a type of fungal keratitis that is more common in contact lens users and in immunocompromised individuals. This condition can also manifest with ocular pain, photophobia, and decreased vision. However, on slit lamp examination, fungal keratitis typically presents as an ulcer with a filamentous edge and an accompanying hypopyon.

Acute onset of unilateral eye pain and redness, watery discharge, photophobia, and blurry vision indicates HSV keratitis. Dendritic corneal ulcers that stain with fluorescein are characteristic of this condition. HSV is widespread and primary ocular infection can follow inoculation via direct contact. However, most ocular infections are caused by viral reactivation and replication, which can occur in immunocompromised individuals like this patient with AIDS. Topical antiviral therapy with trifluridine or ganciclovir is the treatment of choice for HSV keratitis.

See “Keratitis overview” table.

Although acanthamoeba keratitis is more common in contact lens users and also manifests with ocular pain, photophobia, epiphora, and decreased visual acuity, slit lamp examination would show a ring-shaped corneal ulcer rather than a dendritic ulcer. In addition, acanthamoeba keratitis typically develops slowly over the course of weeks, despite antibiotic treatment, and the onset of symptoms is not as rapid as in this patient.

images.title: Herpes simplex keratitis
images.description: Slit-lamp photography of the cornea (fluorescein stain)Dendritic lesions (red overlay) are visible on the cornea.This finding is characteristic of herpes simplex keratitis.

question_text: A 51-year-old man comes to the physician because of a 1-day history of progressive pain, excessive tearing, and blurry vision of his right eye. He first noticed his symptoms last evening while he was watching a movie at a theater. His left eye is asymptomatic. He wears contact lenses. He has atopic dermatitis treated with topical hydrocortisone. His temperature is 37°C (98.6°F), pulse is 85/min, and blood pressure is 135/75 mm Hg. Examination shows a visual acuity in the left eye of 20/25 and 20/40 in the right eye. The pupils are equal and reactive to light. The right eye shows conjunctival injection and an edematous cornea with a whitish exudate at the bottom of the anterior chamber. Fluorescein staining shows a round corneal infiltrate. Which of the following is the most appropriate pharmacotherapy?
content_preview: A 51-year-old man comes to the physician because of a 1-day history of progressive pain, excessive tearing, and blurry vision of his right eye. He first noticed his symptoms last evening while he was watching a movie at a theater. His left eye is asymptomatic. He wears contact lenses. He has atopic dermatitis treated with topical hydrocortisone. His temperature is 37°C (98.6°F), pulse is 85/min, and blood pressure is 135/75 mm Hg. Examination shows a visual acuity in the left eye of 20/25 and 20/40 in the right eye. The pupils are equal and reactive to light. The right eye shows conjunctival injection and an edematous cornea with a whitish exudate at the bottom of the anterior chamber. Fluorescein staining shows a round corneal infiltrate. Which of the following is the most appropriate pharmacotherapy?
hint: This contact lens wearing patient presents with unilateral progressive eye pain, eye redness, impaired vision, and excessive tearing. Together with a round corneal infiltrate and a hypopyon, this is highly suggestive of severe bacterial keratitis.
learning_objective: Choose the most appropriate pharmacotherapy for bacterial keratitis.

answers.explanation_why: Topical ketorolac and artificial tears are used to treat allergic conjunctivitis. This patient's atopic dermatitis increases his risk of developing allergic conjunctivitis. While allergic conjunctivitis also manifests with redness and excessive tearing, it is more common in young adults and most often manifests with itching and bilateral eye involvement. Furthermore, allergic conjunctivitis does not cause a corneal infiltrate or a hypopyon.

images.title: Allergic conjunctivitis
images.description: Right eye of an older adultConjunctival injection, massive chemosis, and tearing are visible. The eyelids appear edematous.This is the classical appearance of allergic conjunctivitis.

answers.explanation_why: Oral acyclovir is indicated in the treatment of herpes simplex keratitis (HSV keratitis) if topical treatment cannot be administered by the patient or has not been effective. While HSV keratitis can manifest with unilateral eye redness and pain, there are no findings on this patient's slit lamp examination suggestive of this condition (e.g., dendritic or geographic corneal lesion or vesicles). The presence of a round corneal infiltrate and a hypopyon indicates bacterial keratitis, for which oral acyclovir is not indicated.

images.title: Herpes simplex keratitis
images.description: Slit-lamp photography of the cornea (fluorescein stain)Dendritic lesions (red overlay) are visible on the cornea.This finding is characteristic of herpes simplex keratitis.

answers.explanation_why:
Empiric topical broad-spectrum antibiotics are the pharmacotherapy of choice in the management of bacterial keratitis. Since this condition can quickly lead to irreversible vision loss and corneal destruction, it is considered an ophthalmic emergency and treatment should be initiated immediately. Following identification of the responsible pathogen and about 2 days of antibiotic therapy, the patient may be additionally started on corticosteroid therapy in order to reduce excessive inflammation. Contact lens use is an important risk factor for bacterial keratitis and is most commonly associated with Pseudomonas aeruginosa.

See “Keratitis overview” table.

images.title: Infective keratitis
images.description: Prominent blood vessels are visible on the sclera and conjunctiva (mixed injection; examples indicated by arrowheads). A dense corneal infiltration (white opacification; green overlay) is visible at the center of the cornea. The peripheral cornea shows slight opacification indicating corneal decompensation (blurred details of the iris). An accumulation of white-yellow exudate (hypopyon; blue overlay) consisting of inflammatory cells and/or bacteria/fungi within the anterior chamber can be seen completely covering the inferior aspect of the iris.These findings are consistent with infective keratitis, associated here with contact lens use.

answers.explanation_why: Topical timolol and pilocarpine are indicated for the treatment of angle-closure glaucoma, which manifests with a sudden, unilateral onset of severe pain, ocular inflammation, and blurry vision. Darkness (e.g., in a movie theater) can trigger this condition since the pupil dilates and causes obstruction of the trabecular meshwork outflow tract. However, further signs and symptoms such as headache, nausea and vomiting, a mid-dilated, nonreactive pupil, and a hard eyeball on palpation are expected in patients with angle-closure glaucoma.

images.title: Angle-closure glaucoma
images.description: Slit-lamp photograph of anterior eye segmentProminent blood vessels are visible on the sclera and conjunctiva (mixed injection). The pupil is medium wide and its shape is slightly irregular. Iris details appear blurred due to corneal endothelial decompensation, leading to corneal edema.

answers.explanation_why: Topical prednisolone may be used to treat anterior uveitis, which can manifest with unilateral progressive eye pain, eye redness, decreased visual acuity, increased lacrimation, and hypopyon. However, pupils are typically constricted or irregular due to posterior synechiae formation. Additionally, a round corneal infiltrate is suggestive of bacterial keratitis. Topical prednisolone may be used to treat severe bacterial keratitis following identification of the pathogen and ∼ 2 days of appropriate therapy but is not the initial treatment of choice.

images.title: Hypopyon
images.description: Left eyeMassive mixed injections are present. Iris details appear blurred, which may result from corneal edema or inflammatory infiltration of the anterior chamber. The pupil (green overlay) is not completely round, which may be due to posterior synechiae. White material can be seen in the inferior region of the anterior chamber (hypopyon, blue overlay).The massive inflammatory process seen here could be due to, e.g., postoperative endophthalmitis or very severe uveitis.Dashed line: surrounds cornea

answers.explanation_why: Topical ganciclovir is indicated to treat herpes simplex keratitis (HSV keratitis), which typically also manifests with unilateral eye redness and pain. However, this patient has no typical findings of HSV keratitis on slit lamp examination (e.g., dendritic or geographic corneal lesion and vesicles). The presence of a round corneal infiltrate and a hypopyon indicates bacterial keratitis, for which topical ganciclovir is not indicated.

images.title: Herpes simplex keratitis
images.description: Slit-lamp photography of the cornea (fluorescein stain)Dendritic lesions (red overlay) are visible on the cornea.This finding is characteristic of herpes simplex keratitis.

question_text: A 45-year-old man comes to the physician because of a 1-day history of progressive pain and blurry vision in his right eye. He has difficulties opening the eye because of pain. His left eye is asymptomatic. He wears contact lenses. He has bronchial asthma treated with inhaled salbutamol. He works as a kindergarten teacher. His temperature is 37°C (98.6°F), pulse is 85/min, and blood pressure is 135/75 mm Hg. Examination shows a visual acuity in the left eye of 20/25 and the ability to count fingers at 3 ft in the right eye. Pupils are equal and reactive to light. A photograph of the right eye is shown. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
content_preview: A 45-year-old man comes to the physician because of a 1-day history of progressive pain and blurry vision in his right eye. He has difficulties opening the eye because of pain. His left eye is asymptomatic. He wears contact lenses. He has bronchial asthma treated with inhaled salbutamol. He works as a kindergarten teacher. His temperature is 37°C (98.6°F), pulse is 85/min, and blood pressure is 135/75 mm Hg. Examination shows a visual acuity in the left eye of 20/25 and the ability to count fingers at 3 ft in the right eye. Pupils are equal and reactive to light. A photograph of the right eye is shown. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
hint: The photograph shows conjunctival injection, accumulation of pus in the anterior chamber (hypopyon), and a round corneal infiltrate suggestive of an ulcer. In a patient using contact lenses, these findings indicate infective keratitis caused by a specific pathogen.
learning_objective: Recognize Pseudomonas keratitis in contact lens users.

answers.explanation_why: Staphylococcus aureus keratitis is the most common cause of bacterial keratitis among individuals who do not use contact lenses, and it can manifest with a painful decline in vision, conjunctival injection, hypopyon, and corneal infiltrates. However, this patient's history of contact lens use and the rapid progression of symptoms make another causative organism more likely.

Pseudomonas aeruginosa easily adheres to contact lenses and is the most common cause of bacterial keratitis among contact lens users. Risk factors include wearing contact lenses for an extended period of time and poor contact lens hygiene. Pseudomonas keratitis typically manifests with a rapid progression of symptoms, such as a decline in vision, eye pain and difficulties opening the affected eye, redness, photophobia, and foreign body sensation. If left untreated, pseudomonas keratitis can lead to corneal perforation within 2–5 days. Therefore, urgent treatment with topical broad-spectrum antibiotics (e.g., cefazolin with tobramycin or gentamicin) should be initiated. In addition, patients should be educated about contact lens hygiene (washing hands before touching the lenses, using fresh lens solution, not using saliva to wet lenses).

Acute angle-closure glaucoma manifests with an acute onset of monocular pain, blurred vision, conjunctival injection, and a cloudy cornea. However, it typically also leads to a mid-dilated, nonreactive pupil and a hard eyeball on palpation. Furthermore, glaucoma does not cause a hypopyon or a corneal infiltrate.

images.title: Angle-closure glaucoma
images.description: Slit-lamp photograph of anterior eye segmentProminent blood vessels are visible on the sclera and conjunctiva (mixed injection). The pupil is medium wide and its shape is slightly irregular. Iris details appear blurred due to corneal endothelial decompensation, leading to corneal edema.

answers.explanation_why: Herpes simplex keratitis (HSV keratitis) can manifest with ocular pain and blurry vision. However, HSV keratitis typically progresses over 1–3 days; unlike this patient's rapid development in one day. In addition, slit lamp examination in HSV keratitis would show the pathognomonic dendritic ulcer rather than the circular corneal infiltrate and hypopyon seen in this patient.

images.title: Herpes simplex keratitis
images.description: Slit-lamp photography with fluorescein stain and cobalt blue light filterDendritic lesions of the cornea appear green under cobalt blue illumination after fluorescein stain.These lesions are characteristic of keratitis caused by herpes simplex virus (HSV).

answers.explanation_why: Epidemic keratoconjunctivitis (EKC) is a highly contagious adenoviral infection that is spread commonly among groups of people (e.g., in kindergartens, nursing homes). EKC usually manifests with bilateral ocular pain, foreign body sensation, blurring of vision, conjunctival injection, and edema of the eyelids and conjunctiva. While corneal involvement with subepithelial infiltrates may develop after a few days, EKC affects both eyes and does not manifest with rapid onset of a circular corneal infiltrate and hypopyon.

Herpes zoster keratitis typically manifests with a prodrome of fever and malaise, which is followed by eye pain, impaired vision, and eruption of vesicles in the dermatomal distribution of the ophthalmic nerve (e.g., ipsilateral forehead, tip of nose). Corneal involvement is seen as a dendritic ulcer (branching pattern on the corneal epithelium) on slit lamp examination. This patient's presentation with rapid progression of ocular symptoms, the presence of a circular corneal infiltrate and hypopyon, with the absence of prodromal symptoms or skin findings is inconsistent with herpes zoster keratitis.

images.title: Herpes zoster keratitis
images.description: Slit-lamp photography, blue-light filter with fluorescein staining of a left eyeSuperficial patchy erosions, marked by the fluorescein staining, are visible in a geographic pattern on the surface of the cornea (examples indicated by red overlay).In combination with the cutaneous red lesions in the supraorbital region, the findings are typical for keratitis caused by herpes zoster ophthalmicus.

answers.explanation_why: Vernal keratoconjunctivitis (VKC) is a subtype of allergic conjunctivitis that manifests with seasonal itching and watering of both eyes and typically occurs in children. The pathognomonic sign of VKC is the presence of giant papillae on the tarsal conjunctiva (cobblestone appearance). A corneal erosion that resembles the shape of a shield (shield ulcer) may occur after several days of symptoms. Although this patient's history of asthma is a risk factor for the development of VKC, the acute onset and rapid progression of symptoms in a single eye, and absence of itching or giant papillae, make it an unlikely diagnosis in this patient.

images.title: Vernal keratoconjunctivitis 1/2
images.description: Ectropionized upper right eyelid of a young boyCobblestone-like lesions, called “giant papillae” (green outline), are visible on the tarsal conjunctive of the upper eyelid.This finding is consistent with vernal keratoconjunctivitis, a severe form of allergic inflammation in the eye. It may lead to further complications, including corneal ulcer.

images.title: Infective keratitis
images.description: Prominent blood vessels are visible on the sclera and conjunctiva (mixed injection; examples indicated by arrowheads). A dense corneal infiltration (white opacification; green overlay) is visible at the center of the cornea. The peripheral cornea shows slight opacification indicating corneal decompensation (blurred details of the iris). An accumulation of white-yellow exudate (hypopyon; blue overlay) consisting of inflammatory cells and/or bacteria/fungi within the anterior chamber can be seen completely covering the inferior aspect of the iris.These findings are consistent with infective keratitis, associated here with contact lens use.
