question_text: A 44-year-old woman comes to the physician because of pain and swelling below her right eye for the past 3 days. She has also had excessive watering from her eyes during this period. She has no history of serious illness and takes no medications. Her temperature is 37.0°C (98.6°F), pulse is 90/min, and blood pressure is 110/70 mm Hg. Examination shows erythema, tenderness, warmth, and swelling below the medial canthus of the right eye. There is purulent discharge from the lower lacrimal punctum on palpation of the swelling. The remainder of the examination shows no abnormalities. The discharge is sent for cultures. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?
content_preview: A 44-year-old woman comes to the physician because of pain and swelling below her right eye for the past 3 days. She has also had excessive watering from her eyes during this period. She has no history of serious illness and takes no medications. Her temperature is 37.0°C (98.6°F), pulse is 90/min, and blood pressure is 110/70 mm Hg. Examination shows erythema, tenderness, warmth, and swelling below the medial canthus of the right eye. There is purulent discharge from the lower lacrimal punctum on palpation of the swelling. The remainder of the examination shows no abnormalities. The discharge is sent for cultures. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?
hint: Pain, erythema, and swelling below the medial canthus of the right eye, along with purulent discharge from the lacrimal punctum, are consistent with acute dacryocystitis.
learning_objective: Recognize acute dacryocystitis, and choose the most appropriate antibiotic therapy.

answers.explanation_why: Dacryocystorhinostomy (DCR) is often indicated in patients who develop acute (or chronic) dacryocystitis, since the underlying cause is usually a nasolacrimal duct obstruction. However, DCR should be deferred until the active infection has subsided. Because this patient has features of active infection (erythema, warmth, purulent discharge from the lower punctum), DCR is not indicated at this time.

An obstructed nasolacrimal duct (NLD) is often the underlying cause of dacryocystitis. Lacrimal sac massage is effective in the management of congenital dacryostenosis, as the obstruction is caused by a persistent mucosal fold within the NLD. However, acquired dacryocystitis, which is often due to concretions, postinflammatory stenosis, or granulomatous diseases, cannot be treated with lacrimal sac massage.

Empirical IV ceftriaxone is indicated in patients with acute dacryocystitis involving systemic symptoms (i.e., fever) or complications (e.g., orbital cellulitis, cavernous sinus thrombosis). Clinical features of orbital cellulitis include exophthalmos, ophthalmoplegia, and diplopia, while those of cavernous sinus thrombosis include headache, periorbital edema, proptosis, and third, fourth, fifth, and/or sixth cranial nerve palsies.

Acute dacryocystitis is most commonly caused by gram-positive cocci (staphylococci, streptococci). Oral antibiotics with gram-positive coverage, such as amoxicillin-clavulanate, would be the first-line empirical therapy in a patient with mild to moderate acute dacryocystitis. As this patient has no features of severe infection, i.e., fever or features of orbital cellulitis (restricted, painful eye movement or diplopia), oral antibiotics are an appropriate treatment option. Warm compresses and NSAIDs are also used to decrease pain and inflammation.

images.title: Dacryocystitis
images.description: Right eye of a 54-year-old male patientA solid and immobile mass can be seen in the right fossa lacrimalis. There is no discharge of pus or other secretions.These findings are typical of dacryocystitis, which can result from chronic inflammation of the lacrimal sac and/or chronic stenosis of the tear duct.

answers.explanation_why: A CT scan of the orbit might be indicated for suspected orbital cellulitis and would show inflammatory stranding of the orbital fat and edema of the extraocular muscles. Patients with orbital cellulitis typically have a fever, exophthalmos, ophthalmoplegia, and diplopia.

question_text: A 55-year-old man comes to the physician because of a 3-month history of a painless, slowly enlarging nodule on his left eyelid. He reports heaviness of the eyelid and blurred vision in his left eye. Treatment with warm compresses has not resulted in improvement. One year prior, he had a similar lesion on his left eyelid that was treated with incision and curettage. Vital signs are within normal limits. Examination shows a solitary, rubbery, nontender nodule on the central portion of the left upper eyelid. The lesion is better visualized on eversion of the eyelid. The remainder of the examination shows no abnormalities. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?
content_preview: A 55-year-old man comes to the physician because of a 3-month history of a painless, slowly enlarging nodule on his left eyelid. He reports heaviness of the eyelid and blurred vision in his left eye. Treatment with warm compresses has not resulted in improvement. One year prior, he had a similar lesion on his left eyelid that was treated with incision and curettage. Vital signs are within normal limits. Examination shows a solitary, rubbery, nontender nodule on the central portion of the left upper eyelid. The lesion is better visualized on eversion of the eyelid. The remainder of the examination shows no abnormalities. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?
hint: Although a painless nodule that is better seen on eversion of the eyelid is characteristic of a chalazion (an obstructed and enlarged meibomian gland), this patient's recurrent, unilateral eyelid lesion should raise concern for a different underlying condition.
learning_objective: Recognize a potential eyelid malignancy, and choose the appropriate diagnostic procedure.

answers.explanation_why: Maintaining eyelid hygiene with bactericidal and antiinflammatory lid cleansers (e.g., hypochlorous acid solution) can help resolve the first episode of a chalazion and prevent bacterial superinfection. This patient's skin lesion, however, is recurrent and has not improved with conservative treatment (e.g., warm compression).

Cryotherapy is used for the treatment of a number of skin lesions that can manifest as recurrent, painless skin nodules (e.g., molluscum contagiosum, basal cell carcinoma, sebaceous carcinoma). Unlike this patient's skin lesion, molluscum contagiosum typically manifests with pearly, dome-shaped papules with central umbilication. Moreover, the diagnosis must be established prior to cryotherapy of a malignant eyelid tumor.

images.title: Molluscum contagiosum with concomitant conjunctivitis
images.description: Right eyeSeveral papules (green overlay) with central umbilication are visible on the eyelid and in the periocular region. Conjunctival injection is also present.These findings are consistent with molluscum contagiosum with concurrent conjunctivitis.

answers.explanation_why: Topical antibiotics are used to treat a hordeolum or bacterial superinfection of a chalazion, both of which can manifest with an eyelid nodule. Unlike the lesion seen here, these lesions are typically painful, erythematous, and purulent.

images.title: Internal hordeolum
images.description: Right eyeThere is local nodular erythematous swelling of the medial part of the right lower eyelid.This finding is consistent with an internal hordeolum (stye), an acute bacterial inflammation of a meibomian gland in the eyelid.

answers.explanation_why: A recurrent or persistent nodule on the eyelid may indicate an underlying malignancy that is masquerading as a benign chalazion. Sebaceous carcinoma of the eyelid is a rare malignancy, which usually manifests as a hard nodule on the eyelid that resembles a recurrent or persistent chalazion. Basal cell carcinoma (most common eyelid tumor) often manifests as a papule with rolled-up pearly borders while squamous cell carcinoma (second most common eyelid tumor) manifests as a small nonhealing ulcer with rolled-up borders. Untreated, these tumors can metastasize and/or invade surrounding structures, including the intracranial cavity. Hence, timely diagnosis with a biopsy of the lesion for histopathological examination is recommended in all recurrent chalazia or those that do not respond to treatment.

images.title: Chalazion
images.description: Left eye with ectropionized lower eyelidA localized, nodular swelling is visible on the medial portion of the ectropionized lower eyelid. Both bulbar and tarsal conjunctiva are hyperemic.This is the typical appearance of a chalazion.

answers.explanation_why: Watchful waiting can be considered in a patient presenting with a first episode of a chalazion, as some lesions resolve spontaneously. This patient, however, presents with a recurrent skin lesion that does not improve with conservative treatment (i.e., warm compressions) or invasive treatment (i.e., incision and curettage).

Mohs micrographic surgery is used for the excision of invasive tumors of the face (e.g., squamous cell carcinoma, basal cell carcinoma, sebaceous carcinoma). Diagnosis of a malignant eyelid tumor must be established prior to surgical treatment; the cause of this patient's lesion, however, is unclear.

images.title: Nodular basal cell carcinoma
images.description: A pink multinodular lesion with central indentation is visible adjacent to the medial canthus of the left eye and the lower eyelid. Dried crusts can be seen on the surface of the lesion, suggesting ulceration.This is the typical appearance of nodular basal cell carcinoma.

question_text: A 62-year-old woman comes to the physician because of increasing blurring of vision in both eyes. The patient says that the blurring has made it difficult to read, although she has noticed that she can read a little better when holding the book below or above eye level. She also requires a bright light to see objects more clearly. She reports that her symptoms began 8 years ago and have gradually gotten worse over time. She has hypertension and type 2 diabetes mellitus. Current medications include glyburide and lisinopril. When looking at an Amsler grid, she says that the lines in the center appear wavy and bent. The results of a funduscopic examination are shown. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
content_preview: A 62-year-old woman comes to the physician because of increasing blurring of vision in both eyes. The patient says that the blurring has made it difficult to read, although she has noticed that she can read a little better when holding the book below or above eye level. She also requires a bright light to see objects more clearly. She reports that her symptoms began 8 years ago and have gradually gotten worse over time. She has hypertension and type 2 diabetes mellitus. Current medications include glyburide and lisinopril. When looking at an Amsler grid, she says that the lines in the center appear wavy and bent. The results of a funduscopic examination are shown. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
hint: The patient's blurring of central vision and Amsler grid findings indicate central metamorphopsia. The fundoscopy showing multiple yellow areas at the macula confirms the diagnosis. Since these spots do not obscure the retinal vessels, the pathology must be below the nerve fiber layer (i.e., either a hard exudate or a druse but not a cotton wool spot). The clustering of spots around the macula, the absence of sharp margins, and the absence of other retinal pathology indicate that these spots are soft drusen rather than hard exudates.
learning_objective: Recognize age-related macular degeneration.

answers.explanation_why: Chronic central serous retinopathy (CSR) manifests with progressive blurring of vision and central metamorphopsia on Amsler grid testing. Hypertension is a risk factor for CSR. Fundoscopy would show elevation of the macula and a halo-like reflex around it; yellow/pale spots on the macula are not consistent with this diagnosis. Finally, CSR most commonly manifests in men between the ages of 20 and 45.

images.title: Acute central serous retinopathy
images.description: Fundus photography of a right eyeThe macula appears elevated (green overlay). Otherwise, the fundus is normal.Circle: optic disc

answers.explanation_why: Uncontrolled hypertension can result in hypertensive retinopathy, which can, in turn, cause progressive impairment of vision, as well as yellow/pale spots on the retina due to soft exudates or hard exudates. However, the spots in this patient are neither soft nor hard exudates. Moreover, in the case of hypertensive retinopathy, other features such as focal attenuation of the arterioles, arteriovenous nicking, and flame-shaped hemorrhage would also be present.

images.title: Grade IV hypertensive retinopathy
images.description: Fundus photography of the right eyeThere are cotton wool spots (blue overlay), narrow arterioles, and a retinal hemorrhage in close proximity to the papilla (hatched overlay). The papilla shows an unsharply demarcated margin nasally (blurry margin of the disc marked by dashed blue line, sharply demarcated margin marked by blue line), which is consistent with the diagnosis of papilledema.These findings are consistent with grade IV hypertensive retinopathy.M: Macula

answers.explanation_why: Patients with diabetes mellitus can develop diabetic maculopathy, a severe form of diabetic retinopathy that can cause progressive blurring of vision, central metamorphopsia on Amsler grid testing, and yellow/pale lesions (hard exudates) on fundoscopy. However, the region of retinal thickening at the macula (the dark red spot) would be larger than one disc diameter (due to macular edema). Also, other features suggestive of diabetic retinopathy, such as microaneurysms, dot and blot hemorrhages, and/or cotton wool spots, would usually be present in the remainder of the retina.

images.title: Proliferative diabetic retinopathy
images.description: Fundus photography of a right eyeNeovascularization (example indicated by arrowhead) is evident at the temporal superior arcade as tortuous vessels originate from the normal retinal vasculature. Microaneurysms and retinal hemorrhages appear as small red dots and larger red blotches (examples indicated by blue overlay). Hard exudates appear as yellow lesions (examples indicated by green overlay). The retinal veins show periodic dilatations (venous beading; example indicated by yellow overlay).The diagnosis of proliferative disease requires the presence of neovascularization.

answers.explanation_why: Cystoid macular edema can present with progressive blurring of vision, central metamorphopsia on Amsler grid testing, and yellow/pale lesions on fundoscopy. However, these spots would be hard exudates, unlike the drusen seen here, and they are typically arranged in a star-shaped configuration around the macula.

A senile cataract is an important cause of impaired vision in older individuals. However, a cataract that is severe enough to impair vision would obscure the fundus on ophthalmoscopy and cause a scotoma instead of central metamorphopsia on Amsler grid testing.

The incidence of presbyopia increases with age, and patients with presbyopia would have increased difficulty reading. However, the fundal changes seen in this patient are not consistent with presbyopia. Amsler grid testing that is performed in a patient with presbyopia (without applying correction) would result in blurring of all lines/spots instead of central metamorphopsia.

Doyne's honeycomb macular dystrophy can present with progressive blurring of vision, central metamorphopsia on Amsler grid testing, and drusen around the macula on fundoscopy. However, the onset of symptoms typically occurs in patients 20–40 years of age. Also, these drusen tend to be arranged radially, in contrast to the drusen in this patient, which are haphazardly arranged around the macula.

The presence of soft drusen near the macula is consistent with age-related macular degeneration (AMD). AMD is the most common cause of impaired vision in older adults in developed countries. Cardiovascular diseases such as hypertension increase the risk of AMD. Nonexudative AMD (dry AMD) is the most common type of AMD and leads to a slowly progressive central or pericentral loss of vision. Exudative AMD (wet AMD) makes up 10% of cases and is associated with retinal neovascularization, retinal hemorrhage, and/or loss of vision that progresses more rapidly.

images.title: Dry age-related macular degeneration
images.description:
Fundus photography of the left eyeThere are drusen (yellow deposits, area marked by dashed blue circle) and retinal pigment epithelium atrophy (blue overlay).Blue circle: optic disc
M: macula

question_text: A 46-year-old woman comes to the physician because of a 2-week history of diplopia and ocular pain when reading the newspaper. She also has a 3-month history of amenorrhea, hot flashes, and increased sweating. She reports that she has been overweight all her adult life and is happy to have lost 6.8-kg (15-lb) of weight in the past 2 months. Her pulse is 110/min, and blood pressure is 148/98 mm Hg. Physical examination shows moist palms and a nontender thyroid gland that is enlarged to two times its normal size. Ophthalmologic examination shows prominence of the globes of the eyes, bilateral lid retraction, conjunctival injection, and an inability to converge the eyes. There is no pain on movement of the extraocular muscles. Visual acuity is 20/20 bilaterally. Which of the following is the most likely cause of this patient's ocular complaints?
content_preview: A 46-year-old woman comes to the physician because of a 2-week history of diplopia and ocular pain when reading the newspaper. She also has a 3-month history of amenorrhea, hot flashes, and increased sweating. She reports that she has been overweight all her adult life and is happy to have lost 6.8-kg (15-lb) of weight in the past 2 months. Her pulse is 110/min, and blood pressure is 148/98 mm Hg. Physical examination shows moist palms and a nontender thyroid gland that is enlarged to two times its normal size. Ophthalmologic examination shows prominence of the globes of the eyes, bilateral lid retraction, conjunctival injection, and an inability to converge the eyes. There is no pain on movement of the extraocular muscles. Visual acuity is 20/20 bilaterally. Which of the following is the most likely cause of this patient's ocular complaints?
hint: This patient presents with features of hyperthyroidism (amenorrhea, hot flashes, diaphoresis, weight loss, tachycardia, hypertension), ophthalmopathy (bilateral exophthalmos, inability to converge the eyes, ocular pain), and a goiter, the combination of which suggests Graves disease.
learning_objective: Recognize glycosaminoglycan accumulation in Graves ophthalmopathy.

answers.content: Granulomatous inflammation of the cavernous sinus
answers.explanation_why: Idiopathic granulomatous inflammation of the cavernous sinus is seen in Tolosa-Hunt syndrome, a rare disease characterized by ocular pain and ophthalmoplegia due to pressure on the nerves adjacent to the cavernous sinus (cranial nerves III, IV, V, and VI). Although this patient also presents with ocular pain and features of ophthalmoplegia (inability to converge eyes, diplopia, difficulty reading), examination shows exophthalmos and features of hyperthyroidism, which are not associated with Tolosa-Hunt syndrome.

answers.content: Abnormal communication between the cavernous sinus and the internal carotid artery
answers.explanation_why: Abnormal communication between the cavernous sinus and the internal carotid artery (carotid-cavernous fistula) manifests with ocular pain, proptosis, and ophthalmoplegia (diplopia, inability to converge eyes) due to compression of the cranial nerves III, IV, V, and VI that lie adjacent to the cavernous sinus. However, other typical features of carotid-cavernous fistula, such as headaches, ocular bruit, and pulsatile tinnitus are absent in this patient, and is not associated with the patient's hyperthyroidism.

Accumulation of glycosaminoglycans (GAG) in the orbital tissues is one of the main causes of Graves ophthalmopathy. Thyroid-stimulating hormone (TSH) receptors are expressed in the thyroid gland as well as the intraorbital adipocytes and fibroblasts. TSH receptor antibodies in patients with Graves disease bind to the orbital TSH receptors and stimulate orbital fibroblasts to secrete GAG and adipocytes to proliferate. GAGs are hyperosmolar, drawing intracellular/intravascular fluid out into the interstitial space and causing edema of the orbital contents. GAG accumulation, edema, and increased adipocytes increase the orbital pressure and push the globe forwards, causing exophthalmos, compression of the extraocular muscles, ophthalmoplegia (inability to converge eyes, diplopia, difficulty reading), and ocular pain.

answers.content: Bacterial infection of the orbital contents
answers.explanation_why: Bacterial infection of the orbital contents (orbital cellulitis) manifests with proptosis, ophthalmoplegia, and ocular pain. Patients with orbital cellulitis typically have a fever, findings pointing towards a source of infection (e.g., rhinosinusitis, dacryocystitis, acute otitis media), and pain on extraocular movements. The presence of hyperthyroidism and goiter indicate a different pathogenesis of this patient's symptoms.

answers.content: Sympathetic hyperactivity of levator palpebrae superioris
answers.explanation_why: In patients with hyperthyroidism, the "staring look" is due to sympathetic hyperactivity of the levator palpebrae superioris. However, hyperthyroidism on its own does not increase intraorbital pressure and therefore does not cause exophthalmos, ophthalmoplegia (inability to converge eyes, diplopia, difficulty reading), and ocular pain as seen here. This patient presents with ocular features that are characteristically only seen in Graves disease.

question_text:
A 65-year-old man comes to the physician because of a 6-month history of muscle weakness. During this period, the patient has had low energy, intermittent nosebleeds, and a 5-kg (11-lb) weight loss. He also reports progressive hearing and vision problems. He has a history of pins-and-needles sensation, numbness, and pain in his feet. Vital signs are within normal limits. Physical examination shows a palpable liver tip 2–3 cm below the right costal margin. There is nontender lympadenopathy in the groin, axillae, and neck. Laboratory studies show:

Hemoglobin
8.8 g/dL

Leukocyte count
6300/mm^3

Platelet count
98,000/mm^3

Erythrocyte sedimentation rate
70 mm/h

Serum

 Na^+

136 mmol/L

 K^+

3.6 mmol/L

 Ca^2+

8.6 mg/dL

 Creatinine
1.3 mg/dL

 AST
32 U/L

 ALT
36 U/L

 Alkaline phosphatase
130 U/L

 Lactate dehydrogenase
220 U/L

A serum protein electrophoresis exhibits a sharp, narrow spike of monoclonal IgM immunoglobulin. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
content_preview: A 65-year-old man comes to the physician because of a 6-month history of muscle weakness. During this period, the patient has had low energy, intermittent nosebleeds, and a 5-kg (11-lb) weight loss. He also reports progressive hearing and vision problems. He has a history of pins-and-needles sensation, numbness, and pain in his feet. Vital signs are within normal limits. Physical examination shows a palpable liver tip 2–3 cm below the right costal margin. There is nontender lympadenopathy in the groin, axillae, and neck. Laboratory studies show: Hemoglobin 8.8 g/dL Leukocyte count 6300/mm3 Platelet count 98,000/mm3 Erythrocyte sedimentation rate 70 mm/h Serum Na+ 136 mmol/L K+ 3.6 mmol/L Ca2+ 8.6 mg/dL Creatinine 1.3 mg/dL AST 32 U/L ALT 36 U/L Alkaline phosphatase 130 U/L Lactate dehydrogenase 220 U/L A serum protein electrophoresis exhibits a sharp, narrow spike of monoclonal IgM immunoglobulin. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
hint: A bone marrow biopsy in this patient would show intranuclear inclusions of IgM deposits in plasma cells, also known as Dutcher bodies.
learning_objective: Recognize Waldenstrom macroglobulinemia.

answers.explanation_why: Chronic lymphocytic leukemia (CLL) primarily occurs in older patients (> 70 years) and could explain this patient's fatigue, weight loss, generalized painless lymphadenopathy, anemia, thrombocytopenia, hyperviscosity syndrome (as indicated by progressive vision and hearing loss), and hepatomegaly. However, CLL is associated with further features, such as lymphocytosis, a history of recurrent infections (e.g., necrotic erysipelas, candidiasis, and/or herpes zoster), and polyclonal gammopathy (i.e., broad-based peak representing a polyclonal increase in immunoglobulins) rather than monoclonal gammopathy (i.e., single spike of monoclonal IgM immunoglobulin).

Hairy cell leukemia affects middle-aged men and causes anemia and thrombocytopenia. However, B symptoms and lymphadenopathy are typically absent. Also, usually massive splenomegaly dominates, recurrent infections occur (due to leukopenia), and the B cells do not lead to monoclonal protein production.

Multiple myeloma (MM) can manifest with weight loss, fatigue, hyperviscosity syndrome (as indicated by progressive vision and hearing loss), and bleeding susceptibility along with a monoclonal spike on electrophoresis in older individuals. However, enlarged lymph nodes are not a typical finding in MM. Moreover, this condition is typically associated with excess production of IgG or IgA, not IgM. In addition, the CRAB symptoms (hypercalcemia, renal disease, anemia, and bone lesions) are classically present to varying degrees. This patient is normocalcemic with adequate renal function and has not reported any bone pain, making MM a less likely diagnosis.

Waldenstrom macroglobulinemia is an indolent type of non-Hodgkin lymphoma that is caused by abnormal production of IgM antibodies by monoclonal plasma cells. This condition usually manifests in older patients with impaired platelet function (nosebleeds), anemia, and mild thrombocytopenia, progressive neuropathy (history of pain and numbness in the feet, muscle weakness), and hyperviscosity syndrome (vision and hearing loss). Lymph node enlargement, as well as increased erythrocyte sedimentation rate, lactate dehydrogenase, and alkaline phosphatase can also be present. Serum protein electrophoresis demonstrating a dense, monoclonal IgM band is essential for diagnosis. Treatment includes administration of CD20 antibodies (e.g., rituximab) and plasmapheresis in case of hyperviscosity syndrome.

Hyperviscosity syndrome is present in about 30% of patients with Waldenstrom macroglobulinemia. This condition is not caused by an increase in hematocrit but rather from the clumping effects induced by the pathologically elevated serum IgM concentrations (i.e., IgM act as cold agglutinins).

This patient's age (> 45 years old) and abnormal production of monoclonal immunoglobulins are consistent with monoclonal gammopathy of undetermined significance (MGUS). However, MGUS is, by definition, not associated with any accompanying clinical symptoms.

Mantle cell lymphoma also affects older males (65–70 years) and causes painless, generalized lymphadenopathy, hepatomegaly, increased lactate dehydrogenase, and constitutional symptoms. However, mantle cell lymphoma is usually also associated with extensive splenomegaly and gastrointestinal discomfort and pain due to stomach and colon involvement. Simultaneous vision and hearing changes are not typically seen and monoclonal proliferation is very rare. Although this condition cannot be ruled out completely in this case, another option is much more likely.

question_text: A 32-year-old man comes to the emergency department for acute pain in the left eye. He reports having awoken in the morning with a foreign body sensation. He had forgotten to remove his contact lenses before going to sleep. After removing the contact lenses, he experienced immediate pain, discomfort, and watering of the left eye. He reports that the foreign body sensation persists and that rinsing with water has not improved the pain. He has been wearing contact lenses for 4 years and occasionally forgets to remove them at night. He has no history of serious medical illness. On examination, the patient appears distressed with pain and photophobia in the left eye. Administration of a topical anesthetic relieves the pain. Visual acuity is 20/30 in both eyes. Ocular motility and pupillary response are normal. Corneal reflex is normal and symmetric in both eyes. Which of the following is most likely to establish the diagnosis in this patient?
content_preview: A 32-year-old man comes to the emergency department for acute pain in the left eye. He reports having awoken in the morning with a foreign body sensation. He had forgotten to remove his contact lenses before going to sleep. After removing the contact lenses, he experienced immediate pain, discomfort, and watering of the left eye. He reports that the foreign body sensation persists and that rinsing with water has not improved the pain. He has been wearing contact lenses for 4 years and occasionally forgets to remove them at night. He has no history of serious medical illness. On examination, the patient appears distressed with pain and photophobia in the left eye. Administration of a topical anesthetic relieves the pain. Visual acuity is 20/30 in both eyes. Ocular motility and pupillary response are normal. Corneal reflex is normal and symmetric in both eyes. Which of the following is most likely to establish the diagnosis in this patient?
hint: Eye pain, excessive tearing, photophobia, and foreign body sensation that appear acutely after the removal of an overworn contact lens are suggestive of a corneal abrasion. Although visual acuity is preserved in corneal abrasion, this patient has a previous history of wearing contact lenses and decreased visual acuity in both eyes, suggesting a refractive error.
learning_objective: Recognize corneal abrasion, and choose the most appropriate diagnostic study.

answers.explanation_why: Fluorescein examination is the test of choice for identifying a corneal abrasion. Corneal abrasions are defects in the corneal epithelium that often occur secondary to corneal trauma. Removal of contact lenses after wearing them overnight is likely to have caused a corneal abrasion in this patient. Fluorescein dye specifically stains the epithelial defects, making them easily identifiable on slit lamp, ophthalmoscopic, or Wood lamp examination. In addition, the conjunctival surface of the eyelids should be examined to rule out a foreign body such as a retained contact lens. In corneal abrasion, photophobia can be attributed to spastic miosis resulting from the trigeminal sensation of the cornea.

images.title: Corneal abrasion highlighted by fluorescein staining
images.description: Slit-lamp photography of the left eye with fluorescein stainingA small area of green staining (black arrow) confirms a corneal abrasion. Significant conjunctival injection is also visible.

answers.explanation_why: Ocular ultrasonography can visualize structures in the back of the eye, especially when examination of the fundus cannot be performed due to opacities in the anterior segment (e.g., bacterial keratitis, dense cataracts), which is, however, not the case here. Abnormalities that can be detected on ultrasound include retinal detachments and vitreous hemorrhage. This patient does not complain of flashes of light, floaters, or sudden loss of vision to suggest any of these pathologies.

Gonioscopy is useful in diagnosing acute angle closure glaucoma. Patients would typically present with severe ocular pain that does not resolve on the application of a topical anesthetic. Examination would show a mid-fixed dilated pupil and conjunctival injection. As this patient has a normal pupillary exam and ocular pain that resolved with the administration of an anesthetic, glaucoma is an unlikely diagnosis.

A CT scan of the orbit is used to evaluate for an intraocular foreign body and/or an open globe injury. While patients with an intraocular foreign body or an open globe injury typically present with pain, decreased visual acuity of the affected eye, not both eyes, is also expected. Patients with an open globe injury usually have additional findings of an irregular pupil and a relative afferent pupillary defect. In addition, this patient has no history to suggest blunt or penetrating ocular trauma.

Ocular discharge cultures may be useful in patients with acute bacterial conjunctivitis or bacterial keratitis. Both of these conditions can occur in contact lens wearers secondary to inadequate contact lens hygiene. Bacterial conjunctivitis and keratitis manifest with tearing and foreign body sensation. However, severe purulent discharge and conjunctival injection are also seen in bacterial conjunctivitis. In keratitis, the visual acuity of the affected eye is decreased and, if severe, corneal edema and hypopyon would be present.

images.title: Bacterial conjunctivitis
images.description: Left eyeThere is massive conjunctival injection (hyperemia) and purulent discharge, especially visible in the medial corner of the eye and the margin of the lower lid.This is the characteristic appearance of bacterial conjunctivitis.

question_text: A 63-year-old woman comes to the emergency department because of a 1-day history of sudden blurring and darkening of her vision in the right eye. Upon waking up in the morning, she suddenly started seeing multiple dark streaks. She was diagnosed with type 2 diabetes mellitus at her last health maintenance examination 20 years ago. Her only medication is sumatriptan. She has smoked one pack of cigarettes daily for 40 years. Her vital signs are within normal limits. Ophthalmologic examination shows visual acuity of 20/40 in the left eye and 20/100 in the right eye. The fundus is obscured and difficult to visualize on fundoscopic examination of the right eye. The red reflex is diminished on the right. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
content_preview: A 63-year-old woman comes to the emergency department because of a 1-day history of sudden blurring and darkening of her vision in the right eye. Upon waking up in the morning, she suddenly started seeing multiple dark streaks. She was diagnosed with type 2 diabetes mellitus at her last health maintenance examination 20 years ago. Her only medication is sumatriptan. She has smoked one pack of cigarettes daily for 40 years. Her vital signs are within normal limits. Ophthalmologic examination shows visual acuity of 20/40 in the left eye and 20/100 in the right eye. The fundus is obscured and difficult to visualize on fundoscopic examination of the right eye. The red reflex is diminished on the right. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
hint: This patient's 20-year history of untreated type 2 diabetes mellitus likely led to proliferative diabetic retinopathy (PDR).
learning_objective: Recognize vitreous hemorrhage in diabetic retinopathy.

answers.explanation_why: Central retinal vein occlusion (CRVO) may manifest with sudden, painless vision loss. However, examination would show engorged vasculature in the fundus, papilledema, macular edema, and intraretinal hemorrhages, not an obscured fundus. Moreover, CRVO is often associated with a relative afferent pupillary defect, rather than a diminished red reflex.

images.title: Central retinal vein occlusion
images.description: Fundus photography of a right eyeMultiple punctual hemorrhages in every quadrant of the retina and flame-shaped hemorrhages in the peripapillary and perivascular region are present (examples marked by blue overlay), as are markedly dilated tortuous veins (example framed by white lines) and mild disk edema (blurry margin of the disc marked by dashed blue line, sharply demarcated margin marked by blue line).This is the classic appearance of central retinal vein occlusion.M: Macula

answers.explanation_why: Central retinal artery occlusion may also manifest with sudden, painless vision loss. However, fundoscopic examination would show a red reflex and allow for a view of the posterior pole, demonstrating a characteristic cherry-red spot and area of retinal whitening from retinal ischemia.

images.title: Central retinal artery occlusion
images.description: Left: lateral view of the right eye in longitudinal (sagittal) section. Depiction of an embolism in the central retinal artery causing retinal ischemia.Right: fundus photography of the right eye. Diffuse retinal ischemia causes edema in the inner retinal layers, manifesting as a gray-white discoloration of the retina (most markedly around the fovea; dotted circle). The fovea centralis, where the inner retinal layers are moved to the side, is not affected by edema. The underlying, well-vascularized choroid shines through, appearing as a cherry-red spot.

answers.explanation_why: Cataracts can cause painless vision loss and are also associated with chronic diabetes mellitus. An advanced cataract can potentially cause an absent red reflex and difficult fundoscopic examination, however, this would not be an acute process unless associated with trauma.

images.title: Cataract
images.description:
Slit-lamp photograph of a left eyeThe pupil is dilated. The lens (solid green overlay) appears cloudy and yellow.This is the typical appearance of cataracts.Dashed lines: optical path from the slit-lamp to the eye
Hatched green overlay: optical cross-section of the cornea, produced by the light of the slit-lamp

answers.explanation_why: Retinal detachment can occur secondary to proliferative diabetic retinopathy and can cause floaters and painless vision loss. Although examination may sometimes reveal an absent red reflex, fundoscopic examination would show a pale area of detached retina, with either subtle or marked elevation depending on the degree of detachment.

images.title: Tractional retinal detachment in proliferative diabetic retinopathy
images.description: Fundus photography of the left eyeFibrovascular proliferation (green overlay) obscures the optic disc (dashed circle) and can be seen extending along the retinal vasculature in fibrovascular strands. This has resulted in tractional retinal detachment (blue overlay). Multiple retinal hemorrhages can also be seen (arrowheads).These findings are characteristic of severe proliferative diabetic retinopathy.M: macula; N: nasal; T: temporal

answers.explanation_why: Acute anterior ischemic optic neuropathy (AION) can manifest with sudden painless vision loss from the occlusion of blood vessels that supply the optic nerve. However, acute AION would not explain this patient's obscured fundus; an edematous, poorly defined, and pale (or hyperemic) optic disc would be expected.

images.title: Papilledema in non-arteritic anterior ischemic optic neuropathy (NAION)
images.description: Fundus photography of a right eyeThe optic disc (dashed circle) shows blurred margins and radial bleedings (arrowheads). The retinal veins are dilated and tortuous (examples indicated by white lines). In addition, the macula (M) shows pigment alterations (blue overlay).This is the typical appearance of papilledema, in this case caused by NAION. Papilledema can also be caused by arteritic anterior ischemic optic neuropathy (AAION), inflammatory processes, or elevated intracranial pressure.Hatched overlay: artifacts

answers.explanation_why:
Vitreous hemorrhage is a complication of PDR in which friable vessels of the neovascularized retina bleed, resulting in sudden, painless vision loss or visual obscuration with haze or floaters. This patient's fundus is difficult to visualize, and examination demonstrates diminished red reflex in the right eye, which is consistent with opacifying blood in the vitreous. The treatment of choice for vitreous hemorrhage is a vitrectomy.

Annual eye exams are recommended for patients with any degree of diabetic retinopathy to monitor for complications such as vitreous hemorrhage and retinal detachment. Biennial examinations can be considered for patients with normal eye findings.

images.title: Vitreous hemorrhage
images.description: Fundus photography of the left eyeFundus details appear blurred. Dark red flowing patches of blood (green overlay) are visible at the temporal edge and in the central fundus, completely covering the aspect of the retina.This is the typical appearance of a vitreous hemorrhage.White circle: optic disc

question_text: A 45-year-old woman comes to the physician because of a 6-month history of progressive irritability, palpitations, heat intolerance, frequent bowel movements, and a 6.8-kg (15-lb) weight loss. She also has a smooth, uniformly enlarged mass at the front of her neck and protuberant eyes with lid retraction. Laboratory investigations show undetectable levels of thyroid stimulating hormone (TSH), elevated levels of free T_3 and T_4, and a raised titer of TSH receptor autoantibodies (TRAbs). Therapy is initiated with radioactive iodine-131 (I^131). This patient is at greatest risk for which of the following complications?
content_preview: A 45-year-old woman comes to the physician because of a 6-month history of progressive irritability, palpitations, heat intolerance, frequent bowel movements, and a 6.8-kg (15-lb) weight loss. She also has a smooth, uniformly enlarged mass at the front of her neck and protuberant eyes with lid retraction. Laboratory investigations show undetectable levels of thyroid stimulating hormone (TSH), elevated levels of free T3 and T4, and a raised titer of TSH receptor autoantibodies (TRAbs). Therapy is initiated with radioactive iodine-131 (I131). This patient is at greatest risk for which of the following complications?
hint: Thyrotoxicosis with painless goiter, ophthalmopathy (e.g., exophthalmos, lid retraction), and elevated TRAb titers are diagnostic of Graves disease.
learning_objective: Recognize Graves disease, and recall complications of radioactive iodine therapy.

answers.explanation_why: Radioiodine therapy for well-differentiated thyroid cancer utilizes higher doses of I^131 and is therefore associated with an increased risk of gonadal dysfunction. The dose of I^131 that is used to treat Graves disease is typically not large enough to cause gonadal dysfunction.
Hypoparathyroidism frequently occurs following thyroidectomy (which can also be used to treat Graves disease), but hypoparathyroidism following radioiodine therapy is quite rare.
Radiation thyroiditis occurs in ≤ 1% of patients treated with radioiodine. A different complication is much more likely.

Thionamides (e.g., propylthiouracil, methimazole), which can be used to treat Graves disease, are frequently associated with hepatotoxicity (up to 30% of cases). With radioiodine therapy, however, the risk of hepatotoxicity is extremely low; only a handful of cases of radioiodine-induced hepatotoxicity have ever been reported.

In up to 40% of patients with Graves disease, radioactive iodine ablation (RAIA) will cause the onset or exacerbation of Graves ophthalmopathy. The exact underlying mechanism is not understood, but it has been hypothesized to involve the release of thyroid autoantigens with epitopes similar to those of retro-orbital connective tissue antigens, and a TSH surge due to therapy-induced hypothyroidism. The TSH surge possibly induces the production of thyrocyte autoantigens and the proliferation of retro-orbital connective tissue (because retro-orbital preadipocytes in patients with Graves disease can express TSH receptors). An exacerbation of Graves ophthalmopathy can be prevented with glucocorticoid therapy for 6–12 weeks after radioiodine therapy.

Most patients with Graves disease become hypothyroid after RAIA and require life-long thyroid hormone replacement.

images.title: Graves ophthalmopathy
images.description: The eyelids are edematous and there is conjunctival injection. The superior sclerae are visible (Dalrymple sign) due to retraction of the upper eyelids.The combination of these signs is typical for Graves ophthalmopathy.

answers.explanation_why: Agranulocytosis is a life-threatening complication associated with thionamide drugs (e.g., propylthiouracil, methimazole), which can be used to treat Graves disease. High doses of I^131 such as those used to treat well-differentiated thyroid cancer can also rarely cause agranulocytosis as a result of bone marrow suppression. However, the dose of I^131 used for radioiodine therapy in Graves disease is not large enough to cause bone marrow suppression.

Vocal cord palsy due to recurrent laryngeal nerve damage frequently occurs following thyroidectomy (which can also be used to treat Graves disease), but vocal cord palsy following radioiodine therapy is extremely rare and has only been reported in a handful of cases to date.

A few retrospective studies on cohorts of hyperthyroid patients have shown an increased relative risk of developing thyroid cancer following radioiodine therapy. The younger the patient at the time of receiving radioiodine therapy, the greater the patient's lifetime risk of developing thyroid carcinoma. However, the absolute risk of thyroid carcinoma remains quite low.

question_text: A 71-year-old woman comes to the physician because of sudden loss of vision in her right eye for 15 minutes that morning, which subsided spontaneously. Over the past 4 months, she has had fatigue, a 4-kg (8.8-lb) weight loss, and has woken up on several occasions at night covered in sweat. She has had frequent headaches and pain in her jaw while chewing for the past 2 months. She does not smoke or drink alcohol. Her temperature is 37.5°C (99.5°F), pulse is 88/min, and blood pressure is 118/78 mm Hg. Examination shows a visual acuity of 20/25 in the left eye and 20/30 in the right eye. The pupils are equal and reactive. There is no swelling of the optic discs. Her hemoglobin concentration is 10.5 g/dL, platelet count is 420,000/mm^3, and erythrocyte sedimentation rate is 69 mm/h. The patient's condition puts her at greatest risk for developing which of the following complications?
content_preview: A 71-year-old woman comes to the physician because of sudden loss of vision in her right eye for 15 minutes that morning, which subsided spontaneously. Over the past 4 months, she has had fatigue, a 4-kg (8.8-lb) weight loss, and has woken up on several occasions at night covered in sweat. She has had frequent headaches and pain in her jaw while chewing for the past 2 months. She does not smoke or drink alcohol. Her temperature is 37.5°C (99.5°F), pulse is 88/min, and blood pressure is 118/78 mm Hg. Examination shows a visual acuity of 20/25 in the left eye and 20/30 in the right eye. The pupils are equal and reactive. There is no swelling of the optic discs. Her hemoglobin concentration is 10.5 g/dL, platelet count is 420,000/mm3, and erythrocyte sedimentation rate is 69 mm/h. The patient's condition puts her at greatest risk for developing which of the following complications?
hint: This woman is > 50 years old and presents with amaurosis fugax, jaw claudication, headaches, constitutional symptoms (night sweats, weight loss, fatigue), and a markedly elevated ESR, all of which suggest giant cell arteritis (GCA).
learning_objective: Recognize giant cell arteritis (GCA), and recall its complications.

answers.explanation_why: Giant cell arteritis (GCA) primarily causes inflammation of medium to large blood vessels. In rare cases, GCA can also cause coronary arteritis, which may manifest with myocardial infarction (MI). Although patients with GCA have a slightly elevated relative risk of MI compared to the general population, MI is a rare complication of this disease.

Approximately 10–20% of patients with GCA will have involvement of the thoracic aorta, which significantly increases the risk of thoracic aortic aneurysms and dissections. The median time between the diagnosis of GCA and thoracic aortic aneurysm is about 10 years. Some medical centers use serial chest x-rays or CT/MR angiography to screen for aortic aneurysms. However, routine screening for large vessel involvement is not generally recommended in patients with GCA because there is limited evidence that it positively affects patient outcomes.

Further complications of GCA include permanent vision loss (if left untreated) and cerebral ischemia (predominantly in the area of the posterior cerebral artery).

Rapidly progressive glomerulonephritis is a known complication of certain types of vasculitis, including granulomatosis with polyangiitis and microscopic polyangiitis. GCA, however, primarily causes inflammation of medium to large blood vessels and does not usually affect the kidneys.

Very close! You likely picked this option because branches of the internal carotid artery (e.g., the posterior ciliary arterial branches of the ophthalmic artery) are affected in amaurosis fugax and vision loss in GCA. However, symptoms in GCA are caused by inflammation of these smaller arteries, not stenosis of the large internal carotid artery, which is a rare complication of this condition. In addition, GCA is more commonly associated with the occlusion of branches of the external carotid artery (e.g., the temporal artery, resulting in headache).

Pulmonary hypertension can develop in diffuse systemic sclerosis, a condition that usually manifests with Raynaud phenomenon, cutaneous findings such as sclerodactyly, and inner organ involvement (e.g., dysmotility of the gastrointestinal tract, cardiac disease, renal disease). Because GCA involves medium to large blood vessels, the pulmonary vessels are not typically involved.

question_text: A 61-year-old man comes to the emergency department because of a 3-hour history of pain and redness of both eyes. He has new blurry vision and difficulty opening his eyes in bright surroundings. He has not had any recent trauma. He uses contact lenses daily. He had surgery on his left eye 6 months ago after a penetrative trauma caused by a splinter. His vital signs are within normal limits. Physical examination shows congestion of the perilimbal conjunctivae bilaterally. Visual acuity is decreased bilaterally. Ocular movements are normal. Slit-lamp examination shows a cornea with normal contours and leukocytes in the anterior chambers of both eyes. The eyelids, eyelashes, and lacrimal ducts show no abnormalities. Which of the following is the most likely cause of this patient's condition?
content_preview: A 61-year-old man comes to the emergency department because of a 3-hour history of pain and redness of both eyes. He has new blurry vision and difficulty opening his eyes in bright surroundings. He has not had any recent trauma. He uses contact lenses daily. He had surgery on his left eye 6 months ago after a penetrative trauma caused by a splinter. His vital signs are within normal limits. Physical examination shows congestion of the perilimbal conjunctivae bilaterally. Visual acuity is decreased bilaterally. Ocular movements are normal. Slit-lamp examination shows a cornea with normal contours and leukocytes in the anterior chambers of both eyes. The eyelids, eyelashes, and lacrimal ducts show no abnormalities. Which of the following is the most likely cause of this patient's condition?
hint: This patient has bilateral anterior uveitis, which typically manifests with bilateral eye pain and redness, photophobia, and perilimbal congestion and hypopyon on slit-lamp examination.
learning_objective: Recognize bilateral anterior uveitis, and recall its underlying autoimmune etiology.

answers.explanation_why: Reactivation of herpes zoster virus within the ophthalmic branch of the trigeminal nerve causes herpes zoster ophthalmicus, which manifests with anterior uveitis. However, this condition typically causes unilateral symptoms, not bilateral symptoms. Moreover, this patient lacks additional manifestations of herpes zoster ophthalmicus such as cutaneous symptoms (e.g., vesicular rash) and fever.

Sympathetic ophthalmia is an autoimmune reaction against retinal antigens that occurs days to years after a penetrating ocular injury or, less commonly, ocular surgery. Damage to the eye can sensitize the immune system to retinal antigens and subsequently cause bilateral granulomatous anterior uveitis. This manifests with bilateral eye pain, redness, and photophobia as seen in this case. Evidence of inflammation of the anterior chamber on slit-lamp examination is typical. This patient is at risk of bilateral blindness; treatment with glucocorticoids should be initiated immediately.

Infection of the cornea with P. aeruginosa causes bacterial keratitis, which manifests with blurry vision, eye pain, and redness. In addition, this patient's contact lens use is a significant risk factor for this condition. However, the absence of purulent discharge and corneal ulcers on slit-lamp examination make this diagnosis unlikely. Moreover, bacterial keratitis rarely manifests with bilateral anterior uveitis.

Impaired drainage of aqueous humor can cause angle-closure glaucoma, which manifests with sudden-onset blurry vision, eye pain, and redness. However, this condition typically causes unilateral symptoms, not bilateral symptoms, and does not typically cause hypopyon. Moreover, this patient lacks additional manifestations of angle-closure glaucoma such as frontal headaches, nausea, and vomiting.

Age-related denaturation of lens proteins results in the formation of cataracts, which cause blurry vision and reduced visual acuity. In some cases, cataracts can also cause photophobia. However, cataract formation is typically painless, insidious in onset, and manifests with clouding of the lens (not redness or hypopyon).

question_text: A 13-year-old boy is brought to the emergency department by his chemistry teacher 20 minutes after being involved in a laboratory accident at his school. During the accident, the boy's right eye was exposed to potassium hydroxide. He has severe pain in his right eye and reports difficulty keeping the eye open. The boy states he was wearing his prescription glasses when the accident occurred and that, immediately after the accident, his eye was irrigated thoroughly with cold tap water for approximately 5 minutes by the teacher. His temperature is 37.2°C (99°F), pulse is 98/min, respirations are 24/min, and blood pressure is 128/78 mm Hg. Ophthalmologic examination of the right eye shows erythema and blistering of the skin over the eyelid, with conjunctival congestion and excessive tearing in the eye. There is a partial thickness laceration above the right eyebrow. Further examination is impeded due to marked blepharospasm. Which of the following is the most appropriate initial step in management?
content_preview: A 13-year-old boy is brought to the emergency department by his chemistry teacher 20 minutes after being involved in a laboratory accident at his school. During the accident, the boy's right eye was exposed to potassium hydroxide. He has severe pain in his right eye and reports difficulty keeping the eye open. The boy states he was wearing his prescription glasses when the accident occurred and that, immediately after the accident, his eye was irrigated thoroughly with cold tap water for approximately 5 minutes by the teacher. His temperature is 37.2°C (99°F), pulse is 98/min, respirations are 24/min, and blood pressure is 128/78 mm Hg. Ophthalmologic examination of the right eye shows erythema and blistering of the skin over the eyelid, with conjunctival congestion and excessive tearing in the eye. There is a partial thickness laceration above the right eyebrow. Further examination is impeded due to marked blepharospasm. Which of the following is the most appropriate initial step in management?
hint: This patient's clinical features (ocular pain, conjunctival congestion, excessive tearing, marked blepharospasm), which appeared after exposure to a caustic chemical, indicate a chemical ocular burn.
learning_objective: Recognize chemical ocular burn, and choose the most appropriate initial management step.

answers.explanation_why: Immediate and thorough irrigation with sterile normal saline (e.g, via a plastic scleral lens) following an ocular chemical burn is the most important step to prevent permanent vision loss. Immediate irrigation initiated by first responders should continue for at least 30–60 minutes or until the pH of the eye has normalized. This process can sometimes take 2–3 hours for alkaline compounds such as potassium hydroxide because they are lipophilic and thus penetrate tissue more quickly. This patient has ongoing symptoms after just 5 minutes of irrigation. Continued irrigation in the emergency department should therefore begin immediately. Once irrigation is completed and the pH has normalized, broad-spectrum topical antibiotics should be administered.

Broad-spectrum topical antibiotics such as erythromycin ointment should be given to all patients with severe chemical ocular burns and should also be administered to this patient. However, another step is more urgent to prevent permanent ocular damage in this patient.

Topical steroids such as prednisolone acetate can help reduce acute inflammation of the eye after chemical injuries. However, steroids might have a negative impact on reepithelialization and increase the risk of secondary infection. Thus, they should be used with caution and for a limited amount of time only. Furthermore, another step is more urgent to prevent permanent ocular damage in this patient.

Intravenous analgesics such as morphine can be administered to patients with severe pain that is not relieved by topical and non-opiate analgesics. However, they are not typically required for chemical ocular injuries. Furthermore, another step is more urgent to prevent permanent ocular damage in this patient.

Immobilization of the eye is indicated in the event of a closed-globe contusion, which is commonly caused by blunt force trauma. Although this patient's eyebrow laceration suggests possible blunt force trauma, addressing the chemical burn to the eye should be the first step in management. Furthermore, crossed bandaging after a chemical ocular burn could increase the risk of a symblepharon, thus leading to further complications.

answers.content: Begin irrigation with weak acidic solution
answers.explanation_why: Theoretically, acidic solutions can neutralize the alkaline pH of potassium hydroxide. However, attempting to neutralize exposure to alkaline agents by irrigation with acidic solutions, and vice versa, is not recommended because the neutralization reaction releases heat, which can cause further damage to the eye.

question_text: A 16-year-old boy is brought to the physician by his mother because of a 2-day history of red, itchy, tearing eyes. He says that the left eye feels “swollen,” but it does not hurt and he can still see everything clearly. He spent the last couple of days at his cousin's house in the countryside but had to return home today as his cousin developed an upper respiratory tract infection. The patient has no history of serious illness and takes no medications. Family history is significant for rheumatoid arthritis in his mother. Immunizations are up-to-date. His temperature is 37.0°C (98.6°F), pulse is 82/min, and blood pressure is 110/70 mm Hg. Ophthalmic examination shows bilateral conjunctival injection with watery discharge and chemosis. There is also bilateral eyelid edema and a 2-mm long abrasion on his left upper eyelid. Visual acuity is 20/20 bilaterally. Fundoscopic examination shows no abnormalities. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
content_preview: A 16-year-old boy is brought to the physician by his mother because of a 2-day history of red, itchy, tearing eyes. He says that the left eye feels “swollen,” but it does not hurt and he can still see everything clearly. He spent the last couple of days at his cousin's house in the countryside but had to return home today as his cousin developed an upper respiratory tract infection. The patient has no history of serious illness and takes no medications. Family history is significant for rheumatoid arthritis in his mother. Immunizations are up-to-date. His temperature is 37.0°C (98.6°F), pulse is 82/min, and blood pressure is 110/70 mm Hg. Ophthalmic examination shows bilateral conjunctival injection with watery discharge and chemosis. There is also bilateral eyelid edema and a 2-mm long abrasion on his left upper eyelid. Visual acuity is 20/20 bilaterally. Fundoscopic examination shows no abnormalities. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
hint: Individuals with this condition often have concomitant rhinitis.
learning_objective: Recognize allergic conjunctivitis.

answers.explanation_why: Keratoconjunctivitis sicca (KCS) can cause bilateral conjunctival injection. However, KCS does not affect the eyelids and is a subacute or chronic condition, not an acute one. Moreover, KCS typically results in dry eyes (rather than excessive tearing) and blurred vision (due to corneal involvement).

Allergic conjunctivitis (AC) typically manifests with bilateral ocular itching, redness, and scant watery discharge, most commonly in young adults. AC is a hypersensitivity reaction against specific allergens (e.g., cat dander, pollen), to which this patient was likely exposed to in the countryside. Examination findings include diffuse conjunctival injection, chemosis, and eyelid edema. Additionally, eversion of the eyelid may show conjunctival papillae. Management of AC includes allergen avoidance, cold compresses, artificial tears, and topical pharmacotherapy (e.g., antihistamines). Systemic pharmacotherapy can be considered if nonocular symptoms are present.

See “Overview of conjunctivitis subtypes in children and adults” table.

images.title: Allergic conjunctivitis
images.description: Right eye of an older adultConjunctival injection, massive chemosis, and tearing are visible. The eyelids appear edematous.This is the classical appearance of allergic conjunctivitis.

answers.explanation_why: Bacterial conjunctivitis typically manifests with unilateral or bilateral diffuse conjunctival injection and thick, purulent discharge. Patients don't typically present with significant itching. Additionally, patients often present with significant eyelid erythema and pain, none of which is seen here.

Although episcleritis can manifest with the acute onset of bilateral ocular redness, tearing, and intact vision, eyelid edema is not consistent with this condition. Furthermore, in affected patients, hyperemia is localized to the globe and the palpebral conjunctiva appears normal; episcleral injection, not conjunctival injection, would be present.

In a minority of cases, episcleritis may be associated with underlying systemic illnesses such as rheumatoid arthritis (RA), which this patient has a family history. However, he has no other features of RA.

Viral conjunctivitis typically manifests with conjunctival injection and watery discharge. However, patients are unlikely to present with significant itching or eyelid edema. Although viral conjunctivitis can affect both eyes, it usually begins unilaterally. Additionally, patients often present with systemic and/or nasopharyngeal signs of viral infection (e.g., lymphadenopathy, pharyngitis).

Exacerbations of blepharitis can cause acute-onset bilateral eyelid swelling, itchiness, and tearing. However, blepharitis primarily manifests with erythema or adherent material (e.g., collarettes, crusty scaly plaques) at the lid margins. The absence of these findings and the presence of conjunctival injection and chemosis make a different diagnosis more likely.

question_text: A 5-year-old boy is brought to the physician for an annual health maintenance examination. His father notes that the boy has several pigmented areas on his skin and a few fleshy bumps. He has also had some blurred vision in his left eye. He has no history of serious medical illness. He lives at home with both parents and is up-to-date on all his immunizations. His father has similar skin findings. His mother has epilepsy and glaucoma. Vital signs are within normal limits. Visual acuity testing shows 20/50 in the left eye and 20/20 in the right eye. Slit-lamp examination shows multiple pigmented iris nodules. Examination of the skin shows eight brownish macules and numerous soft, non-tender, pedunculated lesions on the back, chest, and abdomen. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?
content_preview: A 5-year-old boy is brought to the physician for an annual health maintenance examination. His father notes that the boy has several pigmented areas on his skin and a few fleshy bumps. He has also had some blurred vision in his left eye. He has no history of serious medical illness. He lives at home with both parents and is up-to-date on all his immunizations. His father has similar skin findings. His mother has epilepsy and glaucoma. Vital signs are within normal limits. Visual acuity testing shows 20/50 in the left eye and 20/20 in the right eye. Slit-lamp examination shows multiple pigmented iris nodules. Examination of the skin shows eight brownish macules and numerous soft, non-tender, pedunculated lesions on the back, chest, and abdomen. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?
hint: This child has multiple pigmented iris nodules (Lisch nodules), ≥ 6 hyperpigmented macules (café au lait spots), and numerous soft, pedunculated skin nodules (neurofibromas). These findings fulfill the diagnostic criteria for neurofibromatosis type 1 (NF1).
learning_objective: Recognize neurofibromatosis type 1, and choose the most appropriate next step in management.

answers.explanation_why: CT scan is commonly used in the emergency setting to rapidly evaluate for trauma, space-occupying lesions, hydrocephalus, and intracranial bleeding. While individuals with NF1 are at increased risk of developing tumors of the central nervous system, a CT scan is not the best study for evaluating this patient's visual deficits.

Optic glioma is the CNS tumor most commonly associated with NF1 and typically develops before the age of six years. Although this tumor is usually asymptomatic, patients may present with visual abnormalities, including proptosis, decreased color vision, and/or decreased visual acuity. All patients with NF1 and visual symptoms should undergo MRI of the brain with contrast for further evaluation. In addition, all children with NF1 should undergo an annual ophthalmologic examination to screen for optic glioma.

images.title: Clinical features of neurofibromatosis type 1 and type 2
images.description: Neurofibromatoses are autosomal dominant-inherited neurocutaneous syndromes that are caused by mutations in tumor suppressor genes. Neurofibromatosis type 1 has a typical onset in adolescence and manifests with multiple neurofibromas, benign peripheral nerve sheath tumors that originate from neural crest cells. Neurofibromatosis type 2 has a later onset in early adulthood and manifests with multiple cerebral and spinal tumors.

answers.explanation_why: EEG records electrical activity in the brain and is used to diagnose or screen for seizure activity. While individuals with NF1 are at increased risk of developing tumors of the central nervous system, which could cause seizure activity, this patient has no reported history of seizure and there is no indication to screen for seizures in NF1.

A B-scan ultrasound, also called a brightness scan, uses ultrasound waves to visualize ocular and orbital diseases. It is especially helpful in the detection of retinal hemangioblastomas, which are prevalent in von Hippel-Lindau disease, another neurocutaneous disorder. This patient has NF1 and should undergo a different diagnostic test to evaluate his visual disturbances.

Gonioscopy involves the placement of a lens (gonioscope) on the cornea to visualize the anterior chamber and chamber angle. It is considered the gold standard for diagnosis of glaucoma. Early glaucoma is common in patients with Sturge-Weber syndrome but is uncommon in patients with NF1.

question_text: A 55-year-old woman comes to the physician because of increased blurring of vision in both eyes for the past 4 months. She has tried using over-the-counter reading glasses, but they have not helped. She has a history of hypertension, type 2 diabetes mellitus, and chronic obstructive pulmonary disease. Current medications include lisinopril, insulin, metformin, and a fluticasone-vilanterol inhaler. Vital signs are within normal limits. Examination shows visual acuity of 20/70 in each eye. A photograph of the fundoscopic examination of the right eye is shown. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?
content_preview: A 55-year-old woman comes to the physician because of increased blurring of vision in both eyes for the past 4 months. She has tried using over-the-counter reading glasses, but they have not helped. She has a history of hypertension, type 2 diabetes mellitus, and chronic obstructive pulmonary disease. Current medications include lisinopril, insulin, metformin, and a fluticasone-vilanterol inhaler. Vital signs are within normal limits. Examination shows visual acuity of 20/70 in each eye. A photograph of the fundoscopic examination of the right eye is shown. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?
hint: The fundoscopic image shows neovascularization of the optic disc and the retinal vessels.
learning_objective: Recognize proliferative diabetic retinopathy, and choose the most appropriate next step in management.

answers.explanation_why: IV acetazolamide is used to treat increased cranial pressure (ICP), e.g., due to pseudotumor cerebri. An increased ICP manifests with bilateral papilledema, flame-shaped retinal hemorrhages, and cotton-wool spots on fundoscopy. However, fundoscopic examination in pseudotumor cerebri would not reveal neovascularization.

images.title: Optic disc edema
images.description: Fundus photography of the left eyeLeft image: Blurred disc margins (green overlay) with venous dilatation and tortuosity (blue overlay) and small hemorrhages (examples indicated by arrowheads) are visible.Blurred disc margins suggest optic disc edema. In intracranial hypertension, as seen in this image, optic disc edema is called papilledema.Right image: Resolution of optic disc edema after treatment. Sharp disc margins and normal retinal vessels are visible. There are no hemorrhages.

answers.explanation_why: Topical timolol is used to reduce the intraocular pressure of patients with open-angle glaucoma. Timolol acts by slowing visual field loss and optic disc changes. However, the fundoscopic exam of a patient with open-angle glaucoma would show notching of the neuroretinal rim, disc hemorrhages, and most specifically, cupping and pallor of the optic disc. This condition would not show neovascularization.

images.title: Glaucomatous excavation of the optic disc
images.description: Fundus photography of a right eyeAn enlarged cup (yellow overlay) of the optic disc with thinning of the neuroretinal rim (green overlay) can be seen, especially evident in the temporal superior area of the optic disc (focal notching, indicated by arrow). Cupping leads to kinking of the blood vessels at the base of the cup (examples indicated by arrowheads).This is a pathognomonic finding in glaucoma, predominantly caused by elevated intraocular pressure.

answers.explanation_why: Laser photocoagulation of the retina is used to treat proliferative diabetic retinopathy (PDR), a long-term complication of diabetes that is evident in this patient's fundoscopic examination. PDR develops because chronic hyperglycemia results in the death of retinal microvascular cells and capillary dysfunction, with subsequent ischemia. Dying cells release vascular endothelial growth factor (VEGF), which promotes the growth of new fragile blood vessels (neovascularization) that hemorrhage easily and interfere with the transmission of light. Neovascularization can also cause retinal detachment and scarring. Laser photocoagulation helps reduce the progression of neovascularization and decreases the risk of vision loss. Strict glycemic and blood pressure control should be maintained in patients with PDR. Therapy with VEGF inhibitors may also be recommended, particularly in patients with significant macular edema.

Oral ganciclovir is used to treat cytomegalovirus (CMV) retinitis. Fundoscopic findings of patients with CMV retinitis include a “pizza-pie” appearance of the retina (e.g., retinal hemorrhages, fluffy/granular white opacities around retinal vessels resembling cotton-wool spots, retinal detachment), but neovascularization is not typically found. Moreover, CMV retinitis manifests with floaters, photopsia, and/or visual field defects (due to retinal detachment).

images.title: CMV retinitis
images.description: Fundus photography of a right eyeMultiple retinal hemorrhages (red blotches, white outlines) and areas of retinal necrosis (fluffy white patches, black outlines) are visible in the central retina. In addition, the optic nerve (blue circle) is unsharply demarcated.This combination of red hemorrhages and white retinal necrosis, referred to as the “pizza pie” (illustration) or “cottage cheese with ketchup” appearance, is characteristic of CMV retinitis, which most commonly affects immunocompromised individuals.

answers.explanation_why: An ocular massage is useful for patients with acute retinal artery occlusion. Repetitive pressure to the sclera can dislodge emboli, leading to improved vision. Affected individuals show retinal whitening (due to ischemia) and narrow vessels with a red-appearing fovea centralis (i.e., cherry-red spot) on fundoscopy. Neovascularization is not typically found.

images.title: Acute central retinal artery occlusion
images.description:
Fundus photography of the left eyeThe fovea centralis looks dark red (cherry-red spot; green overlay) due to the transparency of this part of the retina lacking nerve fibres, causing the well-vascularized choroid to shine through. The surrounding retina is pale and opacified, indicating ischemic edema. Narrow retinal arterioles with box-carring (examples indicated by arrowheads) are also visible.

These findings are typical of acute central retinal artery occlusion.

answers.explanation_why: Surgical vitrectomy is commonly performed in patients with retinal detachments, which can be a complication of neovascularization. However, fundoscopy would show a gray-colored, freshly detached retina, a retinal tear, or a detached retina floating freely in the vitreous body that moves with eye movement (affected individuals complain of floaters).

images.title: Retinal detachment in Marfan syndrome
images.description: Fundus photographyA giant tear (blue overlay) with rolled margins (hatched overlay; the arrows show the path along which the retina has rolled up) is visible. The giant tear has caused retinal detachment (yellow overlay); the detached portion of the retina appears brighter than the attached portion of the retina.The risk for retinal detachment is elevated in individuals with Marfan syndrome.

images.title: Proliferative diabetic retinopathy
images.description:
Fundus photography of the right eyeThere is massive neovascularization (examples indicated by arrows) of the optic disk (NVD), cotton wool spots (overlay), hard exudates (circle), intraretinal hemorrhages (examples indicated by white arrowheads), and a microaneurysm (example indicated by black arrowhead).The diagnosis of proliferative disease requires the presence of neovascularization.

Outline: optic disc
