question_text: A 3-week-old boy is brought to the physician for a follow-up examination. He was delivered at 30 weeks' gestation via cesarean section and was cyanotic at birth, requiring resuscitation and admission to the neonatal intensive care unit. His mother received no prenatal care; she has type 2 diabetes mellitus and hypertension. She was not tested for sexually transmitted infections during the pregnancy. The infant appears well. Ophthalmologic examination shows tortuous retinal vessels. There are well-demarcated areas of nonvascularized retina in the periphery. Which of the following is the most likely cause of this patient's retinal findings?
content_preview: A 3-week-old boy is brought to the physician for a follow-up examination. He was delivered at 30 weeks' gestation via cesarean section and was cyanotic at birth, requiring resuscitation and admission to the neonatal intensive care unit. His mother received no prenatal care; she has type 2 diabetes mellitus and hypertension. She was not tested for sexually transmitted infections during the pregnancy. The infant appears well. Ophthalmologic examination shows tortuous retinal vessels. There are well-demarcated areas of nonvascularized retina in the periphery. Which of the following is the most likely cause of this patient's retinal findings?
hint: This infant's ophthalmologic examination shows tortuous retinal vessels and areas of nonvascularized peripheral retina, which are consistent with retinopathy of prematurity (ROP).
learning_objective: Recognize retinopathy of prematurity due to oxygen toxicity.

answers.explanation_why: Retinoblastoma is an important cause of ocular disease in infants and is caused by mutations in the RB1 tumor suppressor gene that are often inherited. However, this patient has no family history of malignancy and the ophthalmologic findings are not consistent with retinoblastoma.

This premature infant likely received supplemental oxygen at birth, which is a major contributing factor in the development of ROP. Higher arterial oxygen tension in a premature infant inhibits the production of VEGF, leading to apoptosis of endothelial cells and cessation of normal retinal vascular formation. Switching to room air results in relative hypoxia due to the lower oxygen concentration, increased metabolic demand of the growing retina, and poor vascular network, leading to the production of proangiogenic growth factors (e.g., VEGF) and uncontrolled neovascularization. The formation of new blood vessels can cause hemorrhages, form fibrovascular membranes, and ultimately lead to retinal detachment or blindness.

images.title: Plus disease of retinopathy of prematurity (ROP)
images.description: Fundus photography of a right eyeThe retina shows tortuous and dilated retinal vessels.This finding is an example of plus disease, which indicates a risk for progression to ROP.

answers.explanation_why: Glucocorticoid deficiency is associated with an increased risk of neonatal respiratory distress syndrome, as glucocorticoids play a vital role in promoting fetal lung maturity by stimulating the production of surfactant. However, glucocorticoid deficiency is not a risk factor for the development of ROP.

Maternal diabetes causes chronic fetal hyperglycemia and can lead to a wide range of complications in the infant. This newborn's mother did not receive prenatal care, which means she was neither screened nor treated for diabetes during pregnancy. Maternal diabetes also increases the risk of prematurity, the single greatest risk factor for ROP. This infant does not have features consistent with chronic hyperglycemia, however, such as macrosomia, neonatal hypoglycemia, cardiac anomalies, and respiratory distress. While this patient's ROP could be related to prematurity caused by maternal diabetes, another factor is much more likely responsible for his ROP.

Syphilis is one of several congenital infections (TORCH infections) that can cause ocular abnormalities in affected infants. Congenital syphilis can manifest with uveitis, keratitis, glaucoma, and congenital cataracts. However, this infant's fundoscopy findings are highly indicative of ROP, and, although infection may worsen the course of ROP, it is not a contributing factor to the development of this condition.

Head trauma as a result of rotational and shearing forces can cause shaken baby syndrome. This condition manifests with retinal and intracranial hemorrhages but does not contribute to the development of ROP.

Mothers receiving routine prenatal care are screened for chlamydia infection to eliminate the risk of chlamydial conjunctivitis in the newborn. This mother's lack of prenatal care puts the infant at risk of this disease, which often manifests 1–2 weeks after birth. However, ocular findings include mucopurulent or watery discharge, eyelid swelling, and chemosis. This disease does not affect the retina.

question_text: A 72-year-old woman comes to the physician because of a 1-month history of frequent headaches, double vision, fatigue, and myalgias. Physical examination shows pallor, tenderness to palpation over the temples, and inward deviation of the left eye. Laboratory studies show an erythrocyte sedimentation rate of 65 mm/h. Temporal artery biopsy shows transmural granulomatous inflammation and fragmentation of the internal elastic lamina. Treatment with high-dose intravenous corticosteroids is begun. The patient's condition puts her at greatest risk of developing which of the following complications?
content_preview: A 72-year-old woman comes to the physician because of a 1-month history of frequent headaches, double vision, fatigue, and myalgias. Physical examination shows pallor, tenderness to palpation over the temples, and inward deviation of the left eye. Laboratory studies show an erythrocyte sedimentation rate of 65 mm/h. Temporal artery biopsy shows transmural granulomatous inflammation and fragmentation of the internal elastic lamina. Treatment with high-dose intravenous corticosteroids is begun. The patient's condition puts her at greatest risk of developing which of the following complications?
hint: A headache, temporal tenderness, double vision, fatigue, and an increased ESR in this woman over 50 years of age are highly suggestive of giant cell arteritis (GCA). Concurrent myalgia possibly indicates polymyalgia rheumatica, which is commonly associated with GCA. Focal granulomatous inflammation of the temporal artery layers with fragmentation of the internal elastic lamina confirms the diagnosis of GCA in this patient.
learning_objective: Recognize giant cell arteritis, and recall its vascular complications.

answers.explanation_why: Pulmonary hypertension may develop in diffuse systemic sclerosis, a condition that usually presents with Raynaud phenomenon, cutaneous findings such as sclerodactyly, and inner organ involvement (e.g., dysmotility of the gastrointestinal tract, cardiac disease, renal disease). Because GCA involves medium to large-sized blood vessels, the pulmonary vessels are not typically involved.

Lower extremity gangrene is often seen as a late complication of thromboangiitis obliterans, also known as Buerger disease. As the disease progresses, patients develop limb threatening ischemia and pain at rest, absent pulses, and digital gangrene. This type of dry gangrene (involving the small and medium-sized blood vessels) is not seen in GCA, which typically only affects larger blood vessels.

Nasal septum perforation may be seen in granulomatosis with polyangiitis, which typically manifests with constitutional symptoms and localized manifestations, such as chronic sinusitis, rhinitis, otitis media, ocular conditions, and/or skin lesions. GCA affects medium to large-sized vessels and therefore does not usually lead to nasal septum perforation.

images.title: Sinonasal changes in granulomatosis with polyangiitis
images.description: CT paranasal sinuses (without contrast; coronal plane)The right maxillary sinus is completely opacified (yellow overlay). An erosion (red arrowhead) through the nasal septum (red overlay) is seen, and a second erosion involves the right orbital floor (white arrowhead).LMS: left maxillary sinus

answers.explanation_why: Palpable purpura is commonly seen in small vessel vasculitides including granulomatosis with polyangiitis, eosinophilic granulomatosis with polyangiitis, immunoglobulin A vasculitis, and polyarteritis nodosa. Because GCA involves medium to large-sized blood vessels, it does not result in cutaneous purpura.

Inflammatory conditions associated with the development of posterior uveitis include Behcet disease, sarcoidosis, spondyloarthritis, and IBD. Although eye involvement can occur in patients with GCA (e.g., anterior ischemic optic neuropathy or central retinal artery occlusion) and blindness is a possible complication of GCA, posterior uveitis is not associated with this condition.

images.title: Multifocal choroiditis in sarcoidosis
images.description:
Fundus photography of a left eyeSeveral choroidal granulomas are visible, appearing as yellow spots (examples indicated by arrowheads).This finding is consistent with the diagnosis of multifocal choroiditis, associated here with sarcoidosis.

Circle: optic disc; M: macula

answers.explanation_why: Giant cell arteritis (GCA) causes chronic inflammation of large and medium-sized arteries, in particular the carotid arteries, its major branches, and the aorta. Approximately 10–20% of patients with giant cell arteritis (GCA) will have involvement of the thoracic aorta, which significantly increases the risk of thoracic artery aneurysms and dissections. The median time between the diagnosis of GCA and thoracic aortic aneurysm is around 10 years.

question_text: An 8-year-old boy is brought to the physician by his mother because of a 3-week history of irritability and frequent bed wetting. His mother also reports that he has been unable to look upward without tilting his head back for the past 2 months. He is at the 50^th percentile for height and weight. His vital signs are within normal limits. Ophthalmological examination shows dilated pupils that are not reactive to light and bilateral optic disc swelling. Pubic hair development is Tanner stage 2. The most likely cause of this patient's condition is a tumor in which of the following locations?
content_preview: An 8-year-old boy is brought to the physician by his mother because of a 3-week history of irritability and frequent bed wetting. His mother also reports that he has been unable to look upward without tilting his head back for the past 2 months. He is at the 50th percentile for height and weight. His vital signs are within normal limits. Ophthalmological examination shows dilated pupils that are not reactive to light and bilateral optic disc swelling. Pubic hair development is Tanner stage 2. The most likely cause of this patient's condition is a tumor in which of the following locations?
hint: This patient presents with vertical gaze palsy and signs of increased intracranial pressure (papilledema). These findings are suggestive of a brain tumor that is causing compression symptoms due to hydrocephalus. Signs of precocious puberty are due to the tumor cell line.
learning_objective: Recognize a dorsal midbrain tumor (pinealoma).

answers.explanation_why: Meningiomas often arise in the cerebral falx and are typically asymptomatic due to their slow growth rate. Compression of the adjacent hemisphere can cause seizures as well as spastic paraparesis and incontinence. Falcine meningiomas do not typically cause hydrocephalus or precocious puberty.

Pinealoma is a childhood tumor of the dorsal midbrain that compresses the pretectal region, resulting in vertical gaze palsy. Because of the close proximity to the cerebral aqueduct, hydrocephalus (due to obstruction of cerebrospinal fluid outflow pathway) can also develop, which would explain this patient's increased intracranial pressure. The most common type of pinealoma in children is germinoma, which often secretes β-hCG, stimulating testosterone production and causing precocious puberty in boys.

Other causes of vertical gaze palsy include stroke, multiple sclerosis, and encephalitis.

Acoustic schwannoma is the most common tumor of the cerebellopontine angle. Compression of structures adjacent to the cerebellopontine angle can cause hydrocephalus, but the absence of vestibulocochlear nerve (CN VIII) involvement (causes unilateral sensorineural hearing loss and tinnitus, unsteady gait) in this patient and the relatively short clinical course (4 weeks) make acoustic schwannoma (a slow-growing tumor) an unlikely etiology. Furthermore, the median age of patients presenting with acoustic schwannoma is ∼ 50 years.

images.title: Acoustic neuroma (vestibular schwannoma)
images.description: Acoustic neuromas are benign tumors that arise from Schwann cells and primarily originate within the vestibular portion of cranial nerve VIII. The tumor originates within the internal acoustic canal with variable extension into the cerebellopontine angle. Early symptoms occur due to pressure on the cochlear nerve (unilateral sensorineural hearing loss, tinnitus) and vestibular nerve (dizziness, unsteady gait, disequilibrium). If the tumor further expands into the cerebellopontine angle, further symptoms arise due to compression of CN V (paresthesia, hypoesthesia, unilateral facial pain), CN VII (unilateral facial weakness), and the cerebellum (ataxia).

answers.explanation_why: Ependymomas are childhood tumors that are typically located in the fourth ventricle. This tumor most commonly presents with noncommunicating hydrocephalus, which can result in compression of a number of CNS structures and cause vertical gaze palsy and central precocious puberty. However, in the case of hydrocephalus due to an ependymoma, symptoms of hydrocephalus (e.g., irritability, urinary incontinence) would precede the onset of vertical gaze palsy unlike this patient who had a vertical gaze palsy before the onset of hydrocephalus symptoms.

Pituitary tumors arise within the sella turcica. These tumors can cause compression of the optic chiasm and manifest with bitemporal hemianopsia. Because the pituitary gland is not in close proximity to the ventricular system, hydrocephalus does not occur. In addition, pituitary tumors originating from gonadotropic cells (gonadotroph adenoma) are typically nonsecretory (inactive), resulting in hypogonadism due to the destruction of functioning gonadotropic cells, instead of precocious puberty.

Pilocytic astrocytoma and medulloblastoma are childhood tumors located in the cerebellar vermis. Hydrocephalus due to compression of the fourth ventricle by these tumors can cause vertical gaze palsy and central precocious puberty. However, in the case of hydrocephalus due to either of these tumors, symptoms of hydrocephalus (e.g., irritability, urinary incontinence) would precede the onset of vertical gaze palsy unlike this patient who had a vertical gaze palsy before the onset of hydrocephalus symptoms. Additionally, compression of the cerebellar vermis would cause truncal ataxia, which is not reported in this patient.

question_text: A 15-day-old female newborn is brought to the physician for evaluation of red eyes with discharge for 3 days. She was born at 37 weeks' gestation to a 26-year-old woman. Pregnancy and delivery were uncomplicated. The mother received irregular prenatal care during the 3^rd trimester of pregnancy. Examination of the newborn shows watery discharge in both eyes and mild eyelid swelling. Which of the following is the most likely cause of this patient's presentation?
content_preview: A 15-day-old female newborn is brought to the physician for evaluation of red eyes with discharge for 3 days. She was born at 37 weeks' gestation to a 26-year-old woman. Pregnancy and delivery were uncomplicated. The mother received irregular prenatal care during the 3rd trimester of pregnancy. Examination of the newborn shows watery discharge in both eyes and mild eyelid swelling. Which of the following is the most likely cause of this patient's presentation?
hint: A gram stain of this patient's discharge would yield a negative result.
learning_objective: Recognize chlamydial conjunctivitis in a newborn, and recall its cause.

answers.explanation_why: Silver nitrate exposure can lead to chemical conjunctivitis, which usually manifests in the 1^st day of life with mild watery discharge and conjunctival injections. Discharge and eyelid swelling was observed in this patient 12 days after delivery, which makes this diagnosis unlikely.

Staphylococcus aureus is the most common cause of bacterial conjunctivitis in adults and typically presents with unilateral conjunctival injection, chemosis, and thick purulent discharge. This patient has watery eye discharge. Moreover, Staphylococcus aureus is not a common cause of conjunctivitis in neonates.

Chlamydial conjunctivitis, which is caused by Chlamydia trachomatis, typically manifests at 5–14 days after birth with watery or mucopurulent ocular discharge in addition to mild eyelid swelling, as seen in this patient. Oral erythromycin is the treatment for chlamydial conjunctivitis.

Gonococcal conjunctivitis, which is caused by Neisseria gonorrhoeae, typically manifests 2–7 days after delivery with profuse, purulent, ocular discharge in addition to a pronounced eyelid swelling. This patient, meanwhile, has a mild eyelid swelling and watery discharge observed 12 days after delivery, which makes this diagnosis unlikely.

Herpes simplex virus 2 is a common cause of viral conjunctivitis in neonates. It typically manifests within the first 14 days of life with nonpurulent, ocular discharge, corneal ulceration, and periocular vesicles. This patient lacks corneal ulceration and periocular vesicles, which make this diagnosis unlikely.

question_text: A 34-year-old man comes to the physician because of a 2-day history of progressively blurred vision. He also reports seeing flashing lights in his visual field. He does not have any pain. The patient has not been examined by a physician in several years. He appears emaciated. Examination shows right conjunctival injection. Visual acuity is 20/20 in the left eye and 20/100 in the right eye. Fundoscopic examination of the right eye is shown. His CD4+ T-lymphocyte count is 46/mm^3. Which of the following is the most appropriate pharmacotherapy for this patient's eye condition?
content_preview: A 34-year-old man comes to the physician because of a 2-day history of progressively blurred vision. He also reports seeing flashing lights in his visual field. He does not have any pain. The patient has not been examined by a physician in several years. He appears emaciated. Examination shows right conjunctival injection. Visual acuity is 20/20 in the left eye and 20/100 in the right eye. Fundoscopic examination of the right eye is shown. His CD4+ T-lymphocyte count is 46/mm3. Which of the following is the most appropriate pharmacotherapy for this patient's eye condition?
hint: Fundoscopy in this patient, whose depressed CD4+ T-lymphocyte count is almost certainly secondary to infection with the human immunodeficiency virus (HIV), shows fluffy, hemorrhagic, perivascular retinal lesions that radiate out from the optic disc (pizza-pie appearance). These symptoms and findings are characteristic of cytomegalovirus (CMV) retinitis.
learning_objective: Recognize CMV retinitis in an HIV patient, and choose the most appropriate pharmacotherapy.

answers.explanation_why:
Valganciclovir or ganciclovir are considered first-line therapy for CMV retinitis, a condition that can cause blurring, vision loss, floaters, and photopsia (flashing lights). It usually occurs unilaterally (right eye in this patient) but can affect the other eye if untreated. Alternative agents include foscarnet and cidofovir. In patients with severe infection (e.g., lesions < 1.5 mm from the fovea or adjacent to the optic nerve head), intravitreal therapy with ganciclovir or foscarnet should also be considered. Other CMV infections that develop in patients with CD4+ T-cell count < 50/mm^3 include CMV esophagitis, CMV colitis, CMV pneumonitis, and CMV encephalitis.

Additionally, this patient should be started on antiretroviral therapy to increase his CD4+ T-lymphocyte count.

images.title: CMV retinitis
images.description: Fundus photography of the left eyeThere are diffuse perivascular retinal hemorrhages (examples indicated by blue hatched overlay), whitish retinal necroses (examples indicated by yellow overlay), and periphlebitis with vascular occlusion (examples indicated by blue overlay). In addition, hard exudates (examples indicated by arrowheads) can be seen. The combination of these features causes the characteristic pizza-pie appearance (zoom-box and illustration).These findings are consistent with retinitis caused by cytomegalovirus, which is most commonly seen in immunocompromised patients.

answers.explanation_why: Acyclovir is used to treat herpes simplex virus (HSV) and varicella-zoster virus (VZV) infections, which can affect the eyes and manifest with visual blurring and conjunctivitis. However, HSV keratitis and VZV keratitis both manifest with corneal ulcers and are typically painful. The extensive hemorrhagic lesions seen in this patient are not common manifestations of HSV or VZV ocular infections. Acyclovir is ineffective against CMV.

images.title: Herpes simplex keratitis
images.description: Slit-lamp photography of the cornea (fluorescein stain)Dendritic lesions (red overlay) are visible on the cornea.This finding is characteristic of herpes simplex keratitis.

answers.explanation_why: Penicillin G is used to treat syphilis, which can affect the uvea and optic nerve (and, less commonly, other ocular structures). Though ocular syphilis causes conjunctival injection and decreased visual acuity, it typically also causes eye pain and photophobia. Syphilitic uveitis also causes perivascular retinal inflammation and depigmentation of the retina, unlike the extensive hemorrhagic lesions seen in this patient. Additionally, isolated ocular findings are rare; patients typically have other findings of primary or secondary syphilis (e.g., chancre, condyloma lata, or generalized lymphadenopathy). Penicillin G is ineffective against CMV.

images.title: Papilledema
images.description: Fundus photography of the right eye of a patient with HIV and syphilisPapilledema with blurred disk margins (black arrows) is visible, indicating papillitis. In addition, tortuous vessels, which represent an unspecific sign, can be seen.Ocular manifestations of syphilis include a wide range of inflammatory intraocular conditions, in this case as papillitis.

answers.explanation_why: Famciclovir is used to treat shingles as well as genital and labial herpes simplex virus (HSV) infections. Although varicella-zoster virus (VZV) and HSV can affect the eyes and cause visual blurring and conjunctivitis, these infections both manifest with corneal ulcers and are typically painful. Famciclovir is neither approved for ocular manifestations of VZV or HSV nor is it effective against CMV.

Sulfadiazine and pyrimethamine are used in combination to treat toxoplasmosis, which can cause chorioretinitis. Although toxoplasmosis chorioretinitis results in decreased visual acuity, it typically also causes eye pain. Additionally, unlike the perivascular retinal lesions seen in this patient, toxoplasmic chorioretinitis causes yellow-white, fluffy lesions in a nonvascular distribution. Sulfadiazine and pyrimethamine are ineffective against CMV.

images.title: Ocular toxoplasmosis
images.description:
Fundus photography of a right eyeThe image appears cloudy, which is consistent with vitreous opacity. There is a yellow-white, fluffy retinal lesion (blue overlay) at the temporal superior vascular arch. The pigmented scar (arrowhead) in the nasal area is most likely the remnant of a previous manifestation of toxoplasmosis. In addition, the optic disc (circle) appears blurred.

M: macula

answers.explanation_why: Trimethoprim-sulfamethoxazole (TMP-SMX) is commonly used for Pneumocystis jirovecii pneumonia prophylaxis in patients with CD4+ T-lymphocyte count < 200/mm^3. It is also used to treat Pneumocystis choroiditis, a condition typically seen in patients with disseminated Pneumocystis infections. Pneumocystis choroiditis manifests with multiple, bilateral, yellow-white choroidal lesions that spare the retina. Visual changes are uncommon. TMP-SMX is ineffective against CMV.

images.title: CMV retinitis
images.description: Fundus photography of the left eyeThere are diffuse perivascular retinal hemorrhages (examples indicated by blue hatched overlay), whitish retinal necroses (examples indicated by yellow overlay), and periphlebitis with vascular occlusion (examples indicated by blue overlay). In addition, hard exudates (examples indicated by arrowheads) can be seen. The combination of these features causes the characteristic pizza-pie appearance (zoom-box and illustration).These findings are consistent with retinitis caused by cytomegalovirus, which is most commonly seen in immunocompromised patients.

question_text: A 60-year-old woman is brought to the emergency department because of sudden, painless loss of vision in her right eye that occurred 30 minutes ago while watching TV. She has coronary artery disease, hypertension, and type 2 diabetes mellitus, and has had trouble adhering to her medication regimen. Her blood pressure is 160/85 mm Hg. Examination shows 20/50 vision in the left eye and no perception of light in the right eye. Direct pupillary reflex is present in the left eye but absent in the right eye. Accommodation is intact bilaterally. Intraocular pressure is 16 mm Hg in the left eye and 18 mm Hg in the right eye. Fundoscopic examination of the right eye shows a pale, white retina with a bright red area within the macula. The optic disc appears normal. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
content_preview: A 60-year-old woman is brought to the emergency department because of sudden, painless loss of vision in her right eye that occurred 30 minutes ago while watching TV. She has coronary artery disease, hypertension, and type 2 diabetes mellitus, and has had trouble adhering to her medication regimen. Her blood pressure is 160/85 mm Hg. Examination shows 20/50 vision in the left eye and no perception of light in the right eye. Direct pupillary reflex is present in the left eye but absent in the right eye. Accommodation is intact bilaterally. Intraocular pressure is 16 mm Hg in the left eye and 18 mm Hg in the right eye. Fundoscopic examination of the right eye shows a pale, white retina with a bright red area within the macula. The optic disc appears normal. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
hint: Indirect pupillary reflex will likely be absent in the left (not right!) eye, which would be consistent with retinal or optic nerve damage.
learning_objective: Recognize central retinal artery occlusion.

answers.explanation_why: Hypertension, diabetes, and atherosclerosis are all risk factors for ischemic central retinal vein occlusion (CRVO). It may manifest with sudden, painless loss of vision and a relative afferent pupillary defect as well as severe edema of the macula and optic disc. However, fundoscopy would reveal focal retinal hemorrhage instead of a white, pale retina. The most common form of CRVO is nonischemic and results in a decrease in visual acuity over the course of a few days instead of sudden loss of vision seen here.

images.title: Central retinal vein occlusion
images.description: Fundus photography of a right eyeMultiple punctual hemorrhages in every quadrant of the retina and flame-shaped hemorrhages in the peripapillary and perivascular region are present (examples marked by blue overlay), as are markedly dilated tortuous veins (example framed by white lines) and mild disk edema (blurry margin of the disc marked by dashed blue line, sharply demarcated margin marked by blue line).This is the classic appearance of central retinal vein occlusion.M: Macula

answers.explanation_why: Both hypertension and diabetes mellitus are risk factors for retinal detachment. Patients with extensive retinal detachment or retinal detachment involving the macula would also present with sudden, painless loss of vision, and an afferent pupillary defect. However, fundoscopy would reveal a gray, detached, freely floating retina. Retinal pallor and a cherry red spot within the macula suggest a different diagnosis.

images.title: Tractional retinal detachment in proliferative diabetic retinopathy
images.description: Fundus photography of the left eyeFibrovascular proliferation (green overlay) obscures the optic disc (dashed circle) and can be seen extending along the retinal vasculature in fibrovascular strands. This has resulted in tractional retinal detachment (blue overlay). Multiple retinal hemorrhages can also be seen (arrowheads).These findings are characteristic of severe proliferative diabetic retinopathy.M: macula; N: nasal; T: temporal

answers.explanation_why:
The patient has multiple risk factors for retinal artery disease, including diabetes, hypertension, and atherosclerosis. Central retinal artery occlusion (CRAO) is characterized by sudden, painless loss of vision and an afferent pupillary defect. Ophthalmoscopy findings of CRAO include retinal pallor and a cherry-red spot in the foveal region. Narrow retinal vessels with a cattle-truck appearance are another classic finding of retinal artery occlusion.

Retinal artery occlusion is an ophthalmologic emergency.

images.title: Central retinal artery occlusion
images.description: Left: lateral view of the right eye in longitudinal (sagittal) section. Depiction of an embolism in the central retinal artery causing retinal ischemia.Right: fundus photography of the right eye. Diffuse retinal ischemia causes edema in the inner retinal layers, manifesting as a gray-white discoloration of the retina (most markedly around the fovea; dotted circle). The fovea centralis, where the inner retinal layers are moved to the side, is not affected by edema. The underlying, well-vascularized choroid shines through, appearing as a cherry-red spot.

answers.explanation_why: Patients with acute angle closure glaucoma may present with sudden loss of vision, and an absent or sluggish direct pupillary reflex. However, the loss of vision in the case of acute angle closure glaucoma is always associated with severe pain and increased intraocular pressure (> 21 mm Hg), as opposed to the normal intraocular pressure in this patient (18 mm Hg in the right eye). The indirect pupillary reflex and the accommodation reflex, which are normal in this patient, would also be impaired. Injection and chemosis of the conjunctiva, as well as trigeminal autonomic symptoms such as nausea, vomiting, and lacrimation, which are frequently present in acute angle closure glaucoma, are absent in this patient. On fundoscopy, the optic disc would appear edematous or hyperemic, in contrast to the normal optic disc in this patient.

images.title: Angle-closure glaucoma
images.description: Slit-lamp photograph of anterior eye segmentProminent blood vessels are visible on the sclera and conjunctiva (mixed injection). The pupil is medium wide and its shape is slightly irregular. Iris details appear blurred due to corneal endothelial decompensation, leading to corneal edema.

answers.explanation_why: Anterior ischemic optic neuropathy may also present with sudden, painless loss of vision. However, fundoscopy would reveal a hyperemic or edematous optic disc and possibly splinter hemorrhages within the optic disc, as opposed to a normal optic disc seen in this patient. Retinal pallor and a cherry red spot within the macula suggest a different diagnosis.

images.title: Papilledema in non-arteritic anterior ischemic optic neuropathy (NAION)
images.description: Fundus photography of a right eyeThe optic disc (dashed circle) shows blurred margins and radial bleedings (arrowheads). The retinal veins are dilated and tortuous (examples indicated by white lines). In addition, the macula (M) shows pigment alterations (blue overlay).This is the typical appearance of papilledema, in this case caused by NAION. Papilledema can also be caused by arteritic anterior ischemic optic neuropathy (AAION), inflammatory processes, or elevated intracranial pressure.Hatched overlay: artifacts

question_text: A 10-year-old boy comes to the physician because of a 4-month history of intermittent red urine. During the past 2 years, he has had recurrent episodes of swelling of his face and feet. Five years ago, he was diagnosed with mild bilateral sensorineural hearing loss. His uncle died of kidney disease in his twenties. His blood pressure is 145/85 mm Hg. Laboratory studies show a hemoglobin concentration of 12.5 g/dL, urea nitrogen concentration of 40 mg/dL, and creatinine concentration of 2.4 mg/dL. Urinalysis shows 5–7 RBC/hpf. Which of the following is the most likely underlying cause of this patient's symptoms?
content_preview: A 10-year-old boy comes to the physician because of a 4-month history of intermittent red urine. During the past 2 years, he has had recurrent episodes of swelling of his face and feet. Five years ago, he was diagnosed with mild bilateral sensorineural hearing loss. His uncle died of kidney disease in his twenties. His blood pressure is 145/85 mm Hg. Laboratory studies show a hemoglobin concentration of 12.5 g/dL, urea nitrogen concentration of 40 mg/dL, and creatinine concentration of 2.4 mg/dL. Urinalysis shows 5–7 RBC/hpf. Which of the following is the most likely underlying cause of this patient's symptoms?
hint: This patient presents with features of nephritic syndrome, including hematuria, hypertension, and recurrent edema of the face and feet, and other signs of renal damage (elevated BUN, elevated creatinine). Sensorineural hearing loss in a patient with renal disease and a positive family history is indicative of Alport syndrome.
learning_objective: Recognize Alport syndrome, and recall its genetic basis.

answers.explanation_why: Type IV collagen, which forms a component of basement membranes, plays an important role in the function of glomeruli and inner ear structures (particularly the organ of Corti). An X-linked defect in type IV collagen is responsible for most cases of Alport's syndrome, which results in progressive sensorineural hearing loss (with high-frequency sounds affected first) and hematuria. Episodes of gross hematuria are sometimes preceded by upper respiratory tract infections. Patients with Alport's syndrome also commonly develop an anterior lenticonus since type IV collagen is the predominant collagen fiber in the lens capsule. A family history of renal disease among males is common in patients with Alport's syndrome.

images.title: Alport syndrome
images.description: Electron micrograph of a kidney biopsy sample.The glomerular basement membrane (GBM) demonstrates an irregular thickness, with splitting and a basket-weave appearance (black arrow).These findings are consistent with Alport syndrome.

answers.explanation_why: A WT1 gene mutation is one of the causes of Wilms tumor, which can result in hematuria, hypertension, and anemia. However, Wilms tumor would manifest in early childhood (usually before the age of 5 years) and patients almost always have a palpable abdominal or flank mass on physical examination. It also does not cause sensorineural hearing loss.

An autosomal-recessive gene defect in fibrocystin is the cause of autosomal-recessive polycystic kidney disease (ARPKD), which leads to the development of multiple bilateral kidney cysts. Hematuria, hypertension, anemia, and raised creatinine in a 10-year-old child with an onset of symptoms during infancy and a positive family history might suggest a diagnosis of ARPKD. However, ARPKD does not account for sensorineural deafness. Instead, patients with ARPKD who survive to adolescence usually have evidence of cirrhosis and portal hypertension (e.g., ascites, splenomegaly).

Antibodies against phospholipase A2 receptors on podocytes are responsible for membranous nephropathy, which typically presents between the ages of 30 and 50 years with nephrotic syndrome, unlike this 10-year-old boy child with nephritic syndrome. It also does not cause sensorineural hearing loss.

Pharyngitis caused by group A beta-hemolytic streptococci (GAS) is common in children 5–15 years of age and can cause poststreptococcal glomerulonephritis (PSGN) 1–3 weeks after the infection. This patient could have had an episode of febrile pharyngitis due to GAS. However, while PSGN would present with nephritic syndrome, it does not explain the 2-year history of intermittent edema or the presence of sensorineural deafness in this patient.

Deposition of IgA in the glomeruli is seen in IgA nephropathy and in Henoch-Schönlein purpura (HSP), both of which may present with nephritic syndrome. However, a purpuric rash would typically precede the onset of renal disease in patients with HSP, and other symptoms such as abdominal pain and/or joint pain would be expected. Moreover, both HSP and IgA nephropathy do not explain the sensorineural deafness in this patient.

question_text: A 53-year-old man is brought to the emergency department because of wheezing and shortness of breath that began 1 hour after he took a new medication. Earlier in the day he was diagnosed with stable angina pectoris and prescribed a drug that irreversibly inhibits cyclooxygenase-1 and 2. He has chronic rhinosinusitis and asthma treated with inhaled β-adrenergic agonists and corticosteroids. His respirations are 26/min. Examination shows multiple small, erythematous nasal mucosal lesions. After the patient is stabilized, therapy for primary prevention of coronary artery disease should be switched to a drug with which of the following mechanisms of action?
content_preview: A 53-year-old man is brought to the emergency department because of wheezing and shortness of breath that began 1 hour after he took a new medication. Earlier in the day he was diagnosed with stable angina pectoris and prescribed a drug that irreversibly inhibits cyclooxygenase-1 and 2. He has chronic rhinosinusitis and asthma treated with inhaled β-adrenergic agonists and corticosteroids. His respirations are 26/min. Examination shows multiple small, erythematous nasal mucosal lesions. After the patient is stabilized, therapy for primary prevention of coronary artery disease should be switched to a drug with which of the following mechanisms of action?
hint: The combination of asthma, aspirin sensitivity, and probable nasal polyposis (multiple small, erythematous nasal mucosal lesions) is known as Samter's triad. The patient develops signs of acute asthmatic attack (wheezing, dyspnea) shortly after initiating therapy with aspirin (an irreversible COX-1 and 2 inhibitor). The patient should be switched to another agent that is used along with aspirin prior to percutaneous coronary intervention.
learning_objective: Recognize Samter's triad, and choose an alternative antiplatelet agent for aspirin allergy.

answers.content: Inhibition of vitamin K epoxide reductase
answers.explanation_why: Competitive inhibition of vitamin K epoxide reductase is the mechanism of action of warfarin. Warfarin is used for the treatment and prevention of thromboembolic disorders (venous thromboembolism, pulmonary embolism) and embolic complications arising from atrial fibrillation. Warfarin is not used for prevention of coronary heart disease.

answers.content: Blockage of P2Y12 component of ADP receptors
answers.explanation_why: P2Y_12 receptor antagonists (e.g., clopidogrel) irreversibly inhibit platelet aggregation by preventing the ADP-mediated formation of the GpIIb/IIIa receptor complex. Clopidogrel is used for the treatment of stable angina pectoris in patients with aspirin allergy as well as adjunctive therapy in acute coronary syndromes. Other indications include secondary prevention of recent stroke, recent myocardial infarction, and peripheral arterial disease.

Factor Xa inhibitors (e.g., apixaban, rivaroxaban, edoxaban) are used for the prophylaxis and treatment of venous thromboembolism, pulmonary embolism and non-valvular atrial fibrillation. Primary and secondary prevention of ischemic heart disease does not include the use of factor Xa inhibitors or any other new oral anticoagulants (NOACs).

Citrate is a calcium-binding salt with anticoagulant properties that is used for the preservation of blood-derived products. Citrate is also used for anticoagulation in patients undergoing dialysis and for the prevention of recurrent urinary calcium stones. Citrate is not used for the treatment or prevention of acute or stable coronary syndromes.

Potentiation of antithrombin (an endogenous anticoagulant) indirectly inhibits thrombin and factor Xa and is the mechanism of action for unfractionated heparin (UFH). UFH is used for anticoagulation in patients with unstable angina (UA), ST elevation myocardial infarction (STEMI), and non-ST elevation myocardial infarction (NSTEMI). However, the mechanism of this patient's stable angina pectoris involves a mismatch between the myocardial oxygen supply and myocardial oxygen demand, secondary to a fixed atherosclerotic occlusion without activating the coagulation cascade. Thus, anticoagulant agents have no therapeutic effect on stable angina pectoris.

question_text: A 69-year-old man undergoes modified radical neck dissection for an oropharyngeal tumor. During the procedure, he requires multiple blood transfusions. Four hours after the surgery, examination shows that the right and left pupils do not constrict when a light is shone into the left eye. When light is shone into the right eye, both pupils constrict. Fundoscopic examination shows no abnormalities. Which of the following is the most likely location of the lesion?
content_preview: A 69-year-old man undergoes modified radical neck dissection for an oropharyngeal tumor. During the procedure, he requires multiple blood transfusions. Four hours after the surgery, examination shows that the right and left pupils do not constrict when a light is shone into the left eye. When light is shone into the right eye, both pupils constrict. Fundoscopic examination shows no abnormalities. Which of the following is the most likely location of the lesion?
hint: The patient presents with a relative afferent pupillary defect (RAPD). Given his need for multiple blood transfusions during surgery, the patient presumably had an episode of intraoperative blood loss. This blood loss could have resulted in hypotension and subsequent ischemic damage to a CNS structure involved in the pupillary response.
learning_objective: Recognize a relative afferent pupillary defect, and recall its associated lesion location.

answers.explanation_why: A relative afferent pupillary defect typically occurs because of unilateral damage to the retina and/or optic nerve (CN II). In this patient damage to the optic nerve (CN II) due to ischemic optic neuropathy has resulted in RAPD. Complete damage to CN II would also result in loss of vision on the affected side.

images.title: Pupillary light reflex
images.description:
The afferent pathway (blue tract) is initiated when light hits the retina:
- Retinal photoreceptors → ipsilateral optic nerve → nuclei of bilateral pretectal areas (nasal fibers of the optic nerve cross to the contralateral side at the optic chiasma)The efferent pathway (green tract) transmits neural impulses to the iris sphincter muscle:
- Nuclei of pretectal area → bilateral Edinger Westphal nuclei (parasympathetic preganglionic nucleus of the oculomotor nerve) → bilateral oculomotor nerves (synapse at the ciliary ganglion) → bilateral iris sphincter muscle (and ciliary muscle) → bilateral pupillary constriction (and accomodation).Shining a light into one eye causes constriction of the ipsilateral pupil (direct pupillary reflex) as well as that of the contralateral pupil (indirect or consensual pupillary reflex).

answers.explanation_why: The pretectal region receives afferent fibers of the pupillary pathway from both eyes. Unilateral damage can, therefore, be compensated by the innervation from the contralateral side. Bilateral damage to the pretectal region, on the other hand, manifests with absent direct pupillary reflexes and indirect pupillary reflexes in both eyes.

Damage to the superior cervical ganglion and its sympathetic nerve fibers is a potential complication of radical deep neck dissection. However, patients in such cases would present with ipsilateral miosis and other symptoms of Horner syndrome (e.g. ptosis, anhidrosis).

Damage to the ophthalmic nerve (a branch of the CN V) results in absent corneal reflex. Ophthalmic nerve damage can also result in sensory deficits in the periorbital region and the ipsilateral forehead. The pupillary response would not be affected.

Damage to the parasympathetic Edinger-Westphal nucleus, which contains the efferent pupillary response pathway, leads to absent pupillary reflex (direct and indirect) in the ipsilateral eye, while the pupillary reflex (direct and indirect) in the contralateral eye remains intact.

Damage to the lateral geniculate body leads to homonymous hemianopia of the contralateral visual field. The pupillary response pathway does not pass through the lateral geniculate body, and so pupillary reactions to light would not be affected.

images.title: Visual pathway
images.description:
1. Retina: The visual pathway begins at the retina. The temporal field of vision is projected onto the nasal portion of the retina and the nasal field of vision is projected onto the temporal portion of the retina.
2. Optic nerves: The axons of the retinal ganglion cells merge to form the optic nerve, which carries the nasal and temporal fibers of the ipsilateral retina.
3. Optic chiasm: The two optic nerves meet at the optic chiasm, where the nasal fibers of each retina cross over to the contralateral side. The temporal fibers remain uncrossed.
4. Optic tracts: Each optic tract carries contralateral nasal fibers and ipsilateral temporal fibers (i.e., the right optic tract carries the nasal fibers of the left eye and the temporal fibers of the right eye). I.e., each optic tract carries the contralateral visual field of each eye.
5. Lateral geniculate nucleus (LGN): The optic tracts synapse onto the ipsilateral LGN.
6. Optic radiation: consists of neurons that carry visual information from the ipsilateral LGN to the ipsilateral primary visual cortex
7. Primary visual cortex: The visual pathway terminates at the primary visual cortex, which is located at the posterior aspect of the occipital lobe. It is responsible for the perception of sight. The right visual cortex receives visual information from the right nasal field and the left temporal field of vision, i.e. the left visual field of each eye.

answers.explanation_why: Damage to the ciliary ganglion, which contains the efferent fibers of the CN III, results in paresis of the sphincter pupillae muscle. Thus, damage to the ciliary ganglion would manifest with mydriasis and absent pupillary reflex (both direct and consensual) in the ipsilateral eye, and normal pupillary response in the unaffected eye.

question_text: A 13-year-old boy is brought to the emergency room 30 minutes after being hit in the face with a baseball at high velocity. Examination shows left periorbital swelling, posterior displacement of the left globe, and tenderness to palpation over the left infraorbital rim. There is limited left upward gaze and normal horizontal eye movement. Further evaluation is most likely to show which of the following as a result of this patient's trauma?
content_preview: A 13-year-old boy is brought to the emergency room 30 minutes after being hit in the face with a baseball at high velocity. Examination shows left periorbital swelling, posterior displacement of the left globe, and tenderness to palpation over the left infraorbital rim. There is limited left upward gaze and normal horizontal eye movement. Further evaluation is most likely to show which of the following as a result of this patient's trauma?
hint: The patient's findings of enophthalmos (posteriorly displaced eye) and infraorbital rim tenderness are suggestive of an orbital floor fracture (orbital blowout fracture). The mechanism of this injury can lead to downward displacement of orbital fat and inferior rectus muscle entrapment, which in turn can cause impaired upward gaze.
learning_objective: Recognize an orbital floor fracture, and recall its radiological sign.

answers.explanation_why: Injury to the lacrimal duct system is associated with nasoethmoid fractures. Fracture of the maxillary bone in this portion of the medial orbital rim can also result in disruption of the medial canthal ligament, causing eyelid displacement and entrapment of the medial rectus muscle, which would prevent horizontal eye movement. Nasoethmoid fractures are the second most common orbital fractures after orbital floor fractures, but this patient has none of the accompanying signs, and such a fracture would not explain his limited upward gaze or inferior orbital rim tenderness.

Clouding of the maxillary sinus is a radiological sign known as the “tear drop sign.” It will most likely be seen on further evaluation due to the inferior rectus muscle and orbital fat herniating through the fractured orbital floor. Other symptoms may include diplopia, crepitus, ecchymosis, and loss of sensation in the area innervated by the infraorbital nerve (midface from the lower eyelid to the upper lip).

images.title: Blowout fracture of the orbital floor
images.description: CT of the midface (frontal view, bone window)Orbital (O) floor fracture (white line shows the original course of the bone), resulting in herniation of the infraorbital adipose tissue (green overlay) into the maxillary sinus (MS). This is also known as the teardrop sign. The inferior rectus muscle (green hatched overlay on the right) is no longer clearly defined on the left and likely entrapped in the area of the orbital floor fracture.

answers.explanation_why: Pneumatization of the frontal sinus is a part of normal development as bone marrow in the frontal sinuses is slowly replaced by air starting at 2 years of age until adolescence. Pneumatization of the frontal sinuses may also occur as a result of orbital trauma in cases of orbital roof fractures. These fractures are rare in adults because of the strength of the orbital roof. They are more common in children, who have a higher cranium-to-midface ratio relative to adults. Orbital roof fractures result in CSF leaks and mucocele formation, none of which are present in this patient.

Cerebrospinal fluid leak is seldom associated with orbital fractures. When CSF leak does occur, it is typically due to an orbital roof fracture with extension to the frontal sinuses. Orbital roof fracture is inconsistent with this patient's inferior orbital rim tenderness and limitation of upward gaze (signifying inferior rectus muscle entrapment).

Disruption of the medial canthal ligament is associated with nasoethmoid fractures. Fracture of the maxillary bone in this portion of the orbital rim could also result in disruption of the lacrimal duct system and entrapment of the medial rectus muscle, which would prevent horizontal eye movement. While these nasoethmoid fractures are the second most common orbital fractures after orbital floor fractures, this patient has normal horizontal eye movement, and such a fracture would not explain his limited upward gaze or inferior orbital rim tenderness.

question_text: An 18-month-old boy is brought to the physician because of a 2-day history of cough, fever, and lethargy. He has been admitted to the hospital twice during the past year for pneumonia. He can stand without support but has not started to walk. He speaks in bisyllables. He is at the 3^rd percentile for height and 4^th percentile for weight. Examination shows diffuse crackles over bilateral lung fields. Abdominal examination shows hepatosplenomegaly. Fundoscopy shows bright red macular spots. Despite being given appropriate antibiotic therapy, the patient dies. A photomicrograph of a section of the spleen obtained during autopsy is shown. Accumulation of which of the following substances is the most likely cause of this patient's condition?
content_preview: An 18-month-old boy is brought to the physician because of a 2-day history of cough, fever, and lethargy. He has been admitted to the hospital twice during the past year for pneumonia. He can stand without support but has not started to walk. He speaks in bisyllables. He is at the 3rd percentile for height and 4th percentile for weight. Examination shows diffuse crackles over bilateral lung fields. Abdominal examination shows hepatosplenomegaly. Fundoscopy shows bright red macular spots. Despite being given appropriate antibiotic therapy, the patient dies. A photomicrograph of a section of the spleen obtained during autopsy is shown. Accumulation of which of the following substances is the most likely cause of this patient's condition?
hint: Electron microscopy of this patient's spleen specimen would most likely also show zebra bodies.
learning_objective: Recognize Niemann-Pick disease, and recall the substance that accumulates in this condition.

answers.explanation_why: Accumulation of limit dextrin is characteristic of Cori disease (type III glycogen storage disease). Although splenomegaly is a clinical feature of Cori disease, cherry-red macular spots and recurrent pneumonia would not be expected.

This patient's clinical features (hepatosplenomegaly, cherry-red macular spots, and psychomotor retardation) and biopsy findings, which show foam cells, are consistent with Niemann-Pick disease. This condition is caused by accumulation of sphingomyelin primarily in lysosomes of the reticuloendothelial system and CNS. Patients with Niemann-Pick disease usually develop normally until 1 year of age, when regression of mental and motor development starts to occur. Additional clinical features such as interstitial lung disease can develop in the type A variant, which manifests with recurrent pneumonia that progresses to respiratory failure and death.

Accumulation of phenylalanine is characteristic of phenylketonuria (PKU). Although motor regression and developmental delay are clinical features of PKU, cherry-red macular spots and hepatosplenomegaly would not be expected. Furthermore, PKU is most commonly diagnosed in the neonatal period because phenylalanine levels are measured as part of newborn screening for metabolic disorders.

Accumulation of galactitol is characteristic of galactosemia. Although involvement of the eyes (e.g., cataracts), hepatomegaly, and cognitive impairment are seen in galactosemia, cherry-red macular spots and recurrent pneumonia would not be expected.

Accumulation of ceramide trihexoside is characteristic of Fabry disease. Fabry disease is the only X-linked recessive sphingolipidosis (meaning it is more likely to occur in males) and typically includes involvement of the eyes (e.g., cataracts, corneal clouding). However, cherry-red macular spots, hepatosplenomegaly, and recurrent pneumonia would not be expected. Furthermore, clinical features of Fabry disease usually only start to develop during late childhood or early adolescence.

Accumulation of cerebroside sulfate is characteristic of metachromatic leukodystrophy. Although involvement of the eyes (e.g., optic nerve atrophy, blindness), motor regression, and developmental delay would be seen in the condition, cherry-red macular spot, hepatosplenomegaly, and recurrent pneumonia would not be expected.

Accumulation of GM2 ganglioside is characteristic of Tay-Sachs disease. Although developmental delay, cherry-red macular spots, and death in early childhood are features of Tay-Sachs disease, hepatosplenomegaly and recurrent pneumonia would not be expected. Moreover, histologic findings would show lysosomes with an onion skin appearance (swollen lysosomes with membranes that appear whorled) as opposed to this patient's foam cells.

Accumulation of glucocerebroside is characteristic of Gaucher disease. Although hepatosplenomegaly is a common feature of Gaucher disease, cherry-red macular spots and recurrent pneumonia would not be expected. Furthermore, histologic findings on microscopic examination would show Gaucher cells (lipid-rich macrophages with an enlarged, crinkled paper-like cytoplasm), which are not present in this patient's biopsy specimen.

images.title: Foam cells
images.description: Microscopic image of the splenic red pulp (H&E stain)Macrophages with a lipid-laden cytoplasm (examples: green overlay). Those cells are often referred to as “foam cells” and are a typical finding in Niemann-Pick disease.

question_text: A 66-year-old man is brought to the emergency department 1 hour after the abrupt onset of painless loss of vision in his left eye. Over the last several years, he has noticed increased blurring of vision; he says the blurring has made it difficult to read, but he can read better if he holds the book below or above eye level. He has smoked 1 pack of cigarettes daily for 40 years. Fundoscopic examination shows subretinal fluid and small hemorrhage with grayish-green discoloration in the macular area in the left eye, and multiple drusen in the right eye with retinal pigment epithelial changes. Which of the following is the most appropriate pharmacotherapy for this patient's eye condition?
content_preview: A 66-year-old man is brought to the emergency department 1 hour after the abrupt onset of painless loss of vision in his left eye. Over the last several years, he has noticed increased blurring of vision; he says the blurring has made it difficult to read, but he can read better if he holds the book below or above eye level. He has smoked 1 pack of cigarettes daily for 40 years. Fundoscopic examination shows subretinal fluid and small hemorrhage with grayish-green discoloration in the macular area in the left eye, and multiple drusen in the right eye with retinal pigment epithelial changes. Which of the following is the most appropriate pharmacotherapy for this patient's eye condition?
hint: The patient's acute, painless, unilateral loss of central vision (central scotoma), together with his history of gradual loss of central vision and fundoscopic findings of a subretinal hemorrhage and grayish-green retinal discoloration, are characteristic of wet age-related macular degeneration (AMD).
learning_objective: Recognize wet age-related macular degeneration, and choose the most appropriate pharmacotherapy.

answers.explanation_why: Ustekinumab is a human monoclonal antibody that acts as an antagonist of both interleukin-12 (IL-12) and interleukin-23 (IL-23). Both of these proteins play a role in immune-mediated disorders; IL-12 induces T_h1-cell differentiation and IFN-γ production, whereas IL-23 plays a role in controlling TH17 development. Ustekinumab is used in the treatment of psoriasis, psoriatic arthritis, and Crohn disease but not wet age-related macular degeneration.
Ruxolitinib is a tyrosine kinase inhibitor that acts as a JAK1/2 inhibitor. It is used in the treatment of polycythemia vera; it is not indicated for wet age-related macular degeneration.

Cetuximab is an epidermal growth factor receptor (EGFR) inhibitor that is used in the treatment of stage IV colorectal cancer, and head and neck cancers. It is not used for the treatment of wet age-related macular degeneration.

Aldesleukin is a recombinant cytokine that acts as an interleukin-2 (IL-2) analog. It is used in the immunotherapy of renal cell carcinoma and metastatic melanoma. However, it is not used for the treatment of wet age-related macular degeneration.

Etanercept is a tumor necrosis factor (TNF) inhibitor that acts as a TNF-α decoy receptor. It is mainly used in the treatment of systemic inflammatory illnesses like rheumatoid arthritis, inflammatory bowel disease (IBD), and ankylosing spondylitis. It has no role in the treatment of wet age-related macular degeneration.

Ranibizumab is a vascular endothelial growth factor (VEGF) inhibitor. VEGF release in wet AMD (also referred to as exudative or neovascular AMD) causes choroidal neovascularization with growth of friable blood vessels prone to bleeding and leaking. VEGF inhibitors delivered intravitreally are the first-line treatment for wet AMD and have become the mainstay of treatment due to their efficacy and safety profile.

Dry AMD, the most common form of AMD, involves the deposition of drusen in and under the retinal pigment epithelium. These depositions cause progressive atrophy of the central and/or pericentral retinal pigment epithelium, resulting in painless central and/or pericentral visual impairment.

images.title: Exudative age-related macular degeneration
images.description: Fundus photography of the left eyeSubretinal and intraretinal hemorrhage (blue overlay) is visible in the region between the optic disc (blue circle) and macula (the macula is not visible, its approximate position is marked with an “M”). The light-yellow spots in the region of the macula indicate exudates and drusen (hatched overlay).Subretinal and intraretinal hemorrhages can result from pathological neovascularization of the choroid (CNV). The presence of CNV is required for the diagnosis of exudative/wet/neovascular macular degeneration.

question_text: A 73-year-old woman is brought to the physician by her son because of a 3-month history of recurrent upper respiratory tract infections. Her son says that she frequently stumbles into the nightstand when she gets up to go to the bathroom at night. She has a history of celiac disease and frequent bouts of diarrhea. She is 173 cm (5 ft 8 in) tall and weighs 54 kg (120 lb); BMI is 18 kg/m^2. Physical examination shows generalized dry skin, multiple bruises on the shins, and triangular keratin plaques on the temporal conjunctiva. A deficiency of which of the following is the most likely underlying cause of these findings?
content_preview: A 73-year-old woman is brought to the physician by her son because of a 3-month history of recurrent upper respiratory tract infections. Her son says that she frequently stumbles into the nightstand when she gets up to go to the bathroom at night. She has a history of celiac disease and frequent bouts of diarrhea. She is 173 cm (5 ft 8 in) tall and weighs 54 kg (120 lb); BMI is 18 kg/m2. Physical examination shows generalized dry skin, multiple bruises on the shins, and triangular keratin plaques on the temporal conjunctiva. A deficiency of which of the following is the most likely underlying cause of these findings?
hint: This patient's dry skin, triangular keratin plaques on the conjunctiva, as well as stumbling at night and a history of celiac disease are consistent with a specific vitamin deficiency.
learning_objective: Recall the clinical manifestations of vitamin A deficiency.

answers.explanation_why: Ascorbic acid (vitamin C) is an antioxidant and enzymatic cofactor that helps to enhance iron absorption in redox and hydroxylation reactions. Vitamin C deficiency (scurvy) can lead to bruising and immunosuppression, the latter of which is consistent with this patient's 3-month history of recurrent upper respiratory tract infections. However, immunosuppression is not specific to scurvy and this patient does not have other dermatological manifestations of scurvy such as perifollicular hemorrhages, petechiae, and corkscrew hairs. Her history of frequent stumbling at night and triangular keratin plaques on the conjunctiva suggest a different deficiency.

Vitamin A deficiency (retinol deficiency) can be seen in conditions of fat malabsorption, such as inflammatory bowel disease (e.g., Crohn disease), celiac disease, cystic fibrosis, and pancreatic insufficiency. Because vitamin A is involved in epithelial cell differentiation and retinal pigmentation, retinol deficiency results in dermatological and ophthalmological manifestations, such as xerosis cutis and Bitot spots. A deficiency in vitamin A can also cause immunosuppression, which explains this patient's recurrent upper respiratory tract infections. Moreover, this patient's recent history of stumbling in the dark most likely results from night blindness (nyctalopia), another common manifestation of vitamin A deficiency.

Zinc is an essential mineral required for the function of many enzymes. Zinc deficiency can cause diarrhea and immunosuppression. While zinc deficiency has dermatological manifestations, it causes acrodermatitis enteropathica rather than xerosis cutis. This patient does not have other expected symptoms of zinc deficiency, such as delayed wound healing, dysgeusia, and anosmia. Moreover, her frequent stumbling at night and triangular keratin plaques on the conjunctiva suggest a different deficiency.

Pantothenic acid (Vitamin B_5) is a cofactor in acyl transfer reactions and fatty acid synthesis. While vitamin B_5 deficiency manifests with nonspecific symptoms including dermatitis and diarrhea, it also causes alopecia and adrenal insufficiency, which are not observed in this patient. Furthermore, vitamin B_5 deficiency would not explain this patient's frequent stumbling at night or recurrent infections.

Riboflavin (vitamin B_2) is a cofactor in redox reactions, such as those involved in the tricarboxylic acid cycle. Riboflavin deficiency causes cheilosis and corneal vascularization. This patient has neither of these findings, and the presence of frequent stumbling at night and triangular keratin plaques on the conjunctiva point to a different vitamin deficiency.

Niacin (vitamin B3) is a cofactor in redox reactions and is derived from the amino acid tryptophan. Niacin deficiency causes glossitis and can lead to pellagra in severe cases. Pellagra typically causes dermatitis involving the C3 and C4 dermatomes around the neck rather than generalized dry skin. Pellagra can also cause diarrhea, but this patient's diarrhea is likely due to celiac disease. Also, triangular keratin plaques on the conjunctiva and frequent stumbling at night suggest a different vitamin deficiency.

images.title: Vitamin B₃ deficiency
images.description: Pellagra can be deadly if left untreated (due to the formerly high mortality rate, “death” is sometimes still listed as the fourth “D” of pellagra). Populations with a diet low in niacin-rich foods (e.g., corn-based diets without proper preparation) are at higher risk.

question_text: A 78-year-old right-handed man with hypertension and hyperlipidemia is brought to the emergency department for sudden onset of nausea and vertigo 1 hour ago. Physical examination shows 5/5 strength in all extremities. Sensation to light touch and pinprick is decreased in the right arm and leg. A CT scan of the brain shows an acute infarction in the distribution of the left posterior cerebral artery. Further evaluation of this patient is most likely to show which of the following findings?
content_preview: A 78-year-old right-handed man with hypertension and hyperlipidemia is brought to the emergency department for sudden onset of nausea and vertigo 1 hour ago. Physical examination shows 5/5 strength in all extremities. Sensation to light touch and pinprick is decreased in the right arm and leg. A CT scan of the brain shows an acute infarction in the distribution of the left posterior cerebral artery. Further evaluation of this patient is most likely to show which of the following findings?
hint: The posterior cerebral artery supplies the occipital lobe.
learning_objective: Recognize posterior cerebral artery infarction, and recall the expected visual field deficit.

answers.explanation_why: Left-sided hemineglect would be consistent with damage to the right parietal lobe (e.g., due to a right middle cerebral artery stroke), which is usually associated with contralateral motor and sensory deficits. In this patient, a posterior cerebral artery stroke was diagnosed and no motor deficits are present.

answers.content: Right-sided homonymous hemianopia with macular sparing
answers.explanation_why: The posterior cerebral artery supplies parts of the thalamus and the visual cortex within the occipital lobe. In addition to contralateral hemisensory loss due to lateral thalamic infarction (as seen in this patient), occlusion to the posterior cerebral artery causes damage to the visual cortex that results in contralateral homonymous hemianopia with macular sparing. Central vision is not impaired in posterior cerebral artery infarction since the corresponding cortical area of the macula is supplied by the middle cerebral artery.

images.title: Posterior cerebral artery infarct
images.description:
A posterior cerebral artery infarct (left-sided here) typically leads to the following:
– Contralateral sensory loss (due to lateral thalamic involvement)
– Contralateral homonymous hemianopsia with macular sparing (because the macula receives collateral vascular supply from the middle cerebral artery)

answers.explanation_why: Gaze deviation towards the side of infarction (in this case: left-sided gaze deviation) combined with contralateral sensory loss, as seen in this patient, would be consistent with infarction of the left middle cerebral artery, which supplies the frontal eye field. Affected patients are also likely to present with right-sided motor dysfunction and aphasia. This patient, however, presents with posterior cerebral artery stroke.

images.title: Middle cerebral artery infarct
images.description:
A middle cerebral artery infarct (left-sided in this case) leads to various combinations of the following:– Contralateral hemisensory loss
– Contralateral hemiparesis, including central facial nerve palsy (with preserved or only mildly impaired forehead movement due to bilateral innervation)
– Ipsilateral gaze deviation
– Contralateral homonymous hemianopia
– Aphasia (if the dominant hemisphere is involved)

answers.explanation_why: Prosopagnosia is most commonly seen with right posterior cerebral artery strokes (e.g., infarction of the right occipitotemporal lobe). This would not be an expected finding in a patient with a left posterior cerebral artery stroke, as seen here.

Right upper homonymous quadrantanopia would suggest a lesion in the left optic radiation and can be seen in strokes involving the left middle cerebral artery. This finding would not be expected in a patient with a posterior cerebral artery stroke.

question_text: A 64-year-old woman comes to the physician because of a 6-month history of headache and impaired vision. She says that she frequently misses turns while driving and hurts herself by accidentally bumping into objects. Confrontational visual field testing shows decreased vision in the left side of both visual fields. The most likely cause of this patient's symptoms is a lesion in which of the following locations?
content_preview: A 64-year-old woman comes to the physician because of a 6-month history of headache and impaired vision. She says that she frequently misses turns while driving and hurts herself by accidentally bumping into objects. Confrontational visual field testing shows decreased vision in the left side of both visual fields. The most likely cause of this patient's symptoms is a lesion in which of the following locations?
hint: A visual deficit involving homologous sides of both visual fields is known as homonymous hemianopsia.
learning_objective: Recognize homonymous hemianopsia, and recall neuroanatomy of the visual pathway.

answers.explanation_why: The cranial nerve II (CN II) transmits visual information from the retina to the optic chiasm, from where it continues on in the optic tract. Damage to the right CN II can cause complete loss of vision in the ipsilateral eye (right anopsia) as well as a right relative afferent pupillary defect. A lesion here would not be expected as the cause of this patient's left homonymous hemianopsia.

The x-shaped optic chiasm is the point of partial crossing of fibers from the optic nerve. Damage to this structure would cause bitemporal hemianopsia in both visual fields, as opposed to this patient's left homonymous hemianopsia.

images.title: Heteronymous bitemporal hemianopsia
images.description: Simulation of right and left visual fieldLoss of vision in the temporal half of both the right and left visual fields can be seen. This can occur when the optic chiasma is compressed, often due to tumors of the pituitary gland or craniopharyngioma.

answers.explanation_why: The cranial nerve II (CN II) transmits visual information from the retina to the optic chiasm, from where it continues on in the optic tract. Damage to the left CN II can cause complete loss of vision in the ipsilateral eye (left anopsia) as well as a left relative afferent pupillary defect. A lesion here would not be expected to cause this patient's left homonymous hemianopsia

The optic tracts relay visual information from the optic chiasm to the ipsilateral lateral geniculate nucleus, from where it continues to the occipital lobe and primary visual cortex. Each tract contains fibers from both the ipsilateral temporal hemiretina and the contralateral nasal hemiretina. The right optic tract, therefore, transmits visual information from the left visual field and vice versa. A right optic tract lesion (e.g., due to compression by an aneurysm, multiple sclerosis, infection, or stroke) has likely caused this patient's left homonymous hemianopsia.

images.title: Overview of visual field defects
images.description:
(1) Ipsilateral anopsia
(2) Bitemporal heteronymous hemianopsia
(3) Contralateral homonymous hemianopsia
(4) Contralateral upper homonymous quadrantanopsia
(5) Contralateral lower homonymous quadrantanopsia
(6) Contralateral homonymous hemianopsia with macular sparing
(7) Contralateral homonymous central scotoma

answers.explanation_why: A left optic tract lesion would cause right homonymous hemianopsia (i.e., on the right side of both visual fields). However, this patient has left homonymous hemianopsia.

The cranial nerve III (CN III) innervates four of six extraocular muscles and provides parasympathetic stimulation to the ipsilateral eye. Damage to the right oculomotor nerve would cause monocular diplopia of the right eye, resulting in blurring of the visual field rather than vision loss. CN III palsy does not cause homonymous hemianopsia.

The cranial nerve III (CN III) innervates four of six extraocular muscles and provides parasympathetic stimulation to the ipsilateral eye. Damage to the left oculomotor nerve would cause monocular diplopia of the left eye, resulting in blurring of the visual field rather than vision loss. CN III palsy does not cause homonymous hemianopsia.

images.title: Structures of the optic pathway
images.description:
Caudal view(A) Right optic nerve
(B) Optic chiasm
(C) Left optic nerve
(D) Right optic tract
(E) Left optic tract
(F) Right oculomotor nerve
(G) Left oculomotor nerve
