question_text: A 62-year-old woman is brought to the emergency department because of the sudden onset of severe left eye pain, blurred vision, nausea, and vomiting. She has had an upper respiratory tract infection for the past 2 days and has been taking phenylephrine to control her symptoms. Examination shows a rock-hard, injected left globe and a fixed, mid-dilated pupil on the left. Gonioscopy shows that the iris meets the cornea at an angle of 10° (N = 20–45°). Systemic pharmacotherapy is initiated with a drug that decreases the secretion of aqueous humor from the ciliary epithelium. The next day, her serum potassium concentration is slightly decreased. Which of the following additional adverse effects is most likely to occur in this patient?
content_preview: A 62-year-old woman is brought to the emergency department because of the sudden onset of severe left eye pain, blurred vision, nausea, and vomiting. She has had an upper respiratory tract infection for the past 2 days and has been taking phenylephrine to control her symptoms. Examination shows a rock-hard, injected left globe and a fixed, mid-dilated pupil on the left. Gonioscopy shows that the iris meets the cornea at an angle of 10° (N = 20–45°). Systemic pharmacotherapy is initiated with a drug that decreases the secretion of aqueous humor from the ciliary epithelium. The next day, her serum potassium concentration is slightly decreased. Which of the following additional adverse effects is most likely to occur in this patient?
hint: The patient's sudden-onset eye pain and blurred vision along with a rock-hard left globe on exam are highly suggestive of acute primary angle-closure glaucoma. A narrow iridocorneal angle confirms the diagnosis. The patient received treatment with acetazolamide.
learning_objective: Recognize acute primary angle-closure glaucoma, and recall the adverse effects of carbonic anhydrase inhibitors.

answers.explanation_why: Epithelial keratopathy is a possible adverse effect of the topical prostaglandin latanoprost, which is a first-line treatment for open-angle glaucoma. This patient, however, has acute closed-angle glaucoma and is being treated with a systemic medication. In addition, latanoprost increases aqueous humor drainage through the uveoscleral pathway, whereas this patient was treated with a medication that decreases the secretion of aqueous humor by the ciliary epithelium. Finally, latanoprost does not affect potassium levels.

Xerostomia is associated with drugs that suppress secretion from the salivary glands, like α2-adrenergic agonists. Apraclonidine, a topical ophthalmic α_2-adrenergic agonist, is often used to treat acute angle-closure glaucoma by decreasing synthesis of aqueous humor by the ciliary epithelium, similar to the medication used here. However, this patient is receiving systemic pharmacotherapy and α_2-adrenergic agonists do not cause a decrease in potassium levels.

Beta-blockers (e.g., timolol) and parasympathomimetics (e.g., pilocarpine) can cause bradycardia. While these medications can be used in the treatment of acute primary angle-closure glaucoma, they are given as topical formulations whereas this patient is receiving systemic treatment. While beta-blockers also improve the symptoms of glaucoma by decreasing aqueous humor synthesis, they are associated with hyperkalemia, in contrast to this patient who developed hypokalemia after starting the medication. Parasympathomimetics, on the other hand, increase aqueous humor drainage via ciliary muscle contraction and trabecular meshwork opening

Acetazolamide, a carbonic anhydrase inhibitor, improves the symptoms of glaucoma by decreasing aqueous humor synthesis by the ciliary epithelium. It is a first-line treatment for acute primary angle-closure glaucoma, which can be precipitated by mydriasis due to darkness, fear, stress, or certain medications (e.g., phenylephrine). However, acetazolamide can impair bicarbonate reabsorption in the proximal tubule, which may cause non-anion gap metabolic acidosis as a result of type 2 renal tubular acidosis. Other important adverse effects of acetazolamide include hypokalemia, sulfa allergy, and hyperammonemia with paresthesias.

images.title: Mechanism of action: glaucoma medication
images.description:
PGF2α analogues (e.g., latanoprost)
– Reduce outflow resistance of trabecular meshwork
– Increase uveoscleral outflow by relaxing ciliary muscle and disrupting turnover of extracellular matrixβ-blockers (e.g., timolol): diminish aqueous humor production by inhibiting Na+/K+ ATPaseα2 agonists (e.g., brimonidine) 
– Reduce episcleral venous pressure 
– Diminish aqueous humor production by inhibiting Na+/K+ ATPaseCholinomimetics (e.g., pilocarpine)
– Widen trabecular meshwork via ciliary muscle activation
– Open up the iridocorneal angle by activating the iris sphincter muscle (miosis)Carbonic anhydrase inhibitors (CAI; e.g., acetazolamide): diminish aqueous humor productionRho-kinase inhibitors (e.g., netarsudil)
– Increase trabecular outflow
– Lower episcleral venous pressure
– Decrease aqueous humor production by increasing noradrenergic transmission

answers.explanation_why: Diaphoresis can be an adverse effect of parasympathomimetic drugs, including the topical ophthalmic formulations (e.g., pilocarpine) given in the treatment of acute primary angle-closure glaucoma. This patient, however, is receiving systemic treatment. In addition, parasympathomimetics increase aqueous humor drainage via ciliary muscle contraction and trabecular meshwork opening, whereas this patient was treated with a medication that decreases the secretion of aqueous humor by the ciliary epithelium.

question_text: One week after being involved in a bicycling accident, a 32-year-old woman comes to the physician because of intermittent double vision. She reports worsening of symptoms when she tries to type on her computer or while buttoning her shirts. Physical examination shows a slight right-sided head tilt. Her left eye is deviated upwards, which becomes even more prominent when she attempts left eye adduction. This patient's symptoms are most likely due to impaired innervation to which of the following muscles?
content_preview: One week after being involved in a bicycling accident, a 32-year-old woman comes to the physician because of intermittent double vision. She reports worsening of symptoms when she tries to type on her computer or while buttoning her shirts. Physical examination shows a slight right-sided head tilt. Her left eye is deviated upwards, which becomes even more prominent when she attempts left eye adduction. This patient's symptoms are most likely due to impaired innervation to which of the following muscles?
hint: This patient's right-sided head tilt, diplopia, upward deviation of the eye that worsens during adduction, and history of blunt trauma to the head suggest palsy of the left trochlear nerve (CN IV).
learning_objective: Recognize trochlear nerve palsy, and recall its affected muscle.

answers.explanation_why: The superior oblique muscle is innervated by the trochlear nerve (CN IV) and is responsible for abduction, internal rotation (incyclotorsion), and depression of the eye during adduction. Impairment of this muscle manifests with vertical and torsional diplopia that worsens when the patient looks down and toward the nose (e.g., while typing on a computer); expected examination findings include external rotation (excyclotorsion), and upward deviation (hypertropia) of the affected eye. Downward gaze is impaired when the affected eye is adducted. The contralateral head tilt in this patient may be conscious or unconscious and serves as a compensatory mechanism.

images.title: Trochlear nerve palsy
images.description: Trochlear nerve palsy (here of the left eye) causes paralysis of the ipsilateral superior oblique muscle. This leads to hypertropia (upwards deviation) that increases in adduction, excyclotorsion (outward rotation) of the affected eye and slight limitation of abduction. The findings may be discrete.Patients typically present with vertical or oblique diplopia. Hypertropia and diplopia usually increases with ipsilateral head-tilt and decreases with contralateral head-tilt. Patients may adopt the latter as a compensatory posture (upper right of image).

answers.explanation_why: The superior rectus muscle is responsible for elevation, incyclotorsion, and adduction of the eye and is innervated by the oculomotor nerve. Impairment in the function of this muscle secondary to nerve injury would cause vertical diplopia, limitation of upgaze in the ipsilateral eye, and downward eye deviation (hypotropia).

The medial rectus muscle is responsible for adduction of the eye and is innervated by the oculomotor nerve. Impairment in the function of this muscle secondary to nerve injury would cause horizontal diplopia, limitation of the ipsilateral eye to the medial gaze, and deviation of the eye outwards (exotropia).

The lateral rectus muscle is responsible for abduction of the eye and is innervated by the abducens nerve. Impairment in the function of this muscle secondary to nerve injury would cause medial deviation of the eye (esotropia) at primary gaze, an ipsilateral abduction deficit, and horizontal diplopia that worsens when looking at distant objects.

images.title: Abducens nerve palsy
images.description: Abducens nerve palsy (here of the left eye) impairs the function of the lateral rectus muscle. This causes esotropia (medial deviation) of the affected eye and limits its abduction. Patients present with horizontal diplopia that worsens when turning the gaze to the affected side or looking at distant objects.

answers.explanation_why: The inferior oblique muscle is innervated by the oculomotor nerve and is responsible for excyclotorsion, elevation, and abduction of the eye. Impairment in the function of this muscle secondary to nerve injury would cause the eye to deviate downwards (hypotropia) and rotate inwards (incyclotorsion).

images.title: Oculomotor nerve palsy
images.description: Oculomotor nerve palsy (here, of the left eye) causes ipsilateral impairment of both motor and autonomic (parasympathetic) nerve functions. Paralysis of the inferior rectus, medial rectus, superior rectus, and inferior oblique muscles results in downward deviation (hypotropia) and outward deviation (exotropia) of the affected eye (down-and-out gaze) due to the unopposed actions of the lateral rectus and superior oblique muscles. Weakness of the levator palpebrae superioris muscle results in ptosis and impairment of parasympathetic function in mydriasis (as well as loss of accommodation and pupillary light reflex, which are not shown). Patients present with horizontal or horizontal and vertical double vision (diplopia) that worsens when turning the gaze away from the affected side. The ptosis, however, may prevent patients from experiencing diplopia.

answers.explanation_why: The inferior rectus muscle is responsible for depression, excyclotorsion, and adduction of the eye and is innervated by the oculomotor nerve. Impairment in the function of this muscle secondary to nerve injury would cause vertical diplopia, limitation of downgaze in the ipsilateral eye, and upward eye deviation (hypertropia).

question_text: A 30-year-old woman comes to the physician for the evaluation of a 2-day history of intermittent dizziness and double vision. She reports double vision whenever she looks to the left. Last summer, she had an episode of weakness in her left leg that resolved spontaneously. Ophthalmologic examination shows weak adduction of the right eye on left lateral gaze. Attempted left lateral gaze results in horizontal nystagmus of the left eye. Convergence testing is normal. This patient most likely has a lesion in which of the following labeled areas of the schematic overview of a transverse section of the midbrain?
content_preview: A 30-year-old woman comes to the physician for the evaluation of a 2-day history of intermittent dizziness and double vision. She reports double vision whenever she looks to the left. Last summer, she had an episode of weakness in her left leg that resolved spontaneously. Ophthalmologic examination shows weak adduction of the right eye on left lateral gaze. Attempted left lateral gaze results in horizontal nystagmus of the left eye. Convergence testing is normal. This patient most likely has a lesion in which of the following labeled areas of the schematic overview of a transverse section of the midbrain?
hint: Impaired horizontal eye movements with weak adduction of one eye and abduction nystagmus of the contralateral eye are indicative of internuclear ophthalmoplegia, which results from a lesion in the medial longitudinal fasciculus. In this young woman with a previous episode of neurologic dysfunction, the most likely cause of the lesion is multiple sclerosis.
learning_objective: Recognize internuclear ophthalmoplegia, and recall neuroanatomy of the midbrain.

answers.explanation_why: The right superior colliculus integrates visual, auditory, and somatosensory information with motor signals. This structure allows the orientation of the head towards stimuli. However, injury of the right superior colliculus would result in the inability to turn the head reflexively towards the left upon sensory stimulation from that side; it would not result in the impaired coordination of the eyes during lateral gaze.

The left superior colliculus integrates visual, auditory, and somatosensory information with motor signals. This structure allows the orientation of the head towards stimuli. However, injury of the left superior colliculus would result in the inability to turn the head reflexively towards the right upon sensory stimulation from that side; it would not result in the impaired coordination of the eyes during lateral gaze.

The medial longitudinal fasciculus (MLF) connects the nucleus of the CN VI (which controls ocular abduction) to the contralateral nucleus of the CN III (which controls ocular adduction). This connection allows for the coordination of both eyes during lateral gaze. Lesions in the MLF, such as those found in multiple sclerosis, disrupt adduction of the eye ipsilateral to the lesion, causing nystagmus in the contralateral eye as diplopia causes it to readjust.
Lesions in the left medial longitudinal fasciculus would cause internuclear ophthalmoplegia. However, double vision would occur on right lateral gaze, not left lateral gaze as seen in this patient.

The red nucleus is a large structure within the rostral midbrain that receives input from various motor areas, particularly the deep cerebellar nuclei. Lesions of the red nucleus can result in extensor posturing, with extension of both upper and lower extremities. However, lesions of the red nucleus do not cause an impaired coordination of the eyes during lateral gaze.

The red nucleus is a large structure within the rostral midbrain that receives input from motor areas, particularly the deep cerebellar nuclei. Lesions of the red nucleus can result in extensor posturing, with the extension of both upper and lower extremities. However, lesions of the red nucleus do not cause an impaired coordination of the eyes during lateral gaze.

Lesions of the right oculomotor nerve would impair the function of the medial rectus, which would, in turn, impair the adduction of the right eye, similar to this patient. However, complete palsy of the nerve would mean that the right eye would be in a down-and-out position and would fail to converge. Thus, nystagmus would not be found.

Lesions of the left oculomotor nerve would impair the function of the medial rectus, impairing adduction of the ipsilateral left eye. However, palsy of the left CN III would leave the left eye in a down-and-out position, without the ability to converge and with no nystagmus. Adduction of the right eye on left lateral gaze would not be impaired.

images.title: Midbrain
images.description:
Cross section(A) Right superior colliculus
(B) Left superior colliculus
(C) Right medial longitudinal fasciculus
(D) Left medial longitudinal fasciculus
(E) Right red nucleus
(F) Left red nucleus
(G) Right oculomotor nerve
(H) Left oculomotor nerve

question_text: A 62-year-old woman comes to the physician for decreased vision and worsening headaches since this morning. She has hypertension and hypercholesterolemia. Pulse is 119/min and irregular. Current medications include ramipril and atorvastatin. Ocular and funduscopic examination shows no abnormalities. The findings of visual field testing are shown. Which of the following is the most likely cause of this patient's symptoms?
content_preview: A 62-year-old woman comes to the physician for decreased vision and worsening headaches since this morning. She has hypertension and hypercholesterolemia. Pulse is 119/min and irregular. Current medications include ramipril and atorvastatin. Ocular and funduscopic examination shows no abnormalities. The findings of visual field testing are shown. Which of the following is the most likely cause of this patient's symptoms?
hint: Visual field testing shows the inability to see the right visual field in either eye (right homonymous hemianopia) with macular sparing, which most commonly results from decreased blood flow to the left occipital lobe.
learning_objective: Recognize occlusion of the posterior cerebral artery.

answers.explanation_why: Degeneration of the macula can be observed in age-related macular degeneration (AMD), which is subdivided into dry and wet AMD types and causes a gradual loss of central vision and metamorphopsia in the affected eyes, unlike what is seen in this patient.

Impaired perfusion of the retina has been observed in central retinal artery occlusion, which is caused by cardiac emboli in young patients and carotid atherosclerosis in old patients. It presents with an acute painless visual loss in the affected eye; it is usually unilateral and does not spare the macula, unlike in this patient.

images.title: Central retinal artery occlusion
images.description: Left: lateral view of the right eye in longitudinal (sagittal) section. Depiction of an embolism in the central retinal artery causing retinal ischemia.Right: fundus photography of the right eye. Diffuse retinal ischemia causes edema in the inner retinal layers, manifesting as a gray-white discoloration of the retina (most markedly around the fovea; dotted circle). The fovea centralis, where the inner retinal layers are moved to the side, is not affected by edema. The underlying, well-vascularized choroid shines through, appearing as a cherry-red spot.

answers.content: Occlusion of the posterior cerebral artery
answers.explanation_why: Occlusion of the posterior cerebral artery, usually due to emboli from the vertebral vessels, aorta, or heart, results in contralateral homonymous hemianopia with macular sparing. The macula is spared because the macular tracts have additional blood supply from the middle cerebral arteries.

images.title: Posterior cerebral artery infarct
images.description:
A posterior cerebral artery infarct (left-sided here) typically leads to the following:
– Contralateral sensory loss (due to lateral thalamic involvement)
– Contralateral homonymous hemianopsia with macular sparing (because the macula receives collateral vascular supply from the middle cerebral artery)

answers.content: Occlusion of the anterior inferior cerebellar artery
answers.explanation_why: Occlusion of the anterior inferior cerebellar artery causes lateral pontine syndrome. It manifests with vomiting, vertigo, nystagmus, ipsilateral cerebellar ataxia, Horner syndrome, facial muscle paralysis (lower motor neuron lesion type), and sensorineural hearing loss as well as contralateral hemisensory loss, none of which is seen in this patient.

The middle cerebral artery (MCA) is the most commonly occluded artery in ischemic strokes. Embolic occlusion of the MCA can occasionally lead to the development of contralateral homonymous hemianopia. However, owing to the extensive area of the brain that the MCA supplies, the other signs of stroke, such as contralateral limb weakness and sensory loss, would also be present. Isolated visual field defects are highly unlikely to occur in MCA embolism.
answers.explanation_but: The contralateral homonymous hemianopia in MCA occlusion rarely exhibits macular sparing. This is because the MCA supplies an extensive area of the brain and, thus, occlusion of the MCA affects not only the occipital visual cortex but also the visual pathways.

answers.explanation_why: Occlusion of the anterior cerebral artery does not affect the visual cortex but causes contralateral limb weakness and sensory loss affecting the lower limb more prominently than the upper limb. Primitive reflexes, like grasp reflexes and rooting reflexes, are also likely to re-emerge. This patient has none of these symptoms.

images.title: Homonymous hemianopia with macular sparing
images.description: Visual field test (perimetry)There is a bilateral loss of right lateral visual fields (black areas) with sparing of the macula (hatched overlay). Bilateral impairment of a unilateral visual field in each eye is known as homonymous hemianopia.

question_text: A 52-year-old man comes to the physician for an annual physical examination. He reports that his vision has progressively improved over the past 6 months and he no longer needs the glasses he used while driving. He has hypertension and type 2 diabetes mellitus. Current medications include glyburide, hydrochlorothiazide, and enalapril. Examination shows 20/20 vision bilaterally. Fundoscopy shows a few microaneurysms of retinal vessels. Which of the following is the most likely explanation for this patient's improved vision?
content_preview: A 52-year-old man comes to the physician for an annual physical examination. He reports that his vision has progressively improved over the past 6 months and he no longer needs the glasses he used while driving. He has hypertension and type 2 diabetes mellitus. Current medications include glyburide, hydrochlorothiazide, and enalapril. Examination shows 20/20 vision bilaterally. Fundoscopy shows a few microaneurysms of retinal vessels. Which of the following is the most likely explanation for this patient's improved vision?
hint: This patient's improvement in vision is likely due to presbyopia.
learning_objective: Recognize "second sight" in presbyopia, and recall its underlying cause.

answers.explanation_why: Decreased susceptibility to glare can be seen in darker colored eyes compared to lighter colored ones. However, it is an unlikely pathology. Increased susceptibility to glare is a finding of normal aging, most likely due to the effects of intraocular light scatter. It is increased in patients with cataract and would not present with an improvement in myopia in middle age.

Denaturation of lens proteins leads to the loss of lens elasticity seen in presbyopia, a classic condition associated with aging. This patient is experiencing the phenomenon of “second sight,” in which presbyopia corrects a long-standing case of myopia, resulting in improved visual acuity due to lens changes.

Liquefication of the vitreous humor is a physiological aging process that leads to condensing and shrinking of the gel-like substance. The vitreous membrane can eventually detach from the retina (posterior vitreous detachment). However, this would cause a worsening in the patient's vision (e.g., floaters, photopsia, scotoma), not an improvement.

Increased ciliary muscle tone is a mechanism that causes decreased diameter of the ciliary muscle, leading to constriction and accommodation of the pupil. It also induces opening of the trabecular meshwork and drainage of aqueous humor. It would be a mechanism for decreasing intraocular pressure in an ocular emergency like glaucoma, but it would not improve myopia during middle age. Furthermore, ciliary muscle tone tends to decrease with aging.

Macular degeneration is classified into two major forms: dry and wet macular degeneration. Dry macular degeneration is caused by the deposition of drusen under the retinal pigment epithelium, and wet macular degeneration is associated with neovascularization in the subretinal space. Both conditions cause decreased visual acuity, scotomas, and eventually blindness. However, since these conditions lead to progressively worsening central visual impairment in old age, they would not present with increasing visual acuity in middle age, as seen in this patient.

question_text: An 8-year-old boy is brought to the physician by his parents for blurry vision for the past 2 months. He is at the 97th percentile for height and 25th percentile for weight. Physical examination shows joint hypermobility, a high-arched palate, and abnormally long, slender fingers and toes. Slit lamp examination shows superotemporal lens subluxation bilaterally. This patient's findings are most likely caused by a defect in which of the following structural proteins?
content_preview: An 8-year-old boy is brought to the physician by his parents for blurry vision for the past 2 months. He is at the 97th percentile for height and 25th percentile for weight. Physical examination shows joint hypermobility, a high-arched palate, and abnormally long, slender fingers and toes. Slit lamp examination shows superotemporal lens subluxation bilaterally. This patient's findings are most likely caused by a defect in which of the following structural proteins?
hint: This patient presents with features of Marfan syndrome (i.e., tall stature, high-arched palate, arachnodactyly, joint hypermobility, and superotemporal lens subluxation).
learning_objective: Recognize Marfan syndrome, and recall the associated defective structural protein.

answers.explanation_why: Defective laminin can cause junctional epidermolysis bullosa, a condition characterized by fragile skin that easily blisters. This patient's symptoms cannot be explained by a defect in laminin.

Defective type III collagen is the cause of vascular Ehlers-Danlos syndrome, which presents primarily with cardiovascular manifestations. These include heart valve defects (especially mitral valve prolapse), aneurysms or dissections of large arteries (e.g., aortic, iliac), and berry aneurysms of cerebral arteries. This patient's symptoms cannot be explained by a defect in type III collagen.

Marfan syndrome is caused by an autosomal dominant mutation in the fibrillin-1 gene, which encodes fibrillin, an extracellular matrix glycoprotein that forms a supportive sheath around elastin. Abnormal elastin production leads to defective connective tissue and excessive growth factor release. Further features of Marfan syndrome include vascular abnormalities (e.g., aortic aneurysm or dissection).

Defective type I collagen is the cause of osteogenesis imperfecta (OI). Patients with OI can present with joint hypermobility, as seen in this patient, but do not develop lens subluxation, high-arched palate, tall stature, or arachnodactyly. Moreover, patients with OI typically have a history of multiple fractures in the setting of minimal trauma along with blue sclerae and hearing loss. This patient's symptoms cannot be explained by a defect in type I collagen.
Defective keratin can cause epidermolysis bullosa simplex, a condition characterized by fragile skin that easily blisters. This patient's symptoms cannot be explained by a defect in keratin.

question_text: Four days after delivery, a 1400-g (3-lb 1-oz) newborn has a tonic seizure that lasts for 30 seconds. Over the past 24 hours, he has become increasingly lethargic. He was born at 31 weeks' gestation. Antenatal period was complicated by chorioamnionitis. Apgar scores were 4 and 5 at 1 and 5 minutes, respectively. He appears ill. His pulse is 130/min, respirations are 53/min and irregular, and blood pressure is 67/35 mm Hg. Examination shows a bulging anterior fontanelle. The pupils are equal and react sluggishly to light. Examination shows slow, conjugate back and forth movements of the eyes. Muscle tone is decreased in all extremities. Which of the following is the most likely underlying cause?
content_preview: Four days after delivery, a 1400-g (3-lb 1-oz) newborn has a tonic seizure that lasts for 30 seconds. Over the past 24 hours, he has become increasingly lethargic. He was born at 31 weeks' gestation. Antenatal period was complicated by chorioamnionitis. Apgar scores were 4 and 5 at 1 and 5 minutes, respectively. He appears ill. His pulse is 130/min, respirations are 53/min and irregular, and blood pressure is 67/35 mm Hg. Examination shows a bulging anterior fontanelle. The pupils are equal and react sluggishly to light. Examination shows slow, conjugate back and forth movements of the eyes. Muscle tone is decreased in all extremities. Which of the following is the most likely underlying cause?
hint: The condition described here is a serious complication of preterm birth.
learning_objective: Recognize germinal matrix hemorrhage in preterm infants.

answers.explanation_why: Galactose-1-phosphate uridylyltransferase deficiency is the underlying cause of galactosemia, which, if left untreated, may present with lethargy, hypotonia, and seizures, as seen here. However, the absence of cataracts (may present within the first days of life), jaundice, and hepatomegaly, make this diagnosis less likely.
answers.explanation_but: Galactosemia can cause coagulopathy and increased risk of bleeding, which may predispose children to the condition of this patient.

answers.explanation_why: Apoptosis of lower motor neurons is the underlying mechanism of spinal muscular atrophy, which is a possible cause of muscular hypotonia in infants. The most severe type (Werdnig-Hoffmann disease) may manifest immediately after birth or up to 6 months of age. Proximal muscles, mostly of the lower extremities, are usually involved symmetrically. However, this patient's seizures, bulging anterior fontanelle, impaired pupillary response, and roving eye movements would not be consistent with this diagnosis.

Hydrocephalus due to congenital causes, such as the Arnold-Chiari malformation, Dandy-Walker malformation, and intrauterine infections, may present in neonates with lethargy, tense fontanelles, seizures, and changes in vital signs due to brain stem compression (e.g., irregular breathing). However, elevated intracranial pressure usually manifests with rapidly increasing circumference of the head in neonates, which is not seen in this infant. Furthermore, instead of the roving eye movements, a downward deviation of the eyes (sunset eye sign) would be expected in patients with hydrocephalus.

images.title: Manifestations of increased intracranial pressure in infants

answers.explanation_why: Phenylalanine hydroxylase deficiency is the underlying cause of phenylketonuria. While most patients are asymptomatic at birth, half of patients with phenylketonuria (PKU) have seizures with cerebral foci, a lag of psychomotor development and a musty body odor by 4–6 months of age. Additional features include light, pale hair and blue eyes (due to decreased melanin production). Since most patients are asymptomatic until severe and often irreversible complications have occurred, direct measurement of phenylalanine levels is an important part of newborn screening for metabolic disorders. The screening test is performed on the second day after birth using blood obtained from a heel prick.

Germinal matrix hemorrhage is the underlying cause of intraventricular hemorrhage (IVH) in preterm infants. IVH is a common complication in preterm infants that usually occurs within the first five days after birth. It is typically seen in neonates weighing < 1500 g and born before 32 weeks' gestation due to the fragility of the germinal matrix. Additional risk factors include peripartal chorioamnionitis and hypoxia (as suggested by this patient's low Apgar scores). Most infants with IVH are asymptomatic, but saltatory (over several days) or, more rarely, catastrophic (over minutes to hours) courses are also possible. Symptoms include lethargy, hypotonia, irregular respirations, seizures, bulging anterior fontanelle, cranial nerve abnormalities (e.g., pupil reacting sluggishly to light), and changes in eye movement (e.g., roving eye movements), all of which this patient has.

Cranial ultrasonography is the preferred method to diagnose IVH in the newborn. Since most patients are asymptomatic, screening ultrasounds are routinely performed in infants with a birth weight < 1500 g and delivery before 30 weeks' gestation.

images.title: Neonatal intraventricular hemorrhage (IVH)
images.description:
Ultrasound head (top row: coronal plane; bottom row: parasagittal plane) of a newbornThe first column shows bleeding confined to the subependymal germinal matrix (red overlay), which is consistent with grade 1 IVH.
The second column shows blood occupying less than 50% of the left lateral ventricle (red overlay), with no enlargement of the lateral ventricles (yellow overlay) or the cavum septi pellucidi (green overlay). In addition, the choroid plexus is clearly demarcated (blue overlay). Together, these findings are consistent with grade 2 IVH.
The third column shows blood occupying more than 50% of the lateral ventricles (red overlay) with enlargement of the cavum septi pellucidi (green overlay) and both lateral ventricles (yellow overlay). This appearance is consistent with grade 3 IVH.These features suggest impaired progressive posthemorrhagic ventricular dilatation (PHVD) due to associated impairment of CSF circulation, which is a potential complication of high-grade IVH.

question_text: A 70-year-old man with chronic myopia comes to the physician because of a 4-month history of difficulty seeing distant objects, especially at night, despite wearing glasses. Examination shows bilateral narrowing of peripheral visual fields, cupping of the optic discs, and elevated intraocular pressure. Gonioscopy shows no abnormalities. He is prescribed a drug. At a follow-up examination several months later, intraocular pressure is normal, but darkening of the iris and an increase in the length of the eyelashes is observed. Which of the following drugs was most likely prescribed?
content_preview: A 70-year-old man with chronic myopia comes to the physician because of a 4-month history of difficulty seeing distant objects, especially at night, despite wearing glasses. Examination shows bilateral narrowing of peripheral visual fields, cupping of the optic discs, and elevated intraocular pressure. Gonioscopy shows no abnormalities. He is prescribed a drug. At a follow-up examination several months later, intraocular pressure is normal, but darkening of the iris and an increase in the length of the eyelashes is observed. Which of the following drugs was most likely prescribed?
hint: The loss of peripheral vision, optic disc cupping, and elevated intraocular pressure in this patient with a normal gonioscopy are diagnostic of open-angle glaucoma, for which he has been given first-line therapy.
learning_objective: Recognize the side effects of prostaglandin F2α analogs used in glaucoma therapy.

answers.explanation_why: Timolol, a topical beta-blocker, can reduce IOP by decreasing aqueous humor synthesis. However, it is not the first-line treatment for open-angle glaucoma. Local side effects include dry eyes and superficial punctate keratopathy, neither of which is seen in this patient. If the drug is absorbed systemically, classic adverse effects of beta blockers may be seen, including shortness of breath, bronchospasm, and bradycardia.

Acetazolamide, a carbonic anhydrase inhibitor, can reduce IOP by decreasing aqueous humor synthesis. However, it is not the first-line treatment for open-angle glaucoma. Furthermore, side effects of acetazolamide include hypokalemia, sulfa allergy, and hyperammonemia with paresthesias, none of which are seen in this patient.

Pilocarpine, a cholinomimetic drug, can be used to treat open-angle glaucoma by increasing trabecular aqueous humor outflow. However, it is not the first-line treatment. Moreover, the most common side effects include cholinergic side effects (sweating, rhinorrhea, dizziness, and nausea), none of which are seen in this patient.

Apraclonidine, an alpha-2 agonist, can reduce IOP by increasing trabecular aqueous humor outflow and by decreasing aqueous humor synthesis. However, it is not the first-line treatment for open-angle glaucoma. Side effects include blurry vision, ocular hyperemia, foreign body sensation, and pruritus, none of which are seen in this patient.

Latanoprost is a prostaglandin F2α analog, which increases aqueous humor outflow via the uveoscleral pathway, thereby reducing intraocular pressure (IOP). Darkening of the iris, changes in the density, length, and color of eyelashes, and epithelial keratopathy are known side effects of long-term use of this drug.

images.title: Mechanism of action: glaucoma medication
images.description:
PGF2α analogues (e.g., latanoprost)
– Reduce outflow resistance of trabecular meshwork
– Increase uveoscleral outflow by relaxing ciliary muscle and disrupting turnover of extracellular matrixβ-blockers (e.g., timolol): diminish aqueous humor production by inhibiting Na+/K+ ATPaseα2 agonists (e.g., brimonidine) 
– Reduce episcleral venous pressure 
– Diminish aqueous humor production by inhibiting Na+/K+ ATPaseCholinomimetics (e.g., pilocarpine)
– Widen trabecular meshwork via ciliary muscle activation
– Open up the iridocorneal angle by activating the iris sphincter muscle (miosis)Carbonic anhydrase inhibitors (CAI; e.g., acetazolamide): diminish aqueous humor productionRho-kinase inhibitors (e.g., netarsudil)
– Increase trabecular outflow
– Lower episcleral venous pressure
– Decrease aqueous humor production by increasing noradrenergic transmission

question_text: A 16-year-old boy is brought to the physician for a follow-up appointment. He has a seizure disorder treated with valproic acid. He has always had difficulties with his schoolwork. He was able to walk independently at the age of 2 years and was able to use a fork and spoon at the age of 3 years. Ophthalmic examination shows hyperpigmented iris nodules bilaterally. A photograph of his skin examination findings is shown. This patient is at increased risk for which of the following conditions?
content_preview: A 16-year-old boy is brought to the physician for a follow-up appointment. He has a seizure disorder treated with valproic acid. He has always had difficulties with his schoolwork. He was able to walk independently at the age of 2 years and was able to use a fork and spoon at the age of 3 years. Ophthalmic examination shows hyperpigmented iris nodules bilaterally. A photograph of his skin examination findings is shown. This patient is at increased risk for which of the following conditions?
hint: This boy presents with a seizure disorder, intellectual disability, developmental delay (walking well and using a fork and spoon should occur at ∼ 14–15 months), café au lait spots (hyperpigmented macules), and hyperpigmented iris nodules (Lisch nodules), all of which are consistent with neurofibromatosis type 1 (NF1).
learning_objective: Recognize neurofibromatosis type 1, and recall its associated conditions.

answers.explanation_why: Vestibular schwannomas, especially bilaterally, are classically associated with neurofibromatosis type 2. NF2 typically presents with complications of schwannomas (e.g., hearing loss or balance problems) and may cause other CNS tumors (e.g., meningioma). Hyperpigmented iris nodules and cognitive impairment, as seen in this patient, are not associated with NF2.

Hemangioblastomas are associated with von Hippel-Lindau disease. Affected patients generally present with renal and pancreatic cysts along with numerous benign and malignant tumors (e.g., hemangioblastomas of the retina, cerebellum, brain stem, and spine; pheochromocytoma; and bilateral renal cell carcinoma). The condition, however, would not explain this patient's skin and cognitive findings.

images.title: Cerebellar hemangioblastoma
images.description: MRI head (with contrast; axial view)A brightly enhancing, sharply delimited nodular mass (white arrow) with nonenhancing, cystic areas is visible within the right cerebellar hemisphere.These findings are consistent with cerebellar hemangioblastoma.

answers.explanation_why: Pheochromocytomas are classically associated with neurofibromatosis type 1. Patients with NF1 are also at increased risk for optic gliomas, especially as children. Hereditary pheochromocytomas are also associated with von Hippel-Lindau disease and multiple endocrine neoplasia type 2 (MEN 2A, MEN 2B).

images.title: Clinical features of neurofibromatosis type 1 and type 2
images.description: Neurofibromatoses are autosomal dominant-inherited neurocutaneous syndromes that are caused by mutations in tumor suppressor genes. Neurofibromatosis type 1 has a typical onset in adolescence and manifests with multiple neurofibromas, benign peripheral nerve sheath tumors that originate from neural crest cells. Neurofibromatosis type 2 has a later onset in early adulthood and manifests with multiple cerebral and spinal tumors.

answers.explanation_why: Leptomeningeal angiomas are seen in Sturge-Weber syndrome. Affected patients may suffer from recurrent seizures owing to these intracranial angiomas. Intellectual disability is also common. However, the distinguishing cutaneous manifestation of this condition is the port wine stain. This patient instead has hyperpigmented macules and pigmented iris nodules, neither of which are seen in Sturge-Weber syndrome.

Cardiac rhabdomyomas are classically associated with tuberous sclerosis, which can also present with intellectual disability and seizures. However, cutaneous symptoms include hypopigmented ash-leaf spots but not hyperpigmented café au lait spots.

images.title: Neurofibromatosis type 1
images.description: Multiple light brown macules with irregular borders (café-au-lait spots) are visible on the upper left arm, shoulder, and back.This presence of multiple café-au-lait spots is highly suggestive of neurofibromatosis type 1.

question_text: A 60-year-old man is brought to the emergency department because of a 30-minute history of dizziness and shortness of breath. After establishing the diagnosis, treatment with a drug is administered. Shortly after administration, the patient develops severe left eye pain and decreased vision of the left eye, along with nausea and vomiting. Ophthalmologic examination shows a fixed, mid-dilated pupil and a narrowed anterior chamber of the left eye. The patient was most likely treated for which of the following conditions?
content_preview: A 60-year-old man is brought to the emergency department because of a 30-minute history of dizziness and shortness of breath. After establishing the diagnosis, treatment with a drug is administered. Shortly after administration, the patient develops severe left eye pain and decreased vision of the left eye, along with nausea and vomiting. Ophthalmologic examination shows a fixed, mid-dilated pupil and a narrowed anterior chamber of the left eye. The patient was most likely treated for which of the following conditions?
hint: The patient's severe eye pain, fixed, mid-dilated pupil, and narrowed anterior chamber on examination are suggestive of acute angle closure glaucoma, which can be precipitated by muscarinic antagonists.
learning_objective: Recognize complications of atropine in atrioventricular block treatment.

answers.explanation_why: The patient was most likely treated for atrioventricular block (AV block), which can manifest with shortness of breath and dizziness. Atropine (a muscarinic antagonist) is used to increase the heart rate in AV block due to its ability to reduce the effects of the parasympathetic nervous system on the SA node and the AV node. In the eye, atropine causes pupillary dilatation, which can result in narrowing of the anterior chamber angle and obstructed flow of aqueous humor between the posterior and anterior chamber, potentially leading to acute angle-closure glaucoma.

images.title: Mechanism of primary angle-closure
images.description: Cross-section of the anterior portion of the eyePressure rises in the posterior chamber if the flow of aqueous humor from the posterior to the anterior chamber is obstructed due to a functional block (pupillary block) between the lens and the pupillary portion of the iris. This increase in pressure causes the peripheral portion of the iris to move anteriorly and to cover parts or all of the chamber angle (particularly in mydriasis or mid-dilation), potentially leading to acute angle-closure with massively increased intraocular pressure. In certain anatomical variants (e.g., shallow anterior chamber), the chamber angle is already narrow and therefore increases the probability of acute and/or chronic angle-closure, which can lead to damage of the optic nerve (glaucoma).

answers.explanation_why: Hypertensive crisis may present with dizziness and shortness of breath. However, the drugs used in its management (mainly nitrates, calcium channel blockers) are not associated with angle-closure glaucoma.

Atrial fibrillation could explain this patient's symptoms of shortness of breath and dizziness. However, drugs used in the management of atrial fibrillation such as beta blockers, calcium channel blockers, digoxin, and anticoagulants are not associated with acute angle-closure glaucoma.

Chronic mitral regurgitation could explain this patient's symptoms of dizziness and shortness of breath. Depending on the degree of LV dysfunction it is either treated conservatively or surgically (valve repair or replacement). Acute mitral regurgitation is an emergency in which diuretics, nitrates, and antihypertensive drugs are used to stabilize the patient. None of these drugs are commonly associated with angle-closure glaucoma.

While a pulmonary embolism could explain the patient's initial presenting symptoms of dizziness and shortness of breath, non-invasive treatment usually consists of O_2, analgesics (e.g. NSAIDs), and heparin, none of which is commonly associated with angle-closure glaucoma.

Pleuritis is an inflammation of the pleura that lines the lungs and is commonly caused by viral infection. It usually presents with a sharp chest pain that worsens with inhalation, but shortness of breath and dizziness are rare. Viral pleuritis is usually managed with analgesic drugs, e.g. NSAIDs, which do not precipitate angle-closure glaucoma.

question_text: A 36-year-old man comes to the physician because of a 1-month history of coughing, fatigue, night sweats, and 5-kg (11-lb) weight loss. His cough is productive of blood-stained sputum. He works as an engineer and traveled to South Africa 2 months ago for a site inspection of a mine. He has no history of serious illness and takes no medications. He appears ill with generalized wasting. His temperature is 38.2°C (100.8°F), pulse is 105/min, and blood pressure is 122/84 mm Hg. Respiratory examination shows dullness to percussion over the right lower lobe and crackles on auscultation. Chest x-ray shows consolidation in the right lower lobe and ipsilateral hilar lymphadenopathy. Microscopy of the sputum shows acid-fast bacteria. Antibiotic therapy is initiated. At his follow-up visit 1 month later, the patient reports bilateral progressive, painless, blurred vision and an inability to distinguish between red and green. An adverse effect of which of the following drugs is the most likely cause of this patient's ocular symptoms?
content_preview: A 36-year-old man comes to the physician because of a 1-month history of coughing, fatigue, night sweats, and 5-kg (11-lb) weight loss. His cough is productive of blood-stained sputum. He works as an engineer and traveled to South Africa 2 months ago for a site inspection of a mine. He has no history of serious illness and takes no medications. He appears ill with generalized wasting. His temperature is 38.2°C (100.8°F), pulse is 105/min, and blood pressure is 122/84 mm Hg. Respiratory examination shows dullness to percussion over the right lower lobe and crackles on auscultation. Chest x-ray shows consolidation in the right lower lobe and ipsilateral hilar lymphadenopathy. Microscopy of the sputum shows acid-fast bacteria. Antibiotic therapy is initiated. At his follow-up visit 1 month later, the patient reports bilateral progressive, painless, blurred vision and an inability to distinguish between red and green. An adverse effect of which of the following drugs is the most likely cause of this patient's ocular symptoms?
hint: This patient presents with symptoms of optic neuritis (blurred vision, dyschromatopsia) following the initiation of tuberculosis treatment. Irreversible blindness may develop with continued use of this drug.
learning_objective: Recall the adverse effects related to ethambutol use.

answers.explanation_why: Rifampin is used in the intensive and continuation phases of tuberculosis treatment. Common adverse effects of rifampin include flu-like symptoms, hepatotoxicity, and a characteristic harmless orange discoloration of body fluids (e.g., urine, and tears). This drug does not cause optic neuritis.

images.title: Orange urine secondary to rifampicin therapy

answers.explanation_why: Pyrazinamide is used in the intensive phase of tuberculosis treatment. Common adverse effects include hyperuricemia, hepatotoxicity, and gastrointestinal disturbances (e.g., vomiting). This drug does not cause optic neuritis.

Ethambutol is used in conjunction with other agents to treat active tuberculosis during the initial phase of therapy. Optic neuritis is an important adverse effect of ethambutol and can manifest with decreased visual acuity, central and peripheral scotomas, and dyschromatopsia. Although its mechanism is unknown, the risk of ethambutol-induced optic neuritis increases with dose. Individuals receiving ethambutol should have ophthalmic evaluations performed at baseline and periodically during treatment.

Isoniazid (INH) is used in the intensive and continuation phases of tuberculosis treatment. Liver injury is a common adverse effect of INH, usually causing mildly elevated transaminases and, more rarely, fulminant hepatitis. Although INH can cause optic neuritis, it is a rare adverse effect that is more likely to develop with a different antibiotic.

Pyridoxine is an essential cofactor in the synthesis of neurotransmitters and heme. Because it competes with isoniazid (INH) in neurotransmitter synthesis, the drugs are commonly used together in antituberculosis therapy. Thus, pyridoxine should be used as an adjuvant in every regimen that includes INH. However, supplementation with pyridoxine does not cause optic neuritis.

question_text: A 61-year-old woman comes to the emergency department because of a 2-hour history of headache, nausea, blurred vision, and pain in the left eye. She has had similar symptoms in the past. Her vital signs are within normal limits. The left eye is red and is hard on palpation. The left pupil is mid-dilated and nonreactive to light. Administration of which of the following drugs should be avoided in this patient?
content_preview: A 61-year-old woman comes to the emergency department because of a 2-hour history of headache, nausea, blurred vision, and pain in the left eye. She has had similar symptoms in the past. Her vital signs are within normal limits. The left eye is red and is hard on palpation. The left pupil is mid-dilated and nonreactive to light. Administration of which of the following drugs should be avoided in this patient?
hint: This patient has a unilateral red, hard, severely painful eye with a mid-dilated, nonreactive pupil as well as frontal headaches, vomiting, and nausea. These features are consistent with acute angle-closure glaucoma.
learning_objective: Recognize acute angle-closure glaucoma, and recall contraindications for mydriatic drugs.

answers.explanation_why: Acetazolamide reduces aqueous humor production via carbonic anhydrase inhibition and is often given in conjunction with other medications for the treatment of acute angle-closure glaucoma. Acetazolamide should be avoided in individuals with sulfa drug allergy, cirrhosis, or severe hypokalemia.

images.title: Mechanism of action: glaucoma medication
images.description:
PGF2α analogues (e.g., latanoprost)
– Reduce outflow resistance of trabecular meshwork
– Increase uveoscleral outflow by relaxing ciliary muscle and disrupting turnover of extracellular matrixβ-blockers (e.g., timolol): diminish aqueous humor production by inhibiting Na+/K+ ATPaseα2 agonists (e.g., brimonidine) 
– Reduce episcleral venous pressure 
– Diminish aqueous humor production by inhibiting Na+/K+ ATPaseCholinomimetics (e.g., pilocarpine)
– Widen trabecular meshwork via ciliary muscle activation
– Open up the iridocorneal angle by activating the iris sphincter muscle (miosis)Carbonic anhydrase inhibitors (CAI; e.g., acetazolamide): diminish aqueous humor productionRho-kinase inhibitors (e.g., netarsudil)
– Increase trabecular outflow
– Lower episcleral venous pressure
– Decrease aqueous humor production by increasing noradrenergic transmission

answers.explanation_why: Epinephrine is an alpha-adrenergic and beta-adrenergic receptor agonist. Epinephrine is used topically to treat open-angle glaucoma because alpha-1 receptor stimulation induces vasoconstriction and subsequently decreases aqueous humor production. Alpha-1 receptor agonism also causes pupillary dilation (mydriasis), which decreases the iridocorneal angle and subsequently decreases aqueous humor outflow. In individuals with angle-closure glaucoma, mydriasis can rapidly increase intraocular pressure and lead to permanent loss of vision. Therefore, epinephrine is contraindicated in this patient. Mydriatic eyedrops (e.g., atropine, homatropine, and tropicamide), which are often used for ophthalmologic examination, should also be avoided in patients suspected to have angle-closure glaucoma for the same reason.

images.title: Anterior chamber angle
images.description: The anterior chamber angle is formed by the iris, cornea, and sclera. It contains the trabecular meshwork, which drains the aqueous humor. The spaces in the trabecular tissue are called spaces of Fontana, which connect the anterior chamber and Schlemm's canal, which is located in the sclera. The aqueous humor drains via Schlemm's canal into the episcleral veins.

answers.explanation_why: Pilocarpine, a muscarinic agonist, is used to treat primary angle-closure glaucoma. M3 receptor stimulation causes miosis, which opens the iridocorneal angle and subsequently reduces intraocular pressure by increasing aqueous humor outflow. Pilocarpine is contraindicated in patients with asthma or COPD, and in cases of angle-closure glaucoma secondary to iritis or lens luxation because miosis can worsen eye pain or glaucoma. The history of similar symptoms in the past suggests primary rather than secondary angle-closure glaucoma.

answers.explanation_why: Apraclonidine, an alpha-2 agonist, is commonly used to acutely reduce intraocular pressure because it decreases aqueous humor production. Apraclonidine is a component of the treatment regimen for individuals with acute angle-closure glaucoma and would be indicated in this patient. This alpha-2 agonist should be avoided in individuals with hypersensitivity to apraclonidine or clonidine and in patients taking MAO inhibitors.

answers.explanation_why: Timolol, a nonselective beta blocker, is commonly used in the treatment of acute angle-closure glaucoma because the inhibition of beta-2 receptors decreases aqueous humor production and leads to contraction of the ciliary muscle. This process increases the pore size of trabecular meshwork and subsequently increases aqueous outflow. Timolol should be avoided in individuals with asthma, COPD, or a heart block.

question_text: An 81-year-old man comes to the emergency department because of left-sided visual loss that started 1 hour ago. He describes initially seeing jagged edges, which was followed by abrupt, complete loss of central vision in the left eye. He has hypertension and type 2 diabetes mellitus. Blood pressure is 145/89 mm Hg. Neurologic examination shows no abnormalities. A photograph of the fundoscopic findings is shown. Which of the following tests is most likely to confirm this patient's underlying condition?
content_preview: An 81-year-old man comes to the emergency department because of left-sided visual loss that started 1 hour ago. He describes initially seeing jagged edges, which was followed by abrupt, complete loss of central vision in the left eye. He has hypertension and type 2 diabetes mellitus. Blood pressure is 145/89 mm Hg. Neurologic examination shows no abnormalities. A photograph of the fundoscopic findings is shown. Which of the following tests is most likely to confirm this patient's underlying condition?
hint: The fundoscopy shows a pale retina with a cherry red spot at the fovea. Together with sudden, painless, transient monocular vision, this finding is concerning for central retinal artery occlusion. Causes include embolism (most common), thrombosis, vasculitis, and fibromuscular dysplasia.
learning_objective: Recognize central retinal artery occlusion, and choose the most appropriate diagnostic study.

answers.explanation_why: Increased glycated hemoglobin concentrations are seen in patients with poorly controlled diabetes mellitus. This patient has a history of diabetes and is therefore at risk of diabetic retinopathy, a condition that can cause visual impairment and blindness. However, vision loss in diabetic retinopathy is typically bilateral and occurs over the course of many years, as opposed to the abrupt, unilateral vision loss seen in this patient. Direct fundoscopy in a patient with diabetic retinopathy shows microaneurysms, hard exudates, and macular edema (nonproliferative) or retinal neovascularization and vitreous hemorrhage (proliferative).

Carotid artery duplex ultrasonography can be used to evaluate for carotid atherosclerosis, a condition that increases the risk of thromboembolism due to rupture of atherosclerotic plaques, which is the most common cause of central retinal artery occlusion. This patient has several atherosclerotic risk factors, including advanced age, hypertension, and diabetes mellitus, which make thromboembolism secondary to carotid artery atherosclerosis the most likely cause of his symptoms.

images.title: Central retinal artery occlusion
images.description: Left: lateral view of the right eye in longitudinal (sagittal) section. Depiction of an embolism in the central retinal artery causing retinal ischemia.Right: fundus photography of the right eye. Diffuse retinal ischemia causes edema in the inner retinal layers, manifesting as a gray-white discoloration of the retina (most markedly around the fovea; dotted circle). The fovea centralis, where the inner retinal layers are moved to the side, is not affected by edema. The underlying, well-vascularized choroid shines through, appearing as a cherry-red spot.

answers.explanation_why: Erythrocyte sedimentation rate (ESR) is a nonspecific inflammatory marker that can be increased in cases of infection, inflammation, or malignancy. Temporal arteritis can cause significant elevation in ESR and is a rare etiology of central retinal artery occlusion, the most likely diagnosis in this patient. However, he lacks other symptoms of temporal arteritis (e.g., headache, jaw claudication, constitutional symptoms). Moreover, a temporal artery biopsy, not ESR, is the gold standard for the diagnosis of temporal arteritis.

A CD4+ T cell count can be used to track the prognosis in patients diagnosed with or suspected of having HIV. Patients with a low CD4 count are more susceptible to cytomegalovirus, which can cause retinitis and vision loss. However, CMV retinitis causes progressive loss of vision over days as opposed to the abrupt onset seen in this patient's case. Direct fundoscopy in a patient with CMV retinitis shows retinal hemorrhages and cotton wool spots.

An optic tonometer is used to measure intraocular pressure (IOP). Increased IOP is seen in patients with glaucoma and patients with increased intracranial pressure (ICP). Both of these conditions can lead to visual impairment. In particular, acute, closed-angle glaucoma can cause sudden-onset visual loss. However, it is typically painful and associated with headache and vomiting, none of which is seen in this patient. Direct fundoscopy in patients with increased ICP shows papilledema.

images.title: Acute central retinal artery occlusion
images.description:
Fundus photography of the left eyeThe fovea centralis looks dark red (cherry-red spot; green overlay) due to the transparency of this part of the retina lacking nerve fibres, causing the well-vascularized choroid to shine through. The surrounding retina is pale and opacified, indicating ischemic edema. Narrow retinal arterioles with box-carring (examples indicated by arrowheads) are also visible.

These findings are typical of acute central retinal artery occlusion.

question_text: A 9-year-old boy is brought to the physician for evaluation of a 3-day history of fever, sore throat, and itchy, red eyes. His symptoms began while he was away at summer camp. His immunizations are not up-to-date. He appears ill. His temperature is 39.1°C (102.3°F). Physical examination shows erythema and edema of the conjunctivae and posterior pharyngeal wall. There is bilateral, tender, preauricular lymphadenopathy. Further evaluation shows infection with a DNA virus. Which of the following is the most likely causal pathogen?
content_preview: A 9-year-old boy is brought to the physician for evaluation of a 3-day history of fever, sore throat, and itchy, red eyes. His symptoms began while he was away at summer camp. His immunizations are not up-to-date. He appears ill. His temperature is 39.1°C (102.3°F). Physical examination shows erythema and edema of the conjunctivae and posterior pharyngeal wall. There is bilateral, tender, preauricular lymphadenopathy. Further evaluation shows infection with a DNA virus. Which of the following is the most likely causal pathogen?
hint: This patient is presenting with signs and symptoms of pharyngoconjunctival fever, a classic manifestation of a specific viral infection.
learning_objective: Recognize pharyngoconjunctival fever, and recall its causal pathogen.

answers.explanation_why: Adenovirus is a nonenveloped, double-stranded DNA virus with a linear structure and the most likely underlying cause of this patient's symptoms. Conjunctivitis and febrile pharyngitis occurring simultaneously in a patient who has spent time in close proximity to other individuals (e.g., summer camp) is highly suspicious for adenovirus infection. Apart from pharyngoconjunctivitis, adenovirus may cause gastroenteritis, pneumonia, acute hemorrhagic cystitis, and epidemic keratoconjunctivitis.

Parvovirus is a nonenveloped, single-stranded DNA virus and the causative organism of erythema infectiosum (fifth disease). Fifth disease most commonly manifests with mild, cold-like symptoms, similar to this patient's presentation, after which a characteristic rash on the cheeks develops (slapped-cheek rash). The lack of rash in this patient, taken together with the simultaneous appearance of both pharyngitis and conjunctivitis, make another diagnosis more likely.

Picornaviridae comprise a heterogeneous group of viruses that are associated with a wide variety of diseases ranging from the common cold (rhinovirus) to viral meningitis (e.g., coxsackievirus, echovirus). However, picornaviridae are nonenveloped, positive-sense, single-stranded RNA viruses, whereas this patient has a DNA virus. Moreover, the picornaviridae are not specifically linked to pharyngoconjunctivitis.

Paramyxoviridae are a family of several viruses including the parainfluenza virus, mumps virus, and measles virus. Measles causes findings similar to those of this patient, including conjunctivitis, fever, pharyngitis, and lymphadenopathy. Moreover, an incomplete vaccination history could support the suspicion of measles in a 10-year-old child. However, this patient does not have a rash, as a measles patient likely would. Furthermore, paramyxoviridae are RNA viruses, while this patient has a DNA virus.

Human herpes virus 6 is an enveloped, double-stranded DNA virus with a linear structure associated with the development of roseola infantum. Roseola manifests with high fever for a few days, followed by a rapid return to an afebrile state and the onset of a maculopapular rash. Affected individuals may also develop pharyngitis and conjunctivitis, which would be consistent with this patient's presentation. However, this patient's age makes roseola very unlikely, as most individuals are seropositive by the age of 3. Also, postoccipital lymphadenopathy rather than preauricular is more characteristic of roseola.

Human herpes virus 4, better known as Epstein-Barr virus, is an enveloped, double-stranded DNA virus and the causative agent of infectious mononucleosis. The pharyngitis seen in this patient could be attributed to mono. However, individuals with mono would not be expected to present with conjunctivitis or preauricular lymphadenopathy, but rather, with hepatosplenomegaly and cervical lymphadenopathy.

question_text: A 68-year-old woman comes to the physician for evaluation of diminished vision for several months. Twenty-eight years ago, she was diagnosed with systemic lupus erythematosus, which has been well controlled with hydroxychloroquine. Fundoscopic examination shows concentric rings of hypopigmentation and hyperpigmentation surrounding the fovea bilaterally. Visual field examination of this patient is most likely to show which of the following findings?
content_preview: A 68-year-old woman comes to the physician for evaluation of diminished vision for several months. Twenty-eight years ago, she was diagnosed with systemic lupus erythematosus, which has been well controlled with hydroxychloroquine. Fundoscopic examination shows concentric rings of hypopigmentation and hyperpigmentation surrounding the fovea bilaterally. Visual field examination of this patient is most likely to show which of the following findings?
hint: The concentric rings of hypopigmentation and hyperpigmentation (“bull's eye maculopathy”) are an adverse effect of hydroxychloroquine therapy. Hydroxychloroquine maculopathy specifically targets the macular rods and cones but spares these same structures within the fovea.
learning_objective: Recognize hydroxychloroquine-induced retinopathy, and recall its characteristic visual field finding.

answers.explanation_why: Bitemporal hemianopia describes the loss of vision in the outer halves of the visual field of both eyes. It is typically caused by a compression of the central region of the optic chiasm due to midline pathologies such as aneurysms, pituitary masses, or craniopharyngioma. Treatment with hydroxychloroquine, however, is associated with damage to the retina itself.

Monocular blindness describes a total visual loss in one eye that can be caused by ischemia of the vessels supplying the retina, retinal vein occlusion, optic nerve compression, or optic nerve neuropathy. Treatment with hydroxychloroquine, however, is not associated with such a complication.

Hemianopia with macular sparing is a form of homonymous hemianopia in which the central visual field is spared. The visual cortex receives dual blood supply from the posterior cerebral artery (supplies the anterior visual cortex, which processes peripheral vision) and the deep branch of the middle cerebral artery (supplying the occipital pole, which processes information from the central visual field). Infarcts of the PCA would therefore lead to hemianopia with macular sparing. Hydroxychloroquine, in contrast, may specifically damage the macula.

images.title: Posterior cerebral artery infarct
images.description:
A posterior cerebral artery infarct (left-sided here) typically leads to the following:
– Contralateral sensory loss (due to lateral thalamic involvement)
– Contralateral homonymous hemianopsia with macular sparing (because the macula receives collateral vascular supply from the middle cerebral artery)

answers.explanation_why: Paracentral scotoma describes an off-center area of visual loss surrounded by normal acuity in the rest of the visual field. As in this case, patients often report difficulty with tasks involving fine visual skills, such as reading, as well as visual color deficits. Paracentral scotoma represents a more advanced stage of retinopathy and is an irreversible complication of hydroxychloroquine whose incidence increases with both the dose and the duration of treatment.

Homonymous hemianopia describes the loss of vision of a unilateral visual field in both eyes. This occurs due to lesions of the optic tract, such as middle cerebral artery infarction, tumors or infections. Treatment with hydroxychloroquine, however, is associated with damage to the retina itself.

Binasal hemianopia describes the loss of vision in the inner halves of the visual field of both eyes. It is a rare finding caused by bilateral lesions of the outermost fibers of the optic chiasm which hold the uncrossed fibers of the optic nerves. Such lesions may result from aneurysms or tumors. Treatment with hydroxychloroquine, however, is associated with damage to the retina itself.

question_text: A previously healthy 46-year-old man comes to the physician for an 8-month history of headache that is more severe in the mornings. His blood pressure is 151/92 mm Hg. Examination shows enlargement of the nose, forehead, and jaw as well as the hands, fingers, and feet. Ophthalmologic examination shows impaired vision in the outer peripheral fields of both eyes. Laboratory studies show a fasting serum glucose concentration of 225 mg/dL. Which of the following findings is most likely to confirm the diagnosis?
content_preview: A previously healthy 46-year-old man comes to the physician for an 8-month history of headache that is more severe in the mornings. His blood pressure is 151/92 mm Hg. Examination shows enlargement of the nose, forehead, and jaw as well as the hands, fingers, and feet. Ophthalmologic examination shows impaired vision in the outer peripheral fields of both eyes. Laboratory studies show a fasting serum glucose concentration of 225 mg/dL. Which of the following findings is most likely to confirm the diagnosis?
hint: This patient's presentation is consistent with acromegaly (hypertension, coarsened and enlarged features, hyperglycemia). His headache and bitemporal hemianopsia indicate local mass effect.
learning_objective: Recognize acromegaly, and recall its diagnostic finding.

answers.explanation_why: Low serum GH can be seen in a number of conditions, e.g., following brain surgery, severe head injury, infection, or in patients with pituitary tumors. Although this patient's clinical symptoms (headache and bitemporal hemianopsia) suggest local mass effect in the pituitary, he also presents with features of acromegaly, which is classically associated with excess serum GH.

Elevated urine cortisol levels are a typical finding in Cushing syndrome, which is most commonly caused by a pituitary adenoma. Pituitary adenoma can result in bitemporal hemianopsia and Cushing syndrome can manifest with hyperglycemia. However, other features of Cushing syndrome include proximal muscle weakness, central obesity, and abdominal striae, none of which are present in this patient.

Low insulin levels are seen in patients with type 1 diabetes mellitus, in which pancreatic beta cells are destroyed, resulting in persistently elevated serum glucose levels. This patient's hyperglycemia is instead due to the endocrinopathy of acromegaly, in which excess growth hormone (GH) levels stimulate gluconeogenesis, causing a state of insulin resistance. Hyperglycemia then induces compensatory hyperinsulinemia; therefore, elevated serum insulin levels would be expected in this patient.

Low urine osmolality is typical in patients with diabetes insipidus, which can occur secondary to brain tumors. Though this patient presents with features suggestive of a local mass effect from the pituitary, he does not have symptoms of diabetes insipidus, such as polyuria, nocturia, or polydipsia.

Elevated prolactin levels (hyperprolactinemia) can result from prolactin-secreting pituitary adenomas, which can also cause bitemporal hemianopsia and headache, both of which are seen here. In men, symptoms of prolactinoma typically include gynecomastia and hypogonadotropic hypogonadism (presenting with erectile dysfunction and loss of libido). Elevated prolactin is rarely seen in individuals with acromegaly, such as this man. In addition, he lacks classic symptoms of hyperprolactinemia, making a different finding more likely.

answers.content: Elevated serum insulin-like growth factor-1 concentration
answers.explanation_why:
An elevated serum IGF-1 concentration is the most likely finding for this patient with acromegaly, a condition most commonly caused by a GH-secreting pituitary adenoma. Excess secretion of GH stimulates IGF-1 synthesis, which in turn stimulates cell growth and proliferation while inhibiting apoptosis. IGF-1 is part of the negative feedback cycle that governs normal GH production, so IGF-1 levels are high in response to the pathologically elevated GH levels.

IGF-1 is the most reliable indicator of acromegaly and measurement of IGF-1 levels is the first step in diagnosing patients with suspected acromegaly. Normal levels of IGF-1 rule out acromegaly as a diagnosis.

question_text: A 9-month-old girl is brought to the physician by her parents for multiple episodes of unresponsiveness in which she stares blankly and her eyelids flutter. She has gradually lost control of her neck and ability to roll over during the past 2 months. She is startled by loud noises and does not maintain eye contact. Her parents are of Ashkenazi Jewish descent. Neurological examination shows generalized hypotonia. Deep tendon reflexes are 3+ bilaterally. Fundoscopy shows bright red macular spots bilaterally. Abdominal examination shows no abnormalities. Which of the following metabolites is most likely to accumulate due to this patient's disease?
content_preview: A 9-month-old girl is brought to the physician by her parents for multiple episodes of unresponsiveness in which she stares blankly and her eyelids flutter. She has gradually lost control of her neck and ability to roll over during the past 2 months. She is startled by loud noises and does not maintain eye contact. Her parents are of Ashkenazi Jewish descent. Neurological examination shows generalized hypotonia. Deep tendon reflexes are 3+ bilaterally. Fundoscopy shows bright red macular spots bilaterally. Abdominal examination shows no abnormalities. Which of the following metabolites is most likely to accumulate due to this patient's disease?
hint: This infant has Tay-Sachs disease, a condition that typically manifests with developmental delay, regression of achieved milestones (e.g., loss of ability to roll over), absence seizures (episodes of unresponsiveness with a blank stare), decreased eye contact, hypotonia, exaggerated startle response (as a result of hyperacusis), and bright red spots on fundoscopy. This condition is more common in individuals of Ashkenazi Jewish descent.
learning_objective: Recognize Tay-Sachs disease, and recall the metabolite that accumulates.

answers.explanation_why: Cerebroside sulfate accumulates in metachromatic leukodystrophy, a condition that typically manifests with developmental delay, regression, and hypotonia starting at 6 months of age, which is similar to this patient's presentation. However, metachromatic leukodystrophy is not associated with bright red spots on the macula, but rather optic nerve atrophy, ataxia, and peripheral neuropathy.

Glucocerebroside accumulates in Gaucher disease (the most common of the sphingolipidoses). Gaucher disease typically manifests with hepatosplenomegaly, bone abnormalities (pain and osteopenia), and pancytopenia, and is more prevalent in individuals with Ashkenazi Jewish heritage. Affected individuals may also have seizures and developmental delay. However, bright red spots on the macula would not be seen.

Galactocerebroside and psychosine accumulate in Krabbe disease, a condition that typically manifests with developmental delay or regression, which is seen in this case. However, individuals with Krabbe disease tend to have hypertonia, not hypotonia, and Krabbe disease does not involve bright red spots on the macula. Instead, visual impairment occurs due to optic nerve atrophy and peripheral neuropathy.

Ceramide trihexoside accumulates in Fabry disease, a condition that typically manifests as severe distal limb pain (due to peripheral neuropathy) and angiokeratomas beginning around the age of 10–17 years. Renal failure and cardiovascular disease occur in most individuals between the ages of 30–40 years. However, the diagnosis of Fabry disease would not explain a developmental delay that started at 6 months of age, nor would it account for the bright red spots on the macula, hypotonia, or absence seizures in this patient.

Sphingomyelin accumulates in Niemann-Pick disease, a condition that typically manifests with neurodegeneration, bright red spots on the macula, developmental delay, and regression. Niemann-Pick disease is more common among individuals of Ashkenazi Jewish descent. However, it also usually causes hepatosplenomegaly, which this patient does not have.

GM2 gangliosides accumulate in the neuronal cells of patients with Tay-Sachs disease. This accumulation is due to a deficiency of beta-hexosaminidase A. Affected patients typically present with progressive neurodegeneration, beginning around the age of 6 months, and cherry-red spots on fundoscopy. Individuals of Ashkenazi Jewish descent are more prone to developing the disease and carrier testing is therefore commonly performed in pregnant patients of this group or patients who wish to conceive. There is no cure and treatment is largely supportive. Usually, patients die of respiratory infections before 5 years of age.

Niemann-Pick disease may manifest without hepatosplenomegaly, which can make it very difficult to differentiate Niemann-Pick disease from Tay-Sachs disease without diagnostic histological evidence (i.e., of foam cells in Niemann-Pick disease and lysosomes with an onion skin appearance in Tay-Sachs disease). Nevertheless, when present, hepatosplenomegaly is usually the key differentiating clinical finding on exam questions.
