question_text: A 38-year-old woman comes to the emergency department because of progressive headache, blurry vision, and nausea for 1 day. Four days ago, she was diagnosed with a right middle ear infection. She appears lethargic. Her temperature is 39.1°C (102.3°F), and blood pressure is 148/95 mm Hg. Ophthalmologic examination shows bilateral swelling of the optic disc. The corneal reflex in the right eye is absent. Sensation to touch is reduced on the upper right side of the face. Serum studies show increased concentrations of fibrin degradation products. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
content_preview: A 38-year-old woman comes to the emergency department because of progressive headache, blurry vision, and nausea for 1 day. Four days ago, she was diagnosed with a right middle ear infection. She appears lethargic. Her temperature is 39.1°C (102.3°F), and blood pressure is 148/95 mm Hg. Ophthalmologic examination shows bilateral swelling of the optic disc. The corneal reflex in the right eye is absent. Sensation to touch is reduced on the upper right side of the face. Serum studies show increased concentrations of fibrin degradation products. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
hint: This patient has manifestations of increased intracranial pressure (e.g., headache, papilledema, focal neurologic deficits).
learning_objective: Recognize cerebral venous thrombosis.

answers.explanation_why: Cerebral venous thrombosis (CVT) is a condition of impaired blood drainage from the brain due to thrombosis of cerebral veins or the dural sinus, which can lead to tissue ischemia. CVT can cause manifestations of increased intracranial pressure (e.g., headache, altered mental status, papilledema, focal neurologic deficits) as seen in this case. Risk factors for the development of CVT include hypercoagulability (e.g., due to oral contraceptive use, pregnancy, and the puerperium), malignancy, and infection. In particular, local infections of the sinuses, mouth, face, neck, and/or ears (like this patient's recent episode of acute otitis media) can precipitate CVT. An increased serum concentration of D-dimer, which is a fibrin degradation product produced during clot breakdown, supports a diagnosis of CVT. Urgent imaging studies are required to confirm the diagnosis.

Hypertensive emergency (blood pressure > 180/120 mm Hg), can manifest with symptoms of end-organ damage, which can include neurologic symptoms such as headache, blurry vision, and papilledema. This patient's blood pressure is 148/95 mm Hg and thus does not meet the threshold for hypertensive emergency. In addition, hypertensive emergency does not cause fever or focal neurologic deficits and would not typically result in increased serum concentrations of fibrin degradation products (e.g., D-dimer).

Subarachnoid hemorrhage (SAH) can cause headache, nausea, fever (from blood irritating the meninges), and focal neurologic deficits (as a result of mass effect). Though some patients with this condition can have a prodromal headache due to sentinel leak, the characteristic manifestation of SAH is a sudden-onset, severely painful headache (i.e., thunderclap headache), which this patient does not have. Papilledema, as seen in this case, is uncommon. In addition, SAH does not cause increased serum concentrations of fibrin degradation products (e.g., D-dimer).

Migraine headache can cause visual disturbances (e.g., blurry vision, photopsia, distorted color perception) and nausea. In severe cases, focal neurologic deficits can be present. However, migraine headache does not cause fever, papilledema, or increased serum concentrations of fibrin degradation products (e.g., D-dimer) as seen in this case.

Idiopathic intracranial hypertension can cause headache, visual disturbances (e.g., transient vision loss, photopsia), nausea, bilateral papilledema, and focal neurologic deficits. However, idiopathic intracranial hypertension does not cause fever or increased serum concentrations of fibrin degradation products (e.g., D-dimer) as seen in this case.

Viral meningitis can cause fever, nausea, and manifestations of increased intracranial pressure (e.g., headache, altered mental status, papilledema, focal neurologic deficits). However, this condition does not cause increased serum concentrations of fibrin degradation products (e.g., D-dimer).

question_text: A 56-year-old man comes to the physician because of progressive worsening of vision in both eyes over the past 6 months. The patient reports that during this period he has had blurry vision and a glare in the evenings. He works as a tower crane operator and spends most of his day outdoors. Ophthalmologic examination shows visual acuity of 20/100 in both eyes. A photograph of the left eye is shown. Damage to which of the following structures is most likely responsible for this patient's current symptoms?
content_preview: A 56-year-old man comes to the physician because of progressive worsening of vision in both eyes over the past 6 months. The patient reports that during this period he has had blurry vision and a glare in the evenings. He works as a tower crane operator and spends most of his day outdoors. Ophthalmologic examination shows visual acuity of 20/100 in both eyes. A photograph of the left eye is shown. Damage to which of the following structures is most likely responsible for this patient's current symptoms?
hint: The photograph shows leukocoria (white pupillary reflex). Chronic UV exposure (e.g., from working outdoors) is a risk factor for this patient's condition.
learning_objective: Recognize cataract presentation, and recall its primary affected structure.

answers.explanation_why: Opacification of the aqueous humor typically occurs in acute uveitis, a condition in which pus accumulates in the anterior chamber (hypopyon). However, opacification would not be restricted to the pupillary area, as seen here. Instead, it would be present in the inferior region of the anterior chamber and obscure the underlying iris. Moreover, the chronic nature of the patient's symptoms and the absence of pain and conjunctival injection make a different kind of ocular damage more likely.

images.title: Hypopyon
images.description: Left eyeMassive mixed injections are present. Iris details appear blurred, which may result from corneal edema or inflammatory infiltration of the anterior chamber. The pupil (green overlay) is not completely round, which may be due to posterior synechiae. White material can be seen in the inferior region of the anterior chamber (hypopyon, blue overlay).The massive inflammatory process seen here could be due to, e.g., postoperative endophthalmitis or very severe uveitis.Dashed line: surrounds cornea

answers.explanation_why: Corneal edema, which can be caused by keratitis, anterior uveitis, acute closed-angle glaucoma, and certain metabolic disorders (e.g., mucopolysaccharidoses), would appear as opacifications on slit-lamp examination and cause impaired visual acuity. However, such opacifications would not be restricted to the pupillary area, as is the case here. Instead, opacification would be present throughout the cornea and obscure the underlying iris.

images.title: Corneal clouding
images.description: There is white-gray clouding of the cornea, making details of the iris appear blurred.Corneal clouding is seen in a variety of diseases (here: mucopolysaccharidosis VI).

answers.explanation_why: Vitreous body pathologies, such as persistent hyperplastic primary vitreous (PHPV) and chronic ocular toxocariasis, can result in impaired visual acuity and leukocoria. However, PHPV typically occurs during childhood, and toxocariasis is accompanied by ocular pain. Moreover, both conditions are typically unilateral, whereas both eyes are affected in this patient.

Gradual, painless loss of vision, glare, and leukocoria in an adult is consistent with cataract. Symptoms develop secondary to clouding of the lens. Cataracts often occur bilaterally and are the most common cause of impaired vision in individuals over 40 years of age. Besides chronic UV exposure, other risk factors for cataracts include advanced age, diabetes mellitus, smoking, heavy alcohol consumption, chronic corticosteroid therapy, and ocular trauma.

Conditions associated with congenital and juvenile cataracts include galactosemia, chromosomal trisomies, certain TORCH infections (e.g., rubella, toxoplasmosis), Marfan syndrome, Alport syndrome, myotonic dystrophy, and neurofibromatosis type II.
Retinal pathologies such as retinoblastoma, retrolental fibroplasia, and Coats disease can cause leukocoria with impaired visual acuity. However, these conditions typically occur in children.

images.title: Leukocoria in a patient with retinoblastoma
images.description: Leukocoria, i.e., a white pupillary reflex, is present in the left eye. The right eye shows normal retinal reflection.Leukocoria can have various causes, including as cataracts, Coats disease, and, as in this case, retinoblastoma.

images.title: Mature cataract
images.description: Slit-lamp examination of the left eyeThere is cloudy white opacification of the entire lens (green overlay). As a result, the red reflex is absent.An additional finding is a posterior synechia (arrow), as the superior part of the pupil is not completely round.

question_text: A 2-year-old boy is brought to the emergency department by his parents because of fever and recurrent episodes of jerky movements of his extremities for the past 6 hours. Pregnancy and delivery were uncomplicated, and development was normal until the age of 1 year. The parents report that he has had gradual loss of speech, vision, and motor skills over the past year. During this time, he has been admitted to the hospital three times because of myoclonic seizures. Physical examination shows hypertonicity of the upper and lower extremities. Fundoscopic examination shows pallor of the optic disc bilaterally. An MRI of the brain shows brain atrophy and hyperintensity of the periventricular and subcortical areas. Two days after admission, the patient dies. Histopathologic examination of the brain shows aggregation of globoid cells and loss of glial cells. The patient’s condition was most likely caused by a deficiency of which of the following enzymes?
content_preview: A 2-year-old boy is brought to the emergency department by his parents because of fever and recurrent episodes of jerky movements of his extremities for the past 6 hours. Pregnancy and delivery were uncomplicated, and development was normal until the age of 1 year. The parents report that he has had gradual loss of speech, vision, and motor skills over the past year. During this time, he has been admitted to the hospital three times because of myoclonic seizures. Physical examination shows hypertonicity of the upper and lower extremities. Fundoscopic examination shows pallor of the optic disc bilaterally. An MRI of the brain shows brain atrophy and hyperintensity of the periventricular and subcortical areas. Two days after admission, the patient dies. Histopathologic examination of the brain shows aggregation of globoid cells and loss of glial cells. The patient’s condition was most likely caused by a deficiency of which of the following enzymes?
hint: Giant, multinucleated histiocytes (globoid cells) on histopathologic examination of the brain are diagnostic of Krabbe disease.
learning_objective: Recognize Krabbe disease, and recall the enzyme deficiency it involves.

answers.explanation_why: A deficiency of sphingomyelinase, which leads to an accumulation of sphingomyelin mainly in the brain, liver, spleen and bone marrow, is the primary defect in Niemann-Pick disease (NPD). This condition can manifest with seizures and progressive neurodegeneration with brain atrophy. However, NPD is typically associated with hypotonia (not hypertonia), a cherry-red spot on the macula on fundoscopic examination (rather than optic disc pallor), interstitial lung disease, and hepatosplenomegaly, none of which is seen here. Moreover, globoid cells on brain biopsy are not a feature of NPD.

A deficiency of arylsulfatase A, which leads to an accumulation of cerebroside sulfate mainly in the central and peripheral nervous system, is the primary defect in metachromatic leukodystrophy (ML). ML can manifest with developmental regression (e.g., loss of speech and motor skills), brain and optic atrophy (optic pallor and vision loss), seizures, and loss of glial cells on brain biopsy, all of which are seen in this patient. However, globoid cells on brain biopsy are not a feature of this condition. Moreover, ML typically also manifests with ataxia and hypotonia (not hypertonia), which are not seen here.

A deficiency of β-glucocerebrosidase, which leads to an accumulation of glucocerebroside in the brain, liver, spleen, and bone marrow, is the primary defect in Gaucher disease. Some patients with this condition present with neurological complications such as developmental regression (e.g., loss of speech and motor skills), loss of vision (from macular atrophy and uveitis), and seizures. However, Gaucher disease is not associated with brain or optic atrophy (optic disc pallor) or globoid cells on brain biopsy. Instead, typical manifestations of Gaucher disease include hepatosplenomegaly, petechiae, painful bone crises, and pathological fractures, none of which is seen here.

A deficiency of β-hexosaminidase A, which leads to an accumulation of GM_2 ganglioside mainly in the brain and retina, is the primary defect in Tay-Sachs disease (TSD). This condition can manifest with developmental regression (e.g., loss of speech and motor skills), vision loss, and seizures. However, TSD is typically also associated with muscle weakness and hypotonia (not hypertonia), hyperreflexia, hearing impairment and a cherry-red spot on the macula on fundoscopic examination (not optic disc pallor), none of which is present here. Moreover, brain biopsy of a patient with TSD typically reveals lysosomes with an onion skin appearance, not globoid cells.

A deficiency of β-galactocerebrosidase, which leads to intracellular accumulation of myelin breakdown products (galactocerebroside and psychosine) in the central and peripheral nervous system, is the primary defect in Krabbe disease. Characteristic pathologic findings resulting from the toxic effect of these breakdown products include globoid cells and progressive loss of myelin sheaths. Krabbe disease most commonly manifests in early infancy with developmental regression (e.g., loss of speech and motor skills), fever, limb spasticity, brain and optic atrophy (optic disc pallor and vision loss), and seizures, as seen in this patient. Further symptoms include peripheral neuropathy, axial hypotonia, absent reflexes, and microcephaly. Progressive decerebration usually leads to death before the age of two.

Hematopoietic stem cell transplantation has been shown to improve outcomes if performed before the onset of symptoms.

images.title: Lysosomal storage disease
images.description: The chart illustrates the breakdown of select sphingolipids in the lysosomes, the corresponding enzymes that catalyze the reactions, and the diseases that an enzyme defect can cause.GM1, GM2, GM3, GA1, and GA2 refer to various gangliosides, i.e., sphingolipids with different sugar residues.

answers.explanation_why: A deficiency of α-galactosidase A is the primary defect in Fabry disease and leads to an accumulation of ceramide trihexoside (globotriaosylceramide) in the endothelium of vessels, the epithelium of many organs, and smooth muscle cells. This condition classically manifests during late childhood with paresthesias and neuropathic pain, hypohidrosis, angiokeratomas, asymptomatic cataracts, and gastrointestinal symptoms. This patient's presentation is not consistent with Fabry disease.

question_text: A 39-year-old woman is brought to the emergency department 30 minutes after her husband found her unconscious on the living room floor. She does not report having experienced light-headedness, nausea, sweating, or visual disturbance before losing consciousness. Three weeks ago, she was diagnosed with open-angle glaucoma and began treatment with an antiglaucoma drug in the form of eye drops. She last used the eye drops 1 hour ago. Examination shows pupils of normal size that are reactive to light. An ECG shows sinus bradycardia. This patient is most likely undergoing treatment with which of the following drugs?
content_preview: A 39-year-old woman is brought to the emergency department 30 minutes after her husband found her unconscious on the living room floor. She does not report having experienced light-headedness, nausea, sweating, or visual disturbance before losing consciousness. Three weeks ago, she was diagnosed with open-angle glaucoma and began treatment with an antiglaucoma drug in the form of eye drops. She last used the eye drops 1 hour ago. Examination shows pupils of normal size that are reactive to light. An ECG shows sinus bradycardia. This patient is most likely undergoing treatment with which of the following drugs?
hint: This drug decreases adenylate cyclase activity. It is used to treat glaucoma because it decreases aqueous humor synthesis.
learning_objective: Recognize the systemic side effects of ophthalmic beta blockers.

answers.explanation_why: Latanoprost, a prostaglandin F2α agonist analog, decreases intraocular pressure by increasing the outflow of aqueous humor. Common side effects include discoloration of the iris, eyelids, and conjunctiva as well as blurred vision, watering/burning, and foreign body sensation. Bradycardia is not an adverse effect of latanoprost.

Timolol is a nonselective beta blocker that is used as an ophthalmic formulation for the treatment of open-angle glaucoma. It blocks ß_2 receptors in the ciliary body of the eye, decreasing aqueous humor production and consequently lowering intraocular pressure. However, because timolol is passively absorbed into the systemic circulation from the eye, it has high bioavailability, potentially leading to systemic side effects such as the blockade of ß_1 receptors in the heart and subsequent negative ionotropic and chronotropic effects. In excess, these effects can cause bradyarrhythmias and orthostatic hypotension, both of which can lead to syncope, as seen in this patient.

Nonselective beta blockers also cause bronchoconstriction, especially in patients with reactive airway disease, and should be used with caution in patients with asthma.

images.title: Mechanism of action: glaucoma medication
images.description:
PGF2α analogues (e.g., latanoprost)
– Reduce outflow resistance of trabecular meshwork
– Increase uveoscleral outflow by relaxing ciliary muscle and disrupting turnover of extracellular matrixβ-blockers (e.g., timolol): diminish aqueous humor production by inhibiting Na+/K+ ATPaseα2 agonists (e.g., brimonidine) 
– Reduce episcleral venous pressure 
– Diminish aqueous humor production by inhibiting Na+/K+ ATPaseCholinomimetics (e.g., pilocarpine)
– Widen trabecular meshwork via ciliary muscle activation
– Open up the iridocorneal angle by activating the iris sphincter muscle (miosis)Carbonic anhydrase inhibitors (CAI; e.g., acetazolamide): diminish aqueous humor productionRho-kinase inhibitors (e.g., netarsudil)
– Increase trabecular outflow
– Lower episcleral venous pressure
– Decrease aqueous humor production by increasing noradrenergic transmission

answers.explanation_why: Dorzolamide, a carbonic anhydrase inhibitor, reduces aqueous humor production. Common side effects include an ocular burning sensation, pruritus, lacrimation, blurred vision, and a bitter taste, but bradycardia is not a known side effect.

Apraclonidine reduces intraocular pressure by decreasing aqueous humor production. While apraclonidine is associated with bradycardia in rare cases, other side effects, e.g., ocular hyperemia, pruritus, foreign body sensation, and blurry vision, are more common.

Tropicamide, an anticholinergic medication, is used commonly as a mydriatic agent. Pupillary dilation can precipitate angle-closure glaucoma in predisposed individuals and is contraindicated in patients with glaucoma. Moreover, tachycardia, not bradycardia, is a side effect of tropicamide, making a different agent more likely.

Pilocarpine, a cholinergic agonist that primarily acts on M_3 muscarinic receptors, reduces intraocular pressure by increasing the trabecular outflow of aqueous humor. Pilocarpine can cause bradycardia, which could explain this patient's syncope. However, pilocarpine also causes sweating, nausea, blurred vision and pupillary constriction, none of which are seen in this patient.

question_text: A 59-year-old man who was recently diagnosed with renal cell carcinoma comes to the physician for a follow-up evaluation. The physician recommends starting treatment with a medication that is also used to treat neovascular age-related macular degeneration. A recent history of which of the following conditions would discourage the use of this drug?
content_preview: A 59-year-old man who was recently diagnosed with renal cell carcinoma comes to the physician for a follow-up evaluation. The physician recommends starting treatment with a medication that is also used to treat neovascular age-related macular degeneration. A recent history of which of the following conditions would discourage the use of this drug?
hint: Both renal cell carcinoma and neovascular age-related macular degeneration can be treated with the monoclonal antibody bevacizumab.
learning_objective: Recall the indications for bevacizumab, and recall its contraindications.

answers.explanation_why: Patients should be evaluated for interstitial lung disease (ILD) before administration of drugs known to cause pulmonary fibrosis, such as bleomycin and busulfan. However, the presence of ILD would not discourage the use of bevacizumab.

Patients should be evaluated for chronic kidney disease (CKD) before administration of nephrotoxic agents such as cisplatin, cytarabine, and ifosfamide. However, the presence of CKD would not discourage the use of bevacizumab.

Patients should be tested for a platinum allergy before treatment with platinum-based drugs such as carboplatin, cisplatin, and oxaliplatin. Bevacizumab does not contain platinum and would not be contraindicated in a patient with a platinum allergy.

Folate deficiency is a relative contraindication to therapy with antifolates such as methotrexate. Folate metabolism is not affected by bevacizumab; folate deficiency is therefore not a contraindication to therapy.

A recent history of gastrointestinal bleeding (e.g., hematemesis, hematochezia) should be ruled out in patients prior to initiating bevacizumab therapy, as the drug increases the risk of GI bleeding and perforations. Other side effects of bevacizumab include hypertension, heart failure, thrombotic events (e.g, VTE), and impaired wound healing.

question_text: A 59-year-old man comes to the physician because of a 6-month history of progressive blurry vision in both eyes. His vision has not improved with the use of reading glasses. His blood pressure is 155/98 mm Hg. Physical examination shows his visual acuity to be 20/80 in the right eye and 20/60 in the left eye. A photograph of the fundoscopic examination of the right eye is shown. Which of the following is the most likely cause of this patient's symptoms?
content_preview: A 59-year-old man comes to the physician because of a 6-month history of progressive blurry vision in both eyes. His vision has not improved with the use of reading glasses. His blood pressure is 155/98 mm Hg. Physical examination shows his visual acuity to be 20/80 in the right eye and 20/60 in the left eye. A photograph of the fundoscopic examination of the right eye is shown. Which of the following is the most likely cause of this patient's symptoms?
hint: The fundoscopic image shows neovascularization of the optic disc and the retinal vessels.
learning_objective: Recognize diabetic retinopathy.

answers.explanation_why: A retinal detachment typically presents with unilateral, acutely decreased vision with prominent floaters and fundoscopy would be expected to show a region of crinkled retinal tissue in the detached area. This patient presents with chronic, bilateral blurred vision, and the neovascularization seen on his fundoscopic examination is not consistent with retinal detachment.

Idiopathic intracranial hypertension manifests with blurred optic disc margins (papilledema) and small hemorrhages on fundoscopy. Patients most often report significant headaches in addition to visual symptoms. Neovascularization of the retina, which is seen on this patient's fundoscopy, would not be expected in idiopathic intracranial hypertension.

images.title: Optic disc edema
images.description: Fundus photography of the left eyeLeft image: Blurred disc margins (green overlay) with venous dilatation and tortuosity (blue overlay) and small hemorrhages (examples indicated by arrowheads) are visible.Blurred disc margins suggest optic disc edema. In intracranial hypertension, as seen in this image, optic disc edema is called papilledema.Right image: Resolution of optic disc edema after treatment. Sharp disc margins and normal retinal vessels are visible. There are no hemorrhages.

answers.explanation_why: Open-angle glaucoma manifests with optic disc atrophy, notching of the neuroretinal rim, and disc hemorrhages on fundoscopy. These changes are caused by impaired absorption of aqueous humor through the trabecular meshwork and chronic increase in intraocular pressure. Patients typically present with chronic peripheral field deficits but retained central visual acuity. Neovascularization of the retina, which is seen in this patient, would not be expected in glaucoma.

images.title: Glaucomatous excavation of the optic disc
images.description: Fundus photography of a right eyeAn enlarged cup (yellow overlay) of the optic disc with thinning of the neuroretinal rim (green overlay) can be seen, especially evident in the temporal superior area of the optic disc (focal notching, indicated by arrow). Cupping leads to kinking of the blood vessels at the base of the cup (examples indicated by arrowheads).This is a pathognomonic finding in glaucoma, predominantly caused by elevated intraocular pressure.

answers.explanation_why: A central retinal artery occlusion leads to sudden, unilateral loss of vision, not chronic, bilateral blurred vision, which is reported here. Typical fundoscopic exam findings include a pale retina and a so-called “cherry red spot” in the fovea. Neovascularization and tortuous vessels, which are seen on this patient's fundoscopic image, would not be expected in a central retinal artery occlusion.

images.title: Central retinal artery occlusion
images.description: Left: lateral view of the right eye in longitudinal (sagittal) section. Depiction of an embolism in the central retinal artery causing retinal ischemia.Right: fundus photography of the right eye. Diffuse retinal ischemia causes edema in the inner retinal layers, manifesting as a gray-white discoloration of the retina (most markedly around the fovea; dotted circle). The fovea centralis, where the inner retinal layers are moved to the side, is not affected by edema. The underlying, well-vascularized choroid shines through, appearing as a cherry-red spot.

answers.explanation_why: Dry macular degeneration is characterized by yellow deposits (drusen) on fundoscopy. Neovascularization, which is seen on this patient's fundoscopic image, would not be expected in dry macular degeneration.

images.title: Dry age-related macular degeneration
images.description:
Fundus photography of the left eyeThere are drusen (yellow deposits, area marked by dashed blue circle) and retinal pigment epithelium atrophy (blue overlay).Blue circle: optic disc
M: macula

answers.explanation_why: Diabetic retinopathy is a long-term complication of diabetes that occurs due to microvascular ischemia and osmotic damage secondary to the chronic elevation in serum glucose. The molecular pathogenesis of these changes involves intraocular sorbitol accumulation, which consumes NADPH and leads to oxidative stress. This oxidative stress ultimately leads to damage of the retinal microvasculature. The release of vascular endothelial growth factor (VEGF) by dying cells promotes the neovascularization of the retina and optic disc that is characteristic of diabetic retinopathy.

images.title: Proliferative diabetic retinopathy
images.description:
Fundus photography of the right eyeThere is massive neovascularization (examples indicated by arrows) of the optic disk (NVD), cotton wool spots (overlay), hard exudates (circle), intraretinal hemorrhages (examples indicated by white arrowheads), and a microaneurysm (example indicated by black arrowhead).The diagnosis of proliferative disease requires the presence of neovascularization.

Outline: optic disc

question_text: A 62-year-old man comes to the physician because of a 2-week history of cough, fatigue, impaired vision, and progressive headaches. He has smoked 2 packs of cigarettes daily for the last 38 years. After a thorough diagnostic workup, a diagnosis of metastatic lung cancer is made. A schematic overview of the patient's visual fields is shown. This patient is most likely to have a metastatic lesion in which of the following locations of the visual pathway?
content_preview: A 62-year-old man comes to the physician because of a 2-week history of cough, fatigue, impaired vision, and progressive headaches. He has smoked 2 packs of cigarettes daily for the last 38 years. After a thorough diagnostic workup, a diagnosis of metastatic lung cancer is made. A schematic overview of the patient's visual fields is shown. This patient is most likely to have a metastatic lesion in which of the following locations of the visual pathway?
hint: This patient's visual field defects indicate a lesion in the parietal lobe.
learning_objective: Recognize left lower homonymous quadrantanopsia, and recall the associated lesion location in the visual pathway.

answers.explanation_why: The inferior bundle of right optic radiations (right Meyer loop) is located in the right temporal lobe and transmits visual information from the left superior quadrants of the visual field (i.e., from the right lower quadrant of both retinas). Therefore, damage to the right Meyer loop would result in left upper homonymous quadrantanopsia (“pie in the sky”), which does not correspond to the visual defect seen in this patient.

The inferior bundle of left optic radiations (left Meyer loop) is located in the left temporal lobe and transmits visual information from the right superior quadrants of the visual field (i.e., from the left lower quadrant of both retinas). Therefore, damage to the left Meyer loop would result in right upper homonymous quadrantanopsia (“pie in the sky”), which does not correspond to the visual defect seen in this patient.

The superior bundle of left optic radiations (left dorsal optic radiation) is located in the left parietal lobe and relays information from the right inferior quadrants of the visual field (i.e., from the left superior quadrant of both retinas). Therefore, damage to the left superior bundle of optic radiations results in right lower homonymous quadrantanopsia, which does not correspond to the visual defect seen in this patient.

The left optic tract transmits information from the right half of each eye's visual field (i.e., from the temporal half of the left retina and nasal half of the right retina). Therefore, damage to the left optic tract would result in right homonymous hemianopsia, which is not seen here.

The visual pathway transmits visual information from the retina to the visual cortex (Brodmann area 17) through the optic nerve, optic chiasm, optic tract, lateral geniculate nucleus, and optic radiations. The superior bundle of right optic radiations (right dorsal optic radiation) relays information from the left inferior quadrants of the visual field, i.e., from the right superior quadrant of both retinas. Therefore, damage to the right superior bundle of optic radiations would produce left lower homonymous quadrantanopsia (“pie on the floor”), as seen here.

images.title: Overview of visual field defects
images.description:
(1) Ipsilateral anopsia
(2) Bitemporal heteronymous hemianopsia
(3) Contralateral homonymous hemianopsia
(4) Contralateral upper homonymous quadrantanopsia
(5) Contralateral lower homonymous quadrantanopsia
(6) Contralateral homonymous hemianopsia with macular sparing
(7) Contralateral homonymous central scotoma

answers.explanation_why: The left macula transmits visual information from the center of the left eye's visual field. Therefore, damage to the left macula (e.g., due to macular degeneration) would result in a left central scotoma, which does not correspond to the visual defect seen in this patient.

The right optic tract transmits information from the left half of each eye's visual field (i.e., from the nasal half of the left retina and temporal half of the right retina). Therefore, damage to the right optic tract would result in left homonymous hemianopsia, which is not seen here.

The right macula transmits visual information from the center of the right eye's visual field. Therefore, damage to the right macula (e.g., due to macular degeneration) would result in a right central scotoma, which does not correspond to the visual defect seen in this patient.

question_text: A 72-year-old woman comes to the emergency department because of a 4-hour history of reduced vision in her eye. She says that she can see black moving spots and flashes of light in her right eye. The symptoms started when she was jumping on a trampoline with her grandchild. She does not report pain. Her medical history is significant for type 2 diabetes mellitus and atrial fibrillation. Since childhood, she has worn glasses for progressive myopia. Her medications are metformin, metoprolol, and apixaban. She is alert and fully oriented. Vital signs are temperature 37.0°C (98.6°F), pulse 78/min, respirations 12/min, and blood pressure 136/84 mm Hg. Examination shows a visual acuity in the left eye of 15/20 and minimal detectable acuity in the right eye. A photograph of the fundoscopic examination of the right eye is shown. Fundoscopic examination of the left eye shows no abnormalities. Which of the following is the most likely cause of the patient's vision loss?
content_preview: A 72-year-old woman comes to the emergency department because of a 4-hour history of reduced vision in her eye. She says that she can see black moving spots and flashes of light in her right eye. The symptoms started when she was jumping on a trampoline with her grandchild. She does not report pain. Her medical history is significant for type 2 diabetes mellitus and atrial fibrillation. Since childhood, she has worn glasses for progressive myopia. Her medications are metformin, metoprolol, and apixaban. She is alert and fully oriented. Vital signs are temperature 37.0°C (98.6°F), pulse 78/min, respirations 12/min, and blood pressure 136/84 mm Hg. Examination shows a visual acuity in the left eye of 15/20 and minimal detectable acuity in the right eye. A photograph of the fundoscopic examination of the right eye is shown. Fundoscopic examination of the left eye shows no abnormalities. Which of the following is the most likely cause of the patient's vision loss?
hint: Fundoscopic examination of this patient's right eye shows gray crinkled tissue.
learning_objective: Recognize retinal tear with neurosensory detachment.

answers.explanation_why: Occlusion of the central retinal artery manifests with acute painless loss of vision in one eye. Possible causes of this condition include emboli from the atria secondary to atrial fibrillation and atherosclerotic thrombi (e.g., due to diabetes mellitus). However, fundoscopic examination would show grayish discoloration of the entire retina and a cherry-red spot at the fovea centralis.

images.title: Acute central retinal artery occlusion
images.description: Fundus photography of a right eyeNarrow retinal arteries with box-carring of the retinal vessels (black dashed outline) and a pale retina indicating nerve fiber layer edema are visible. The fovea centralis appears red (cherry-red spot; purple overlay) due to the transparency of this part of the retina lacking nerve fibres, causing the well-vascularized choroid to shine through. Additionally, at the temporal superior arcade an embolus is present (arrow-head).This is the classical finding of acute central retinal artery occlusion.Purple circle: Optic disc

answers.explanation_why: Choroidal neovascularization with intraretinal bleeding is the underlying mechanism of wet age-related macular degeneration. Although this condition is acute and painless, it is associated with impairment of central vision only. Furthermore, fundoscopic examination in wet age-related macular degeneration would show retinal hemorrhages and macular edema, which are not present in this patient.

answers.content: Retinal tear with detachment of the neurosensory retina
answers.explanation_why:
A retinal tear with detachment of the neurosensory retina from the retinal pigment epithelium is the underlying mechanism of retinal detachment (RD), which most commonly manifests with sudden, painless vision loss and symptoms such as spots and flashes of light in the visual field of the affected eye. On fundoscopic examination, the neurosensory retina is detached from the retinal pigment epithelium on the temporal side, resulting in a corrugated, opaque appearance compared to the intact medial side. The most frequent causes of RD are tears or holes in the retina (rhegmatogenous RD); less commonly, RD can occur without a retinal tear (nonrhegmatogenous RD). Risk factors include high myopia, trauma (in this case, likely caused by jumping on a trampoline), previous intraocular surgery, and posterior vitreous detachment.

The prognosis in RD is good if surgery is performed at an early stage and if there is no macular involvement. Without treatment, progressive RD causes blindness, especially if the macula is involved.

answers.content: Impaired drainage of aqueous humor from the eye
answers.explanation_why: Impaired drainage of aqueous humor from the eye is the underlying cause of acute angle-closure glaucoma. This condition typically manifests as a severely painful, reddened, and inflamed eye, with an opacified cornea that may be perceptibly harder on palpation than the unaffected eye. Patients may report headaches, nausea/vomiting, and halos around light sources, none of which are present in this patient. While visual acuity may be affected, the patient's painless loss of vision is not consistent with acute angle-closure glaucoma.

images.title: Angle-closure glaucoma
images.description: Slit-lamp photograph of anterior eye segmentProminent blood vessels are visible on the sclera and conjunctiva (mixed injection). The pupil is medium wide and its shape is slightly irregular. Iris details appear blurred due to corneal endothelial decompensation, leading to corneal edema.

answers.content: Detachment of the posterior vitreous corpus
answers.explanation_why: Separation of the posterior vitreous corpus from the internal limiting membrane of the retina is the underlying mechanism of posterior vitreous detachment, for which myopia is a risk factor. Posterior vitreous detachment also manifests with symptoms such as spots and flashes of light in the visual field of the affected eye, however, ophthalmological examination would show a Weiss ring in the vitreous cavity. Complications of posterior vitreous detachment include retinal tears or holes, retinal detachment, and vitreous hemorrhage.

images.title: Posterior vitreous detachment
images.description:
Fundus photography of a right eyeA thin, oval opacity (Weiss ring; yellow outline) can be seen in the vitreous. Retinal details are blurred due to the preretinal focus of the photograph. The patient reported seeing floaters.These findings are typical of posterior vitreous detachment.

Circle: optic disc; M: macula

images.title: Rhegmatogenous retinal detachment
images.description: Fundus photography of the right eyeThere is detachment of the temporal (left side of the image) and central neurosensory retina (blue overlay) from the retinal pigment epithelium, involving the fovea centralis, creating an opaque, corrugated appearance of the retina compared to the intact medial side.A retinal tear was identified superotemporally at the 11-o'clock position (not shown here), classifying this as a rhegmatogenous retinal detachment.Blue circle: optic disc; M: macula

question_text: An 82-year-old man is brought to the emergency department because of a 2-hour history of decreased vision in his right eye. He has no pain in the eye and has never had a similar episode in the past. He has type 2 diabetes mellitus, hypertension, and open-angle glaucoma. He does not smoke and occasionally drinks 1–2 glasses of wine. Current medications include metformin, glipizide, lisinopril, and topical latanoprost. His temperature is 36.6°C (97.9°F), pulse is 68/min and regular, respirations are 14/min, and blood pressure is 135/82 mm Hg. Ophthalmologic examination shows visual acuity of 20/200 in the right eye and 20/60 in the left eye. The direct pupillary reflex is brisk in the left eye but absent in the right eye. Applanation tonometry shows an intraocular pressure of 20 mm Hg in the right eye and 18 mm Hg in the left eye (N = 10–21). Fundoscopy of the right eye shows the findings in the photograph. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?
content_preview: An 82-year-old man is brought to the emergency department because of a 2-hour history of decreased vision in his right eye. He has no pain in the eye and has never had a similar episode in the past. He has type 2 diabetes mellitus, hypertension, and open-angle glaucoma. He does not smoke and occasionally drinks 1–2 glasses of wine. Current medications include metformin, glipizide, lisinopril, and topical latanoprost. His temperature is 36.6°C (97.9°F), pulse is 68/min and regular, respirations are 14/min, and blood pressure is 135/82 mm Hg. Ophthalmologic examination shows visual acuity of 20/200 in the right eye and 20/60 in the left eye. The direct pupillary reflex is brisk in the left eye but absent in the right eye. Applanation tonometry shows an intraocular pressure of 20 mm Hg in the right eye and 18 mm Hg in the left eye (N = 10–21). Fundoscopy of the right eye shows the findings in the photograph. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?
hint: Fundoscopy shows flame-shaped hemorrhages in all four retinal quadrants (blood and thunder appearance), tortuous dilated veins, papilledema, and cotton wool spots. In conjunction with sudden painless loss of vision and an afferent pupillary defect, these findings suggest central retinal vein occlusion (CRVO). Risk factors for this condition include older age, diabetes mellitus, hypertension, and glaucoma.
learning_objective: Recognize central retinal vein occlusion, and choose the most appropriate diagnostic test.

answers.explanation_why: Intravenous thrombolysis may be considered in the management of central retinal artery occlusion. This condition manifests with sudden, painless loss of vision and an afferent pupillary defect in one eye. However, fundoscopy typically shows a cherry-red spot at the fovea centralis against a grayish-white discoloration of the entire retina, as well as retinal plaques/emboli (i.e., cholesterol emboli, platelet thrombi, calcific plaques).

images.title: Central retinal artery occlusion
images.description: Left: lateral view of the right eye in longitudinal (sagittal) section. Depiction of an embolism in the central retinal artery causing retinal ischemia.Right: fundus photography of the right eye. Diffuse retinal ischemia causes edema in the inner retinal layers, manifesting as a gray-white discoloration of the retina (most markedly around the fovea; dotted circle). The fovea centralis, where the inner retinal layers are moved to the side, is not affected by edema. The underlying, well-vascularized choroid shines through, appearing as a cherry-red spot.

answers.explanation_why: Emergency retinal tamponade is the treatment of choice for rhegmatogenous retinal detachment. This type of retinal detachment can manifest with sudden, painless loss of vision and an afferent pupillary defect in one eye. However, this condition is often preceded by prodromal symptoms that result from posterior vitreous detachment, including floaters, photopsia, and scotomas. Moreover, ophthalmoscopy typically shows a detached gray retina that floats freely in the vitreous body and has a blood-vessel orientation different from the normal retina; a deeply red retinal tear may also be visible.

images.title: Rhegmatogenous retinal detachment
images.description: Fundus photography of the eyeThe detached part of the retina is visible as a yellow-gray, bullous elevation (blue overlay) in the upper part of the image. The detachment is due to a retinal tear (dashed outline).

answers.content: Topical pilocarpine and systemic acetazolamide therapy
answers.explanation_why: Topical pilocarpine and systemic acetazolamide are indicated for treating acute angle-closure glaucoma, which is common in older adults and causes sudden-onset, unilaterally blurry vision, decreased visual acuity, and a nonreactive pupil, similar to what is seen here. However, this condition typically manifests with a reddened and severely painful eye that is hard on palpation, a cloudy cornea, headache, as well as nausea and vomiting. In contrast, this patient has a normal intraocular pressure on tonometry.

images.title: Angle-closure glaucoma
images.description: Slit-lamp photograph of anterior eye segmentProminent blood vessels are visible on the sclera and conjunctiva (mixed injection). The pupil is medium wide and its shape is slightly irregular. Iris details appear blurred due to corneal endothelial decompensation, leading to corneal edema.

answers.explanation_why: Fluorescein angiography (FA) is indicated as the next step to confirm the diagnosis of CRVO, evaluate the severity of CRVO, and decide whether laser photocoagulation should be performed. Retinal nonperfusion predisposes to complications of neovascularization (i.e., rubeosis iridis, neovascular glaucoma, vitreous hemorrhage, retinal detachment). To prevent neovascularization, CRVO must be treated with panretinal photocoagulation and intravitreal injection of VEGF inhibitors and/or steroids. Further work-up includes optical coherence tomography, which helps to determine the extent of macular edema and monitor the response to treatment. CRVO has a poor prognosis: visual acuity only improves in a third of patients.

images.title: Fluorescein angiography in ischemic branch retinal vein occlusion
images.description:
Fluorescein angiography of the right eyeThere is hypoperfusion of the temporal inferior vascular arcade, with capillary nonperfusion visible as areas of hypofluorescence (blue overlay). Vessels are tortuous. There is no neovascularization.This is the typical appearance of ischemic RVO on fluorescein angiography.Blue circle: Optic disc
M: Macula

answers.explanation_why: MRI of the head is indicated for patients with optic neuritis. This condition manifests with sudden-onset unilateral vision loss and an afferent pupillary defect. However, optic neuritis is usually seen in adults under 50 years of age and manifests with retrobulbar pain that increases with eye movements, which is not reported in this patient. Most affected individuals have multiple sclerosis; other common etiologies include infections (e.g., tuberculosis, Lyme disease) and use of toxic substances (e.g., ethambutol, methanol). Moreover, loss of color vision and visual field defects (e.g., central scotoma) are common features, and ophthalmoscopy findings may be normal (in retrobulbar neuritis) or show signs of papillitis. This patient, in contrast, has classic findings of CRVO on fundoscopy.

images.title: Papillitis in optic neuritis
images.description:
Fundus photography of the left eye of a patient with acute vision loss and painful eye movementsDiscrete optic disc edema is visible: Discrete blurring of the nasal superior, superior, and temporal superior disc margin can be seen (green overlay). Otherwise, the fundus is normal.

This finding, in addition to the patient's symptoms, suggests papillitis in optic neuritis.M: macula; circle: optic disc

images.title: Central retinal vein occlusion
images.description: Fundus photography of the right eye of a 76-year-old patientFlame-shaped retinal hemorrhage is visible in all four quadrants (example indicated by green outline). The tortuous veins (green arrows) are markedly dilated and there is papilledema with loss of sharp demarcation of the optic disc (green overlay).These findings are typical for a central retinal vein occlusion.

question_text: A 74-year-old woman comes to the physician because of progressively blurry vision. About 3 years ago, she stopped using her reading glasses for several months because her eyesight improved temporarily. She is a landscape painter. For the past year, she has mostly been working inside her studio instead of outside her house. She comments that “the bright sunlight makes me see halos around lights and then I cannot distinguish between the nuances of colors anymore.” The patient recently stopped driving at night because she no longer trusts her eyes. She has a history of type 2 diabetes mellitus, asthma, and atrial fibrillation. She has smoked 1.5 packs of cigarettes daily for 40 years and occasionally drinks 1–2 glasses of wine. Her medications include metformin, albuterol, budesonide-formoterol, digoxin, and rivaroxaban. Her temperature is 37.0°C (98.6°F), pulse is 89/min and irregular, respirations are 13/min, and blood pressure is 135/82 mm Hg. Ophthalmologic examination shows visual acuity of 20/80 in both eyes. On fundoscopic examination, the retina is hard to visualize and the red reflex appears darkened. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?
content_preview: A 74-year-old woman comes to the physician because of progressively blurry vision. About 3 years ago, she stopped using her reading glasses for several months because her eyesight improved temporarily. She is a landscape painter. For the past year, she has mostly been working inside her studio instead of outside her house. She comments that “the bright sunlight makes me see halos around lights and then I cannot distinguish between the nuances of colors anymore.” The patient recently stopped driving at night because she no longer trusts her eyes. She has a history of type 2 diabetes mellitus, asthma, and atrial fibrillation. She has smoked 1.5 packs of cigarettes daily for 40 years and occasionally drinks 1–2 glasses of wine. Her medications include metformin, albuterol, budesonide-formoterol, digoxin, and rivaroxaban. Her temperature is 37.0°C (98.6°F), pulse is 89/min and irregular, respirations are 13/min, and blood pressure is 135/82 mm Hg. Ophthalmologic examination shows visual acuity of 20/80 in both eyes. On fundoscopic examination, the retina is hard to visualize and the red reflex appears darkened. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?
hint: This patient's bilateral progressive, painless loss of vision, halos around lights, reduced night vision, and temporary near vision improvement, along with darkening of the red reflex and obscuration of the ocular fundus indicate bilateral cataracts. Risk factors for cataract formation include advanced age, diabetes mellitus, and smoking, all of which are seen here.
learning_objective: Recognize bilateral cataracts, and choose the most appropriate next step in management.

answers.explanation_why: Intravitreous injection of bevacizumab is the first-line treatment for patients with exudative age-related macular degeneration (wet AMD), which can cause progressive and painless loss of vision. However, wet AMD affects one eye first rather than both eyes, and progresses over weeks to months rather than years. Additionally, this condition does not cause a temporary improvement in near vision, darkening of the red reflex, and obscuration of the ocular fundus. Finally, the visual impairment is usually central or pericentral and patients generally present with metamorphopsia and scotomas, none of which are seen here.

Surgical replacement of the lens is the treatment of choice for patients with cataracts with significant cataract-related visual impairment, as seen in this patient. The standard surgical technique is extracapsular cataract extraction. There is no pharmacological therapy available except in galactosemia, in which the cataract is reversible when following a galactose-free diet. Untreated cataracts eventually lead to complete blindness.

images.title: Mature cataract
images.description: Slit-lamp examination of the left eyeThere is cloudy white opacification of the entire lens (green overlay). As a result, the red reflex is absent.An additional finding is a posterior synechia (arrow), as the superior part of the pupil is not completely round.

answers.explanation_why: Laser photocoagulation of the retina is used in the treatment of both proliferative (PDR) and nonproliferative diabetic retinopathy (NPDR). Diabetic retinopathy is the most common cause of visual impairment in patients aged 25–74 years in the US and can also cause bilateral, progressive, painless vision loss. However, diabetic retinopathy is not associated with the visualization of halos around lights, a temporary improvement in near vision, or the darkening of the red reflex. Characteristic fundoscopic findings of PDR include preretinal neovascularization, vitreous hemorrhage, retinal detachment, and fibrovascular proliferation, while characteristic fundoscopic findings of NPDR include hard exudates and macular ischemia.

Topical latanoprost is the preferred first-line treatment for patients with open-angle glaucoma, which also causes bilateral, progressive vision loss that can be associated with halos around lights. Advanced age, diabetes mellitus, and steroid use, all of which are seen in this patient, are known risk factors for open-angle glaucoma. However, a temporary improvement in near vision and a fundoscopy showing darkening of the red reflex and obscuration of ocular fundus are not expected. Additionally, in patients with open-angle glaucoma, the visual field loss progresses from peripheral to central over time, which is not seen here.

answers.content: Administration of topical pilocarpine and timolol
answers.explanation_why: Topical pilocarpine and timolol are the first-line treatment for acute angle-closure glaucoma, which can cause blurred vision associated with halos around lights and manifest with a hard to visualize retina (due to corneal opacification). However, acute angle-closure glaucoma is usually unilateral rather than bilateral, and patients typically present with a red, painful eye with a fixed pupil, which is not seen here. Additionally, the visual impairment has a sudden onset rather than a progressive course. Furthermore, beta blockers should be avoided in this patient with asthma because of the risk of bronchoconstriction.

Blurred vision is a common side effect of digoxin therapy, affecting 1–10% of patients taking this cardiac glycoside. However, digoxin therapy is not associated with halos around lights, temporary improvement in near vision, darkening of the red reflex, or obscuration of the ocular fundus. Other visual side effects of digoxin therapy include central scotomas, photopsia, diplopia, and dyschromatopsia. Finally, further side effects (gastrointestinal, neurological) would be expected in the case of digoxin toxicity.

question_text: A 21-year-old woman comes to the emergency department because of a 1-hour history of redness in the left eye. She says that there was no recent trauma. Her vision has not been affected, and she does not have eye pain or a foreign body sensation. There is no personal history of serious illness. Her father was diagnosed with ulcerative colitis a few years ago. Her only medication is an oral contraceptive. She appears anxious. Her temperature is 37.0°C (98.6°F), pulse is 82/min, respirations are 15/min, and blood pressure is 124/84 mm Hg. Ocular examination shows the findings seen in the photograph. Her visual acuity is 20/20 bilaterally. The pupils are equal and reactive to light; ocular movements are not restricted. The optic fundi are normal. The remainder of the physical examination shows no abnormalities. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?
content_preview: A 21-year-old woman comes to the emergency department because of a 1-hour history of redness in the left eye. She says that there was no recent trauma. Her vision has not been affected, and she does not have eye pain or a foreign body sensation. There is no personal history of serious illness. Her father was diagnosed with ulcerative colitis a few years ago. Her only medication is an oral contraceptive. She appears anxious. Her temperature is 37.0°C (98.6°F), pulse is 82/min, respirations are 15/min, and blood pressure is 124/84 mm Hg. Ocular examination shows the findings seen in the photograph. Her visual acuity is 20/20 bilaterally. The pupils are equal and reactive to light; ocular movements are not restricted. The optic fundi are normal. The remainder of the physical examination shows no abnormalities. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?
hint: The photograph shows a focal, well-demarcated, conjunctival erythema, which is consistent with a subconjunctival hemorrhage (SCH).
learning_objective: Recognize subconjunctival hemorrhage, and choose the most appropriate management.

answers.explanation_why: Topical moxifloxacin (i.e., fluoroquinolone) therapy is the appropriate treatment for pseudomonas keratitis. This condition typically affects contact lens wearers, is characterized by a fulminant course, and manifests with erythema of the entire conjunctiva and sclera, not with a focal and well-demarcated red conjunctival area like the one seen in this patient. Moreover, patients usually present with purulent discharge, foreign body sensation, photophobia, and/or pain, none of which are seen here.

images.title: Infective keratitis
images.description: Prominent blood vessels are visible on the sclera and conjunctiva (mixed injection; examples indicated by arrowheads). A dense corneal infiltration (white opacification; green overlay) is visible at the center of the cornea. The peripheral cornea shows slight opacification indicating corneal decompensation (blurred details of the iris). An accumulation of white-yellow exudate (hypopyon; blue overlay) consisting of inflammatory cells and/or bacteria/fungi within the anterior chamber can be seen completely covering the inferior aspect of the iris.These findings are consistent with infective keratitis, associated here with contact lens use.

answers.explanation_why:
In the case of spontaneous, nonbullous subconjunctival hemorrhage (SCH) without other symptoms (e.g., changes in visual acuity, photophobia, eye pain, foreign body sensation), no further diagnostic workup or treatment is needed. Spontaneous SCH typically occurs as a result of maneuvers that increase venous pressure in the eyeball (e.g., coughing, straining, heavy lifting, vomiting, Valsalva maneuver). Patients should be reassured that this condition, although sometimes appearing dramatic, resolves spontaneously when the blood is reabsorbed (usually within 2–3 weeks). The patient should be told that the area of hemorrhage may increase during the first days after SCH as a result of the redistribution of blood in the loculated subconjunctival space.

In the case of SCH associated with trauma, bullous SCH, or one of the aforementioned symptoms, further ophthalmologic workup is indicated, such as slit lamp examination to rule out conditions of the anterior eye (e.g., conjunctival lacerations, foreign bodies) and/or CT scan to rule out intraocular or intraorbital injury (e.g., globe rupture). Patients with recurrent spontaneous SCH should be evaluated for underlying conditions (e.g., poorly controlled hypertension, coagulopathies) and patients on an anticoagulation regimen should be evaluated for overmedication. SCH in young children can be a sign of child abuse.

images.title: Resolution of subconjunctival hemorrhage
images.description: Photograph of a patient's left eye showing subconjunctival hemorrhage.Top (one week after hemorrhage): large, sharply demarcated areas of the sclera are red, indicating recent subconjunctival hemorrhage.Bottom (four weeks after hemorrhage): while the lateral sclera is still red, the medial sclera has become yellow, indicating reabsorption of the blood and resolution of the hemorrhage.Usually, subconjunctival hemorrhage resolves spontaneously within 2–3 weeks, with the color changing from red to shades of orange and yellow before clearing completely. Persistent or recurrent hemorrhage requires further investigation.

answers.explanation_why: A CT scan of the orbit must be performed in patients with subconjunctival hemorrhage (SCH) who present with a history of blunt trauma and associated symptoms (e.g., diplopia) in order to exclude intraocular and/or intraorbital injury (e.g., globe rupture, orbital fractures, retrobulbar hemorrhage). This patient, however, has spontaneous SCH with no history of blunt trauma.

images.title: Lid hematoma and subconjunctival bleeding
images.description: A lower eyelid hematoma on the right side is visible. Subconjunctival bleeding is present temporally as well.A traumatic cause was reported (fist to the eye), further investigation regarding orbital floor fracture is needed, especially as the patient reports binocular diplopia while looking upwards (not shown), suggesting an infringement of the inferior rectus muscle.

answers.explanation_why: Topical prednisolone therapy may be used for short-term treatment of allergic conjunctivitis (AC) in patients refractory to other treatment options (e.g., antihistamines). AC manifests with bilateral conjunctival erythema, itching, and/or epiphora, not painless, unilateral, well-demarcated conjunctival redness.

images.title: Allergic conjunctivitis
images.description: Right eye of an older adultConjunctival injection, massive chemosis, and tearing are visible. The eyelids appear edematous.This is the classical appearance of allergic conjunctivitis.

answers.explanation_why: Slit lamp examination should be performed in patients with symptomatic subconjunctival hemorrhage (SCH) to exclude underlying conditions of the anterior eye (e.g., conjunctival and scleral lacerations, keratoconjunctivitis, corneal abrasions, foreign bodies, anterior uveitis). Manifestations of these conditions include eye pain, foreign body sensation, and/or photophobia. This patient, however, has spontaneous SCH with no other symptoms.

Measurement of blood clotting indices is indicated in patients with recurrent subconjunctival hemorrhage (SCH) and in patients with other signs of bleeding diathesis (e.g., petechiae, epistaxis) to evaluate for an underlying bleeding disorder. In addition, coagulation studies should be obtained in patients with SCH who are on an anticoagulation regimen to rule out overmedication. This otherwise healthy patient, however, has spontaneous SCH with no other symptoms.

images.title: Subconjunctival hemorrhage
images.description: Left eyeA small subconjunctival hemorrhage is visible adjacent to the temporal inferior limbus.This is the typical appearance of subconjunctival hemorrhage.

question_text: A 56-year-old woman comes to the physician because of a 4-month history of fatigue, dry mouth, blurry vision, and a persistent nonproductive cough. She does not have shortness of breath, a rash, or joint pain. She has no history of serious illness and takes no medications. She does not smoke or drink alcoholic beverages. Temperature is 37.2°C (99.0°F), pulse is 76/min, respirations are 12/min, and blood pressure is 124/72 mm Hg. Physical examination shows injected conjunctivae and swollen parotid glands. Examination of the oral cavity shows dry mucous membranes and prominent tongue fissures. The lungs are clear to auscultation. The remainder of the physical examination shows no abnormalities. On slit-lamp examination, tear film break-up time is decreased. The results of a complete blood count show no abnormalities. Serum studies show positive antinuclear antibody titers, negative anti-Smith and anti-dsDNA antibody titers, and IgG4 antibody titers that are within the reference range. An ECG and a CT scan of the chest show no abnormalities. This patient is at greatest risk for which of the following complications?
content_preview: A 56-year-old woman comes to the physician because of a 4-month history of fatigue, dry mouth, blurry vision, and a persistent nonproductive cough. She does not have shortness of breath, a rash, or joint pain. She has no history of serious illness and takes no medications. She does not smoke or drink alcoholic beverages. Temperature is 37.2°C (99.0°F), pulse is 76/min, respirations are 12/min, and blood pressure is 124/72 mm Hg. Physical examination shows injected conjunctivae and swollen parotid glands. Examination of the oral cavity shows dry mucous membranes and prominent tongue fissures. The lungs are clear to auscultation. The remainder of the physical examination shows no abnormalities. On slit-lamp examination, tear film break-up time is decreased. The results of a complete blood count show no abnormalities. Serum studies show positive antinuclear antibody titers, negative anti-Smith and anti-dsDNA antibody titers, and IgG4 antibody titers that are within the reference range. An ECG and a CT scan of the chest show no abnormalities. This patient is at greatest risk for which of the following complications?
hint: Features of sicca syndrome (e.g., dry mouth and tongue fissures due to xerostomia; blurred vision, injected conjunctiva, and decreased tear film break-up time due to keratoconjunctivitis sicca) and positive antinuclear antibodies (ANAs) in a patient without a history of another autoimmune disorder are consistent with primary Sjogren syndrome (SS).
learning_objective: Recognize primary Sjogren syndrome, and recall its complications.

answers.explanation_why: Focal segmental glomerulosclerosis (FSGS) is the most common cause of nephrotic syndrome in adults and can occur idiopathically or secondary to HIV infection, sickle cell disease, heroin use, severe obesity, and interferon therapy. The most common renal complications of primary SS are tubulointerstitial nephritis and type 1 renal tubular acidosis. Glomerular involvement in primary SS is rare and, when it does occur, typically manifests as membranoproliferative glomerulonephritis or membranous nephropathy, not FSGS.

Lofgren syndrome occurs in 5–10% of patients with sarcoidosis, which occurs more commonly in women and can manifest with features of pulmonary involvement (e.g., cough), keratoconjunctivitis sicca, xerostomia, and parotid enlargement. However, in patients with sarcoidosis, chest imaging would typically show hilar lymphadenopathy, which is the earliest manifestation of pulmonary involvement. Primary SS, which is more likely in this patient, is not associated with Lofgren syndrome.

Patients with Sjogren syndrome (SS) have an increased risk of developing non-Hodgkin lymphomas of the exocrine glands, particularly the parotid gland. The most important risk factor for lymphoma development in SS is persistent salivary gland enlargement. Although the pathophysiology of lymphoma development in SS is not entirely known, B-cell activation and chronic inflammation are thought to play a role. MALT lymphoma is the most common lymphoma in patients with SS, followed by diffuse large B-cell lymphoma. Other common complications in patients with SS are related to xerostomia and include gastroesophageal reflux disease, atrophic oral candidiasis, and increased risk of dental caries. Patients with SS can develop a dry cough as a result of xerotrachea and xerobronchitis (the most likely cause in this patient with a normal chest CT) or interstitial lung disease. Patients with primary SS are often positive for anti-Ro and anti-La antibodies, both of which are specific types of ANA.

Parotid enlargement is more common in primary than in secondary SS.

Retroperitoneal fibrosis (RPF) is associated with IgG4-related disease, which can manifest with xerostomia, xerophthalmia, and parotid gland enlargement. A dry cough may also be seen in IgG4-related disease as a result of interstitial lung disease. However, positive antinuclear antibody titers are not seen in IgG4-related disease. Instead, serum IgG4 antibody titers are often well above the normal range (≥ 2 times the upper limit). RPF is not typically associated with primary SS, the diagnosis in this patient.

Libman-Sacks endocarditis (LSE) is associated with systemic lupus erythematosus (SLE), which typically occurs in women and can cause a dry cough (due to pleuritis or interstitial lung disease), fatigue, positive ANA titers, and, occasionally, features of secondary SS (keratoconjunctivitis sicca, xerostomia). However, negative anti-Smith and anti-dsDNA antibody titers indicate a different cause for increased ANA titers. Moreover, patients with SLE usually have a malar or discoid rash, photosensitivity, oral ulcers (rather than tongue fissures), arthralgia, and/or hematological abnormalities, none of which this patient has. Primary SS has been reported to cause autoimmune myocarditis but is not associated with LSE.

question_text: A 72-year-old man comes to the emergency department 45 minutes after a sudden transient loss of vision in his right eye. The vision loss was painless and lasted for 5 minutes. He had no other symptoms and says he has never had a similar episode before. He has a history of hypertension, hyperlipidemia, and type 2 diabetes mellitus. He has smoked one pack of cigarettes daily for the past 48 years and drinks one beer daily. Current medications include enalapril, atorvastatin, and metformin. He is 167 cm (5 ft 6 in) tall and weighs 89 kg (196 lb); BMI is 32 kg/m^2. His temperature is 37.1°C (98.8°F), pulse is 72/min and regular, respirations are 13/min, and blood pressure is 148/91 mm Hg. Visual acuity is 20/32 bilaterally. Intraocular pressure is 15 mm Hg in the right eye and 16 mm Hg in the left eye (N = 10–21). The pupil is reactive and the cornea and anterior chamber are clear. Fundoscopic examination of the right eye shows a few microaneurysms, increased tortuosity of the retinal arterioles, and bright yellow, refractile bodies at the bifurcations of the retinal arterioles. Erythrocyte sedimentation rate is 15 mm/h. Which of the following is the most likely explanation for this patient's loss of vision?
content_preview: A 72-year-old man comes to the emergency department 45 minutes after a sudden transient loss of vision in his right eye. The vision loss was painless and lasted for 5 minutes. He had no other symptoms and says he has never had a similar episode before. He has a history of hypertension, hyperlipidemia, and type 2 diabetes mellitus. He has smoked one pack of cigarettes daily for the past 48 years and drinks one beer daily. Current medications include enalapril, atorvastatin, and metformin. He is 167 cm (5 ft 6 in) tall and weighs 89 kg (196 lb); BMI is 32 kg/m2. His temperature is 37.1°C (98.8°F), pulse is 72/min and regular, respirations are 13/min, and blood pressure is 148/91 mm Hg. Visual acuity is 20/32 bilaterally. Intraocular pressure is 15 mm Hg in the right eye and 16 mm Hg in the left eye (N = 10–21). The pupil is reactive and the cornea and anterior chamber are clear. Fundoscopic examination of the right eye shows a few microaneurysms, increased tortuosity of the retinal arterioles, and bright yellow, refractile bodies at the bifurcations of the retinal arterioles. Erythrocyte sedimentation rate is 15 mm/h. Which of the following is the most likely explanation for this patient's loss of vision?
hint: This patient presents with painless, monocular amaurosis fugax (i.e., sudden transient vision loss). His fundoscopic examination shows Hollenhorst plaques (bright, yellow, refractile bodies at the bifurcations of the retinal arterioles), which are consistent with cholesterol crystal embolization. He also has signs of hypertensive retinopathy (e.g., microaneurysms, increased tortuosity of the retinal arterioles).
learning_objective: Recognize stenosis of the internal carotid artery.

answers.explanation_why:
Dry age-related macular degeneration (AMD) causes the formation of drusen, which are yellow retinal spots that can have a refractile appearance. However, these spots would be clustered around the macula rather than the bifurcations of the retinal arterioles and dry AMD does not cause acute visual impairment.

Wet AMD can lead to subretinal hemorrhage, manifesting with acute monocular visual impairment. This patient does not have subretinal hemorrhage or any other signs of wet AMD (e.g., gray-green retinal discoloration, serous detachment of the retina) on fundoscopic examination and contrary to this patient's presentation, visual impairment after subretinal hemorrhage resolves slowly over several weeks.

answers.content: Granulomatous inflammation of the ophthalmic artery
answers.explanation_why: Granulomatous inflammation of the ophthalmic artery is seen in giant cell arteritis (GCA). This condition may cause anterior ischemic optic neuropathy (AION), which can manifest with monocular amaurosis fugax. However, patients with GCA usually have other symptoms as well (e.g., constitutional symptoms, jaw claudication, headache) and, most importantly, an elevated erythrocyte sedimentation rate. Furthermore, AION due to GCA typically manifests with papilledema on fundoscopic examination.

answers.content: Stenosis of the internal carotid artery
answers.explanation_why:
Carotid artery stenosis (CAS) can manifest with monocular amaurosis fugax due to retinal ischemia, caused by stenosis-induced hypoperfusion, thrombosis, or microemboli. This patient has several risk factors for atherosclerosis (hypertension, hyperlipidemia, diabetes mellitus, smoking), and fundoscopic examination revealed cholesterol crystal emboli, which most commonly originate from carotid artery atheromas.

Workup for patients with amaurosis fugax generally includes carotid duplex ultrasound to screen for CAS. Carotid revascularization is indicated for patients with symptomatic (e.g., those with amaurosis fugax), severe CAS, and should be considered for patients with symptomatic, moderate CAS, and asymptomatic patients with severe CAS.

answers.content: Immune-mediated demyelination of the optic nerve
answers.explanation_why: Immune-mediated demyelination of the optic nerve (i.e., optic neuritis) typically manifests with monocular vision loss with a progressive onset over hours/days and a peak in impairment after 1–2 weeks, unlike this patient's presentation with amaurosis fugax. Patients with optic neuritis develop papilledema (in the case of papillitis) or have normal fundoscopic findings (in the case of retrobulbar neuritis).

images.title: Papillitis in optic neuritis
images.description:
Fundus photography of the left eye of a patient with acute vision loss and painful eye movementsDiscrete optic disc edema is visible: Discrete blurring of the nasal superior, superior, and temporal superior disc margin can be seen (green overlay). Otherwise, the fundus is normal.

This finding, in addition to the patient's symptoms, suggests papillitis in optic neuritis.M: macula; circle: optic disc

answers.content: Thrombotic occlusion of the retinal vein
answers.explanation_why: Thrombotic occlusion of the retinal vein (i.e., central retinal vein occlusion) typically leads to a sudden, monocular loss of vision. However, vision loss in central retinal vein occlusion usually does not resolve spontaneously. Furthermore, this condition manifests with massive retinal hemorrhages, dilated tortuous retinal veins, macular edema, and papilledema on fundoscopic examination, none of which is seen here.

images.title: Central retinal vein occlusion
images.description: Fundus photography of the right eye of a 76-year-old patientFlame-shaped retinal hemorrhage is visible in all four quadrants (example indicated by green outline). The tortuous veins (green arrows) are markedly dilated and there is papilledema with loss of sharp demarcation of the optic disc (green overlay).These findings are typical for a central retinal vein occlusion.

answers.content: Stasis of blood in the atrium
answers.explanation_why: Stasis of blood in the atrium, which occurs in patients with atrial fibrillation (Afib), increases the risk of atrial thrombus formation and arterial thromboembolism. Transient embolic occlusion of the central retinal artery would cause amaurosis fugax. However, this patient does not have an irregular pulse to suggest Afib, and thromboemboli, which are composed of platelets and fibrin, have a white-gray, pale, and nonrefractile appearance on fundoscopy.
