question_text: A 4-week-old male newborn is brought to the physician by his mother because of a 2-day history of nasal discharge and cough. He was born at 39 weeks' gestation to a 23-year-old woman gravida 1, para 1, after an uncomplicated delivery. Two weeks ago, his mother noticed a “thick yellow-green discharge” from his left eye that was treated at home with teabag compressions. The mother has no medical insurance and did not receive prenatal care. The patient appears irritable. He is at the 50th percentile for length and weight. His temperature is 37.4°C (99.3°F), pulse is 130/min, respirations are 65/min, and blood pressure is 80/55 mm Hg. Pulse oximetry on room air shows an oxygen saturation of 93%. Physical examination shows short, repetitive episodes of cough with brief inspirations between each cough. Bilateral, diffuse crackles are heard on auscultation of the chest. There is mild swelling of the left eyelid. Polymerase chain reaction tests of nasopharyngeal and ocular secretions are positive for the same pathogen. Which of the following is the most likely causal microorganism?
content_preview: A 4-week-old male newborn is brought to the physician by his mother because of a 2-day history of nasal discharge and cough. He was born at 39 weeks' gestation to a 23-year-old woman gravida 1, para 1, after an uncomplicated delivery. Two weeks ago, his mother noticed a “thick yellow-green discharge” from his left eye that was treated at home with teabag compressions. The mother has no medical insurance and did not receive prenatal care. The patient appears irritable. He is at the 50th percentile for length and weight. His temperature is 37.4°C (99.3°F), pulse is 130/min, respirations are 65/min, and blood pressure is 80/55 mm Hg. Pulse oximetry on room air shows an oxygen saturation of 93%. Physical examination shows short, repetitive episodes of cough with brief inspirations between each cough. Bilateral, diffuse crackles are heard on auscultation of the chest. There is mild swelling of the left eyelid. Polymerase chain reaction tests of nasopharyngeal and ocular secretions are positive for the same pathogen. Which of the following is the most likely causal microorganism?
hint: This patient developed neonatal conjunctivitis and now presents with nasal congestion and features of pneumonia (tachypnea, hypoxemia, cough, and crackles on auscultation). Eosinophilia on a complete blood count is a relatively specific diagnostic clue for this newborn's condition, which could most likely have been prevented with adequate prenatal care.
learning_objective: Recognize Chlamydia trachomatis infection in neonates, and recall its clinical manifestations.

answers.explanation_why: Neisseria gonorrhoeae, which can cause neonatal conjunctivitis with thick, purulent ocular discharge and pronounced eyelid swelling, is transmitted perinatally during vaginal delivery and can be screened for during prenatal care (prenatal gonorrhea screening). However, gonococcal conjunctivitis typically manifests in newborns 2–7 days after delivery, whereas this patient's presentation began after 2 weeks. In addition to neonatal conjunctivitis, N. gonorrhea infection can cause disseminated gonococcal infection and septic arthritis, but not pneumonia.

images.title: Infant with gonococcal ophthalmic disease
images.description: The eyelids are swollen, with purulent exudate forming crusts around them. Below the crusts there may be a large reservoir of pus. Special care should be taken and safety goggles should be worn when examining the eyes.

answers.explanation_why: Respiratory syncytial virus (RSV) infection can cause rhinorrhea, bronchiolitis, and, occasionally, afebrile pneumonia during infancy or the late neonatal period. Both bronchiolitis and pneumonia cause cough, hypoxemia, and crackles on auscultation. Conjunctival injection may be present in patients with RSV infection, as seen here. However, RSV does not cause purulent conjunctivitis.

Parainfluenza virus type 1 typically causes croup, which can manifest with nasal congestion, a cough (classically a “barking seal” cough), and features of respiratory distress (e.g., tachypnea, hypoxemia). Patients may be afebrile or only have a low-grade fever during the prodromal phase. However, croup is characterized by hoarseness and inspiratory stridor, rather than crackles, and it more commonly affects children 6 months to 3 years of age. Moreover, this patient's history of purulent conjunctivitis suggests a different diagnosis.

Streptococcus pneumoniae can cause pneumonia during infancy and the late neonatal period. However, pneumococcal pneumonia typically has a more severe presentation with high fever, whereas this neonate has afebrile pneumonia. Moreover, S. pneumoniae is a common cause of conjunctivitis in older children and young adults (pneumococcal conjunctivitis), but not in neonates.

Streptococcus agalactiae (group B streptococcus; GBS) infection in neonates can manifest as pneumonia, and this patient's mother most likely did not receive prenatal screening for GBS colonization. However, neonatal pneumonia due to GBS would manifest within the first 6 days of life (early-onset GBS infection), whereas the pneumonia in this newborn manifested at 4 weeks of life. Late-onset GBS infection, which occurs 1–12 weeks after birth, usually manifests with neonatal meningitis or neonatal sepsis, but not pneumonia. Moreover, GBS is a rare cause of neonatal conjunctivitis.

This newborn has Chlamydia trachomatis infection that likely was transmitted during delivery and is manifesting as neonatal conjunctivitis and afebrile pneumonia syndrome. Neonatal conjunctivitis due to C. trachomatis typically manifests 5–14 days after birth and likely explains this patient's mucopurulent eye discharge and swelling. Chlamydial pneumonia, which usually manifests 4–12 weeks after birth can be accompanied by neonatal conjunctivitis and is characterized by a staccato cough with or without low-grade fever and features of interstitial pneumonia on chest x-ray. C. trachomatis infection is treated with macrolide antibiotics (e.g., erythromycin). Prenatal screening for C. trachomatis infection is indicated for pregnant women < 25 years of age.

Herpes simplex virus 2 (HSV-2), which can be transmitted during vaginal delivery (if the mother has active genital herpes), would cause neonatal keratoconjunctivitis and, in the case of disseminated disease, pneumonia. However, HSV-induced keratoconjunctivitis is associated with vesicles and nonpurulent watery discharge, not purulent discharge. Moreover, disseminated HSV infection usually occurs within a few days of the onset of mucocutaneous or ophthalmological disease; pulmonary involvement 2 weeks after the onset of ophthalmological disease indicates a different diagnosis.

Bordetella pertussis infection (pertussis) can result in nasal discharge and cough without fever during the catarrhal stage, which may be brief in young infants. The catarrhal stage would be followed by paroxysms of a staccato cough with hypoxemia, as seen here (paroxysmal stage). Young infants are also at higher risk of developing complications of pertussis, such as pneumonia, and a lack of prenatal care (e.g., third trimester Tdap immunization) increases the risk of pertussis. However, B. pertussis does not cause neonatal conjunctivitis, so it is not the most likely causal organism.

question_text: A 40-year-old woman comes to the office because of a 3-month history of itchiness in both eyes. During this time, she has also had difficulty swallowing solid food. She is sexually active with her husband and has recently noticed increased pain with sexual intercourse. Medical history is unremarkable and she takes no medications. Her sister has vitiligo. Vital signs are within normal limits. Oropharyngeal examination shows dry mucous membranes and prominent tongue fissures. Ophthalmologic examination shows normal visual acuity and scleral injection in both eyes. A filter paper placed on the patient's lower eyelid wicks 3 mm of moisture after 5 minutes. Which of the following is most appropriate to confirm the diagnosis?
content_preview: A 40-year-old woman comes to the office because of a 3-month history of itchiness in both eyes. During this time, she has also had difficulty swallowing solid food. She is sexually active with her husband and has recently noticed increased pain with sexual intercourse. Medical history is unremarkable and she takes no medications. Her sister has vitiligo. Vital signs are within normal limits. Oropharyngeal examination shows dry mucous membranes and prominent tongue fissures. Ophthalmologic examination shows normal visual acuity and scleral injection in both eyes. A filter paper placed on the patient's lower eyelid wicks 3 mm of moisture after 5 minutes. Which of the following is most appropriate to confirm the diagnosis?
hint: This patient's itchy eyes and abnormal Schirmer test due to xerophthalmia in combination with dysphagia due to xerostomia indicate sicca syndrome, which is typical of Sjogren syndrome (SS). Patients with SS can also present with dyspareunia caused by vaginal dryness.
learning_objective: Recognize Sjogren syndrome, and choose the most appropriate diagnostic study.

answers.explanation_why: Labial (rather than parotid) salivary gland biopsy is an accurate test for SS and would show sialadenitis with dense focal lymphocytic infiltrations. However, a salivary gland biopsy is only necessary to confirm the diagnosis in patients without evidence of systemic autoimmunity. Therefore, a less invasive test should be performed first.

Upper endoscopy can be performed in patients with dysphagia, which this patient has. Dysphagia is often seen in patients with SS due to xerostomia. However, upper endoscopy would only exclude other causes of dysphagia (e.g., malignancy), which is not sufficient to confirm the diagnosis of SS. Other gastrointestinal manifestations of SS include dyspepsia and reflux esophagitis.

In patients with SS, urinalysis can show signs of glomerulonephritis or interstitial nephritis (e.g., proteinuria, hematuria, red blood cell casts), which are possible extraglandular vasculitic manifestations of SS. However, vasculitic manifestations only occur in approx. 10% of patients with SS. Therefore, urinalysis is not the most appropriate test to confirm the diagnosis.

Sialometry is a noninvasive test to measure saliva flow and can quantify salivary hypofunction in patients with xerostomia due to Sjogren syndrome (SS). While sialometry can support the diagnosis of SS, it is mainly performed in research settings and not generally used to diagnose SS.

Anti-Ro/SSA antibodies and anti-La/SSB antibodies are present in about 70% of patients with SS and confirm the diagnosis if seen in combination with typical clinical features of this condition (e.g., sicca syndrome). Other autoantibodies seen in patients with SS include antinuclear antibodies, which are positive in up to 97% of cases, and rheumatoid factor, which is positive in > 90% of cases of secondary SS (i.e., secondary to autoimmune diseases such as rheumatoid arthritis and systemic lupus erythematosus). In patients without serological evidence of autoimmunity or concomitant autoimmune disease, labial salivary gland biopsy is essential to confirm or exclude the diagnosis.

question_text: A 22-year-old woman comes to the physician because of a 1-day history of pain and swelling in her right eye. She has not had any visual changes. She is sexually active with multiple male partners and uses condoms consistently. There is no personal or family history of serious illness. She appears well. Vital signs are within normal limits. A photograph of the right eye is shown. The right eyelid is mildly tender on palpation. Physical examination shows no other abnormalities. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?
content_preview: A 22-year-old woman comes to the physician because of a 1-day history of pain and swelling in her right eye. She has not had any visual changes. She is sexually active with multiple male partners and uses condoms consistently. There is no personal or family history of serious illness. She appears well. Vital signs are within normal limits. A photograph of the right eye is shown. The right eyelid is mildly tender on palpation. Physical examination shows no other abnormalities. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?
hint: An acute, painful, erythematous nodule of the eyelid, in conjunction with this patient's otherwise unremarkable clinical presentation, is consistent with hordeolum (stye).
learning_objective: Recognize hordeolum (stye), and choose the most appropriate initial management.

answers.explanation_why: Topical antibiotics, such as gentamicin, can be considered in patients with frequent hordeola or severe symptoms (e.g., concurrent blepharoconjunctivitis), neither of which are reported here. Therefore, a different, first-line treatment should be tried in this patient before considering topical antibiotics.

A hordeolum is an acute purulent inflammation of the eyelid, most commonly due to Staphylococcus aureus, that occurs in two forms. This patient has an internal hordeolum, which typically arises at the palpebral conjunctiva. External hordeolum is more common and typically arises at the lid margin. For both types of hordeolum, the first step in management is the application of warm compresses and gentle massage to promote drainage of the blocked gland. Additionally, eyelid margin hygiene (i.e., debris removal with a clean cotton swab) should be maintained. If the patient has severe symptoms or does not respond to conservative treatment after 1–2 weeks, an ophthalmologist should be consulted for incision and curettage and antibiotic treatment (e.g., topical gentamicin, systemic cephalexin).

Excisional biopsy is performed in cases of recurrent or persistent chalazion to rule out malignancy (e.g., sebaceous carcinoma). Although chalazia can resemble hordeola in appearance, they are slow-growing and not associated with signs of inflammation (e.g., erythema, pain). This patient's clinical presentation is diagnostic of a hordeolum; therefore, there is no indication for an excisional biopsy.

images.title: Chalazion
images.description: Left eye with ectropionized lower eyelidA localized, nodular swelling is visible on the medial portion of the ectropionized lower eyelid. Both bulbar and tarsal conjunctiva are hyperemic.This is the typical appearance of a chalazion.

answers.explanation_why: Incision and drainage can be used in the treatment of hordeolum manifesting with severe symptoms (e.g., large hordeolum) or not showing any response to medical management within 1–2 weeks of therapy. As this patient presents with mild symptoms for 1 day only, a different, first-line treatment should be tried before considering incision and drainage.

Intravenous ceftriaxone is used in the treatment of conjunctivitis caused by Neisseria gonorrhea. Although neisserial conjunctivitis is seen in young, sexually active adults, like this patient, the presentation is usually more severe with marked eyelid swelling, profuse purulent discharge, and hyperemic conjunctiva, none of which are seen here. Systemic antibiotic therapy (e.g., oral cephalexin) may be indicated in persistent or severe hordeolum associated with complications (e.g., preseptal cellulitis) if conservative measures have been exhausted.

images.title: Internal hordeolum
images.description: Right eyeThere is local nodular erythematous swelling of the medial part of the right lower eyelid.This finding is consistent with an internal hordeolum (stye), an acute bacterial inflammation of a meibomian gland in the eyelid.

question_text: A 68-year-old man is brought to the emergency department by his wife because of sudden loss of vision in his right eye that occurred 1 hour ago. He does not have eye pain. He had several similar episodes of loss of vision; as these episodes all resolved after some minutes, he did not follow up on them. He has a history of hypertension, coronary artery disease, and type 2 diabetes mellitus. His father died from myocardial infarction at the age of 70 years. He has smoked up to one pack of cigarettes daily for 43 years and drinks one alcoholic beverage 3–5 days per week. Current medications include aspirin, nitroglycerin, lisinopril, metoprolol, atorvastatin, and metformin. His temperature is 36.7°C (98.1°F), pulse is 78/min, and blood pressure is 148/84 mm Hg. Ophthalmologic examination shows no perception of light in the right eye and 20/40 vision in the left eye. Corneal reflexes are brisk. The swinging flashlight test shows dilation of both pupils when the right eye is illuminated. Intraocular pressure is 17 mm Hg in the right eye and 16 mm Hg in the left eye. Examination of the lids and conjunctiva shows no abnormalities. Neurologic examination shows no other focal findings. On auscultation, there is a bruit over the right carotid artery. Fundoscopy of the right eye shows the findings in the photograph. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
content_preview: A 68-year-old man is brought to the emergency department by his wife because of sudden loss of vision in his right eye that occurred 1 hour ago. He does not have eye pain. He had several similar episodes of loss of vision; as these episodes all resolved after some minutes, he did not follow up on them. He has a history of hypertension, coronary artery disease, and type 2 diabetes mellitus. His father died from myocardial infarction at the age of 70 years. He has smoked up to one pack of cigarettes daily for 43 years and drinks one alcoholic beverage 3–5 days per week. Current medications include aspirin, nitroglycerin, lisinopril, metoprolol, atorvastatin, and metformin. His temperature is 36.7°C (98.1°F), pulse is 78/min, and blood pressure is 148/84 mm Hg. Ophthalmologic examination shows no perception of light in the right eye and 20/40 vision in the left eye. Corneal reflexes are brisk. The swinging flashlight test shows dilation of both pupils when the right eye is illuminated. Intraocular pressure is 17 mm Hg in the right eye and 16 mm Hg in the left eye. Examination of the lids and conjunctiva shows no abnormalities. Neurologic examination shows no other focal findings. On auscultation, there is a bruit over the right carotid artery. Fundoscopy of the right eye shows the findings in the photograph. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
hint: Fundoscopy shows retinal pallor, a cherry-red spot in the foveal region, and box-carring of the retinal vessels. These findings suggest ischemia.
learning_objective: Recognize central retinal artery occlusion.

answers.explanation_why: Optic neuritis (ON) may manifest with a sudden loss of vision and an afferent pupillary defect, both of which are seen here. ON is most commonly caused by multiple sclerosis (MS), and this patient's history of recurring loss of vision could be consistent with the relapsing course of MS. However, fundoscopy is typically unremarkable in ON; the findings seen in this patient would not be expected.

images.title: Papillitis in optic neuritis
images.description:
Fundus photography of the left eye of a patient with acute vision loss and painful eye movementsDiscrete optic disc edema is visible: Discrete blurring of the nasal superior, superior, and temporal superior disc margin can be seen (green overlay). Otherwise, the fundus is normal.

This finding, in addition to the patient's symptoms, suggests papillitis in optic neuritis.M: macula; circle: optic disc

answers.explanation_why: Ischemic central retinal vein occlusion (CRVO) manifests with sudden, painless loss of vision and a relative afferent pupillary defect. Furthermore, hypertension, diabetes mellitus, and atherosclerosis are risk factors for CRVO. However, in ischemic CRVO, fundoscopy would reveal multiple foci of retinal hemorrhage as well as severe edema of the macula and optic disc, neither of which is consistent with the findings seen in this patient.

images.title: Central retinal vein occlusion
images.description: Fundus photography of the right eye of a 76-year-old patientFlame-shaped retinal hemorrhage is visible in all four quadrants (example indicated by green outline). The tortuous veins (green arrows) are markedly dilated and there is papilledema with loss of sharp demarcation of the optic disc (green overlay).These findings are typical for a central retinal vein occlusion.

answers.explanation_why:
Central retinal artery occlusion is characterized by sudden, painless loss of vision and a relative afferent pupillary defect, which manifests with no perception of light in the affected eye and an abnormal swinging flashlight test. A past history of amaurosis fugax is also common. This patient has multiple risk factors for retinal artery disease, including diabetes mellitus, hypertension, and atherosclerosis. Along with the multiple cardiovascular risk factors, a carotid bruit suggests carotid artery atherosclerosis, which can lead to the release of a thrombus and subsequent occlusion of the central retinal artery; this is the most common cause of central retinal artery occlusion.

Retinal artery occlusion is an ophthalmologic emergency.

images.title: Central retinal artery occlusion
images.description: Left: lateral view of the right eye in longitudinal (sagittal) section. Depiction of an embolism in the central retinal artery causing retinal ischemia.Right: fundus photography of the right eye. Diffuse retinal ischemia causes edema in the inner retinal layers, manifesting as a gray-white discoloration of the retina (most markedly around the fovea; dotted circle). The fovea centralis, where the inner retinal layers are moved to the side, is not affected by edema. The underlying, well-vascularized choroid shines through, appearing as a cherry-red spot.

answers.explanation_why: Acute angle-closure glaucoma (AACG) can manifest with a sudden loss of vision and a relative afferent pupillary defect, both of which are seen here. However, the loss of vision is always painful and patients have an increased intraocular pressure (> 21 mm Hg), as opposed to the normal intraocular pressure in this patient. Furthermore, patients with AACG often present with injection and chemosis of the conjunctiva as well as trigeminal autonomic symptoms (e.g., nausea, vomiting, lacrimation). On fundoscopy, the optic disc would appear edematous or hyperemic, in contrast to the normal optic disc in this patient.

images.title: Angle-closure glaucoma
images.description: Slit-lamp photograph of anterior eye segmentProminent blood vessels are visible on the sclera and conjunctiva (mixed injection). The pupil is medium wide and its shape is slightly irregular. Iris details appear blurred due to corneal endothelial decompensation, leading to corneal edema.

answers.explanation_why: Anterior ischemic optic neuropathy can manifest with sudden, painless loss of vision, which this patient has. However, fundoscopy would show a hyperemic or edematous optic disc and possibly splinter hemorrhages within the optic disc, as opposed to the normal optic disc seen in this patient. Retinal and macular changes, which are seen here, would not be expected in anterior ischemic optic neuropathy.

images.title: Papilledema in non-arteritic anterior ischemic optic neuropathy (NAION)
images.description: Fundus photography of a right eyeThe optic disc (dashed circle) shows blurred margins and radial bleedings (arrowheads). The retinal veins are dilated and tortuous (examples indicated by white lines). In addition, the macula (M) shows pigment alterations (blue overlay).This is the typical appearance of papilledema, in this case caused by NAION. Papilledema can also be caused by arteritic anterior ischemic optic neuropathy (AAION), inflammatory processes, or elevated intracranial pressure.Hatched overlay: artifacts

answers.explanation_why: Massive vitreous hemorrhage can manifest with sudden, painless loss of vision and an afferent pupillary defect, both of which are seen here. Furthermore, both hypertension and diabetes mellitus, which this patient has, are risk factors for vitreous hemorrhage. However, the view of the retina on fundoscopy would be obscured by blood, and visualization of the optic disc and macula would not be possible, in contrast to this patient's clearly visible fundus.

Extensive retinal detachment or retinal detachment involving the macula can manifest with sudden, painless loss of vision and an afferent pupillary defect, both of which are seen here. Furthermore, both hypertension and diabetes mellitus, which this patient has, are risk factors for retinal detachment. However, fundoscopy would show a gray, detached, freely floating retina.

images.title: Rhegmatogenous retinal detachment
images.description: Fundus photography of the eyeThe detached part of the retina is visible as a yellow-gray, bullous elevation (blue overlay) in the upper part of the image. The detachment is due to a retinal tear (dashed outline).

answers.explanation_why: Exudative (wet) age-related macular degeneration (AMD) can manifest with unilateral, acute, painless vision impairment. Furthermore, cardiovascular disease and smoking history, both present in this patient, are risk factors for AMD. However, AMD usually does not lead to a complete loss of vision, but rather manifests with central scotoma (a blind spot) and metamorphopsia. Moreover, fundoscopy in wet AMD would show gray-green retinal discoloration, subretinal or intraretinal hemorrhages, and macular edema.

images.title: Acute central retinal artery occlusion
images.description: Fundus photography of a right eyeNarrow retinal arteries with box-carring of the retinal vessels (black dashed outline) and a pale retina indicating nerve fiber layer edema are visible. The fovea centralis appears red (cherry-red spot; purple overlay) due to the transparency of this part of the retina lacking nerve fibres, causing the well-vascularized choroid to shine through. Additionally, at the temporal superior arcade an embolus is present (arrow-head).This is the classical finding of acute central retinal artery occlusion.Purple circle: Optic disc

question_text: An 81-year-old woman is brought to the physician by her son because of a 1-day history of worsening eye pain and loss of vision in her left eye. She underwent cataract surgery on both eyes 3 days ago. Medical history is remarkable for type 2 diabetes mellitus, hypertension, and osteoarthritis of her knees. Her current medications include metformin, enalapril, and acetaminophen. She has no known drug allergies. Her temperature is 36.9°C (98.4°F), pulse is 62/min, and blood pressure is 139/84 mm Hg. Examination shows conjunctival injection and hypopyon of the left eye. Visual acuity is 20/40 in the right eye and there is only light perception in the left eye. Ocular motility is full. No retinal vessels can be seen on fundoscopic examination of the left eye. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?
content_preview: An 81-year-old woman is brought to the physician by her son because of a 1-day history of worsening eye pain and loss of vision in her left eye. She underwent cataract surgery on both eyes 3 days ago. Medical history is remarkable for type 2 diabetes mellitus, hypertension, and osteoarthritis of her knees. Her current medications include metformin, enalapril, and acetaminophen. She has no known drug allergies. Her temperature is 36.9°C (98.4°F), pulse is 62/min, and blood pressure is 139/84 mm Hg. Examination shows conjunctival injection and hypopyon of the left eye. Visual acuity is 20/40 in the right eye and there is only light perception in the left eye. Ocular motility is full. No retinal vessels can be seen on fundoscopic examination of the left eye. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?
hint: Acute-onset visual loss, ocular pain, conjunctival injection, hypopyon, and a hazy retina after undergoing cataract surgery are highly suggestive of acute postoperative endophthalmitis.
learning_objective: Recognize acute postoperative endophthalmitis, and choose the most appropriate management.

answers.content: Perform CT scan of the orbits and initiate systemic antibiotic therapy
answers.explanation_why: A CT scan of the orbits and systemic antibiotic therapy is indicated for patients with orbital cellulitis, which can manifest with ocular pain, vision loss, and chemosis following ophthalmic surgery. However, orbital cellulitis typically manifests with fever, eyelid swelling and erythema, ophthalmoplegia, and proptosis.

images.title: Orbital cellulitis
images.description: The left upper and lower eyelids are red and severely swollen, resulting in the patient not being able to open the eye. Orbital cellulitis is an emergency requiring immediate treatment.

answers.content: Collect vitreous humor for culture and administer intravitreal antifungal therapy
answers.explanation_why: Collection of vitreous humor for culture followed by administration of intravitreal antifungal therapy (e.g., amphotericin B, voriconazole) is indicated in patients with suspected fungal endophthalmitis. This condition is usually insidious rather than acute and typically manifests with creamy white retinal nodules on fundoscopy, which are not seen here. Postoperative endophthalmitis is more commonly due to bacterial infection.

images.title: Fungal endophthalmitis
images.description: Fundus photography of a right eyeWhite and fluffy vitreous or retinal infiltrates are visible. Retinal details are blurred through the vitreous cellular infiltrate.Candida is a common cause of fungal endophthalmitis. In patients with a systemic candida infection, endogenous endophthalmitis is a possible complication, as in the case here.

answers.content: Remove the intraocular lens and administer intravitreal antibiotic therapy
answers.explanation_why: Although intravitreal antibiotic therapy is indicated in patients with acute postoperative endophthalmitis, removal of the intraocular lens is usually not necessary.

answers.content: Perform vitrectomy and administer intravitreal antibiotic therapy
answers.explanation_why: Acute endophthalmitis is an ophthalmological emergency as patients can rapidly develop permanent vision loss. Empiric intravitreal antibiotic therapy should be initiated as soon as acute endophthalmitis is suspected; vitreous samples can be collected for culture before initiating empiric antibiotic therapy. The empiric antibiotic therapy should cover coagulase-negative Staphylococci and Staphylococcus aureus (e.g., vancomycin plus ceftazidime), which are the most common causative pathogens. In patients with severe vision loss, pars plana vitrectomy is indicated, and the tissue removed via vitrectomy should be sent for culture. Intravitreal antibiotics should be initiated immediately after vitrectomy. The intraocular lens placed during cataract surgery can usually be left in place.

answers.content: Collect vitreous humor and blood for culture and initiate systemic antibiotic therapy
answers.explanation_why: Collection of vitreous humor and blood for culture followed by systemic antibiotic therapy is indicated in patients with endogenous endophthalmitis. This condition, however, typically occurs via hematogenous spread to the eye during systemic infection, of which this patient has no features (e.g., fever, signs and symptoms consistent with a distant infectious focus). As this patient recently had ocular surgery, an exogenous rather than endogenous source of infection is more likely.

question_text: An 8-year-old boy is brought to the emergency department by his parents because of a 2-day history of worsening pain and swelling in the right eye. He has had fever, nasal congestion, and pain over the right cheek for the past 10 days that did not improve with over-the-counter medication. Three years ago, he was diagnosed with atopic dermatitis. There is no family history of serious illness. His only medication is topical hydrocortisone. Immunizations are up-to-date. His temperature is 38.4°C (101.1°F). Ophthalmologic examination shows erythema, tenderness, and swelling of the right eyelid; there is mild conjunctival injection. The pupils are equal and reactive to light; extraocular muscles are intact and their movement is not painful. Examination of the left eye shows no abnormalities. Visual acuity is 20/20 bilaterally. There is purulent nasal discharge. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
content_preview: An 8-year-old boy is brought to the emergency department by his parents because of a 2-day history of worsening pain and swelling in the right eye. He has had fever, nasal congestion, and pain over the right cheek for the past 10 days that did not improve with over-the-counter medication. Three years ago, he was diagnosed with atopic dermatitis. There is no family history of serious illness. His only medication is topical hydrocortisone. Immunizations are up-to-date. His temperature is 38.4°C (101.1°F). Ophthalmologic examination shows erythema, tenderness, and swelling of the right eyelid; there is mild conjunctival injection. The pupils are equal and reactive to light; extraocular muscles are intact and their movement is not painful. Examination of the left eye shows no abnormalities. Visual acuity is 20/20 bilaterally. There is purulent nasal discharge. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
hint: This patient has no symptoms that would suggest the involvement of extraocular muscles (e.g., reduced vision, ophthalmoplegia, or painful eye movement) or intraorbital fat tissue (e.g., proptosis).
learning_objective: Recognize preseptal cellulitis.

answers.explanation_why: Hordeolum commonly manifests with ocular pain. However, this condition is characterized by localized, tender, erythematous, pus-filled nodules at the distal lid margin. This patient's presentation with erythema and swelling of the entire eyelid is suggestive of a different condition.

images.title: Internal hordeolum
images.description: Right eyeThere is local nodular erythematous swelling of the medial part of the right lower eyelid.This finding is consistent with an internal hordeolum (stye), an acute bacterial inflammation of a meibomian gland in the eyelid.

answers.explanation_why: Cavernous sinus thrombosis is a life-threatening complication of bacterial rhinosinusitis that can manifest with erythema and swelling of the eyelid, ocular pain, and fever. However, more severe symptoms, such as headache, ophthalmoplegia, vision changes (e.g., diplopia, vision loss), signs of cranial nerve dysfunction (e.g., tinnitus, facial palsy), and seizures are expected in cavernous sinus thrombosis. This patient's presentation with normal visual acuity and intact extraocular muscles is suggestive of a different condition.

Orbital cellulitis is an infection of the orbital contents posterior to the orbital septum that can manifest with unilateral eyelid erythema and swelling, ocular pain, and fever, and is commonly preceded by bacterial rhinosinusitis. However, orbital cellulitis characteristically manifests with reduced vision, ophthalmoplegia, proptosis (due to inflammation of the intraorbital fat), and/or painful eye movement (due to inflammation of the extraocular muscles), none of which are seen here.

images.title: Orbital cellulitis
images.description: The left upper and lower eyelids are red and severely swollen, resulting in the patient not being able to open the eye. Orbital cellulitis is an emergency requiring immediate treatment.

answers.explanation_why: Orbital abscesses can occur as a complication of bacterial rhinosinusitis and manifest with fever, ocular pain, eyelid swelling, and erythema. However, in orbital abscesses, more severe symptoms of orbital involvement (e.g., ophthalmoplegia, reduced vision, and proptosis) would be expected. This patient's presentation with unlimited eye movement and normal visual acuity suggests a different condition.

Preseptal cellulitis is an infection of the eyelid and periorbital soft tissues anterior to the orbital septum that does not involve the orbital contents (see “Orbital cellulitis vs. preseptal cellulitis” table). This condition is commonly preceded by upper respiratory tract infections such as bacterial rhinosinusitis, but it can also develop as a result of a contiguous local soft tissue infection (e.g., due to dacryocystitis, insect or animal bites, or local trauma). Typical manifestations include ocular pain and unilateral eyelid erythema and swelling; chemosis and fever are less commonly seen. While diagnosis is primarily clinical, a CT scan of the orbits and sinuses should be performed if there is evidence of orbital cellulitis, or if symptoms are severe (e.g., marked eyelid swelling, high fever, leukocytosis) or fail to regress under adequate therapy. Treatment consists of oral antibiotics with coverage for methicillin-resistant Staphylococcus aureus (MRSA) and close outpatient follow-up.

question_text: A 12-year-old boy is brought to the physician by his mother because he has been falling behind in school and his teachers have voiced concerns. The boy says that he has trouble reading the board but does not have trouble reading books or using a computer screen. He has no personal or family history of serious illness. Both his parents and his older sister wear eyeglasses. He takes no medications and his immunizations are up-to-date. Visual acuity is 20/40 in both eyes. Prescribing which of the following lenses is the most appropriate next step in management?
content_preview: A 12-year-old boy is brought to the physician by his mother because he has been falling behind in school and his teachers have voiced concerns. The boy says that he has trouble reading the board but does not have trouble reading books or using a computer screen. He has no personal or family history of serious illness. Both his parents and his older sister wear eyeglasses. He takes no medications and his immunizations are up-to-date. Visual acuity is 20/40 in both eyes. Prescribing which of the following lenses is the most appropriate next step in management?
hint: Clear near vision with blurred far vision is consistent with myopia.
learning_objective: Recognize myopia, and choose the appropriate corrective lenses.

answers.explanation_why: Convex lenses help to focus light on the retina in patients with hyperopia. A patient with hyperopia is able to see objects at a far distance without difficulty but has trouble seeing objects at a near distance (e.g., books, computer screens, cell phone screens). This patient, however, has difficulty with long-distance vision (e.g., reading the board), which indicates myopia rather than hyperopia.

Progressive lenses are used in the treatment of presbyopia. Patients with this condition have difficulty focusing on objects viewed at arm's length or closer, which is not the case with this patient. Moreover, presbyopia almost exclusively affects adults.

Cylindrical lenses are prescribed for patients with astigmatism. Patients with this condition have a reduction in both near and far vision. Difficulty with vision only at a far distance is consistent with myopia, for which cylindrical lenses are not indicated.

Prismatic lenses are used in paralytic strabismus. While patients with paralytic strabismus can have deficient visual acuity, they typically also present with a compensatory head posture, diplopia, and/or impaired extraocular muscle function, none of which are seen here. Moreover, paralytic strabismus usually has a secondary cause (e.g., neuropathy, myopathy, demyelinating diseases, trauma).

Concave lenses are used to correct myopia. The increased axial length of the eye in myopia results in the focal point of an image being anterior to the retina, leading to blurry far vision and clear near vision. Concave lenses diverge incoming light, allowing it to be focused on the retina. Although mild myopia does not always require correction, this patient's myopia with 20/40 vision has affected his daily activities (school performance) and, therefore, needs treatment. Asymptomatic children with severe myopia should also use corrective lenses in order to prevent bilateral refractive amblyopia.

images.title: Emmetropia, myopia, and hyperopia
images.description: Deviations in eye anatomy that affect refractory media (e.g., axial length of the eye, cornea curvature) can result in refractive errors.Emmetropia: The axial length of the eye and refractive power are balanced, resulting in a focal point on the retina.Myopia: An increased axial length of the eye or increased refractive power results in a focal point anterior to the retina. Near objects can be seen clearly but distant objects are blurred. This can be corrected using a concave (diverging) lens.Hyperopia: A decreased axial length of the eye or decreased refractive power results in a focal point posterior to the retina. Distant objects and even near objects may be seen clearly depending on the ability of the lens to accommodate (generally, the younger the individual, the greater the ability to accommodate) and the degree of hyperopia. Hyperopia can be corrected using a convex (converging) lens.

question_text: A 57-year-old man comes to the office because of a 6-month history of foreign body sensation in his eyes. During this time, he has felt like there is sand in his eyes, and this sensation has slowly increased. He has no recent trauma and does not have eye pain or redness. He reports that he sometimes has difficulty looking at objects on the far temporal sides. He works for the postal service and spends most of the day outdoors delivering mail. He has hypertension that is well-controlled with enalapril. His temperature is 37.0°C (98.6°F), pulse is 78/min, and blood pressure is 124/81 mm Hg. Ocular examination shows the findings in the photograph. The pupils are equal and reactive to light. The optic fundi are normal. The remainder of the physical examination shows no abnormalities. In addition to wearing sunglasses, which of the following is the most appropriate treatment?
content_preview: A 57-year-old man comes to the office because of a 6-month history of foreign body sensation in his eyes. During this time, he has felt like there is sand in his eyes, and this sensation has slowly increased. He has no recent trauma and does not have eye pain or redness. He reports that he sometimes has difficulty looking at objects on the far temporal sides. He works for the postal service and spends most of the day outdoors delivering mail. He has hypertension that is well-controlled with enalapril. His temperature is 37.0°C (98.6°F), pulse is 78/min, and blood pressure is 124/81 mm Hg. Ocular examination shows the findings in the photograph. The pupils are equal and reactive to light. The optic fundi are normal. The remainder of the physical examination shows no abnormalities. In addition to wearing sunglasses, which of the following is the most appropriate treatment?
hint: This patient has a triangular, fibrovascular wedge of conjunctival tissue growing from the nasal conjunctiva towards the cornea known as pterygium, for which chronic UV radiation exposure is an important risk factor.
learning_objective: Recognize pterygium, and choose the most appropriate treatment.

answers.explanation_why: Topical antibiotics are an appropriate treatment for bacterial conjunctivitis, which manifests with foreign body sensation. Unlike a pterygium, bacterial conjunctivitis usually manifests with generalized erythematous conjunctiva and purulent discharge and does not restrict ocular motility.

Laser photocoagulation is used to treat ocular conditions associated with neovascularization (e.g., diabetic retinopathy, branch retinal vein occlusion) by minimizing the growth of new vessels. Although neovascularization is a mechanism in the pathophysiology of pterygium, laser photocoagulation is not recommended as an initial treatment and is only used as adjuvant therapy for recurrent pterygium.

Surgical excision is the preferred treatment for a pterygium that restricts ocular motility and/or impairs visual acuity. Additional indications for surgical excision include progressive growth and persistent irritation that is resistant to conservative therapy. A small pterygium that does not require surgery can be managed with UV protection measures (e.g., wearing sunglasses and a hat) and ocular lubricants (e.g., artificial tears) to reduce foreign body sensation and chronic irritation. Recurrence after surgical removal is common and indicates a high risk of recurrence after subsequent procedures.

Vascular endothelial growth factor (VEGF) inhibitor therapy is used to treat ocular conditions associated with neovascularization (e.g., age-related macular degeneration, diabetic macular edema) by targeting angiogenesis. Although levels of VEGF are increased in pterygium tissue, anti-VEGF therapy is not routinely recommended because there is limited evidence that it improves symptoms or affects prognosis.

Reassurance and artificial tears are an appropriate initial treatment for a small pterygium with local irritation and no impairment of vision and eye movement. These measures are insufficient for this patient with restricted ocular motility.

Topical lubricants are also appropriate for pinguecula, which is a conjunctival lesion with symptoms of local irritation (e.g., foreign body sensation) caused by chronic exposure to UV light. A pinguecula is a yellowish plaque that is confined to the conjunctiva and therefore does not impact ocular motility or vision.

images.title: Pterygium
images.description: Slit-lamp photography of the left eyeA fibrovascular proliferation (marked by overlay) originating from the nasal conjunctiva is seen growing onto the cornea.This is the typical appearance and localization of a pterygium.

question_text: A 2-hour-old male newborn is examined in the hospital nursery. He was born at 39 weeks' gestation to a 27-year-old mother, gravida 1, para 1, after an uncomplicated pregnancy and delivery. The patient's Apgar scores were 9 and 10 at 1 and 5 minutes respectively. Family history is remarkable for type 2 diabetes mellitus and open-angle glaucoma in his father. He appears well. He is at the 80^th percentile for length, weight, and head circumference. Temperature is 36.8°C (98.2°F), pulse is 150/min, and respirations are 44/min. Genitourinary examination shows abnormal foreskin and two meatal openings. Examination of the eyes shows partial absence of the iris. Which of the following is the most appropriate recommendation for this patient?
content_preview: A 2-hour-old male newborn is examined in the hospital nursery. He was born at 39 weeks' gestation to a 27-year-old mother, gravida 1, para 1, after an uncomplicated pregnancy and delivery. The patient's Apgar scores were 9 and 10 at 1 and 5 minutes respectively. Family history is remarkable for type 2 diabetes mellitus and open-angle glaucoma in his father. He appears well. He is at the 80th percentile for length, weight, and head circumference. Temperature is 36.8°C (98.2°F), pulse is 150/min, and respirations are 44/min. Genitourinary examination shows abnormal foreskin and two meatal openings. Examination of the eyes shows partial absence of the iris. Which of the following is the most appropriate recommendation for this patient?
hint: This patient's aniridia and genitourinary anomaly (hypospadias) suggest WAGR syndrome.
learning_objective: Recognize WAGR syndrome, and choose the appropriate screening method for associated malignancies.

answers.explanation_why: MRI of the brain may be used to screen for neuroblastoma, which occurs in several genetic syndromes (e.g., Turner syndrome, Beckwith-Wiedemann syndrome, neurofibromatosis, Hirschsprung disease). This patient has WAGR syndrome, which increases the risk for another condition.

Nephroblastoma (Wilms tumor) is associated with WAGR syndrome. Approximately 50% of children with WAGR syndrome develop nephroblastoma; therefore, screening ultrasound should be obtained quarterly until at least five years of age. Treatment typically consists of surgical resection and chemotherapy; radiation therapy is possible in advanced stages. Nephroblastoma has a good prognosis with survival rates > 90%.

Measurement of metanephrines (via serum or 24-hour urine collection) is used to screen for pheochromocytoma in patients with von Hippel-Lindau syndrome. Screening for pheochromocytoma is not recommended until 11 years of age, and this patient is a newborn. Moreover, this patient has WAGR syndrome, which increases the risk of a different condition.

Urinalysis is used in the workup of Denys-Drash syndrome, which manifests with genitourinary abnormalities (e.g., undescended testis), early-onset nephrotic syndrome with proteinuria, and nephroblastoma. This patient's presentation is consistent with WAGR syndrome, for which screening urinalysis is not recommended.

Alpha-fetoprotein measurements can be used to screen for hepatoblastoma, which is associated with several genetic syndromes (e.g., Beckwith-Wiedemann syndrome, Trisomy 18, Trisomy 21), and yolk sac tumors. This patient has WAGR syndrome, which increases the risk of another condition.

content_preview: Patient Information Age: 38 years Gender: F, self-identified Race/Ethnicity: unspecified Site of Care: office History Reason for Visit/Chief Concern: "My eyesight has been getting worse over the past couple of days." History of Present Illness: 4-day history of progressively blurred vision reports seeing flashing lights denies any ocular pain Past Medical History: unremarkable Medications: none Allergies: no known drug allergies Family history: mother and father: alive with no chronic conditions Psychosocial history: has smoked one-half pack of cigarettes daily for 10 years sexually active with multiple male partners; does not use condoms consistently Physical Examination Temp Pulse Resp BP O2 Sat Ht Wt BMI 36.7°C(98.1°F) 70/min 16/min 114/76 mm Hg - 165 cm(5 ft 5 in) 48 kg(105 lb) 18 kg/m2 Appearance: sitting in a chair; not in acute distress HEENT: white plaque on the dorsal surface of the tongue, easily scraped off; visual acuity is 20/40 in the right eye and 20/100 in the left eye; findings of left eye funduscopic examination shown Neck: no jugular venous distention or carotid bruits; no cervical lymphadenopathy Pulmonary: clear to auscultation Cardiac: regular rhythm; no murmurs Abdominal: soft and nontender; liver and spleen cannot be palpated Extremities: no femoral bruits; dorsalis pedis, radial, and femoral pulses intact; no lymphadenopathy Neurologic: alert; cranial nerves intact Diagnostic Studies slit lamp examination: no abnormalities Which of the following is the most appropriate pharmacotherapy for this patient's ocular condition?
hint: Painless vision loss with photopsia (flashing lights) and the funduscopic findings of fluffy, hemorrhagic, perivascular retinal lesions that radiate out from the optic disc (pizza-pie appearance) are characteristic of cytomegalovirus (CMV) retinitis, which typically occurs in immunocompromised patients. A history of high-risk sexual behavior, oral candidiasis (white plaques that are easily scraped off), and findings of CMV retinitis suggest an HIV infection in this patient.
learning_objective: Recognize CMV retinitis in immunocompromised patients, and choose the most appropriate pharmacotherapy.

answers.explanation_why:
Valganciclovir or ganciclovir are considered first-line therapy for CMV retinitis. which usually occurs unilaterally but can affect the other eye if untreated. Alternative agents include foscarnet and cidofovir. In patients with severe infection (e.g., lesions < 1.5 mm from the fovea or adjacent to the optic nerve head), intravitreal therapy with ganciclovir or foscarnet should also be considered. In HIV-positive patients, manifestations of severe CMV disease such as retinitis, esophagitis, colitis, pneumonitis, and encephalitis usually occur when the CD4+ T-cell count is < 50/mm^3. Patients with HIV infection should also be started on antiretroviral therapy to increase the CD4+ T-cell count.

See “Ophthalmologic complications of HIV” table.

Acyclovir is used to treat herpes simplex keratitis, herpes zoster ophthalmicus, and varicella zoster retinitis. These conditions are more likely to occur in individuals with HIV infection but cause painful vision loss. Varicella zoster retinitis causes vitreous opacification and yellow-white retinal patches starting from the periphery rather than the extensive retinal hemorrhagic lesions seen in this patient. Patients with herpes simplex keratitis and herpes zoster ophthalmicus would have corneal ulceration on slit lamp examination. Acyclovir is not effective against CMV.

images.title: Herpes simplex keratitis
images.description: Slit-lamp photography of the cornea (fluorescein stain)Dendritic lesions (red overlay) are visible on the cornea.This finding is characteristic of herpes simplex keratitis.

answers.explanation_why: Sulfadiazine-pyrimethamine is used to treat toxoplasmosis, which can cause chorioretinitis. Although toxoplasmosis chorioretinitis results in decreased visual acuity, it typically also causes eye pain. Additionally, unlike the perivascular retinal lesions seen in this patient, toxoplasmic chorioretinitis causes yellow-white, fluffy lesions in a nonvascular distribution. Sulfadiazine and pyrimethamine are ineffective against CMV.

images.title: Ocular toxoplasmosis
images.description:
Fundus photography of a right eyeThe image appears cloudy, which is consistent with vitreous opacity. There is a yellow-white, fluffy retinal lesion (blue overlay) at the temporal superior vascular arch. The pigmented scar (arrowhead) in the nasal area is most likely the remnant of a previous manifestation of toxoplasmosis. In addition, the optic disc (circle) appears blurred.

M: macula

answers.explanation_why: Penicillin G is used to treat ocular syphilis, which primarily affects the uvea and usually causes painful vision loss. Although this condition can result in perivascular retinal inflammation and retinal depigmentation, the extensive hemorrhagic lesions seen in this patient are not typical. Additionally, isolated ocular syphilis is rare; patients typically have other findings of syphilis (e.g., chancre, condyloma lata, generalized lymphadenopathy). Penicillin G is ineffective against CMV.

Trimethoprim-sulfamethoxazole (TMP-SMX) is commonly used for Pneumocystis jirovecii pneumonia prophylaxis in patients with CD4+ T-lymphocyte count < 200/mm^3. It is also used to treat Pneumocystis choroiditis, a condition typically seen in patients with disseminated Pneumocystis infection. Pneumocystis choroiditis manifests with multiple, bilateral, yellow-white choroidal lesions that spare the retina. Visual changes are uncommon. TMP-SMX is ineffective against CMV.

images.title: CMV retinitis
images.description: Fundus photography of the left eyeThere are diffuse perivascular retinal hemorrhages (examples indicated by blue hatched overlay), whitish retinal necroses (examples indicated by yellow overlay), and periphlebitis with vascular occlusion (examples indicated by blue overlay). In addition, hard exudates (examples indicated by arrowheads) can be seen. The combination of these features causes the characteristic pizza-pie appearance (zoom-box and illustration).These findings are consistent with retinitis caused by cytomegalovirus, which is most commonly seen in immunocompromised patients.

question_text:
A 10-year-old girl is brought to the emergency department with a 2-day history of fever, confusion, impaired vision, and weakness. Her parents report that her symptoms have worsened rapidly, and she now requires assistance to walk. Two weeks ago, she had an upper respiratory tract infection that resolved spontaneously. She has no history of serious illness and takes no medications. She does not smoke, drink alcohol, or use other substances. Immunizations are up to date. She appears somnolent and is oriented only to person. Her temperature is 39°C (102.2°F), pulse is 90/min, respirations are 18/min, and blood pressure is 110/60 mmHg. There is minimal movement when a painful stimulus is applied to each limb. Fundoscopic examination shows bilateral optic disc swelling. A CT scan of the head reveals scattered hypodense lesions in the brain parenchyma but is otherwise unremarkable. Cerebrospinal fluid analysis shows:

Pressure
160 mm H_2O

Glucose
60 mg/dL

Total protein
58 mg/dL

Leukocyte count
27/mm^3

 Lymphocytes
98%

Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
content_preview: A 10-year-old girl is brought to the emergency department with a 2-day history of fever, confusion, impaired vision, and weakness. Her parents report that her symptoms have worsened rapidly, and she now requires assistance to walk. Two weeks ago, she had an upper respiratory tract infection that resolved spontaneously. She has no history of serious illness and takes no medications. She does not smoke, drink alcohol, or use other substances. Immunizations are up to date. She appears somnolent and is oriented only to person. Her temperature is 39°C (102.2°F), pulse is 90/min, respirations are 18/min, and blood pressure is 110/60 mmHg. There is minimal movement when a painful stimulus is applied to each limb. Fundoscopic examination shows bilateral optic disc swelling. A CT scan of the head reveals scattered hypodense lesions in the brain parenchyma but is otherwise unremarkable. Cerebrospinal fluid analysis shows: Pressure 160 mm H2O Glucose 60 mg/dL Total protein 58 mg/dL Leukocyte count 27/mm3 Lymphocytes 98% Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
hint: Optic disc swelling without elevated intracranial pressure suggests optic neuritis.
learning_objective: Recognize acute disseminated encephalomyelitis.

answers.explanation_why: Multiple sclerosis (MS) can manifest with CNS lesions, optic neuritis, and lymphocytic pleocytosis on CSF analysis. However, an MS exacerbation typically develops over days to weeks, unlike the rapidly progressive symptoms seen here, and is not associated with fever, altered mental status, or elevated CSF protein levels.

Acute disseminated encephalomyelitis (ADEM) is a multifocal, inflammatory, demyelinating disease of the CNS. This condition predominantly affects children and young adults and occurs days to weeks after a viral infection or vaccination due to cross-reactivity between a viral and myelin antigen. ADEM is characterized by rapid onset and progression of neurological deficits and altered mental status. Patients often have a fever, and CSF analysis typically shows lymphocytic pleocytosis and elevated protein levels. Although the brain is primarily affected, patients can also develop optic neuritis, as seen here, and transverse myelitis. Characteristic neuroimaging findings are multiple poorly defined lesions in deep and subcortical white matter. A CT scan may show parenchymal lesions but is often nondiagnostic, and an MRI is necessary to confirm the diagnosis. Treatment involves high-dose intravenous corticosteroid therapy for 3–5 days.

images.title: Acute disseminated encephalomyelitis
images.description: MRI head (FLAIR; axial plane) of a 60-year-old with rapid cognitive decline starting 2 weeks after an elective dental procedure.Multiple large confluent hyperintense lesions are demonstrated in both cerebral hemispheres in an asymmetric pattern. The lesions are predominantly located within the white matter (example indicated by green overlay). In addition to these lesions in the supratentorial region, further hyperintense lesions are visible in the midbrain (example indicated by red overlay), indicating infratentorial involvement.Acute disseminated encephalomyelitis (ADEM) is an autoimmune-mediated inflammatory demyelinating condition. It is difficult to differentiate from other inflammatory conditions, especially multiple sclerosis, and tissue diagnosis may be the only way to confirm diagnosis. An immunologic trigger may be present in the clinical history. An infection from the dental procedure in this case may have been the trigger for ADEM.

answers.explanation_why: Progressive multifocal leukoencephalopathy (PML) causes brain lesions and can result in elevated CSF protein levels. However, PML usually affects immunocompromised individuals and progresses over several weeks. Moreover, fever and lymphocytic pleocytosis on CSF analysis do not typically occur in PML.

images.title: Progressive multifocal leukoencephalopathy
images.description: MRI head (left: T2-weighted; right: diffusion-weighted; axial plane) of a patient with common variable immunodeficiency syndromeA confluent, hyperintense area (green overlay) without mass effect is seen in the right frontoparietal subcortical white matter. High signal intensity on the diffusion-weighted image (red overlay) indicates diffusion restriction.The MRI features and immunocompromised state suggest progressive multifocal leukoencephalopathy (PML), even though PML lesions are typically multifocal, bilateral, and asymmetric. PML lesions generally show little or no mass effect or contrast enhancement.

answers.explanation_why: Neuromyelitis optica spectrum disorder (NMOSD) can manifest with rapidly progressive optic neuritis, neurological deficits, and elevated protein and pleocytosis on CSF analysis. However, NMOSD mainly affects the optic nerves and spinal cord. Brainstem and brain involvement are less common in this condition. Additionally, NMOSD typically occurs in adults and is not associated with fever or parainfectious pathogenesis. A recent infection in this patient makes a different condition more likely.

Acute inflammatory demyelinating polyneuropathy (AIDP) can occur after a viral infection and manifest with rapidly progressing muscle weakness and elevated protein levels on CSF analysis. However, fever, optic neuritis, brain lesions, and pleocytosis are not typically seen in this condition, and a change in mental status would occur only if the patient develops respiratory failure due to diaphragm paralysis.

question_text: A 56-year-old woman comes to the ophthalmologist because of vision changes over the past several months. She has worn glasses for nearsightedness since adolescence and typically requires them for driving and distance vision. Recently, she has noticed that she does not need her glasses to read the newspaper or do close-up needlework. She reports no eye pain, redness, discharge, or floaters. Medical history is significant for hypertension treated with lisinopril. She does not smoke or drink alcohol. Family history is unremarkable. She appears well. Visual acuity with her current distance correction is 20/20 in both eyes. Without correction, distance vision is 20/400 bilaterally. Near vision without correction is 20/25 in both eyes. Slit lamp examination shows no abnormalities. Intraocular pressure is 16 mm Hg in both eyes. Funduscopic examination shows no abnormalities. Which of the following is the most likely cause of this patient's improved near vision?
content_preview: A 56-year-old woman comes to the ophthalmologist because of vision changes over the past several months. She has worn glasses for nearsightedness since adolescence and typically requires them for driving and distance vision. Recently, she has noticed that she does not need her glasses to read the newspaper or do close-up needlework. She reports no eye pain, redness, discharge, or floaters. Medical history is significant for hypertension treated with lisinopril. She does not smoke or drink alcohol. Family history is unremarkable. She appears well. Visual acuity with her current distance correction is 20/20 in both eyes. Without correction, distance vision is 20/400 bilaterally. Near vision without correction is 20/25 in both eyes. Slit lamp examination shows no abnormalities. Intraocular pressure is 16 mm Hg in both eyes. Funduscopic examination shows no abnormalities. Which of the following is the most likely cause of this patient's improved near vision?
hint: This patient presents with second sight, which is a temporary improvement in near vision.
learning_objective: Recognize presbyopia as a cause of improved near vision in a patient with myopia, and distinguish it from other causes of visual change.

answers.explanation_why: Presbyopia is the age-related loss of accommodation caused by decreased elasticity of the lens and typically begins in a patient's mid-40s. This condition can cause second sight, a temporary improvement in near vision without correction in previously myopic patients. Second sight occurs because the focal point of the lens shifts, partially compensating for its inability to accommodate. Visual acuity with distance correction remains normal.

Hypertensive retinopathy typically leads to gradual vision loss or visual field defects, not improved vision. In addition, funduscopic examination in this condition shows retinal vascular changes (e.g., arteriolar narrowing, cotton wool spots, hemorrhage).
Age-related macular degeneration leads to progressive central vision loss, not improved vision. In addition, funduscopic examination in this condition shows pigmentary changes and/or drusen.

Acute angle-closure glaucoma manifests with sudden onset of severe eye pain, headache, nausea, blurred vision, and a red, hard eye with elevated intraocular pressure, none of which is seen in this patient. In addition, this condition does not cause improved vision.

Cataract can cause second sight, in which myopic shift temporarily improves near vision. Cataract typically manifests with progressive, painless blurring of both distance and near vision, glare, and reduced acuity even with correction as the condition progresses. This patient presents with visual acuity with 20/20 distance correction, and slit lamp examination shows no abnormalities. Therefore, cataract is unlikely to be the cause of improved near vision in this patient.
